description:
I have been stopping here for years to load up on my favorite Dim Sum.  There is everything one's heart could desire for take away.  The prices are very reasonable!  The Dim Sum is always fresh and sooo tasty!

This is an easy exit off of 19th and if you get there before 10, you can usually find a parking space.  They also have the two types of Chinese tamales - wrapped in bamboo leaves and wrapped in lotus leaves.  Sofie and I took some home to eat for dinner.  A complete meal that only requires being steamed.  Directions: place in your InstaPot, press "steam", wait for the beeper, serve and eat!  Delicious!

People are friendly and don't mind if you do not speak Chinese and say, "Those, those and some of those; and that one too!  4 of 'em!".  If you want to learn Chinese, they will tell you the names gladly.

Just say: "Saam go gin doy!" and you will be presented with three delicious sesame seed balls - crisp sesame dough on the outside filled with sweet and flavorful sesame seed paste.  My favorite dessert after enjoying the meat filled tasties.
author: Steve S.

description:
My group and I had a serious dim sum craving and ventured to SF. We saw the amount of reviews on Yelp and decided to give this place a try. 

I had the har gao, siu Mai, and egg yolk bun. I love the har how here, but the buns were mediocre. The siu mai were okay, but it's best fresh out of the kitchen. 

I wasn't really sold by the dim sum here so I'll probably try a few more places around SF before declaring my favorite.
author: Emily C.

description:
Really cheap and good quality dim sum! You can definitely feed 2 hungry people for around $13! Everything is good and there's a lot of meat and filling in all the dumplings and buns. The black bean spare ribs is quite delicious too. My favorites were the shrimp and chive dumplings, baked BBQ pork bun, and beef shu mai.

Line goes by sort of fast since these ladies are super efficient. Time also passes by quickly when you're filling out the order form, trying to figure out what to eat.

Seating is really lacking here. Even if you luck out and find a seat, you'll be eating next to 1) the people waiting in line, 2) the workers pushing carts back and forth, and 3) other people trying to squeeze in the seat next to you. It's best if you take it to go and eat it in your car if you have to.

Cash only.
author: Sally L.

description:
Many many good things. A few bad things, it's a fine ballance. They have a limited level of nice, limited smile and limited. They are not gracious. 
They have soy sauce and hot chili. I wish they had more like vinegar and hot mustard, but they don't. Also, if you don't get here early there is going to be a line, sometimes a long line, I think it could be a half hour at worst. 

Its not expensive at all, this might be some of the cheapest dim sum in town. Don't expect to eat in. You could, it's just not warm and inviting at all. They have a big variety but not huge. Over the years people have asked if it's good for vegetarians. I don't believe it is. That being said though, you could manage if you are vegetarian to find enough to eat. If you were not too picky. 

I love this place and I hope it stays just the way it is forever.
author: Ben M.

description: CASH ONLY!!! But the quality is so good! The prices are cheap and they have the best Shiu Mai and Xiao Long Biao I've ever had! They're perfect for to-go! I loved it!!
author: Robby T.

description:
SF native (currently living in Houston) this place is a hole in a wall Dim sum blessing!!!!!!! We picked up a few boxes for a picnic at Dolores park. 

Expect a line and bring cash. My fave that never disappoints: deep fried meat dumpling!!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
CASH ONLY!!! 

This place is gold. I came here with a friend and I love how you can order pieces of a item as oppose to getting an order where it comes with 3 dumplings or whatever (3 dumplings for $2.55 so if you get 1 dumpling it's just a 1/3 of the price). Everything taste just as good as any dim sum restaurant. The food was quite fresh and some of the items were huge like the buns. Well worth it! There was a gentleman worker who constantly pushed a kart of food to the front. That guy was hilarious because the store isn't very big but as he made his way to the front he would make a beep beep noise to clear the way. 

When we got here there was already a good size line inside that went all the way to the back. The total wait was probably about 15-20 minutes. You can get the food togo or dine in, there are several tables and they provide you with utensils. The ketchup bottle is a chili sauce and yellow is a soy or vinegar sauce. A coin flip with the yellow bottom. 

Wouldn't have asked for a better dim sum experience. I know this is a to-go kind of place but if they served chrysanthemum tea, this would so legit. If you go to dim sum you know better than to just get the jasmine tea! Until next time!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Great place for picking up dim sum. Suuuper cheap ($1-3 per order)and fast in & out. The food is already ready, they just box up whatever you like. 

We got the shrimp dumpling (super plump and full of meat!), streamed pork buns (my fave- really soft pillowy bread), pork shiu mai, and egg custard. 

FYI: Cash only!! Also, closer to the end of the day things do start to run out.
author: Miranda N.

description:
This dim sum place checks all the boxes for what you'd expect from a good dim sum place. The food is made fresh, price is extremely reasonable, service is quick and quality is fantastic!

My friends and I stopped by on a Saturday around 5pm and they ran out of many dishes, I'd recommend coming earlier. Which is pretty standard for any dim sum place. We got 27 dumplings and 6 pork buns for $25!! (3 dumplings for $2.55). The siu mai and ha gao dumplings were bigger than expected and we all got full very quickly. 

Unlike the typical dim sum restaurant, this place is a take-away shop. You're given all your dishes at once rather than intermittently by people pushing carts. This place is also cash only so come prepared! There's a Walgreens across the street with an ATM, but there's a $3 withdrawal fee.

Overall, this place is delicious, definitely worth every penny and struggle to find street parking. I'm planning another trip to SF soon just so I can take my boyfriend here!
author: Quynh T.

description: So good! A must stop for me every time I come to San Francisco. The dim sum selection is basic to other dim sum places, however their portion size of each dim sum is big and the service is fast. CASH ONLY! Check out my pic, paid for all that for $18!
author: Lia A.

description:
Delicious and SUPER CHEAP dim sum! 

Good Luck Dim Sum is a very efficient take out place with all your basic dumplings and buns. You stand in line and fill out a sheet of the items you want and then give it to the workers to assemble together! The quality of the dim sum is fair and tastes very familiar and comforting. I love the shrimp and pork dumplings, steamed BBQ pork buns, and turnip cake. The soy sauce on the tables is super delicious. It's sweet and slightly tangy. Make the perfect dipping sauce by adding some of the chili sauce they offer too. 

Sure customer service is lacking and the store looks run down but that's nothing surprising in my opinion. I feel like that's very typical for dank Chinese​ joints so I never really take that into account when reviewing a place like this. The workers there are all about efficiency and getting customers in and out. 

Overall, a great place to grab some quick dim sum on the go! Eating there might be tricky because it's a small place with few tables. But the wait usually isn't too long.
author: Natalie D.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is new to me. As I followed a friend who was loading up on goodies this past weekend, I decided to purchase a baked pork bun as my litmus test to their offerings. The pork bun is average in size and when I broke it open saw that it was filled with very red sauce and meat. Upon my first bite I thought to myself, "OMG, this is really sweet."
Indeed, expecting a slight sweetness as well as savory elements, the stark sweetness of GL's pork bun was quite offputting. Not to be defeated, I did eat the entire bun before coming to a decision. I don't like sweet pork buns at all. And I'm not likely to spend another $1.50 for a Good Luck pork bun in the future.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Good prices for quality of dim sum. Bothered by the fact though that you have to pay for your to go boxes. It isn't much (20 cents per box ) but doesn't that seem petty ?

Customer service isn't great - be prepared to be hurried. Things sell out too so be prepared for alternatives.  They are always sold out of the dried shrimp crepe when I'm there.
author: Lily F.

description:
Always a favorite spot to get Dim Sum.

We spent $71 and ended up with dinner for five plus enough leftovers for breakfast the next two days. The thing I love about this place is they have tons of options that aren't pork. Most of the time I only see pork siu mai, but here they have chicken and beef! Same with the steamed buns, I can get chicken steamed buns here! It's awesome.

Honestly, my favorite thing by far is the shrimp dumplings. We ordered 8 servings and they come three to a serving. The woman looked at us like we didn't understand what we were doing. In the end, even 24 shrimp dumplings were too few. 

They only take cash, so make sure you bring some! Also, we parked four blocks down and fed the meter for 20 minutes. The whole transaction took us 19 minutes (but a majority of that was deciding what we wanted to eat).

This is the type of place you get in and out. They now charge 20 cents per pastry box, but since we ordered so much they just gave it to us.
author: Christina G.

description: My parents like the bun here, I love the shrimp dumplings and the noodle rolls. Noodle rolls are my life' especially the one with shrimp. Also, you can try the sesame ball if there is.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Take Note: Health Score is a paltry 72/100. 

With such good Yelp reviews, I immediately recognized the name of this place, and miraculously nabbed a parking spot on busy Clement Street. 

Having ordered a good variety of dim sum takeout, I had an opportunity to try out a good mix of offerings, i.e., siu mai, har how, fun gor, shark fin dumplings (it's faux shark fin, so just relax!), etc.

Strangely, the pork filling in the siu mai and shark fin dumplings seemed to a tad pink in the center.  Undercooked pork? If so, not good! It was a little worrisome for me, but it's been about 24 hours later, and all is good. Thank goodness, but I can still see that slightly pink center in my minds' eye. I have been nuking the leftovers through and through! I've never seen a pink center in dumplings before. In fact, they tend to be overlooked sometimes.  Having said that, the fillings were tasty, and the wrappings on all the dim sum held up well, and didn't fall apart.

I disliked the fun gor though. The pork filling had a strange texture, which was slightly gravy-like, as if they over did it with the water and cornstarch. It's unfortunate, as I really liked the texture of the fun gor wrapper, which was perfect, just like grandma would've made.

What I did like was the steamed ricke cake (Bhak tong go). Theirs was fresh, nicely thin and very moist. It's difficult to make correctly, and I might return for this, if I was in the area.

I had fairly high expectations for Good Luck Dim Sum, after all I've been reading about it. In retrospect though, I wish I would've dug a little deeper, as there are quite a few recent one-star reviews. Nonetheless, unfortunately, this place doesn't really set itself apart from any other takeout dim sum spots in any way at all - not in food, price, service, and well, the cleanliness rating speaks for itself.
author: Lori N.

description: I go in every so often in the morning for the sesame balls. They always taste fresh and are reasonably priced. Remember to bring cash!
author: Gloria N.

description: Me and two friends sped walked for 25 mins just to get to this place. We were in desperate need for some deliciousness, and when I read the reviews, I knew we had to go here. The place itself is cozy. No big hall with tons of carts and loud chit chat. Nope, just a food stand with some tables and chairs in the back. You don't need more when you got food this good. The three of us shared a feast of dumplings and buns and chicken feet (can't forget the chicken feet), after which I immediately went back to the counter to order round two for our flight back to Chicago. Absolutely can't recommend this place more. Go and spend all your money here (though you won't be spending that much because it's super affordable and an amazing bang for your buck)!
author: Shelby G.

description:
Fast, easy, delicious. I come here if I want some quick dim sum and they are always making fresh batches. They only take cash so be prepared to bring some, and if you forget you can go to the Walgreens across the street and get request cash back from the cashier.

This place is cleaner than other food places in the area and while the food is good it isn't the best quick dim sum place I've been to. 

If you want some fast, easy, delicious dim sum his place is the place to go.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Came to SF for the Color Factory and was craving dim sum for brunch. We wanted something cheap, filling, and quick and I didn't have any interest sitting in a dim sum restaurant with crowded carts and inattentive service. So I relied on trusty Yelp and discovered Good Luck Dim Sum! Unlike Good Mong Kok Bakery (also considered) this place has a dine in option which was crucial for us as the weather was looking bad and we didn't want to eat dim sum in our car. 

Upon arriving, I thought there would a menu which I can circle the ones I wanted and how many but it was just a take out menu. Nonetheless we ended up ordering:

Chicken Siu Mai & Beef Siu Mai - both were average to me because they were a little drier than I'm used to but it was still good. I preferred the beef and my boyfriend referred the chicken.

Dumplings - we ordered the shrimp one & the shrimp and chive one. Both were fresh and delicious! I would recommend getting these.

Steamed Buns- tried the BBQ pork one and the chicken one. Both were delicious! The BBQ pork one is legit not like the super fake red coloring  one you usually get elsewhere and decent sized pork pieces. The chicken one was seasoned ground chicken although was missing some peas or an egg which is what I usually prefer. 

Chicken sticky rice - this was average! I've had better back in San Jose. Too much rice compared to chicken ratio but it was cooked right. It is wrapped in banana leaf or lotus leaf or something. Obviously don't eat that part. It had one small slice of Chinese sausage for the whole thing.

Potstickers - not really memorable at all. Not hot and no crispy. Pass.

egg rolls- I don't recommend as it was cold, didn't have much filling, and really greasy. Also pass. 

Red bean Fried Sesame ball- bomb! Hot fresh and crispy. 80 cents each. Wish I got more.

I would normally give this place 3 stars but rounded up to 4 because all of this was under $25 for two big eaters and we had 3 chicken steamed buns and 3 pieces of chicken Siu Mai after! 

They pile everything on a paper plate and give you two little paper boat trays to eat and it's on a kitchen lunch tray if you dine in. Be sure to be clear about 1 order vs 1 piece when you pick which ones you want. We came at 11:11 AM on a Monday and some items were sold out and some of the food was cold. Takeout boxes are 20 cents each. At the tables there was a sweeter thick soy sauce and chili sauce to eat with everything. There's a sign to clean up after yourself and throw away your plate. I would come here again on a budget or seek out a different spot with the XLB (soup dumplings).
author: Celine L.

description:
Do you know one of the workers  here is a magician?  I used to like coming here when I'm on the go and needed a quick bite.  This is no longer the case. 

I ordered my usual and on this occasion found a long strand of hair in my lotus leaf wrap ( lo mai gai).  As soon as I saw it, I gave them a chance to resolve it before writing this review.  Here is how the conversation went:

ME: Hi I just opened my lotus leaf wrap, took a bite out of it and found this.
GLDS: That is not hair. What hair? 
ME: The hair you took out of my hand and threw into the trash!
GLDS: I don't see any hair.
ME: Of course you don't, you took the evidence and threw it away.

UNBELIEVABLE! Good Luck will no longer get any more business from me. Not returning.
author: Peter C.

description: I love going to Good Luck Dim Sum -- they have great hours and are usually open later than other dim sum places. It is ideal because it is a grab and go. The workers are very nice and it is easy to order because you fill out the pink paper. They have a wide variety of dim sum options, however I would suggest going earlier to make sure they don't run out. We ordered the chicken shu mai, potstickers and charged siu bao. They were all delicious!
author: Gina B.

description:
This is a solid dim sum place with a different atmosphere (i.e. order and then take it to your table). They have all of the standard options at reasonable prices (**cash only**). Especially if you are more of a newbie to dim sum or can get intimidated by somewhat crass Chinese ladies, just get the piece of paper and make your order that way (circle and indicate how many) - it doesn't matter whether you're eating in or out, they'll still take it that way. 

As someone who grew up going to LA Chinatown on a weekly basis, I think that this is some solid dim sum, but neither is it like a heavenly offering. In a blind taste test, there would be no way to differentiate most of their items; an exception would be the turnip cake, which had some other bits of other things in there, which I see less often at other places. Even the ratios of things are similar. This is more or less why this is a 4-star review for me.

Parking is not always easy (and is metered). Seating inside is fairly limited and not good for groups over 4. One downside to getting all of this at once, rather than over time via the cart-delivery system, is that the end of your meal will probably be rather room temperature, so think carefully about what you order and the order in which you eat it. They also charge $0.20 per take-out container, and I'm pretty sure it's not because they're upholding the typical Bay Area environmentalism...
author: B. G.

description:
Been coming here for years. Whenever my fam and I visit our Chinese grandparents in SF, we always stop by to get breakfast takeouts from GLDS. It's the super cheap and awesome version of an American driv thru. Expect fast and zero-frill service, if you know the mainland Chinese way, you know what I mean- don't be a princess here.
1) fill out the pink slips and hand it to one of the serving ladies (they speak mainly canto and a bit of mandarin)
2) pay cash 
3) take yo box full of goodies that cost less than $10 and enjoy elsewhere (there's limited/meh seating)
author: Ellen C.

description:
This place is so good. For the price, you get tons of selections to choose from. Make sure to note, while you are in line you need to fill out a form to order. The ladies do not have time to help you out or have you point around for your orders. This place is small and the line can reach the back which makes everything cramped.
When ordering they don't go by quantity that will come in a order, they want you to literally saw the number per dim sum you would want. So the first round we made the mistake of writing 1 and we literally got 1 dim sum versus 1 order. Rookie mistake.
I'm sure you can find really delish dim sum at sit down restaurants, but for the price and to go this is really awesome. I love the egg custard. I'm craving dim sum as I write this! Must try. oh, CASH ONLY!
author: francis c.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall spot for quick, cheap dim sum! You won't find any dim sum carts here, just a glass counter showcasing dim sum and steamers full of buns and dumplings. There isn't a whole lot of seating here, so it's not great for large groups, but you can get your food to go.

It gets really busy here around 11AM-12PM on weekends, but the line moves pretty fast. Get one of the pink menus/order sheets and circle what you want. They have pretty much all of your classic dim sum items here.

CASH ONLY! But you won't need much of it. $10 can easily get you a filling lunch.

* CHIVE DUMPLING W/ SHRIMP (3 for $2.40) - 4.5/5
Solid dumplings. Good ratio of chive and shrimp

* CHICKEN SIU MAI (3 for $2.40) - 3.5/5
Pretty average siu mai. Not bad but very dense.

* WHITE SUGAR CAKE (3 for $2.40) - 4.5/5
I was so excited to see that they had this! For some reason, it's hard to find at actual dim sum restaurants.. Nice bouncy texture. Not dry like at some places.

* DRY SHRIMP CREPE ($1.20) - 3/5
I wasn't sure what this was since I can't read Chinese but wanted to find out so I ordered it. It turned out to be a rice noodle roll (chang fen), which I usually order at dim sum, but this one was just plain rice noodle with a little bit of dried shrimp in the noodles. I prefer the ones with actual meat rolled inside. At least it was a decent, filling portion of 2 rolls.

* BAKED BBQ PORK BUN ($1.30) - 4/5
Pretty good. The bread was fluffy and sweet, and the bbq pork filling wasn't overly sweet. Good ratio of bread to filling too, and the buns are huge!
author: Jessie L.

description:
Long line but worth the wait at Good Luck Dim Sum. This is my go to place for dim sum on Clement Street. First thing you do is grab the paper and pencil to write how many pieces you want of each item. If you come here later in the afternoon, a lot of the popular items will already be out (and the selection is already pretty small as is). 

Really don't think you can go wrong with anything you order here, just be aware that selection is limited so certain items run out quick. I've definitely had multiple times where I've had to rearrange my entire order when I got to the front.
author: Arezou A.

description: Just dumb luck we stumbled onto this place was happy to get quick service and delicious Xiaolongbao and Bbq pork buns
author: Matthew G.

description:
Best takeout dimsum joint in the city.  Top picks, beef shu mai, pan seared shrimp and chive dumplings, hai gao, fried taro balls, congee with Chinese doughnuts.  OUTFKNSTANDING!

*Ok let's talk service, I hear about the rude ladies serving in the front and let's just say I don't condone but I understand.  If I was standing, serving and answering 1000x repetitive questions while standing in front of hot steamers, I'd be pissy too.  This place is definitely a know what you want and move along type of deal. 

Food 5
Service 3*
Overall 5
author: Patrick C.

description:
Highlight is definitely the Steamed or baked pork buns! 

There's so much tasty meat inside. The baked bun has an amazing crust the steamed bun tastes amazing. Of course I had to get one of each. 

I also ordered both the Chicken and Beef Sui Mai. The chicken one was a little bland. I probably should have had some hoisin or soy sauce to dunk it in. The beef sui mai had a weird taste to it and didn't look all the way cooked to me. Don't think I'll be ordering that again. 

Also got the shrimp dumpling. It was good but nothing spectacular. 

Overall I will totally be coming back! The pork buns are delicious and I can't wait to try the chicken sui mai with sauce. And the price is amazing. Under $7 for 6 pieces.
author: Michael P.

description: High quality of dimsim for the money you pay. I've been their customers for long time and never disappointed. For the service, I rarely got a smile or nice chat from the workers but, I guess, it is regular for dim sum restaurant.
author: Mel L.

description: Good Luck Dim Sum is the best togo dim sum place I've tried so far. The prices are reasonable as well. Grab a pink sheet and circle what you want or you can just tell the ladies and they'll grab it for you. I think this place is cash only. I would get the pork Siu Mai, custard egg tart, steamed bbq pork bun and sesame mocha ball with red bean inside. I wouldn't recommend the shrimp dumplings because I think the skin is too think (but also spoiled from SoCal dim sum so I'm just used to thin skin). Good Luck will suffice until I am reunited with 626 dim sum.
author: Caitlyn S.

description: Nice hole in the wall. There are so many of them, this one has more seating. It is kind of dirty but that is what makes it a hole in the wall! Food is good, not the freshest but definitely good eats. Most of it is authentic and its definitely cheap! Cash only though!
author: Allan K.

description:
Excellent place for Dim Sum. Extremely long line, but goes by fast. About 10-12 tables available. 

Strongly recommend!
author: Yatin R.

description: Authentic, delicious, and a true feel for dim sum in San Francisco.  Prices can't be beat!!  Highly recommend.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Your standard bakery for Chinese dim sum and buns.  It's nothing fancy and you mark on a paper what you want and then they give it to you. There's a few tables that are usually filled and also dirty, so recommend just getting it to go. If i lived in the area, it would probably be my go to.

Cash only of course.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Great selection of tasty take out dim sum, there is some limited seating inside. We went with the beef and pork shiu mai, shrimp and chive dumplings and bbq rolls. The shiu mai and dumplings were the standout. 

Worth stopping buy if you are in the neighborhood and a short bike from golden gate park.
author: Matt T.

description: Don't judge the quality of the food of this restaurant by the decorations. There is always a long line for good reasons. The short ribs rice bowl is amazing. A lot of black beans favor. The vegetable comes with the rice is fresh. When you mix the sauce with the rice, you just have one of the best traditional HongKong/Chinese food in your life. Wait, I haven't talked about the price, because that is so cheap and seems I just paid nothing for all the thing!
author: Terry S.

description:
Good, inexpensive and authentic dim-sum to-go. Check the hours to make sure they're open. The shrimp dumplings are great, as are the sesame red bean balls.
Not low-carb friendly ;)
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
You are in SF, but it feels like a dingy restaurant in a alley in Hong Kong or Beijing. Our quest for the Best Dim Sum in San Francisco, led us here.

You stand in line. Pick up a paper and pencil to mark out what you need. It's OK if you don't understand what is what, no one does. Until you get to a counter, where you ask what's in the display and they point to chinese characters.

We really enjoyed a couple shrimp varietals, but were aghast at the pancake (it's a long snaky, doughy, flavorless) concoction. There are 5-6 tables, but by the time you are done placing an order and getting it, the crowd has taken all the tables. Get a jacket and claim a table while you are in line.

The best part about this place is, despite the hits and misses, and no one to recommend what's good and what's not, you end up with a bill of $15 for 10 different items! What?
author: Sam K.

description:
Food: 3.0/5.0
Service: 2.0/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 2.0/5.0
Overall: 3.0/5.0

Convenient neighborhood dim sum/bakery spot that opens early and prices relatively cheap.  Nothing to write home about, but it works and the line can get pretty long by mid-morning.  They keep the bins turning over pretty quickly so you can feel pretty good about the freshness of the product.
author: Damian W.

description:
A Good Luck Dim Sum review, in haiku form:
If you need dim sum,
and you are looking elsewhere,
I wish you good luck.
author: Carl M.

description: Very reasonably price Dim Sum. The crepe was a bit thick than what I preferred, but the taste is phenomenal. if you want something quick, cheap while taste decently well, this is the place
author: Vic S.

description:
So cheap and so good! 3 adults eating plus drinks for $16, you can't beat it! The food was good too! The line was out the door when we arrived and that makes for good food in my mind. We waited in line and found that they are cash only so bring yo cash! 

We got pot stickers, they were okay. The shrimp dumplings, the real MVPs of the meal, I got two orders of those. The BBQ pork buns were SO BIG! Like the size of my hand huge. The pork dumplings were super good too! The food here is really tasty and I highly recommend the shrimp dumplings!
author: Nicole K.

description: I guess if you never have had dim sum then this is a good place to start, because it really only gets better from here. Years back I used to rave about their shrimp dumplings (aka har gou, xia jiao) but alas, the rice casing is a bit too thick. The shrimp inside is still good. Unfortunately it goes down hill from here. The pork dumplings (aka shumai, shaomai) can be decent, if fresh-- big if-- but all too often they are cold and need to be microwaved. Microwaved dim sum from a dim sum spot, which allegedly is one of the best in San Francisco, is super lame! The same goes with the rest of the dim sum. It's hit or miss and often needs to be nuked. Super lame alert. They charge you a buck for a sad tea bag in a styrofoam cup. The hot sauce is decent, but loaded with msg. All in all, we are in a sad dim sum state in San Francisco. Someone save us!
author: Brian J.

description:
This place is well-known for their takeout dim sum. Like what a few others have said, the quality control is starting to get lax.

In the past I respected this place due to the amount of quality control they put into making sure the food didn't have "foreign" items in it.

Apparently with the massive amount of success, it looks like that are constantly understaffed nowadays.

I usually buy a bunch of different stuff and bit into a small rock pebble when I was eating a taro cake earlier. I've no idea how it got there, my guess it may have already been inside the raw ingredients prior to cooking.

Luckily I didn't bite so hard and was able to detect the small rock pebble early. 

The food is great here, but with it being understaffed, stuff is bound to come up.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Dim sums are one of my favorite foods for many different reasons but I love how you can literally eat them for breakfast, lunch, and dinner without any issues.  I don't know what it is about dim sums but they all taste good to me.  

This place was actually better than most places.  I highly recommend shrimp dumplings, chive dumplings, crystal dumplings, bbq pork bun, and pork shu mai.  

Everything tasted VERY FRESH and it was all very flavorful.  A lot of places don't have the right balance of meat portions to the carb portions but here, they give you good portions with your carbs.  

We were in & out of there within 35 min max.

I'll definitely be back
author: Jang N.

description:
We wanted to get some dim sum to picnic with at Golden gate so we stopped by here. This neighborhood is insane though, there's a dim sum place on every single block, it's like Starbucks. This place was no more popular than the numerous other ones we've walked by, every place had a few customers. 

We walked in around 9:30am no wait an walked straight in on Sunday. There's a pink slip with the menu so you can write on it or mark the quantity. We got the pork and beef shumai, har gao, taro shrimp, bamboo wrapped pork sweet rice,  lotus wrapped chicken rice, and egg tarts. The egg tarts were great, the crust super flaky with the right amount of sweetness. The shumai's were OK, to me it was too dense and kinda dry. The har gao was great though I kept biting into REALLY large pieces of strong ginger. The wrapped sweet rices were good, a meal in itself. It wasn't all great though, I HATED the taro shrimp dumpling. It was huge and not only had a taro paste with shrimp, it had LARGE pieces of cilantro which makes me gag thinking about it. I nearly puked in my mouth and it was just the worst. 

I would generally recommend but avoid the taro shrimp if you hate cilantro like I do!!
author: Amy K.

description:
Every time I go into a Chinese restaurant and the service sucks I always have my buddy's voice in my head saying "the meaner they are the better the food will be." Which unfortunately holds true to most true Chinese restaurants. Sure enough the lady that served me my dim sum had the meanest resting bitch face ever, so I was thinking damn this food is gonna be awesome. Sure enough it was! I would like to think everything good about them goes into their food and nothing is left for them to express. 

Cheap as hell food but oh so good quality (5/5 for taste). Got the shark fin, shumai, baked meat bun,  shrimp dumpling. All were so damn good, I don't think anything you order from this place will do you wrong. 

When we arrived there was a short line out the door but it didn't matter because it went fast. Great sign seeing local Chinese people out the door. Hardly any room to pass through front entrance and more than likely the store was bare minimum health code standards. But DUDE, food is so worth it. 

Overall, if you're trying to compare dim sum places which I really wanted to do, I would like to think this place has to be amongst the top 3.
author: Adel O.

description: Good simple dim sum and a very good price. Line can get long so be aware but if you go early your usually okay.
author: Andrew M.

description:
There is zero atmosphere and zero service here - the precursors of a good dim sum restaurant. Really solid dim sum that I found on a whim while my friends and I were searching for a quick takeout dim sum place in the neighborhood.

You take a pink slip, check off what you want to order, and bring it to the counter before they load it up onto a paper plate for you. The shrimp dumplings are my favorite, and I also always order the pork dumplings, chicken siu mai, and steamed BBQ buns. They have traditional ketchup and mustard bottles filled with soy sauce and chili sauce, lol. You can sit down at one of the tables in the back to eat, but it's more of a "grab and go" kind of place. 

Usually, 3 people can fill up on about $20 worth of food, since it's so carb heavy. Super cheap hangover cure!
author: Denise L.

description:
LOVE !!! it's sooooo good and savory. 

get 3 for $2.20 for the good shrimp dumpling, pork siu mai, and chive dumpling with shrimp. Cheap and good food! love the sauce in the yellow (looks like for mustard) bottle! it's like a sweet soysauce! makes the dim sum extra good.
author: Daisy M.

description: Terribly good, would give 6 stars if possible. Get food to go and enjoy anywhere. Consistently fresh and good, make sure to confirm your order.
author: Matt T.

description: I love that their dim sum is fresh and steamed right in front of you.  This place is a to-go dim sum spot that you don't want to miss. They are CASH ONLY I gave it 4 stars because the cleanliness isn't the greatest inside. Aside from that, i recommend getting here when they open because the lines can go out the door.
author: J N.

description: Super cheap, quick, and delicious dim sum. Not much seating so plan to take it to go, CASH only, incredibly cheap!! Fed two adults for $10!
author: Jessi C.

description: I love me some good har gao and chives dumplings and this place DOES NOT disappoint. My friends and I grabbed 20+ pieces of all their individual dim sum options and went HAM! They use real ingredients and you can tell the difference from the texture of the food, I've worked at different restaurants before, I know quality when I taste it. Anyways, highly recommend the har gao and the chives dumplings, I could not stop eating them!
author: Jie L.

description: Food is good but service is slow and they have typical rude chinese. This woman asked me for the last name i placed my order under, i answered her. She gave me attitude and said there could be other orders under the same last name. True! Well why did u ask? Or why didnt u ask for my fone number? Then she goes on and bitch about me To her coworker in front of me. She didnt feel awkward behaving this way?
author: Ellie D.

description: If you go here, go EARLY! Went on a Sunday morning around 9am and there was already a line! Waited about 30mins. Besides the wait, there is limited seating if you wanted to eat in. They do offer takeout boxes for an additional $0.20 per box. The food was amazing! I really enjoyed the porridge (great value for amount and price). Just be careful when you're ordering, we weren't sure if some items were a steamed bun or not. Either way, I would come back.
author: Ron S.

description: Get there in the morning before their porridge runs out! Good Luck Dim Sum is one of my favorite places in inner sunset. It's cash only, but your money goes pretty far at this restaurant. When ordering, you fill out a pink sheet of paper with your desired quantities. Remember to arrive early!
author: Bryan R.

description: I know it's cheap but the dim sum was not worth it. The buns and siu mai were hard on the inside and not warm.
author: Haru M.

description: The mean ladies almost add to the authentic experience. No atmosphere. Straight to the point dim sum, not your fancy sit down place if you're looking for that. The chicken bun, chive dumplings, pot stickers, and porridge are a must! Insanely cheap prices. Recommend!
author: Christine D.

description:
The ladies are pretty rude here. To avoid getting distasteful glances or being yelled at, grab one of those pink sheets and circle what you want, pay (cash only) and leave with delicious dim sum. Don't ask too many questions, don't stand in line and get called on if you're not prepared. I witnessed a customer before me get denied a big chicken bun-but when my friend requested 6 big chicken buns right after, they grabbed them for her. 

My favorites here are:

- shrimp dumpling
- shark fin dumpling 
- Chinese chive dumpling 
- big chicken bun 
- fried stuffed dumpling 
- sweet rice puff w/ coconut + peanut 
- egg yolk bun (they don't explode)
- egg tart
author: Laura T.

description:
My husband was still hungry post brunch from B Star Bar. We saw a massive mob by Good Luck Dim Sum footstep so we stopped in to check it out. 

My husband opted for their ha gow ($2.20 for 3) and one giant sesame ball (80 cents each or $2.20 for 3) - he devoured them directly from the plastic bags and couldn't be happier. A very satisfying, quick snack/meal for just $3. 

Definitely would consider coming here for dim sums regularly if we live in the area. We saw a group of teens/college kids with boxes and boxes of dim sums spread out across their table - why wait for the fancy dim sum carts when you can have equally tasty yet cheaper option here in Good Luck.
author: Wing C.

description:
Authentic, cheap, no-frills dim sum is what you'll find at Good Luck Dim Sum.

It's a small hole in the wall place with a handful of tables inside.  I came around 9:30 on a Sunday morning and there was a small line, but it moved fairly quickly since they have a sheet where you can circle what you want before you get to the front.  Don't be one of those who don't follow protocol and hold up the line.  Beware that the line forms inside the restaurant, so even if you see no one outside, don't assume there's no wait.   

They roll the dim sum out in large batches and everything is so inexpensive you'll want it all!  Most of your typical dim sum items come 3 for $2.20, while a few things like egg custard and BBQ buns are $1.  They have some other random dishes as well and almost everything is under $5.

I tried the siu mai, shrimp dumplings, deep fried stuffed dumplings, BBQ pork bun and custard.  Everything was really tasty and satisfied my dim sum craving.  If you're a fan of siu mai, you'll be happy to know they have pork, beef and chicken options here. 

Don't forget to bring cash and an empty stomach when you come.
author: Christal M.

description: The dim sum are cheap the yummy! Be ready for the line though!
author: Candice O.

description:
Came here the day after CNY in the evening when I wanted dim sum. Most of what we ordered satisfied my craving but some dishes were lacking.

The dried scallop egg fried rice is great! One of my all time favorites - 5/5

The dim sum was an average 3/5

Chicken broccoli 1/5. Very Americanized
author: Jasper L.

description: Yummy quick and affordable food, the ladies here are super nice and sweet. My favorite was the sesame ball.
author: Geenah M.

description:
The Chinese don't mess around here. If you're looking for a nice sit-down meal where dim sum is wheeled out on a silver cart and ordered in a civilized manner, then this is not the place for you. 

Nah, you end up waiting in a long line winding to the back of the room where a jolly Chinese man comes out with hot piping dim sum and he politely navigates his cart around the people saying "beep beep umm beep beep." 

Grab a pink paper and pen to look at the menu and place your order by circling what you want. Once you get to the front of the line, hand your paper over and a Chinese lady will gather your order. Cash only btw! 

I highly recommend this place because it's cheap and delicious. Get the pork sao mai, luo me ji, luo bo Gao, and porridge. The wait is long but it's worth it.
author: Emily F.

description: Delicious, quick, cheap. Maybe not the best quality dim sum you'll ever have, but it's damn tasty and always satisfying.
author: Michael L.

description:
01/28/2017: I really wanted to love this place because of how affordable it is. They have a pretty wide selection of dim sum and other goodies such as chowmein by the lb, fried rice, egg tarts, chicken bowl etc. 

Pros:
I loved their har gow (shrimp dumplings) you get 3 pieces per order (which is the typical serving). I honestly loved their dipping sauce as well mixed with some chili sauce to kick it up a notch. ($2.20)

Steamed BBQ bun was ok (not enough meat inside) but for the price you get what you pay for pretty much. ($2.20)

Dumplings were huge and same as above 3 pieces per order. It was good for the price. ($2.20)

Sweet rice stuffed with crushed peanuts and coconut (very tasty) $1 

Cons:

Baked BBQ bun (I really wanted to love this cause this is my fave from mayflowers or any other dim sum places). But the bread and filling ratio was 80% bread 20% meat. I love bread but the filling wasn't that great (it was just ok). ($1)

Egg roll was blah (3 for $2.20)

Egg tart was ok ($1 each)

Another dumpling with green onion and meat inside (gross according to my bf and friends) 3 for $2.20

The service was good and all but our server lady had the worst attitude. This place gets really packed and I bet she is tired considering it is Chinese New Year's Day. I asked her for how much my friend's order since they only accept cash only she straight up gave me an attitude saying "I don't know I didn't help her. I only added yours. Next time you tell me you pay together." She Rolled her eyes after when I said we just read it's cash only.. so anyways My bf paid for our food and we just handed our friend cash to pay for her food separately since it was such a big deal. 

Bottom line this place is popular for the price and some of their yummy selections but the service is definitely not it lol.. But then I'll def swing by again if I'm in the area and enjoy some Har gow.
author: melanie l.

description: My very first time having Dim Sum, and now the bar has been set amazingly high. Can't wait to come back!
author: Tim T.

description: Dope little hole-in-wall where you can feed two enormous people for under $20.
author: Gina D.

description: Okay, it has been 6 years since the last time I came here and this place has improved. The dim sum is still great. The service is a bit more organized and we didn't really encounter too many problems. The people here work super quick. Hats off to them!
author: Tina R.

description:
Authentic and delicious. Walk into this small place and have your order ready to go! The sweet buns are amazing, dumplings and pot stickers too, and pretty much everything looks great. 

At a price point of 3 for $2.40(yes, 3 pork buns for $2.40), it's hard to say no to. I've already been twice this week. Will be back again soon for a filling and delicious$5 lunch.
author: Michael S.

description: First time here... yeah not as good as I thought it would be.. service is so bad. I asked for 3 egg tarts and the lady literally said because I didn't put it on the paper that means I didn't order it. She literally missed my whole order and I paid 33.30 for barley any food honestly..
author: Mickie K.

description: For only $9, I got 9 of the dim sum items and a large porridge. It was enough food for two meals and it traveled easily to enjoy in the park.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Okay first of all I have no idea why this place have 4 stars?!

First of all when you come in the ladies that work there are rude when you ask them questions about their menu and without waiting for our response just goes helps another customer. Very unprofessional!

Second of all the place inside is dirty with sticky floors and stinky bathroom :(

So we ordered to sample a little bit of everything.

Shrimp dim sum was the only thing which was okay.

Pork potstickers and dim sum was unbearable to eat. It tasted weird!

Vegetable egg roll was so oily that my whole napkin was stanched in oil. Grows!

Overall very disappointed about this place and would never recommend this place to anyone!
author: Marina M.

description: Super cheap and have sooo many options to choose from. Their crystal dumplings and pork buns are a couple of my favorites. Don't expect to find seats and a table though. Plan on getting your food and sauces to go and eat elsewhere.
author: Jazmin M.

description:
This is my FAV place in SF for affordable dim sum. There will be a line if you come later in the day, but well worth the semi-short line. CASH ONLY~

Parking:
A little tough to find a parking spot, but parking meters and lots are scattered around.

Food:
This place has THREE different siu mai's (chicken, beef, pork), rice porridge (1000 year old duck egg and minced pork), shrimp dumplings, chinese donuts, and so many other yummy buns. You get an order of three things for around $3.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
THE CHICKEN SIU MAI IS A MUST. I used to love siu mai but most of it is made with pork so after I stopped eating red meat, I had to stop eating the dish! But, the chicken siu mai here is so good... I thought about it for a few weeks straight afterwards! 

I love the dried shrimp cheung fen as well, especially with the soy sauce and hot sauce mixture that is provided at the tables. The porridge is piping hot and definitely hit the spot as well. The bbq pork buns are huge for $1 each. 

All the items were really affordable and delicious. The service was not the greatest but it's fast so they get you in and out quickly. Overall, a spot that I would love to come again and again when I visit!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Food tasted good, and there's plenty of seating available. (It's San Francisco though, 10-12 tables is what I call plenty. Holes in the wall have 2.)

It's very cheap too, I love it just for that. And being in the Richmond district, there's decent parking and no crazy crowd around like in Chinatown.

One improvement: not clear what items are available, not sufficiently marked, and the lady could be less impatient, and more friendly towards customers. I was aware of this and did my homework by writing down what I wanted. Maybe you should too.
author: Matthew C.

description:
This is fast dim sum to-go spot and cash only despite no sign indicating so.  It's not much of a place you'd want to sit and attempt to enjoy all these goodies with an atmosphere lacking pleasantries conducive for a ravenous appetite.  There was a tiny line on a Saturday morning but not much.  I got three heaping boxes of edible loot for about $50.

They have all the yummy basic stuff like shrimp dumplings (ha gow) and shui mai.  The shui mai comes in pork, beef, or chicken.  I had to try all three.  All of these are not as soft and tasty as everything else- more like a hardened meatball.  The cha sui bow is alive and well here.  (pork bun)  They also have the chicken variety.  Yes, I tried that too.  The BBQ pork is best though.  -love those turnip cakes...  The ahn caut (egg custard) is delicious and sweet.  There's just a whole lot of other goodies I could go on about.  Taro root and shrimp dumpling is different and to my liking.  If you like taro root, this is a yes.  All in all...if you love dim sum and want it to go.  This place moves it quickly.   Oh, yeah those sticky rice tamales are quite nice too.  They are a bit stingy on the meat ingredients though.

I'd totally do another drive-by dim sum stop here again, hand them my green and give my belly some good luck!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
It honestly baffles me to see that this place is so highly rated. I guess the prices at Good Luck Dim Sum are decent, but that's really the only thing they have going for them. I still feel like I wasted my money because the food and service are absolutely horrendous. 10/10 would recommend never coming here!!

First off, the lady behind the counter was incredibly rude to me and my bf -- ignoring questions we had about the food, and rushing us to order faster, when there was no one else behind us in line?! Initially, I actually wasn't too bothered by this because the food behind the counter looked so enticing, but I was unfortunately disappointed...

Overall the dim sum here is nothing short of meh. The dumpling skins were all way too thick and all our food came out really cold (like below room temperature cold), which upset me because I could see steam wafting out of the plates of other customers around us.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Deli style dim sum with about 30 seats. Many of the customers were there to pick up something to take home. During a Friday afternoon at about 2, it was busy enough so that the kitchen staff was constantly resupplying bao, buns, and dumplings. Everything was fresh and hot, well-flavored and well-prepared. I particularly liked the turnip cakes and the shrimp dumplings, but everything I tried tasted good.

It's a very utilitarian place, with one of the small tables commandeered to stack pink pastry boxes. There were 3 front-counter workers, and who knows how many cooks behind the scene. When it calmed down a bit, the counter workers resupplied condiments on the 8 or so tables -- just a bit late for me to slather my goodies with an adequate supply of soy sauce or hot chili sauce (which, by the way, was very fresh and tasty, too).

Yes, cash only, mildly impatient counter folks trying to keep the line moving, incredibly cheap prices, downbeat simplicity in the dining room. If I lived in SF, I'd be here all the time.
author: John M.

description: I wish I lived close by so I could go more often.  It's worth making the trip though.  The dim sum is the best for the price.
author: Parastoo E.

description: Really great Dim Sum and pork buns. Everything is elegantly presented in front you and tastes amazing. I highly recommend coming here for a good and quick snack. Be aware that there are only 9 tables available. So try to make it for non peak hours if you want a place to sit.
author: Kuba J.

description: Incredible Dim Sum! This is my go to place in the city for a to go spot that will always leave you feeling thankful you took the plunge. If you are looking for a sit down Dim Sum spot I would go to Lai Hong lounge. LHL has the best Dim Sum I have had in the US-- and I LOVE Dim Sum! Happy eating!
author: Meryl D.

description:
One of my absolutely fun things to do after visiting Glide Memorial on a Sunday is to head straight to Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement St for a Dim Sum hook-up and then walk it off by browsing through Green Apple Books & Music.

Last week my director at work was doing an on-site visit to an office two blocks away, seeing an opportunity I sent an order text for an I buy you fly and an hour later there was a bag of goodness on my desk.  Since I work all the way out in Dublin this was a big treat. As testament to how good the stuff is, I sent a text out to my coworkers to help themselves to dim sum, stepped away from my desk for about 15 minutes and returned to find only a single pot sticker and two shrimp har gows left?!?!  

Flash forward today, we dropped a friend off at SFO And I took the opportunity to get more on Thanksgiving day.  The hubs and I drove up and quickly found parking on the street, I figured there be a line but I had no clue that the line would be so long!  By the time I made it up to the counter they were out of shrimp har gow, Chinese donuts and baked pork buns?!?!  Since the food is always coming out I learned that my wait was a good 5 to 15 minutes, The lady helping me at the counter wasn't sure.  So I got what I could and then returned straight to the counter with my container to have it filled up with the good stuff 15 minutes later.  

The hubs and I took our loot to GGP, now that's a Thanksgiving brunch.
author: Ann T.

description:
Is it my fault for having expectations?  Yes, sets one up for disappointment.  
We were cold and damp from the drizzle. 
Very small selection so we ended up getting leek dumplings and more leek dumplings, a few shrimp and beef shiu mai or other. No tofu-mushroom wrap creations, No veggies. No other choices besides pork.
So we went to Gourmet Dim Sum and Xiao Long Bao to get our fixes. 
Crazy # of chicken wantons in the soup at Gourmet Dim Sum!  
Glad they are so close to each other.  
Made for a fun dimsum house hopping lunch.
author: Yaseng Y.

description: A few weekends ago we did a taste test to compare the a few different highly rated dim sum places.  Good luck ranked someone near the middle for us. The highlights of Good Luck were the potstickers (which had a really good thick noodle exterior and pretty decent interior) and the eggs rolls.  Wish they had a sweet and sour or some sauce for the egg rolls but I didn't see any.  The big disappointment here is the pork buns (especially the baked) were our least favorite of any of the places we tried (it had a sweet kinda sticky coating on top we didn't care for). The potstickers and egg rolls are like a 4/5 but the pork buns are like a 1.5/5.
author: Scott D.

description: Quick, Delicious and Fun.  It's a Dim Sum hustle house for those on the run.  Shared tables always lead to interesting conversation.
author: Ged R.

description:
The line is usually quick and efficient, but it can get a bit long at lunch time.  This place is pretty reasonably priced, costing around $2.40 per order of dim sum (three pieces per order).  I always hear good things about this place, but the food here to me isn't really that impressive.  It's certainly a big step down from dim sum you can find at actual restaurants, which was expected.  I usually order the siu mai and the shrimp dumplings here if I need a quick and cheap bite to eat.  

The siu mai are my favorite of the two - they're really plump and juicy here, but I do think they went a bit too far on the sodium/MSG with it.  The shrimp dumplings are not as good as the siu mai - the skin is usually not as soft as I'd like it to be, and the filling tastes okay.  

Overall, the food is good if you lower your expectations a bit (think of this  as fast food instead of restaurant quality dim sum), but it's nothing amazing or special.
author: Tim L.

description: This was good for a quick and casual lunch. The chili garlic paste is more srircha style based (which I was not a fan of) versus your traditional oil paste. Good meat dumpling ratios and a killer price!
author: Christine N.

description:
Nice fresh dim sum, steaming good food variety is good. Good hot tea as well.
Small place, grab a menu list, check off what you want, stand in line (line moves fast) hand it to one of the ladies and they'll pull ur order and pay. Very few tables. Very nice hole in the wall dim sum restaurant.
author: M I.

description: Pretty good for a cheap, to-go dim sum place but definitely not what I expected good dim sum to be. However, I must say, their dumplings especially shrimp dumpling (har gow) is pretty good. Worth a try since it's so affordable.
author: Kristie H.

description: Awesome food for a great price. The sesame buns were to die for. If you only eat at one Chinese place eat here.
author: Vera P.

description:
#104/2016

You know when a craving hits and you try to shake it? 

I practically started humming Foreigner's "Urgent"

("Oh oh it's urgent, urgent, emergency! urgent urgent urgent urgent! E-mer-gen-ceee! So ur-gent!")

So I started Yelping & messaging Ann S. for the best to-go dim sum spot on Clement. If I couldn't find it fast enough, she'd know. 

I briefly considered but discarded the thought of PM'ing Cherylynn N. but because I've never met her she might think I was a weirdo. 

Besides, by then I was driving: Can't text and drive yo, even to Yelp.

I headed to Clement Street, finding the spot (cross-checked on Yelp for goodness and cleanliness of course after pulling up to a nearby meter (kismet, right?) and the very unassuming Good Luck Dim Sum. 

They didn't have a huge variety of steamed items so I went right for the ha gao: chock full of plump, juicy, fresh shrimp with delicious wrappers that barely contained the lovely melt-in-your-mouth deliciousness.

The beef and chicken sui mai were huge. You ate one and by itself it was practically lunch. 

(I ate two more to confirm: yep, filling!)

Eating my meal backwards from the way I ordered it at the counter, I had a couple bites of the chicken & rice bowl and not only was it too much food (ravenous hunger tends to make you over-order), the chicken was unappetizingly fatty and a little undercooked. I felt less guilty pushing it aside. 

The bowls are truly a complete meal with plenty of meat, two pieces of Chinese sausage and some streamed bok choy. 

All of this for less than $4!

2 orders each ha gao and chicken & pork sui mai and the chicken rice bowl with steamed bok choy: $12.50.

I didn't try their baked char sui bao so guess I'll have to return....
author: Jennifer O.

description: Rain or shine there's always a line.  Excellent dim sum at reasonable price.  Fun place to take someone who's never tried for the experience.  Can walk up and down Clement to explore neighboring Chinese produce and seafood markets.
author: Roy A.

description:
I dont come to this place for smiles and good service. When i come to good luck, i come for the food. Everything is delicious. The shrimp dumplings are amazing. I love the siu mai. The steamed pork buns are something i could eat all day.

The workers here are not friendly or welcoming. So if you are a first timer, go in there with an aggressive attitude and place your order in a loud firm voice... or else these ladies are going to get on your nerves... the food and price is worth the mediocre service.
author: Matthew S.

description:
Simple, affordable & worth it. After spending the day at the beach, stopped by to grab a snack. No fuss of waiting for a table or check at the end of our meal. The ladies were nice, efficient and attentive. I was in and out within 5 minutes! Definitely stop by if you're looking for quick service. 

The dim sum i ordered was succulent and fresh. Everything tasted great!!
author: Nancy O.

description:
On the way to the beach? Going to the park for a picnic? Stop by this place to get some dim sum to-go. You can get 3 pieces for $2. This isn't your average sized appetizer. These dim sum pieces are on steroids. 

My top favs to get are:
Shrimp dumplings
Shrimp and chive dumplings
Potstickers
Pork siu mai

A pink box of dumplings would be perfect to share with some friends or by yourself if you're feeling greedy. Don't forget to ask for a to-go cup for your soy sauce and spicy sauce. I swear, their soy sauce is a little sweeter than usual which adds a sweet and savory combination with every bite.
author: Rachelle Y.

description:
This place is CASH ONLY.

I've eaten here almost every single time I visit SF. 

This little dimsum joint in the Richmond area is literally a gem. The best, freshest, one of the most delicious dimsum's I've ever had. You walk in and grab a pink menu and a pen from the counter and start circling / marking the quantity and kind you want. Then you get in line and hand the paper to the next server and they literally pack your dimsum & order straight from the giant steamers. So fresh, so good. The dimsum ranges from $2.50 for 3 pcs (they're huge!) to about $5 for the rice bowls (it's a lot!). My favorites are the shumai, the shrimp har gow, and all the buns - pork, chicken, bbq. EVERYTHING. 

Granted they only have seating for about 20 people or less and you kind of have to linger and wait for someone to leave to snag a table to eat at but it is SO WORTH IT. 

My first time here, we spent $16 to feed 3 hungry people and had enough pork buns left over to bring to Sutro Baths to eat. Just 2 weeks ago, we spent $60 at lunch to feed 5 very very hungry people, and had enough left over for dinner and midnight snack. SO MUCH BANG FOR YOUR BUCK & THE QUALITY IS EXCELLENT. 

SOLID DIMSUM SPOT THAT WILL NOT PUT A DENT ON YOUR WALLET. GO!
author: Bay M.

description:
The best place to get a lot of food on a tight budget. The first time I came here, I only had $8 in my wallet, and was able to get 3 shrimp dumplings, a steamed bbq pork bun, and a sesame ball.

The second time around, I had $20, and I went to town! I got all the things I wanted for myself, my vegetarian sister, and my parents, and it only came up to $12.

As far as take-out dim sum, this place is good and has a decent variety (mostly in the morning, good luck in the afternoon when their inventory is limited).  I really like the shrimp and taro dumplings, but it did have pork in them, so my sister sadly couldn't eat them. 

What I like about this dim sum place is the pink menus available.  You can circle what you want and give it to one of the ladies.  Someone behind me scoffed saying those menus are for non-Chinese speaking patrons, which contextually seemed like he was aiming at a certain race.  Well, he didn't impress his date, an Asian female, who exclaimed she doesn't speak Chinese, as he went on to order in Chinese.. Well, I find them very helpful since I don't speak Chinese, and you will too if you don't either.  There's a tray that's supposed to have pencils, but it was empty the last time I was there. So it helps if you have a pen handy.

There's not a lot of seating inside, so I always take my dim sum to go.  It's a good place to satisfy that craving when you're trying to save money.

Cash only!
author: Vira P.

description:
This place isn't the fancy restaurant, but the food tastes very good! (Cash only).
We love everything we've tried, and we've come multiple times. We would probably come every week if we lived closer. 
Prices are good, food is freshly made. 
It's usually packed so it can be hard to find a seat. 

If you plan on getting food to go, remember to bring your own topper wear and say "no thank you" to their one-time use plastic bags or plastic boxes! Yea, it's not always convenient to carry that around but think of the difference you can make if others see you do it and do the same! :-)
author: P. H.

description: Bang for the buck, decent tasting dim sum for the money and a few tables inside. Not fancy, but cheap eats worth a visit or two
author: Michael A.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is one of the many hole-in-the-wall takeout dim sum places located along Clement St. Though this place seems very hyped, I didn't find it much different from any other casual dim sum takeout I've tried.

I came on a Saturday afternoon for lunch, and after ordering at the counter, you can take your dim sum and sit and one of the tables in the back. We started with the classic shrimp dumplings, which were nice, but they might have been sitting out for a while, as they weren't particularly warm. We also had the chicken and sticky rice, which was also fine, but there didn't seem to be a lot of meat in the filling. Finally, we had the mala gao, the steamed sponge cake, but because these were just sitting on a tray, they had cooled down to room temperature and didn't have the same wow factor that you get when tearing apart a freshly steamed cake.

Overall, I found this a pretty average dim sum experience that definitely can't replace what you get at a nice dim sum restaurant. The value, however, was certainly fantastic, as our whole meal came to just $7.
author: David K.

description:
A dependable place for steaming hot dim sum that you usually grab to go, if only because there aren't a whole lot of seats here. The prices are quite excellent, although if going by such staples as har gow, siu mai, and cheong fun is any indication, you get what you pay for. 

Nevertheless, a solid spot for a cheap, satisfying dim sum fix.
author: Vincent L.

description: The food was so good. We ordered pork buns, chicken buns, sesame balls, shrimp dumplings, rice cakes, and the lotus leaf with chicken and sticky rice. Personally i wasn't a fan of the shrimp dumplings because i found them to be very fishy but my boyfriend really liked them. The other food was so good though. It was also very cheap and filled us up really quickly.
author: Amanda R.

description:
There aren't many push cart dim sum places in the city but there are still good dim sum places nonetheless. I took my mom here when she visited and this time I brought Mink. This cozy dim sum restaurant is legit and I would recommend it to anyone craving dim sum in the city. There is usually a line but the wait isn't too long. 

Parking: Street (Residential is free or Metered Parking).

Dine In: 8 tables to dine on (tables aren't always clean but you can bus it yourself). Condiments on table (Soy Sauce that's on the sweeter side and Hot Sauce). 

Take Out: It's $0.20 per box. 

Drinks: They sell cold drinks (Juice, Soda, Soy Milk, Hong Kong Style Coffee & Water). Water is $1.00. They have Hot Tea but I'm not sure if they charge for that. 

Food: You order at the counter and you can choose how many pieces of each item you want or how many lbs. They also have other dishes aside from typical dimsum such as desserts, noodles and jook (rice porridge). It's very affordable and good dim sum here! 

Payment: Cash Only

Service: Quick and Efficient. They can take orders in English or Chinese. 

Con: There are a few rude old Chinese people that come to your table to do their business while you're there. Typical but annoying. Not the restaurants fault.
author: Daniel C.

description: Such an amazing place that transcends space and time to joyously propel din sum to your mouth at a great price and with unparalleled taste. Get everything and push the lining of your stomach.
author: Cameron M.

description:
If you like big juicy tasty siu mai then come here! Ordering is easy, food is delicious, authentic and affordable.

One of my fav dim sum spots! :)
author: Shamekia R.

description:
Best to go dim sum on clement. The food is always consistently delicious! 

I think the pricing may have increased over the years, but they're still super cheap compared to any site down place, and relatively the same as any of the other doors down the street (but for better quality). 

Pro-Tip: they're closed on Tuesdays!
author: Lisa N.

description: So to be honest I've been going to this place for years like since I was a child. The place I grew up with closed so my mom stared bring us strictly here. Yes, we would go to multiple dim sum houses as often times there are diff offerings not to mention taste. Anywhoo the only reason why I am not giving it 5 stars is because I personally experienced something that kept me from going there for months!!! Either way they are solid. I enjoy their mushroom chow mein, ha gow, sesame balls and if I did eat pork (yeah I know lol but believe me you can't convince me) I'd say the shu mai was to hurt some1 for (I've only heard). Enjoy, Happy Eating!
author: domenique c.

description: Everything we ordered was delicious, staffs are very friendly, my only concern is some items were served at room temperature, super high turnover. Limited seating area, the place is mainly for takeout orders.
author: Sabrina S.

description: Good dim sum. Cranky staff. Cash only. The shrimp hargow is my fave here. Porridge is tasty. My grandmother loves their egg custards. On my last trip, they did not give us 3/12 of the things we ordered to go. We did not realize until we had already left. I was SO bummed. Ordering process is standard - you circle the items you want and write in a quantity. Would have been a tough miss. You always have to ask for sauce to go, they often don't have sauce cups. All in all, great food, pay close attention while they build your to go order so you can be sure to get all the items you want, don't forget to ask for sauces to go.
author: Brittany T.

description:
----------------
CASH ONLY and grab a menu so you can # or circle your orders before they serve you. There is very limited seating (not good for group of 4 or more). So picnic it out or something.
-----------------
Basically good luck dim sum is cheap (you can feed 4 people with ~$20), fast, and tasty. I haven't tried too many dim sum places on clement st so I can't tell if this place is way overhyped or actually better than its neighbors (there is always a crazy long line). Doesn't matter because this place is solid. Its nothing that's going to change your world but if you are craving dim sum, this place is legit. They have a variety of baos and dumplings. Not too many desert choices or veggie/dishes but they do have zhongzhi, egg tarts, and some other pastries. Bring your  own sauce if you are picky with that stuff (they only have soy sauce and red chili sauce). 

I'm glad this place isn't a try-hard restaurant. It's got a very street-fast food feel. You order bulks of whatever and everything is straight forward. Wish there were more places like this in the city.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Love getting dim sum here! It's cheap, fast, fresh, and delicious. You can order take out quickly or buy your food and sit at a table. They all the food ready and all you have to do is point at what you want. 

Everything here is relatively cheap, $1-2 if not less. My personal dim sum faves are cha siu bao (pork buns), egg tarts, zhong zi (rice wrapped in banana leaves), and the spare ribs! Mmm. 

Cash only though and if there's a huge line, the workers might be in a rush to finish your order so they can be a bit rude.
author: Wendy D.

description: BEST TO GO DIM SUM!! people are very nice and always helpful, inexpensive and sooo delicious! Must try the shrimp dumplings, sesame balls, egg custard cups, and bao buns. Been going here for 10+ years and the quality has remained the same!
author: Amelia S.

description:
Dim Sum is, basically, comfort food - and there's no reason to expect it to cost an arm and a leg. Good Luck Dim Sum is consistently good, and frequently fine - for a unreal price. Grab an order sheet, circle the items you want, and the girl behind the counter will fill the order. The price? It's three for $2.40 for many items, or $1.10 each for the remainder.

My favorites over two visits:

-  Fried Sesame Ball is surprisingly delicious and filling. The balls are around 2-1/2 inches in diameter, and have crunchy and savory dough. On the inside, there's a dollop of warm red bean paste. ***1/2

- Steamed Big BBQ Bun is spicy and satisfying, a larger cake that has an alluring brown toasted dome. The bready dough is glutinous and almost addictive in itself. ***1/2

- Sweet Rice Puff w/Coconut, Peanuts is a surprising combination of flavors that works. The coconuts and peanuts add a crunchy, chewy texture that works nicely with the glutinous rice. I've never tried this taste before. ***1/2

- Turnip Cake has an almost shrimp-like flavor, mild but appealing. And surprisingly delicious. ***

- Custard is an almost mandatory dessert at many Chinese restaurants, but this version has just enough sugar to be special. The pastry just crumbles in your mouth. ***1/2

- Deep Fried Taro Root - Not the best version I've eaten of this classic, but the combination of subtly-crunchy and savory is still a winner. ***

- Sweet Rice Chicken Wrapped in Lotus Leaves - This dish is dramatic and fun to open, but the glutinous rice and seasoned chicken is flavorful and satisfying - almost the Chinese version of a burrito. This is special. ****

All of the items I tasted were flavorful and worth ordering again.
author: Thirsty C.

description:
Ehhhhh...
Definitely the McDonald's version of dim sum.  You get in the queue and grab a pink menu and just make your selection.  Keep in mind that each order is 3 pieces for $2 which is pretty cheap.  The place could just a wipe down.  The tables were filthy and I didn't dare look under the table.  The dim sum we ordered was just ok, it would have been better if it was hot.  It was just luke warm temperature.  It was also served on paper plates and with plastic forks.  I firmly believe that some of the best foods are found in hole in the wall places but this definitely wasn't the case.   I'd pass on this one or else take it to go if you really want to try it.
author: Nyla K.

description:
It was indeed good luck finding this place! I gotta have my dim sum yum fix from time to time. This place is always packed whenever I come. I recommend grabbing a menu and paper while you wait in line and write down what you want and how much. Trust, it'll make the process go a lot faster. 

There is seating here but I feel more comfortable taking my food and eating it at home. I feel like this place wasn't intended to anyway.  Bring some sauce containers since they don't provide any. 

I generally get the basic: eggrolls, siu mai, deep fried stuffed dumpling, and har gow. And they all taste great! Everything is super cheap which is great for me! You can get full roughly around under $15. What a steal am I right? 

Authentic, cheap, and delicious.
author: Breanna N.

description:
Been in the USA for more than five years and this is the worst service I have ever received! Almost ruined my day but I guess I have to move on anyway. GTH.

Hope I can give them ZERO star!
author: Zhenjie C.

description:
Good and legit af. Get any of their rice bowls ($4.00!!!) if you want to fill yourself up with a near-trivial amount of money 

Come for the great dim sum, stay for the guy that carts dim sum around while yelling "CHOO CHOO"
author: Kevin L.

description:
Long lines, and no seats but three star forGreat Dim Sum! If you are looking for a good dim sum place and you are heading into the city I recommend this place! It's very cheap and a lot of food! 

The bad is that sometimes the lines are so long that you have to wait to eat! It's took us about 20 mins and it was around 2 pm not really high time for food! It also has no seating you have to get really lucky to find a seat because there is only five or six tables!

Also this a typical parking in sf! Good luck trying to find parking you might have to walk down the street a couple blocks to get to this place from your car. There is no parking here!
author: Ariel V.

description:
I stopped here on the way back from Santa Cruz to Santa Rosa.    What better place than a dim sum place in San Francisco to pick up some delicious dim sum.   I ordered char siu bao, sui mai, shrimp dumplings, beef & veg. dumplings, and egg custard to go.   

Everything was delicious and reasonably priced.   Good Luck Dim Sum will be my go-to place every time I pass through San Francisco.
author: Dana H.

description:
A hit and miss kinda of place.  Sometimes its good and other times its so so.  Unfortunately the last time I was here it was the worst I've had in all the times we've come here.  

Tables are never cleaned so you have to clean up yourself.  I'm always scared walking to their restroom to get a wet paper towel to wipe down our table because the floor always feels slippery.  I don't know if its because they never mop it and its just caked on grease.  Feels like a lawsuit waiting to happen.
author: Naty D.

description:
Not sure why this place is so popular; must be another hole-in-the-wall hype thing in SF. Absolutely bland and gross tasting dim sum. Watery (unsalted) flavoring of the pork siu mai. Floury daikon cake. Steamed char siu bao was soggy and incredibly glutinous, and they use the pink artificially-flavored char siu seasoning that I know all too well. Everything that was fried came out soggy. And the most offendable thing: everything was cold, not even warm, and we ate in (so the food didn't have a chance to start getting cold. It was already cold!)

Would you go anywhere for soggy and cold dim sum? Nope. Glad I only paid $4.06 for my share. I did get full though. I would get your takeout dim sum elsewhere.
author: E N.

description:
OMG, I have never felt so freaking cool!

I have been eating at Good Luck Dim Sum since I was a toddler. I am just now looking at it on yelp for the first time and to my amazement everyone (including reputable Chinese friends, which is most important) is raving about this place.

Literally before I could even read, my dad would take me to my doctors appointments at CPMC on California and afterwards we'd go to "the dim sum place by See's Candies." Hah, look at me-- great taste at such a young age *hair flip*

To this day, I still get HAR GOW, siu mai, shrimp & chive dumplings, SHARK FIN DUMPLINGS, steamed bun, custard tart, and sesame balls. Sometimes my dad just buys me a bagful of sesame balls because those used to be my fave lol. 4 stars for the dim sum, +1 star for the nostalgia :)

The best part of all-- this place is cheap. Sometimes I get more than I need to because by the time I'm done ordering what I want, I'm like "Wait, that's it? Give me more _____."

Come thru, it's lit
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: Cheap, fresh, and tasty! I remember I was so overwhelmed during my first visit because I had no idea what I wanted. There are so many dim sum items! Now I've about tried most of them and honestly everything taste so delicious. There is nothing fancy about this place, just authentic and legit dim sum. The lines can be long over the weekend, but the ladies work hard and move fast! Cash only. Take them to go and eat at home for more comfort if you live close by.
author: Nana L.

description:
Can't beat the price. Great value for money.
Sweet bao buns were incredible. Fresh, fluffy, sweet and good dollop of char sui in the middle.
author: Geoff H.

description:
This is by far the best place for dim sum without the fanfare and show that comes with dining in. The location itself is pretty narrow and has limited seating. However, most people that venture here take their order to go. It's a quick operation that makes being in line not so bad. 

Once you're inside, take one of the pink slips and pens to mark the items you want. This eliminates any potential language barriers, so it's positive for both sides!
