Three tiers are available: 3 for 2 dollar items, items for less than a dollar and then the a la carte items. I always go for the siu mai, fried stuffed dumplings, leek dumplings and the turnip cake because it makes you want to turn up! Eh eh!? Okay sorry. But I won't apologize for eating it all myself because the food is great. An added bonus is that it usually costs less than 10 dollars to get you full. If you're still hungry, I highly recommend the baked bbq buns. They're huge and the pork filling is better than most places around the city. 

The women who keep the line moving are really nice. I'm not sure if they have any ownership but they definitely work like it's their store. If you're nice, they might just throw in some extra goodies. This assumes they've seen your face a bajillion times, which will likely happen because you'll come back after your first time here.
author: Quoc N.

description:
3.5 stars. Great for budget style dim sum, but knocked stars off for consistency

Their ha-gow is better than similar nearby dim sum stores- skin isn't too thick and the shrimp is cooked well.

Favorite item in this store is their pan fried chive dumplings. Usually, the skin is thin and is generously stuffed with chives; but the last time I went the dumpling skin was too thick, understaffed and greasy. This wasn't the first time it was 'off'


Their steamed taro dumpling, peanut/sugar mochi, and steamed white sugar cake is also decent
author: J D.

description: My boyfriend and I were visiting from SoCal. We were at Golden Gate Park and were craving dim sum but didn't want to drive to Chinatown, and happened upon this place. Glad we came here! Food was delicious and very cheap! We ended up with 6 beef siu mai, 3 shrimp dumplings, 6 pot stickers, and one BBQ pork bun...all for $12!! It filled us up and we ended up saving some for our drive back to SoCal. Parking is street but plenty of street parking on a Wednesday morning. CASH ONLY!!!
author: Amanda N.

description: Major crowds on a weekend but the ladies work fast and get you in and out quickly.  Can't go wrong with just about anything on the menu.  Best to get the food to go because there is hardly space to eat in the back area unless you go on a weekday.
author: Shelton F.

description:
CASH ONLY

this is a great place to grab a quick plate of dim sum on the weekends. to those visiting good luck: i think of this as a "to go" kind of place. if you want something fancier or an "experience" go to tong kien or hong kong lounge...that's what you're looking for.

the noms: har gow, siu mai, shrimp/chive dumplings, pork buns are all solid choices.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Fast, Easy, but Cash Only.

Just grab a couple racks of your dim sum basic, and go over to GG bridge or GG Park to sit back and relax.
author: Alvin L.

description: I really like their banana leaf wrapped sticky rice and their giant chicken bun, also their small steamed bbq pork buns. Compared to others just down the street, their stuff tastes more flavorful. Ate here twice during one weekend and I keep wanting more sticky rice!
author: Mei W.

description: Super reasonable, sizeable, and delicious dim sum! The only downside is there is no sauce (vinegar). Also, it's only a carry out store so you'll have to find a place to eat elsewhere!
author: Christine N.

description:
Cheap and quick dim sum! This place is CASH ONLY!

The lady at the counter spoke English so there were no issues with us ordering. We came towards the later part of the day and they were out of some items like shrimp dumplings. We got a ton of shumai and pork dumplings in a to-go box and it only ended up being $8 which was a great deal. The quality is solid and the serving size of each dumpling is huge too!

There's also some seating inside but note it's not one of those fancy dim sum restaurants with carts being pushed around if that's what you're looking for.
author: Linda X.

description:
I bought 20 bucks worth of dim sum and threw most of it away like 95%. I didn't like the soggy dim sum and yes, the best thing is the cheap prices but you really get what you pay for!

I rather pay more for better  tasting food so I will hit up Koi Palace the next time I have a dim sum craving.
author: Gangsta G.

description:
Probably the best dim sum place in town. Grab your items to go, it's cash only and not a lot of seating. They do have a cash only sign, but it's hard to clock, so come prepared--you're going to want a lot of food. I've always had good luck with their siu mai, lo bak go (turnip cake), har gao (shrimp dumplings), and lo mai gai (sticky rice steamed in banana leaf). Don't pick weird amounts--the menu clearly indicates that one order includes X amount of items (three is the usual). 

It's all delicious dry, but grab some sauce to go. Sweet soy sauce makes even better.
author: Jasmine G.

description:
Delicious shrimp & chive dimsum, you get 3 for $2.20! The shark's fin shumai was also very tasty and the house porridge was satisfying enough. Perfect for cold rainy days in the city.  
Cash only.
author: Marie P.

description: Yummy, yummy, yummy Dim Sum.  I had the shu mi and pork dumpling.  Parking is a challenge on weekends but well worth the time.  Can't eat here as it is a take out place.
author: Mike K.

description:
One of the worst tasting dimsum places I have I ever been to. This place was so bad that it warranted my first 1 star yelp review.

I lived 12 years in HK so I'd like to think that I know something about good dimsum and this place does not have it. I came here because of the high reviews and the insanely cheap prices but my terrible experience began pretty much as soon as I ordered the food. 

The Cantonese woman was super rude whenever my gf and I asked questions about the menu, she would not answer my questions until like the second/third time I asked (pretty sure she was just ignoring us) and she would just go off and chat with some of the other women working there without finishing helping us. Also the food was stone cold and the wrappers for all of the dumplings were so thick (especially the hargao that everyone raves about lol) like dangg it was like eating some dough straight up. Could have been an off day for them but honestly have no idea why this place has such high reviews or why there's even a line. Place did not satisfy my dimsum cravings, more like blunted it and just ruined it.
author: Harry L.

description:
Was taken here by a friend and it has become one of my favorite places for delicious, cheap, authentic dim sum. 

You'll probably be in line for a little bit (esp if you come on a Sunday). But this gives you time to look over the menu which is written in Chinese and English on your order form (and stare at everything that comes out in the big steamers!)

Everything is quite a steal! Most of the savory items will be 3 for $2, including the shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings, shiu mai, and turnip cake. A lot of sweet items like the mochi rice puff with peanuts and coconut, egg yolk bun (steamed white bun with a sweet yellow filling - love!) will be $0.90. Sweet rice wrapped in lotus leaf, a baked BBQ pork bun, Chinese donut, and porridge are all going to be a dollar or 2 more. But they will ALL be worth it! 

My favorites - dumplings! They aren't pan fried dumplings, so their skin will be chewy and glutinous. The shrimp and chive dumplings have a great balance of the two ingredients, and the plain shrimp one is stuffed full of delicious shrimp.

If you don't know what to order, just be adventurous - everything is delicious!
author: Venus F.

description: I am so so so glad that I found this place. My boyfriend and I would spend about $60+ sitting in at a dimsum restaurant. I'd been persistently telling him that we should go to this spot so we could experience the "to go" dimsum and he absolutely loved it. I ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT TOO! We got a pound of chicken feet, porridge, 12 dumplings (har gow and chive dumplings), sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves, egg tarts, and egg bun....ALL FOR ONLY $22 bucks. I am a huge lover of har gow so I was super happy to see that it was on point! Definitely will be coming back more for some dim sum here!
author: Monica L.

description:
For fast, easy, delicious dim sum with that curt yet charmingly expected Chinese attitude the ladies have to get you your food as fast as possible, this is my Dim Sum spot in SF. 
Love it here. Bring cash & tip a few bucks! I'm talking to you millennials!!!
author: Everette R.

description: Oh, oh, oh. Friend brought us to this place and I was a little hesitant, but the food was really good. Had an assortment of all kinds of hinds. Definitely a must come back place!
author: RobD F.

description:
Delicious, cheap dim sum. Wait is usually about 10 mins. I really like the Chinese chives dumping and the hargow. 

Be aware - cash only!
author: Shirls S.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is one of the more popular "take out" / "to go" Dim Sum spots on Clement Street in the Richmond District of San Francisco.

The food is fresh and reliable.  They only accept CASH, so bring your US DOLLARS and leave the checks and credit cards at home.

The portions and pricing is fair and reasonable.

Parking is tough in the Richmond District on Clement Street, the heart of the shopping area, but it's not impossible to find a meter nor free parking if you have the right amount of patience, karma, and timing.
author: Rick S.

description:
Can I just tell you how THRILLED I am that one of my favorite hole in the wall dim sum joints has a health score of 81/100?! 

Located on Clement between 9th & 8th,  awesome dumplings and buns are made fresh throughout the day.

In the steamer baskets:
Assorted steamed buns and dumplings are 3 for $2.00. 

Glass cases:
Most buns and pastries are $0.90 each. 

Highly recommend:
* Steamed BBQ pork bun
* Shrimp dumpling
* Pork siu mai
* Custard bun
* Sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves
* Taro puff 

Bring your cash. And perhaps your own reusable containers. Good Luck Dim Sum is cash only and charges $0.20 per box.

Dine in or take it to go. Either way you won't be disappointed.
author: Geminyna J.

description:
Super quick and efficient. Get your dim sum and get out! Well, not really, but you can have your food ready in a minute. No waiting for a push cart or even worse - waiting for other people to look over the cart. 

I got it to go, b/c I was rushing my final day visiting San Fran. That, and the tables were full, and it was a bit stuffy in there.

Basically $.70 for every piece of dim sum. There are some special items, too, but the couple I had weren't really good. The sausage roll was awfully tough. It tasted like breakfast sausage, and I had it at 5pm. Maybe that's the reason 

Buns were fluffy enough. Fair amount of filling. Not too crazy about the BBQ filling. It had this weird gelatinous texture to it.

Dumplings were on point. Good amount of filling and great taste. Good selection, including shark fin.

Deep fried stuffed dumpling ironically had almost no stuffing in it. It was literally some green onion flecks and a huge pocket of air.

As with many restaurants, your mileage may vary. Stick with the tried and true items, and you'll be ok.

PS A very important PS This place was one of the few we were looking at that didn't rate at the bottom of the food inspection scale. This was a huge reason why we ended up going here instead of some of the other dim sum spots.
author: Neal N.

description: Shrimp dumpling, potstickers, beef shumei, pork bun, sesame ball, all so delicious and a good portion! The best dim sum I've ever had. We went on Saturday around 1pm. Place was packed. Food is 4 stars but I rated the environment a 3. The ppl working there should show some TLC to there tables, and walls. We sat down and the table was greasy and left food from the previous person.
author: Cristina S.

description:
After too many overpriced dim sum meals, I decided to grab some take-out to help my sad sad wallet out for a day!

3 pcs shrimp dumpling (har gow) for $2
3 pcs shrimp/chive dumpling (I think?) for $2
1 BBQ pork bun for $0.90

I totally forgot foods get taxed, and my total was $5. I opened up my little bag of take-out goodies as I'm walking down Geary, and these guys were GLUED to the little paper boat they were in! While it's nice and affordable, I guess there really is a reason that sit down places cost more, and it's not just for the service. The pork bun was pleasant, and I'm hoping that my subpar experience was simply due to it being past the usual brunch/lunch time when I arrived.
author: Christine L.

description:
How can you compete with affordable and delicious dim sum? The food is worth the long lines. The counter servers work fast. Luckily there are order forms to keep track of all the delectable treats. 

Instead of listing all the great treats, try them all! So far I've had shark fin dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings, and rice porridge. I can't wait to try more.
author: Joanna S.

description:
If you are looking for delicious cheap eats in the Inner Richmond area, Good Luck Dim is the place to go. At this dim sum place, you fill out an order form and order/pay at the counter; no carts being pushed around. Our group of 7 ordered $60 worth of dim sum and we ate it for 2.5 meals. The seating is sparse (about 4-6 tables that seat 4) but if you can, grab a table so you can enjoy your meal super fresh. You can also watch the endless line of fresh dim sum being carted up to the front to be sold. 

My favorite items I had were the taro cake, pork shu mai, and the steamed bun. Everything tasted super fresh and not at all greasy. 

CASH ONLY & no hot mustard.
author: Anna-Marie T.

description: Cheap, no-fuss dim sum. Cash-only. Husband and I ordered shrimp dumplings, beef shumai, steamed BBQ pork buns, and crispy mushroom puffs. All in all we spent $8, enough for a quick lunch. I can't believe how generous the kitchen is with how much meat comes with each piece of fresh dim sum. This is definitely a must-try spot.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Omg, who knew you could get dim sum for such a low, low price?! I wish they had pork dumplings (xiao long bao) but they can fulfill your other cravings.  1.80 for an order for three pieces for things like shu mai, shrimp dumpling, pork buns and beyond blows my mind.  They have the salt and pepper spareribs, porridge, the sticky rice in leaves or whatever it's called in English (dim sum is about the only thing where I think in Chinese).  We even had leftovers when the meal for three was only $20!   Be sure to grab the egg tarts for desert as usual.  Decent and cheap.
The main downfall of this hole in the wall is the parking and that it's cash only.
author: Emily L.

description:
In a bite: some of the best dim sum I've had in the Bay Area!

My palate for legitimate, tasty dim sum was developed with dim sum from Hong Kong and the 626 (Southern California). That being said, this place was good even by such high standards! I tried a large selection of their items (shrimp dumplings, egg tarts, chicken siu mai, fried taro, bbq pork bun, egg roll, turnip cake, and xian shui jiao) and each was satisfying in texture and taste. 

While the food was wonderful, -1 star from perfection based on the experience being slightly chaotic and confusing. The employees who work here were not unfriendly; however parking is definitely hard to find in this neighborhood and the process of ordering your dim sum could be clarified. (while we stood in line and ordered by telling the staff what we wanted, there was apparently a pink sheet that we could have marked our order on that would have been much easier to use if we had known it existed at the time)/
author: Annie Z.

description:
I'll get straight to the point here. It's authentic, cheap, quick, and delicious. Need I say more? There are tons of Dim sum joints in Sacramento, where I'm from but in all honesty, all of them combined don't compare to this hole in the wall. Sure, there aren't women dressed in ethnic gowns pushing carts and seating is pretty limited, but it's really a pick what you want, pay, and bounce type of place . Why sit in when you can walk a couple blocks to golden gate park and have a picnic ? 

Be sure to try their Chinese donut . It's greasy, soft, crunchy, and oh so good! You won't need Chapstick if you're eating one of those bad boys. That grease will smother your lips like it's meant to be Carmex but edible ! So it basically beats any Chapstick I've ever used!
author: Monica C.

description: I was craving dim sum today and I thought about this place.  I've been here once and I really liked it, like a lot.  Street parking is hard to find.  I guess if you drive around, you'll eventually find one.  It's a small place, not too many tables.  This is not your ordinary cart pushing dim sum restaurant.  I've seen more people get it to go.  It's cheap and everything I had was good.  The lines can be long, out the door but I think it's totally worth it!
author: Yuka N.

description:
Quick and reasonably priced. I grew up on dim sum so I do have favorites hahah, but overall the food here is pretty good. The pork siu mai and shrimp dumpling I thought were great! I also got both the steamed and baked pork buns, which were decent, but not the best I've ever had. 

PARKING: it's clement, busy area, can be a nightmare to find parking, but be patient hahah. There's metered and unmetered parking spots around the general area. 

SERVICE: super fast! Those ladies are quick 

NOTE: CASH ONLY!
author: Vivian S.

description:
Initially I was going to give a low 4 stars. It was a decent price for decent food. For example, the chicken rice in lotus leaf I'm used to eating with more flavor and filling.

I'm usually pretty happy with my experiences and give places 5 stars leniently, so why not this time? Well, initially four stars because the lady helping me was kind of rude. This was my first time here so looking at the menu and all the items, I figured the 3 for $2.20  section meant you can mix and match. I even told the lady (and stuck up a finger indicating 1, and she acknowledged) and wrote a 1 next to each item that I wanted one of each. Later when she started putting together the items on a plate, and I was like "no, no, no, one of each" that she threw this little hissy fit and was mumbling some things in Cantonese about why the heck I would do this.

So, why 2 stars? Near the latter third of my meal, I could feel my stomach knotting up and being very achy. This continued on as I walked around the street and did grocery shopping. As I sit here typing this over an hour later, I am still feeling it at around the same discomfort level. It is the type (at least now) that isn't diarrhea but gives you lots of gas.

I may have the names wrong, but here are the descriptions of what I ordered:
1) Sweet white spongey like cake.
2) Sweet chicken rice wrapped in lotus leaf
3) Shrimp dumpling
4) Beef shui mai
5) Chicken shui mai
6) Fun kaw (sic) that is the flatter triangular skin one
7) Some other item from the 2.20 menu I forgot, either chicken or beef. 

The reason I don't want to give them 1 star is because I want to give them the benefit of the doubt that this is a fluke incident, and I know of at least one other person who has gone there a lot and hasn't had stomach problems as a result.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
I don't get the craze about this dim sum place with its long queues. I gave this shop a few chances and was always disappointed. Besides the Dim Sum tasting below average, their Dim Sum is always COLD. 

Across the road, one street back, there's a shop called Xiao Long Bao. The Dim Sum there is much much better.
author: Victor C.

description:
I love this place! I grew up in the Inner Richmond, and Clement Street is basically my backyard. There are many dim sum and Chinese food options in the area, and they're all pretty good, but for some reason, Good Luck is my favorite when I have cravings for dim sum. They have all the usual items you would want, plus more, and it's way cheaper than eating in a restaurant. Most of the common items (shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, steamed BBQ pork buns, etc.) are $2.10 for 3 pcs (current price), but their specialty items are priced slightly higher but still reasonably cheap.

My favorites include: shrimp dumplings (duh), pork siu mai, taro puffs, bbq pork buns, porridge (surprisingly), chive dumpling with shrimp, and many others! They have pink slips & pens available so you can circle/fill out what you want while waiting in line (very efficient!). 

Good Luck is a to-go place, but they do have limited seating in the back. Lines are very long on weekend mornings, but the workers are super quick! It is definitely worth the wait because their dim sum is delicious, and you can easily get full for really cheap. 

Overall, I'd give them 4.5 stars, rounded up to 5. I just wish they accepted credit cards and had more seating.
author: Angela C.

description: Good Dim Sum! Came here with my family and we loved it. Good dim sum and very cheap. We loved every bite and they were really polite. Definitely coming back for more of the shrimp and beef dim sum!
author: Jordan T.

description: Delicious AND cheap dim sum?? I'm all for it! This is my go to place if I'm ever craving dim sum and it doesn't kill my wallet too. For under $10 you can get so full off their huge selection. You fill out these pink papers of what you want and can either take it go to (they charge  $0.20 for a to-go box) or eat it there. Keep in mind that they only take cash! If you choose to eat there, their sauces are pretty good (soy sauce and some kind of chili/spicy red sauce). Service is pretty quick and workers are sort of friendly.... but mostly borderline rude. Most of the time they're trying to work really fast to get all orders out. Highly recommend their fried dumplings and har gow.
author: Isabelle N.

description:
OK first of all, I believe that the people that make the dim sum need to wear a hairnet or covering.  

My wife bought  naah mei gei (lotus wrapped sticky rice), there was a long black hair mixed with the rice,,, really nasty,   I had to toss the who thing.  I have a short military hair cut so there is no way it came from me.

Then I had one of their Dai Bao (Big Bun), the char sui (BBQ Pork) inside was hard...not chewy...but hard.  

The pork dumplings (Siu Mi) was good though.
author: Jerry W.

description:
There are other Dim Sum joints that may have better reviews, but they're likely to be in Chinatown. Good luck finding parking out there. 

Come to Good Luck Dim Sum in the Richmond District where there's plenty of parking and everything's $1! 

Nice variety of meats (pork, chicken, shrimp, etc.) and desserts. Soda available to wash down your meal. 

Watch yourself,  you will get full quicker than expected. Great place to pop in for a quick meal!
author: Francisco A.

description:
Probably the best dim sum bakery in SF. Fresh, delicious dumplings and a unique and flavorful DIY sauce sets this apart from the other options you have. My favorites are the shrimp dumplings, pork buns and pan friend shrimp & chive dumplings.

Not only can you and a friend/SO share a meal for $10-12, it will be of top notch authentic quality.

There's usually a line and it is cash only. Also know why you want by the time you get to the front. A lot of the items come in 3 to an order so be sure to be clear if you are ordering number of pieces or an order to ensure you get what quantity you are looking for.

Oh and did I mention the soy sauce?!? Must try!
author: Peter D.

description:
So I did something rather stupid here. I've walked by this long-standing place dozens of times and always noticed the long lines. Funny thing is that I was either on my way to a meal or on my way home after just finishing one. Last Saturday, I was waiting for my car to be serviced when I finally decided yes, I would like to see what the fuss was about here. I didn't know the drill, and frankly everyone in line looked like they knew exactly what they wanted. When I noticed the pink sheet with all the dim sum choices, I was in a bit of a quandary how to order a mix of them until someone handed me a mini-golf pencil for me to circle my choices.

Now here's the stupid part. When I read "3 for $1.90", I thought that meant I should choose three different dim sum. With that misconception in my head, I decided to circle six items in that section and add a Custard Tart and a Sweet Rice Bun for $0.90 each (photo: http://bit.ly/1Jv2Ghh). I was quite proud of my thoughtfully coordinated order when I submitted it to one of the three women who were a blur of kinetic energy as they masterfully grabbed the dim sum with their tongs from the various steam baskets and trays (photo: http://bit.ly/1A4n803). What immediately became clear to me was the "3 for $1.90" actually meant I was getting three of all six dim sum I ordered.

That meant I was getting a whopping 18 dim sum in one of those flimsy plastic to-go containers. I was too embarrassed to stop her. She filled that tray so fast that I didn't notice what a hefty bag of dim sum I was about to carry out the door. It was probably too humiliating for me to eat it there at one of the formica tables they have set up since they would have expected the rest of my baseball team to show up. So I lugged all that dim sum back to the waiting room of the car dealership: three Shrimp Dumplings, three Pork Siu Mai, three Beef Siu Mai, three Chicken Siu Mai, three Steamed Pork Dumplings, and three Potstickers (photo: http://bit.ly/1EvQnOK).

It was just $11.40 for all of that. Luckily, they were out of the sweet ones I ordered, or more likely, the woman felt I ordered enough and moved on to the next customer. You'll be happy to know there is a happy ending to my tragic mistake. As I sat waiting for my car to get ready, I only had time to try one of each kind as I originally intended and found them to be as tasty and abundant as I heard they were. As for the rest of them, I gave them to a young Chinese family who were waiting for their car. I explained my conundrum, and they were happy to take the rest off my hands. So my misfortune turned into someone else's good luck. It's called the Circle of Dim Sum. Seriously. Look it up.

FOOD - 4 stars...no matter how many you order, they're all warm and tasty
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...not much to say about this closet of a place except to say it works
SERVICE - 3 stars...fast, that's all
TOTAL - 4 stars...now I know what the fuss is about but for Pete's sake, don't over-order like I did
author: Ed U.

description:
Not the best dim sum i've ever had, but it satisfies your craving and is incredibly cheap. I got the Chinese sausage roll, egg custard bun, pork siu mai, har gow, and sticky rice. The dough on the buns was was starchy, fluffy and sweet, and I appreciated how I saw them making it fresh in the back. The meat seemed like it was of suspect quality but tbh at dim sum it often is. If you're nearby and have a craving, stop by! It's cheap, sweet, salty, greasy comfort food. But if you're not, it's probably not worth the trip. 

Oh, btw -- this is a more intimidating ordering process than most so be wary of that when you go there. If you speak the language though, you're probably fine.
author: Emily M.

description: Cheap, quick and simple. They have a chili garlic paste vs chili oil that I usually have.
author: Gerald M.

description:
Just found hair in my chicken feet, super grossed out and disappointed since I bought $35 in dum sum this morning.  I actually didn't ask for a receipt and with the little I received I am wondering about the validity of the amount I paid.

Buyer beware, I would include a pic but please please don't eat here.

There are much cleaner places that offer dim sum without armpit hair.
author: Charles B.

description: My favorite to-go dim sum spot in San Francisco. The shrimp dumplings here are the best in the game. Also can't beat the prices here. You can feed a family of 4 here for less than $15. The spot is tiny and parking on Clement St. is near impossible, but that doesn't stop me from going out of my way to come back to this spot whenever I am in the city.
author: Victor N.

description: Great dim sum.  First time here and took a chance based on reviews.  Glad we came. We'll be coming back again for sure.  $20 for two of us and we're stuffed.  Food-gasm!
author: Riley K.

description:
So cheap! Its typical of a take-out dim sum place, so it can be overwhelming with the amount of activity... with the asian women yelling at each other for something or another, and a line of people both waiting to order and at the tables, it can be difficult to know what you're ordering and if its too much food. 

They have a lot of the basic offerings like buns and dumpling-like things, but since we were a group of 4, it was kind of annoying that most things came in sets of 3. I remember the pork bun being somewhat uncooked, and the egg custard just... not tasting as buttery and delicious as it should have. Maybe I just prefer the sit-down kind of dim sum better. 

They ran out of congee :(
author: Katy Q.

description:
I came across this place a while back... thought I would try it out since there were so many reviews about this place. When I got here during lunch hours, this place was packed with people. The line was long, but their service was fast! So the wait wasn't too bad. 

I've tried several dim sum places around here, and so far this is the best one. Their dim sums are covered with a lid so when you order to-go, the food remains hot. Other places I've been to always had no lid so whenever I eat their food its cold and gross. Also, I think it's more sanitary having a cover over it because when I see people order they are usually spitting, and I don't want people spitting in my food.

[When you walk in, remember to grab their order sheet to mark how many pieces of diim sum you want and they will take your order.]

What I love best is their shrimp dumplings. It's pretty big compared to the bay area shrimp dumplings. Also, the dim sums here are fairly cheap. They have a lot of options for you to choose, but obviously not as much if you dine-in in a restaurant. 

The store is pretty small, so tables are limited. If you want to dine in to eat make sure you grab a table before you order your food. 

Overall, if you're on the go and want some fast, cheap dim sum, this is the place to go! Make sure to check this place out!
author: Noel K.

description:
I have only been here once but I'm obsessed. It's good dim sum for a spectacular price. Dim sum restaurants rarely have good service, so I'm more than happy to hit up this dim sum bar and pay the fraction of the cost for a full dim sum meal.

My boyfriend and I ate as much dim sum as we wanted for $15 total. I also love how you can order by piece or set, so you can have pretty much anything you desire without worrying about having too much of one thing.
author: Jocelyn H.

description:
Cash only! 

A great place to get your dim sum fix if you're a party of one or two- perfect to pick up some snacks to go as well. One of my favorite places to drop by for lunch. The place and the menu are kind of overwhelming and the place always seems rushed so I'll list my favorite things to get:

My go-to's are the pork shu mai, sometimes swapped out for the beef or shark fin dumplings since you get 3 for$2.20. 

Lotus rice - wrapped in bamboo leaves and deliciously sticky. 

Pork buns- fluffy and delicious 

Chicken feet are soaked in sauce and not the best I've ever had but tasty, around $5 or $5.50 for a serving (1 pound). 

I also love the sesame balls with red bean paste inside.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Great cheap fast dim sum joint and which is good for both a snack or a meal (though they close early). You can mix and match so go wild.

I don't like it as much as new mong kok in Chinatown which still remains the mack.
author: Misha T.

description:
We definitely over ordered here!  Which is very easy to do when you don't realize that each order comes with three pieces!

Not much of a sit down place, just some tables and chairs in the back.  Restroom very clean.

The line gets very long but there are moments when it ebbs.

Really enjoyed some of their dim sum here!  The chives one were my fav.
author: Lan C.

description: Love it. Could eat here more if I lived in SF. All are great and I love the flat half moon steamed pouches. Has a gravy like soup inside. Mmmmmm
author: K M.

description: Really mediocre dim sum at best. First time going to a dim sum location where they put everything on a tray. If you're looking for something traditional, this is definitely not the place. They don't even serve tea!! The spring rolls, baked cha siew bao and chive dumplings were all cold. And they don't have shrimp churng. Total disappointment.
author: Eric L.

description:
Fast & cheap. To-go dim sum that you order at the counter. There's limited seating inside with maybe around 10 tables. For the price of the dim sum, it's not that bad. When the price to food ratio is in my favor, I like to give thumbs up to the places I eat at.

CASH ONLY. 

Bottom line: Good bang for your buck
author: Joyce D.

description:
Came here yesterday before going on a hike and I liked it. Actually my friends and i, we all did. Especially the price LOL. 3 items for $1.90! We bought a whole bunch of food for under $22. It was really good too. I really liked the potstickers! They were so big! Lol. The shrimp dumplings were good too. Also the BBQ Steam Pork Bun was yummy. The Fried Taro Root was good, but for me it was too much deep fry. Lol, but it IS deep fried so yeah. I didn't like the chicken Siu Mai. The Shark Fin Dumpling was good too.

If you take the food to go, they charge 20 cents for the box.

BRING CASH!!! They do NOT take card!

I would come back though. Those potstickers!! So big and GOOD!! Ahaha!!
author: Akemi H.

description: Good dim sum, reasonable price, this was always my second go to, but my first place is gone so this is it. Food was good, help is friendly. Parking is a bitch Worth a stop. I will definitely stop again when I'm in the city on Clement Street a lot easier than Chinatown !
author: Pamela K.

description:
It was NOT a good luck kind of day.  Clement Street: where the Chinese restaurants outnumber the hole-in-the-wall bars and coffee shops 10 to 1.  Oh look, a Dim Sum place named Good Luck, we excitedly said as she checked in with Yelp to see that they had pretty good reviews.  Enter we did and that was the end of our good luck for the day.  

The place is just short of grimy and dirty. But we said what the heck and ordered this and that at their sticky counter and took the items to our table that had not been bussed.  No table had for the 40 minutes we were there, and the floor was sticky, the table was stickier yet.  People in the back of the restaurant were busy making dumplings by hand, one can see them in a dirty kitchen as you go to the restroom that has no towels and a hideous sticky commode.  The red and yellow (standard ketchup and mustard plastic squeeze bottles that were on each table) were stickier than leftover molasses.  They held the soy and pepper sauce used to drown out the dim sum or give it flavor perhaps.  

Yet we bit into our room temp, not hot, dim sum after dim sum.  The dough was similar to eating styrofoam we imagined, the pork inside one was a surprise shredded poor quality meat with bottled red sauce for flavor, the spring roll was very greasy and we had to wipe off the grease on their tiny napkins, the shrimp was tasteless, the veggies didn't go crunch instead wilted in your mouth... you get the picture.  

Then the deserts:  anything to take the taste away from our dim sum we thought.  The egg custard mini pie was so bland and filled with something inedible, we just gagged at the fake color of yoke.  The sticky bun was like a dog toy that had been chewed by a rabid skunk, not even close to being good but was fun to roll around on the formica table top.  Value for your money?  Yes, if you are broke.    

Best thing was the bottled water to wash this rancid food down.  Oh, cash only.  Duh?  You'd call your bank to get your credit card reversed for sure.  

And that night, sorry to report, it was indeed Good Luck!  Our stomachs and intestines were cleansed completely, thanks to this culinary adventure.  Never again is an understatement.  Walk on by... unless you are feeling lucky?
author: Pembrooks O.

description:
Felt like I was back in Asia. Cash only!
The interior isn't spotlessly clean or well decorated.. There are about 7 tables inside that seats four each, but you gotta fight for those tables. the ordering is also a nightmare especially for people who don't know what the dishes are (the translation names aren't the most elucidating. They also tend to sell out of the good stuff earlier on in the day, too.
HOWEVER. The prices are super affordable ($20 will get two people stuffed and still have another half a meal's worth leftover). The ladies who are working at the front don't have time to be nice to you, but there's this guy who brings the food from the back to the front and that guy made my day. People were constantly in the way of his food cart but he had the biggest smile and kept saying "beep beep!" to let people know that they should move. 
and of course the food! great dim sum! The porridge is not super special, but great. All the buns and dumplings that I got were also bomb. The malay cake - which ive never had before - was my fav. One thing that was subpar was a rice and pork rib dish, because that came cold :/
but for that price and legitness? totes five stars worth!
author: Grace P.

description:
Looked up "Best Dimsum in San Francisco" in the internet and this came up in a newspaper article.

As usual, parking in this area is a challenge.

It's cheap and the service is fast.

Unfortunately, I didn't know it was mainly a "to-go" dimsum and I dragged my whole family there. There was very limited seating.

So you walk in there is a counter where you are to line up, give your dimsum order to one of the ladies behind the counter, they'll put it in a Styrofoam box, take your payment and you can be on your way. Out the door or to one of the tables.

The main lady (older) behind the counter taking food orders is soooooooo rude. The younger lady is nicer. But you could tell she is scared of the older lady because she only smiles when the older lady's back is turned away.

CASH ONLY!!!

Bottomline: Dimsum selection is limited but cheap, good sized, and solidly good.
author: Kislev A.

description: The line was so long. Not sure what the big hoopla about this place. The food is just OK. Had to wait for a few items. Also received wrong item, I ordered BBQ pork buns but ended up with chicken veggies buns. Restaurant is pretty clean considering the location.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I have heard about this place from friends and read good reviews, so gave it a try.
In the middle of busy Chinatown, you may be better off on foot. Parking is a huge issue. 
Long line moves rather quickly, so it's fun to stand outside and watch.
Taste of the actual dim sum is ok. I would say below average. Very cheap, though.
It's one of those fun things you can do when you go to Chinatown.
Don't expect most delicious dim sum.
author: Toshie L.

description:
Arguably the best you-get-how-much-for-$20?!? you can spend on Dim Sum.

Q: Is it better than ____? 

Did you spend more than $20?

Yes -- Maybe, but probably not by much. Depends on how much over $20.

No -- Probably not. Good Luck hits that sweet $20 spot.

Tip: Genki Crepes is a couple of blocks away.
author: James G.

description:
"No dim sum for you!"

We usually visit the Bay Area annually and when in the city, will always try to get to San Fran's second Chinatown in the Richmond district, Clement Street. And in this area, is a special Dim Sum hole-in-the-wall, Good Luck Dim Sum.  

There is really nothing special about the offerings, pretty typical stuff with good taste and pricing.  You know, the har gao, siu mai, dan tat, baked and steamed bao, etc.  their congee/jook rice porridge is spot on and has a nice clean consistency and great taste for only $2.20 a serving.  There are a few tables to sit at after getting your food but most people line up, order their dim sum and out the door they go.  

There is usually a pretty good continuous  line of people buying stuff in this narrow and somewhat cramped establishment so you have to know the routine, you know, like Seinfeld and the soup nazi episode.  Grab an ordering sheet, know what you want, list what and how much you want and give it to the counter person when it's your turn.  They do not have time for questions and will not hesitate to bark at you to keep the line moving.  They are "equal opportunity" and will bark and "stink eye" anyone regardless of race, color or creed who doesn't follow the routine-I know.

Their stuff is really consistent and pretty tasty, the pricing is good and the rice porridge is nice comfort food that they offer.  Just know what you want- and all will be right with the world :)
author: Ric C.

description: Best ha gow hands down! Order 2 dozen for myself AND I would kill it all.  so fresh and so perfect.
author: Angelina L.

description: Ordered takeout here, I highly recommend it. It's a fast and easy set up to order pick up on your way home from work. This place is set up like a bakery you pick your items they will place them in your takeout box which they charge for FYI. The earlier you get there the more likely they won't run out of items. In my case, by 6pm some items were no longer available.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Cheap prices at a popular long standing spot that gets super packed weekends by 11am!!! 

My all time favorite dim sum spot of good memories.

Just get there early!!
author: Alissa H.

description:
This place is probably one of the busiest dim sum shops on Clement. Most "main dishes" are $2/3 pieces. The service is quick and efficient.  Do not expect amazing customer service because they're super busy and the restaurant is cheap - you aren't paying for service. When you come towards closing, they're definitely trying to get rid of food and will either 1) throw in extra food for free or 2) offer extra food like it's free and then charge you (has happened to me twice lol).

Delicious food, cheap prices. Great for a cheap and cute date on Clement St. and you can grab dessert or boba at so many shops afterwards.

Seating is ample, but during peak business (usually lunch time) there's gonna be people hovering over tables and watching families and old people eat. Be nice and offer a seat or ask politely to sit in on an old couple! lol
author: Jacquelyn T.

description:
Based on a to-go style dim sum restaurant, this is by far my FAVORITE!!!! I feel deprived all my years living in San Francisco and not going to this place sooner. Thanks to great Yelp Reviewers, I was influenced to try this place out and I'm so glad I did!

Quick Tips:
Pork, beef, and shrimp shui mai 3 pieces for about $2
Hot sauce and special soy sauce
Stop by during the week for no wait

Con: 
I unfortunately crave dim sum on Tuesdays and ,of course, they are closed. That's just my Luck. (hardy har har) Come here any other day and some in for some GOOD LUCK Dim Sum. :)
author: Briana H.

description:
Delicious, cheap dim sum! Constant flow of customers so food stays pretty fresh. Ordering is easy even if you don't know Chinese - you can grab a menu and choose what items you want & how many. They charge for boxes/bags & there's seating in the back.

Wasn't very hungry when we stopped by so I missed out on many of their other items, but love their shrimp dumpling and steamed bbq pork bun. However, the deep fried stuffed dumpling I got wasn't very stuffed and the pork siu mai was just okay to me.
author: Shirlene L.

description:
After a grueling 4am to 11am drive to SF from LA, Good Luck Dim Sum was the first spot I hit!

At $2 for 3 pieces this place is a bargain and quality made like most products made by the Chinese. I ordered the shark fin and shrimp dumplings. Good size and quality! $6.20 and 9 dumplings I was out the door with a good snack/mini meal.

They offer lots of other things aside from just dumplings like congee, egg rolls, etc (whatever you expect from a typical dim sum spot)

Keep in mind this is mainly a to-go spot. 7 or so tables that can seat four people. Cash only! Also mind that parking is a pain in the area!
author: Kevin N.

description:
Every time we visit San Francisco, my mom wants to come here. We always end up buying boxes and boxes full of food to take home with us on the flight back. ITS JUST THAT GOOD! 

Most of the dim sum is about $2 for 3 pieces while some of the pastries are 90 cents. Also you have to pay 10 cents for boxes. We typically get the shrimp dumplings and the child dumplings with shrimp. We also got the bbq pork buns, deep fried stuffed dumplings, shrimp taro dumplings, and their egg custard pastries. 

Their shrimp dumplings and egg custard pastries are really why we keep coming back here! They are to die for!! Every time we think we've ordered too many, they disappear within seconds and we regret not buying more. 

The line can get fairly long but the ladies behind the counter are super efficient so the wait isn't too bad but still worth it!
author: Jacqueline L.

description: Favorite dim sum. Idk if I can say that it's because the food here is the best quality or if it's just because the soy sauce/vinegar stuff in the squeezey bottles is uniquely sweet and syrupy. It's a perfect complement to the food and I've never had that anywhere else.  They also have a relatively decent bathroom.
author: Christina H.

description:
What glorious dim sum selections that you can take away or eat it for here! (Limited seating though!)

They are even prepared with the paper menu so you can select ahead of time on how many you want for each particular dish.  It is translated to English for better understanding on what the variety is!  My favorite was their steamed beef siu mais.

Cash only and the servers speak a bit English.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I love dumplings and have been to a few places in the city and by far the best tasting food. Well I was in the area and decided to grab a quick bite.  I greeted the staff with a "hello, good morning" and in return I got a blank stare and was ignored. I arrived before 5 customers who were all Asian  and was helped last, even after trying to get their attention that I was next they ignored me. One woman made eyes contact with me after helping out another customer and walked away into the kitchen to avoid helping me. The woman who Took my order sure was not eager to help me at all, she had a forced and unhappy look on her face. The food wasn't that great I took a bite of the dumplings I ordered and threw the rest away. I will definitely tell my friends to avoid this place. Lacking friendly customer service. Wasn't felt welcomed at all.
author: Louie A.

description:
Service was awesome! dropped by here for a quick carb load before heading to the zoo :) Total meal fpr $15 was enough for 2 people! couldnt asked for a cheaper yet satistfying way to start our day!

Love their shrimp w/ taro dumplings and chive dumplings! would definitely pass on the egg custord buns (the skin is way too thick).

seatting is tight with alot of turnover. dont expect to sit at a wiped down desk- and try not to look at the floor under your table. there is discarded chicken feet bones everywhere!
author: James L.

description: Cheap and delicious take out dim sum in the Richmond.  3 pieces of dim sum for $2.40 (cash only) - YUM! I pretty much love everything here, but especially the sesame balls, fried taro puffs, and bbq pork buns.  The line can be long sometimes, but it does move quickly.  Perfect for a picnic in the park or to bring home.
author: Caroline T.

description: We went on Thanksgiving Day 2017 ~5:30pm. The dim sum was barely warm. We had siu mai, haw gaw, pot stickers, stream pork bun, lotus leaf wrap, fried taro dumpling...we were disappointed with the dim sum. It wasn't streaming or hot. The flavor wasn't there.
author: an t.

description:
I am pretty flabbergasted that I have never reviewed this place. Ever since my girlfriend moved in the Inner Richmond neighborhood a little over an year ago, I have made it my mission to come here at least once per visit.

Though the lines may be long, don't let is discourage you from trying this place out. It moves super quick. What we usually do, is grab the paper menu and circle the things we want, so the transaction will be a lot easier. Something I love is that each order is 3 pieces for $2. So for about $10, you can mix and match and be very content with yourself. My personal favorites are the sesame balls filled with red bean paste, sticky rice wrapped in the banana leaf, and turnip cake.

I remember coming once at closing time and the lady literally threw in 4 sesame balls in for free. Though it wasn't the freshest, you can't complain with free and delicious food! And it is cash only so just be wary of that! Highly recommend!
author: Alan N.

description:
Very reasonable price dim sum to go or simple quick eat-in. 

Recommended: Har Kow, Siew Mai, Char Siew Pao, Egg tarts
OK: fried spring roll, 
Skip: Turnip cake, Rice roll
author: Samuel A.

description:
I stopped by this place while I was showing some of my friends around San Francisco. This is a hole in a wall place where the menu is no in english, which to me is always a good sign. I came in toward closing so they ran out of some of my favorite things so make sure to come early. 

I wanted to give this place 5 starts, it was so delicious. I sat and ate and thought about how great of a review I woudl leave. Seriously super yummy and affordable dim sum. We paid under $20 for 3 people and we were stuffed. This is CASH ONLY place so don't forget to bring some $$$ :))))

Alrighty now the reason why I am giving it 3 stars. I got sick after eating there and it wasn't just me. My boyfriend got sick as well hence I had to ding this place 2 stars. I don't know if my stomach could't handle the rich dumplings or it was because I came in later in the day after they had been sitting out but I wish I didn't eat so much. 

If you've got an iron stomach, want delicious dim sum and don't want to pay too much this is definitely the place for you.
author: Dasha K.

description: There are lots of dim sum bakeries in SF but Good luck has some of the best food. Parking in Inner Richmond is definitely easier than Chinatown but the line at good luck gets quite long. The morning we were there the staff was struggling to fill both call-in and waiting orders and the kitchen was behind resulting in repeated shortages of certain items. On the positive side the price and quality were excellent, so a 5 for food but try to go at off days or hours for best selection.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Five stars for taste and price, but one star for service. It is cash only here, and most of the available parking nearby is metered. I have only ordered to go, because the ambience is not great, and the people aren't friendly.
author: WeiWei H.

description: Definitely coming back for their pork dumplings. You can tell they're house made with slap-yo-self-this-ish-is-so-fresh love. Lol. Cash only!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
This was my fourth stop in my search for good dim sum on clement street.

*Note* I am basing all of my dim sum reviews on the following three items (as they are my favorites): Baked bbq pork bun, Har gao and Siu Mai.

Bao - This was really, really sticky. There was also way too much bread. The filling was of the very gooey variety with the tiniest pork pieces in it. I did not like any part of this.

Har gao - Average filling, extremely sticky/gooey on the outside. This was alright.

Siu mai - This was not great either. The filling was a bit oily for my liking and the outside was rather dry.

-

Coconut peanut pastry - This was an impulse buy that I really enjoyed. It was basically mochi on the outside, with some coconut flakes as a coating. Inside was ground peanuts mixed with coconut flakes. I really liked this item although it doesn't really make up for the poor quality of the rest.

Likely will not be returning here either.
author: Mark O.

description: No frills hole in the wall kind of place. We had 3 x siu mai, 3 x har gao, chicken feet, hearty congee, sesame ball and egg tart for the grand total of $12. It was an immensely satisfying 15 minute meal.
author: Lindt C.

description: Sesame balls- yum! And turnip cakes were delicious too. The potsticker dough in particular was tasty and shrimp dumpling seemed great to me. This spot not a place for its ambiance but the ability to load up a plate of tasty dim sum fare for a great price. The ordering was easy for those not super familiar with dimsum give the sheet that you circle/order from at the counter up front. Would make a great to go spot or there are a few tables.
author: J K.

description:
My friend and I were craving dim sum but didn't have the time for a sit down dim sum place in Chinatown so we found this place on Yelp. There was a bit of a line inside when we came but it went by pretty quick. You have to grab a menu and pen and circle which orders of dim sum you would like. Unfortunately, they were out of sesame balls which are one of my favs. I also wished they had some veggie dishes as well. 

Our Order:
-Shrimp Dumplings! (YUM)
-Shrimp and Chive Dumplings
-Porridge
-Egg Rolls
-Pork Shumai

I wasn't a fan of the bbq pork in the pork buns. The service was super quick in getting our order and luckily we were able to swoop in on a table. What I loved the most was how cheap everything was! Our whole order was only $14 which fully fed 2 of us
author: Jami K.

description: Great Dim Sum. No hot mustard. Cash Only. There was a line the whole time we were there but it moves quickly. Mmm.
author: Hunter J.

description: This place makes amazing dim sum for so cheap. There are so many options and they make it all fresh it's very impressive. For the quality of food this place is so inexpensive. I would highly recommend it anytime you're in that area of SF.
author: Asher W.

description:
Cheap, quick, and tasty dim sum. The majority of the items are 3 pieces for 2 dollars, and the pieces are pretty generous - no skimping on the ingredients. We were able to eat decently for about 10 dollars between two people, and could have easily been very full for just a few dollars more. The items that weren't 3 for 2 dollars were typically the larger items, or some more unique items. These were also reasonably priced, no more than 3 dollars are so at the most. 

The place is cash only, and there isn't much seating, so it's a better place to get something to go.
author: Wayne H.

description: Amazing dim sum for amazing prices. The dining area offers no fancy frills, but who cares when the food is so good and affordable! Get your cash ready and take your pick. The dim sum are freshly made with new batches coming out from the kitchen. Ordering is such a fast process which is great when you're hungry. I ordered several different kinds, but the shrimp dumpling and sesame ball were my favorite. I forgot to take a picture, because they were instantly devoured. I highly recommend this place!
author: Myrrh B.

description: Absolutely cheap for the quality food they made. Will definitely go again. Line looks long but the wait is not too bad:)
author: Alison C.

description:
My sis and I stopped at this place for breakfast Sunday morning, before I headed back to LA. It's been on our bookmark for a while. Very affordable and good food.

We got porridge which comes with egg and shredded pork. Also got 2 orders of pork siu mai, shrimp dumpling, 2 steamed pork dumpling, and 2 sausage rolls for the road.  All of that for a little less than $15. Yum!! (We ate some before I remember to take a picture lol) 

I recommend coming early, the line got really long as we were getting ready to leave. There are only a few tables, so it looks like most people order for to-go. Just like most of SF, there's only metered parking for this restaurant. Please keep in mind that it's cash only.
author: Pammy P.

description:
As someone who has been spoiled by sit-down dimsum places all my life, I was really surprised when I walked in and saw that this is a to-go dimsum shop. All the goodies are premade and kept behind the counter towards the front, you order with one of the ladies behind the counter, and pay for everything all together. 

The quality wasn't bad, especially for premade food, but it's a far cry from places such as Asian Pearl in Fremont or Koi Palace in Dublin. Prices are incredibly reasonable, which makes the quality easier to stomach. I would recommend sticking with the foods that don't mind sitting around for a while, such as the porridge.

Pork and thousand year egg porridge:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco?select=YYqPK8TXJmm8qV-SMKBw7A#iXNkyJjy5B0WK7BM8ppwmw)
This was probably my favorite thing here, as porridge doesn't mind sitting around for a while. The porridge was flavorful and savory. The pieces of thousand year egg were well-boiled to a good texture but not overcooked so that they were soggy. The green onion and crisps on top tasted fresh and complemented the porridge well. 

Fried stuffed taro buns:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco?select=YYqPK8TXJmm8qV-SMKBw7A#VbMfYIktNuBYPiFiqO-AOw)
Since these were pre-fried and set out to sit, they were lukewarm at best when I got to them. The outside tasted of stale oil, and the inside filling was lacking. I would definitely not recommend these. 

Pork shu mai (left), shark fin dumplings (middle), shrimp dumplings (right):
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco?select=YYqPK8TXJmm8qV-SMKBw7A#UBzkmaQ7Uza6ctj2PDfuaQ)
These steamed goodies were okay. They were at least warm from being kept in the steamer, but the shu mai and shark fin dumpling wrappers were falling apart and dry. The fillings were mediocre and not very memorable. I did appreciate the whole shrimp in the shrimp dumplings though.

Egg tart:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco?select=YYqPK8TXJmm8qV-SMKBw7A#cKgHGifWAHOmlpSEs6QdJw)
I have an unhealthy obsession with egg tarts, so I had to at least get one to try here. I'm rather glad I only got one, as it was mediocre at best. The filling was a little too gelatinous and not eggy enough for me, the outside wasn't flaky but rather doughy, and it was cold from sitting. 

Temperature is a huge factor for me, so I probably enjoyed my meal here less than usual. The food really wasn't bad, especially for the price point, but if I ever come back, I might bag everything to go and reheat it up at home.
author: Maggie X.

description:
dude NO LIE, this place is BOMBBDOTCOMM. The dimsum here rivals some of the dim sum i've eaten in nice restaurants. And this place, it's more like a to-go establishment than a sit-down one. But its freaking delicious. its making me want dimsum now.....

The ladies behind the counter speak Cantonese and Mandarin. They have you fill out a pink slip that shows you the prices and food items in English and Chinese. But I dont think you need to really give it to them if you know what youre ordering and you speak Chinese. Their dimsum is fresh and i see that they keep them warm in a huge bamboo steamer. They also have some of the other dimsum that doesnt need to be kept warm (like egg tarts and fried taro balls) in a glass case. 

I got 3 Sui Mai, 1 steamed BBQ pork bun, 1 veggie pork bun, and 2 ha gow (shrimp dumpling). All that costed $4.90. Less than $5! If you order a lot, their container is 20cents. So if you bring your own, you can save those few cents. 

Minus one star because the lady was rude to me when she told me the price of all my dimsum. Parking is lightweight good because there are marked parking spots across the street. 

CASH ONLY.
author: Vivian H.

description: So yummy! Pork shu Mai and (shrimp) ha gao! Try the Chinese style dumpling too, and don't forget to pour on the Chile sauce. Cash only, ATM across the street. $15 for a good meal for two.
author: windy E.

description: I've had better across the street before the fire. Cheap eats but steamed pork buns, spring rolls and potstickers were less than average. No vinegar. What's up with that.
author: Andie S.

description:
OK, so if you don't know what to order, and never ate dimsum, don't come here because this is pretty much a to-go order place or you can eat in the joint, but it's pretty much self-serve, self-clean and it's super greasy, dirty.  As in, your feet will slide since there's so much grease on the floor.  With that said, all the best foods come from dirty ass places. 

The food here is cheap! Also, pay attention to pricing and how many certain things come in. Some are single items, some come in 3's.  Grab a paper, and circle what you want. 

I think their dimsum here is better than the other places i've been in SF, it's just that you don't get that cart service, nor do you get the hot sauce and the hot tea and the sit down feel. I think you should just get a bunch of food to go and eat it at a park with your friends. 

People also speak English, so for people like me who don't speak any kind of chinese besides a few words for food, it's perfect. Actually I just say one word and point my fingers of how many I want.. "dan tat" *holds up thumb, index and middle*  haha
author: Meena N.

description:
So cheap and good! The three of us stuffed ourselves practically sick (with no regrets) for $21.30. The flavors are all delicious with no pretention-just good, cheap dim sum the way it should be. Favorites were the radish cake which was flavorful and fresh and the pork shumai which was super juicy. My main complaint is the thickness of the dumplings skins... They're all a bit thick which takes away from the impact of the filling. The egg tart crust was also too thick affecting the ratio of egg to crust. Also did not enjoy the sweet rice with chicken which wasn't sticky or flavorful enough for me.

Fyi another reason for takeaway (besides the mentioned lack of seating) would be that some of the food comes cool and would benefit from reheating.
author: Daffodil L.

description: Amazing Dim Sum place! Super cheap and very popular. There might be a line but totally worth it!
author: Simon W.

description: Great place for a quick dim sum at a very reasonable price. Food move quick as people just keep lining up. What ever you like you can't go wrong here.
author: LL Y.

description:
There are very few restaurants that I regularly crave, Good Luck Dim Sum is at the top of that list. Good Luck is the very first place I go when I land in San Francisco and my last stop on my way out (unless of course I leave or arrive on a Tuesday). The BBQ steamed pork buns are the stuff of dreams...fluffy bun, sweet, tender juicy pork. The potstickers are huge and flavorful. I can (and have) eaten more than my fair share of those hot, chewy, savory dumplings. The pork siu mai, a porkalicious delight. Eggrolls = excellent. Dunk all of those off with a little soy sauce and hot chili sauce and I'm in heaven. The best part (well certainly one of them) is I can get enough to feed a small army (aka myself and sometimes my mom) and get change back for a $20. I ask you, where else in the Bay Area can you do that aside from the Costco food court? There are many places I'm willing to stand in line for, but Good Luck may be the only exception. If I could, I think I would eat here every day for the rest of my life. At my wedding...the pork buns and potstickers will be served (God help my future husband). At my funeral, all I ask is that people celebrate my life with dumplings. And at any and every celebration in-between - Good Luck Dim Sum will take center stage! The experience is chaotic, you will probably get yelled at if you attempt to order improperly or do anything of any 
 sorts, but that is part of the magic. If you have not been there, get there. If you are nearby as you read this, RUN don't walk!
author: Betsy R.

description:
Looking for authentic dim sum in a no-nonsense, low-key environment, then this is your place. The menu says 3 for $2 on almost everything, but I found that the ladies behind the counter are happy to sell individual pieces for $0.70. This is better when you're eating alone and want to sample a bunch of things. 

The pork bun was exactly as expected with the fluffy bun surrounding a hot, orange substance that was very tasty and hopefully was pork. 

I didn't like the sesame bun since it was very chewy without much flavor. 

The shrimp dumplings were just ok. I am not a fan of the smooth, white covers since they feel a little Slimey.  The shrimp was well cooked and good size. 

Based on another review I ordered the chicken, sausage and rice dish for $3.50. Certainly a great value since you get a whole plate of rice and meet with some bok choi. But I wouldn't recommend it. There was hardly any sausage and the chicken looked deformed to me. It wasn't chopped up into bite sized pieces. I think it was a thigh but can't be sure. Didn't taste bad, but I only ate half. 

The chicken/pork dumpling was my favorite. Traditional dumpling cover with a delicious filling that had a lot of flavor. I went back for more of these. 

My three stars is based on good value for your money. This is fast food dim sum. Anyone on a budget should flock here for the cheap eats. I would recommend going to Chinatown for the traditional sit down dim sum experience.
author: Craig I.

description: Incredible. The food is super tasty and ridiculously fast. There's no bells and whistles here, just straight up authentic dumplings. Go hungry, fill up and roll out. My boyfriend and I went, we ordered more food than we could eat and we paid $14 in total. One thing, the tea is just a teabag and hot water. Probably skip it.
author: Kylie F.

description: Hands-down the best Dim Sum I've ever had. Any and every time I go into the city I make sure to stop here. Cheap (usually about $9 for two people plus leftovers) and absolutely delicious.
author: Audrey H.

description:
If you're looking for some fast, efficient, tasty legit dim sum, this place is a delight. With its affordable prices and thorough menu, I was very satisfied!

$2 for 3 pieces of each Dimsum option. I got the classics: shrimp dumpling, deep fried taro, and siu mai. I was very full after.. Basic seating options with no real waiter option but when the food is that good and fast who cares! 
 
Customers kept lining up taking things to go or dropping in for a quick bite, I'll definitely come back if I'm in the area!
author: Tammy J.

description:
Qipian huo zhiliao.
Wen wen wo de ji zhua.
Gei wo yixie dianxin chi.
Ruguo ni bu zheyang zuo.
Wo buzaihu.
Wo hui la xia ni de neiyi.

Google translate told me that's Chinese for:

Trick or treat.
Smell my chicken feet.
Give me some dim sum to eat.
If you don't.
I don't care.
I'll pull down your underwear.

Ni liu xia youya, jiujinshan.

You stay classy, San Francisco.
author: Dan B.

description: Pieces are smaller than Wing Lee which is down the street, but this establishment is way cleaner.
author: Joshua M.

description:
So cheap, so good. 

Deep fried dumpling is the best!
I've tried better bbq pork bun in Chinatown.
Other than that, the pork porridge was a plus to the meal we had. 

We got so much food worth $10.
To go more food before we left for my family to try :)
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Great dim sum!!
We enjoy every moment there.
The price is very good for the value.
Highly recomended place
author: Liron Z.

description: Cheap, delicious, and authentic. Can't go wrong with anything you order! Go crazy with whatever you want!. Seating is limited, and they put food on paper plates, but you get the hole in the wall experience.
author: Y W.

description:
There wasn't a long line when I went around noon time today (Sunday), 7 ppl ahead of me. The line went by quickly as I see these ladies quickly and impatiently filling plastic bags with hot dim sum orders. Once it was my turn, the lady took my orders, but when I asked about the shark fin dumpling, she kept yelling "pork"! I said "I don't want pork, SHARK.FIN." She still kept repeating pork. So I finally understood, and said "no shark fin?" She said "yes". So why didn't you just say that in the first place...? 
I got a sesame ball ($0.70), mediocre and disappointing. Filling was not much, full of the rice dough like many other dim sum places.
I also got a sweet rice ball with crushed peanut and coconut filling ($0.90), also disappointing. Again full of dough, filling was flavorless. I had better in a place in Chinatown. 
Overall, the place is cheap indeed. I'll try their dumplings instead next time. I do like that there are a few seats inside, but can only fit two people per table. Don't come here with more than 4 friends and try to sit down. Take your food to go.
author: Alice S.

description:
Good, cheap and fast. What more can I ask for from dim sum take out?! Came on a Saturday afternoon. No wait at all.

Shrimp dumpling & Pork siu mai - Shrimp dumplings were filled with delicious shrimp and the Siu mai was full of pork goodness! Yum!

Custard tart - Custard was a little too loose for me. As if it needed to a little more cooking time. Almost fell apart in my hands when I ate it.

Egg rolls & Steamed bbq pork bun - I didn't try these but the Egg rolls looked nicely fried and the Steamed bun looked like it had a nice texture.

All in all, you can't beat 5 items for around $6.50.
author: Elena N.

description:
I find it to be an enormous travesty that I've been coming to San Francisco on fairly regular occasions, yet I've barely scratched the surface of the dim sum options available to me in the City.  It also helps to have friends that are like-minded, but yeah uhhhh that's something I don't have much control over.  Anyways, next best option is to just stop by one of these to-go dim sum places.

The benefit of going to a to-go place?  It's soooo cheap.  Honestly, I have no idea how they can get away with $1.70 each for most standard items.  I haven't even seen this type of low pricing in L.A!  When you can run the train on pork siu mai (two of them, they're my fav), shrimp dumplings, egg rolls, shark fin dumping, turnip cake, steamed pork dumplings, BBQ pork buns, and porridge (seriously, $2?) for $16, you just shut up, pay, and walk out the door.  It's practically highway robbery for that price!  I suppose you can get away with that kind of pricing by keeping all transactions cash-only.

I suppose I should also remark on the food.  Certainly I can't claim that it's the best dim sum I've ever had in my life.  Overall though, I can't say anything underwhelmed either.  So pretty much, it doesn't suck and gets the job done!  Again, the price definitely helps.  And the porridge definitely hit the spot, especially when you need something easy for the stomach in the morning.

As expected, parking ranges from crappy to diabolical.  It's in the hub of all the Chinese food places, so it's to be expected.  Luckily my friend who dropped me off had the patience to wait for me in the line, which moved pretty fast but still took about 20 minutes on a Sunday morning.

Overall, it's cheap and gets the job done.  I just need to figure out a way to get around this horrible parking situation!
author: Alexander Y.

description: This dim sum is legit. I've had it for takeout a few times, and it tastes just as though it was served at a restaurant but without the loud, busyness of a actual dim sum restaurant. I like the lotus leave rice, and all the shu Mai and ha gaw are delicious too.
author: Arnold W.

description: Sometimes you just gotta have some dumplings and an egg custard tarts and potstickers and sesame ball things.You don't  want to commit to a fancy expensive resturante.This is the place.The truely professional  customers bring their own plastic containers for takeout orders.A few tables in back.You circle what you want on menu or point.Easy.
author: I. W.

description:
Yummmmm! Got a bunch of stuff: chive/shrimp dumplings, turnip cake, chive "dumpling," and two zong zi (1 chicken, 1 pork).

The chive/shrimp dumplings were excellent, and the chive "dumpling" was also pretty solid. Everything else was just aight for me - the zong zi, I felt, didn't have enough "stuff," but there sure was quite a bit of rice! This will be my new post-grocery spot for dumplings, for sure, tho.
author: Shendi X.

description: Best quality & bang for your buck dim sum in all of sf.  Love the ladies who work the counter.  Been coming here for 20+ years....still excellent in every way!
author: Kim W.

description: Shark fin soup on the menu? Is that even legal?! No thank you.
author: Helen P.

description: Maybe my taste buds have changed.. but the last time I was there, I was disappointed.. :(  I think I have to downgrade my review.
author: Lyra G.

description: Delicious dim sum in SF! since Lucky Fortune closed a while ago I've been coming here ever since. Havent found somewhere better for dim sum in the city yet. Its cheap and easy and fills you up
author: Gabriel L.

description:
Delicious dim sum at a great price!  Remember to bring cash! 
We were able to make our visit on our last day in SF and it was totally worth it.
Everything we ordered was great!
Would recommend the shrimp dumplings, egg tart, steamed pork buns, and shrimp & chives dumplings :)))
author: Helen K.

description:
Deem sum is good, but watch/count what they pickup as they sometimes cheat you.  

I'm chinese and they still short changed me.  

Had one order of shrimp dumpings, chicken siu mai, and sticky rice balls.  She only gave me one ball instead of 3, and charged me regular $2.20 normally for 3 rice balls.
author: Nan W.

description:
If you want delicious, affordable dim sum, this is the place to go. You order at the counter so it's not like dim sum at restaurants where people come by pushing carts and you order tea. They pack it for you in boxes but there are a couple of seats and tables if you want to eat your food while it's still warm. 

My favorite was their shrimp dumplings. Their chashu pork buns was pretty good but the bun was cold and a bit dry. The egg custard tarts were on point, with very flaky crusts! 

There was a long line on Sunday but it moved pretty quickly. I'll definitely be back!
author: Aimee Z.

description: Some of the servers have started making up their own prices and pocketing the difference. I've already been short-changed on 3 separate occasions this past month.
author: Hao H.

description:
A hole in an wall kind of joint. T wanted some food before we went on our hike in the Presidio. I was not exactly certain about the quality of Dim Sum. My favorite spot in the city remains to be that little line out of door take out only place on Stockton with an unfortunate name, but it's my spot and I can't be unfaithful. 

However, there are advantages to this place. The price is very good. Like New York Chinatown good. It's also very efficient. I ordered our food in Chinese to impress my friend, who was, as per usual, some white dude who's not originally from California.  While the quality is at best, average, it's easy to go and order something and be out of there in no time at all, and when you order in Chinese (cantonese), they tend to become ever so slightly friendlier. Bonus for me. 

I quite like the idea of having a decent Dim Sum take out en route to the Presidio. This is where you may ask yourself: how many places in America can you grab some hot dim sum items like Hagao and Shumai and go for a hike in the woods? There is something utterly unreal about this scene. On one side,  it reminds one of the orient, and on the other, a bygone war-era fort turned into a park filled with newly paved trails. 

While the food is just okay, the location is superb and the variety of dim sum on the offering is pretty impressive.

We ate at the meadow in the park, away from the parents with little children having birthday parties. When did the city get infested with parents with young children? They are popping up everywhere, I bet each one of them knows how to order dim sum at a ripe age of 3. 

I later asked a colleague what I should have gotten besides the usual, as she's a fan of that place. She said to get the custard buns. I missed that. Perhaps we'd give it another try some day.
author: Victoria E.

description:
On the way there, we realized this was not your traditional sit-down dim sum place, but after moving to SF for almost 3 months, I realized I just needed to have some. 

The place is a large counter when you walk in, with a glass case that showcases some of the sweets. There are tables and chairs in the back, I'd say around 6 tables, and can seat around 15 people. Since we live so far, I didn't want to pack everything in a to-go box and then spend another 15 minutes Ubering home while the food got cold since I knew we were ordering a ton. You sort of have to stand awkwardly to the side and just wait for people to finish up, but most diners are aware this is a fast, to-go place so each table typically clears up after 10 minutes or so.

You order at the counter, and the to-go boxes cost 20 cents a piece. We ended up having to get a to-go box because there was more food than I thought. You can choose to purchase the dimsum by piece of "by set" which typically comes with three pieces. 

The chao sao bao here is HUGE, not the typically palm-sized ones, and after eating that as our "first course" we were pretty stuff, and had also ordered 4 other small dishes. However, have to say that this place makes great tasting food. Even though it was a hole in the wall, didn't feel like the food was dirty (even though it was served on a tray with a paper towel and paper plates). Our entire meal between two people only cost $16 (and we shared a bottle of water). However, we didn't finish our food, and actually packed some up for the next day. 

If it wasn't so far, and wasn't cash only, I'd go much more often!
author: Julia Z.

description:
The constantly long line is enough to tell you how good they are. 

The pork shu mai is the best of the shu Mai's. Their steamed BBQ pork buns are awesome and their porridge is great for hangovers!
author: Mandi W.

description: I really wish there was some way I can pay for their dim sum online, have them freeze the food I bought, and ship it over to my house... I'm from Texas and came to visit my brother a couple of months ago. I visit him often and always just passed by the place. I finally came in and got some dumplings and WOW, I can't get it out of my mind now... The dumplings are HUGE and it was so cheap! I got 3 piece beef shu mai, 3 piece shrimp dumplings, and 2 piece pork bun or for 5 bucks. They were so large, I couldn't finish it in 1 sitting (maybe if I was starving, I could). I can't get this place out of my mind... I wish there was a dim sum place just like this place where I live... I'll be asking my brother soon to buy a crap load of their dumplings before he flies home to visit family. I hope he actually will.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Lucky Dim Sum is my go-to place for cheap, fresh dim sum.
