Initially, I was only familiar with BBQ pork buns, but over time I have tried some of the other items they have and have not been disappointed. With less than $20, my fiancé and I have plenty to eat! Be sure you have cash as they do not accept credit cards. Also, like others have mentioned, the customer service is not the best but don't take it personal. Be prepared to encounter a long line on weekend mornings due to its popularity. Parking can also be difficult. Seating can be hard to get and you have to be ready to snag a table as soon as you see people starting to clean up. Also note, the table area is not the most appealing to the eye or the cleanest. 

With all the downsides (parking, cash only, ugly seating area, and dry customer service) the food is still good and highly recommended! Must try!
author: Sandra M.

description: Amazing food, pretty quick line when I was there (Sunday afternoon) next time I'm in SF I will definitely be making another stop here for food!
author: Katie A.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum offers one of the best to-go dim sum in the city. Lines are long, but they move at a fair, steady rate. The food is cheap. Dirt cheap. On average, three dumplings cost you less than $2, and you can get full from eating six (at least I do). Most items are loaded with carbs and protein, so you'll be satisfied quickly, but sluggish within a few hours because everything's so greasy.

My two particular favorites here are the fun kor and the sticky rice ball. Fun kor is a steamed, semi-circular pillow-shaped dumpling that's filled with ground meat. Their version has a nice, flavorful filling; however, there's not a lot of this yummy filling because the dumplings are so flat. And the skin is so thick, too. The sticky rice ball is huge (about the size of a tennis ball), and it's very substantial. The sweet glutinous rice is chewy and sticky. There's small pieces of pork and green onion dispersed throughout. The outermost sheet layer is meant to hold the ball together when steamed, and although it's edible, it's very dry.

Being able to speak Cantonese is beneficial, but not necessary. Though you're guaranteed quicker, better service if you do speak it. Good Luck.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Impeccable handcraft merged with fast food speed. The downside is the lack of seats for eating inside on a rainy day. 

The menu has three categories of dim sum, buns, dumplings, and specialties. Their chive buns have a thick, soft, mochi like skin, while the filling carouse the mouth with  juice and freshness. 

The place is unique, will go inspite of the long line.
author: Bai H.

description:
Ate here for a late lunch and was very impressed! 
FOOD: amazingly tasty and original, all the flavor was there as expected, even more impressed on the freshness of the food
ATMOSPHERE: for the price of the food and the location it is Good, better food than what you pay for! It's great to tour San Fran and on a stop and go placekick up food for a great low price and a quality taste
PRICE: OMG so helpful to the wallet! I ate with one other and together our meal with two sodas and stuffed bellies was $15 
That's $15 for a multi serving meal, lots of options and very good! Try it out if you love oriental food
author: Savannah S.

description:
Love this place, but as you can see from the reviews, it's kind of unusual. This is mostly a take-out place. Yes, there are a few tables, but it's very spartan, to put it mildly. The food is really good, and very cheap. I love the siu mai and the shrimp dumplings. Egg rolls are good, too, if a little heavy.

The ordering process is, well, rather strict, but not difficult.

Grab a pink menu, circle what you'd like, bring cash, and you'll have no problem. Note that 1 order of shrimp dumplings is 3 pieces, and is ordered as "1." (not three). Bring a hearty appetite.
author: G C.

description: This place is legit... hole in the wall did sum spot, with traditional, Chinese ladies pressuring you to place your order while an old Chinese guy is walking up and down the restaurant refilling dim sum and saying "beep beep!" As he passes the crowded line. You gotta love it. This place is cash only and has really great dim sum for cheap. Standard fare dim sum (shrimp dumplings, pot stickers, etc. are 3 for $2.40). If you like porridge, they have delicious porridge! So flavorful and only $2.80 for one order. Come early or be prepared to wait.
author: Anna V.

description: Best dim sum we've been to so far. Food is really tasty! Favorites are the shrimp sui mai, potstickers, chicken and sausage rice, and the mushroom chow mein. Good prices for the amount of food we got! Around $30 to feed a family of 4 and we had leftovers! Fast service as well. 10/10 would come again.
author: Sheila S.

description:
You want your toilet to hate you? 

EAT HERE. 

Good luck.
author: Janice C.

description:
Was in the area and knew there were a lot of dim sum places on Clement St.  But which one to try?  Yelp reviews for Good Luck sent me on my way.

Looked over their board and the dim sum and was pleasantly surprised most were $1.99 for 3!  The dim looked good, so ordered some sui mai, shark's fin dumplings and chicken buns.  3 of each for a grand total of a little over 6 bucks.  Score!

Sui mai was pretty good.  Not the best ever, but good.  The shark fin were so-so.  The chicken bun were a total score.  3 buns for $2!  The buns were soft, the filling tasty.

I'm always on the lookout for good, cheap take-out dim sum.  Thanks to Good luck, I found I good one on Clement.
author: Steve G.

description: Very good price for very good food.  For those people complaining about service what the hell do you expect?  It is a one $ sign Chinese restaurant.  You are giving up service for a lower price.  Would you really want them to improve customer service and increase the price ?   Just order your shit and go!!!!
author: Victor S.

description:
This is my go to dim sum location on Clement! I'm lucky I live close by so I can avoid all the lines but if you're trying to come  on a weekend morning, be prepared to wait almost an hour. 

Tips: cash only, closed Tuesdays, long lines sat/sun mornings from 7:30 through lunch. Best time to go on weekdays or right after lunch (1:30pm Sunday no wait), be ready with your order (they have pink paper menus with Chinese and English and pens to circle your order with if you choose. These are located on the top left of the glass bakery display)

Get: all the shrimp dumplings you can, chicken and sausage in sticky rice wrapped in banana leaf
author: Julian Y.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is a small, take-out dim sum joint in San Francisco's "new" Chinatown.  Specifically, it's located on Clement St. between 8th and 9th Aves.  Together with Wing Lee Bakery a couple blocks east, they have all your "fast food" dim sum needs covered -- good, cheap dim sum.

This is not a sit-down restaurant with carts.  Instead, you stand in line to order and your dim sum is served to you in a bag, to-go.  There are a handful of tables inside if you want to sit down and eat.  Most of the dim sum is prepared in the kitchen in the back, then wheeled out front to the ordering counter, where the food sits behind the storefront window and interior glass displays.

There's almost always a line to order.  It's first-come, first-served.  You should get your order right the first time because if you want anything else (e.g. an additional pork bun or drinks), you'll have to start back at the end of the line.  I echo other folks' sentiments about the ladies who work here.  They get impatient if you don't know what you want, so it's best to have your order ready when it's your turn.

You can get any of the following 3 dim sum items for $1.70:

- Fried sesame ball
- Deep fried stuffed dumpling
- Egg roll
- Deep-fried taro root
- Flower roll
- Crisp white sugar cake
- Shrimp dumpling
- Pork siu mai
- Beef siu mai
- Shark fin dumpling
- Pot sticker
- Crystal dumpling
- Shrimp taro dumpling
- Fun kor (shout-out to the Teochew dumpling!)
- Turnip cake
- Chicken siu mai
- Chive dumpling w/ shrimp
- Steamed pork dumpling
- Malay cake
- Steamed BBQ pork bun
- Vegetable pork bun
- Chicken bun

Egg custard, rice puffs with coconut and peanuts, lotus seed buns, sausage rolls, egg yolk buns, sweet rice buns, chive dumplings, and lucky balls are available for $0.70 each.  Baked BBQ pork buns ($0.90), Chinese long donuts or krullers ($2.00), rice porridge or congee ($2.00), chicken and sausage rice ($2.70), chicken feet ($4.00/lb), and other common dim sum items are also available.

Unfortunately, no cheong fun (rice noodle rolls) here.  Maybe they're too messy for the "to-go" format of this place.

Since this restaurant is busy, the foods turn over fast and most of the dim sum is fresh.  The portion sizes are quite generous and they keep a good stock of all the items.  I recommend just about everything.  My favorites include the fried sesame balls, deep-fried taro, pork siu mai, steamed BBQ pork buns, baked BBQ pork buns, egg custard, and chicken and sausage rice.

You can consider this stuff authentic Chinese fast food.  Some of the dim sum, particularly the fried items, can be a bit greasy.  One BBQ bun (steamed or baked) or the chicken and sausage rice could easily suffice for a large snack or even a lunch.

Good Luck Dim Sum is only open in the mornings and afternoons.  They close at 6:30pm everyday and are closed all day on Tuesdays.  Bring cash because credit cards aren't accepted.
author: Daniel B.

description: The food here is delish! I have been coming to this location since 1994. Ya that long! They are fast and have fantastic prices. The only challenge is the parking. But once you get your parking down you are good to go. They are always closed on Tuesdays so do not forget that. The customer service is not always super friendly but they keep that line moving and the food is so yummy! There is such a wide variety and the quality is very good. I suggest getting a little of everything and trying a bite. It is best to go with a group and share. We usually get enough for 6 or 7 people and only spend around $20 and share. Totally worth it. And when it comes to DimSum, Clement beats China Town...just saying :-)
author: Orleana P.

description: Get dim sum to go quickly in the morning at this place. The sui mai is small and the taste is average. We came for the rice porridge and the fried donut/bread you eat with it. The har gow and the deep fried taro is good. They only take cash as payment.
author: Mike W.

description: Didn't live up to its billing. Steamed bao were cold, dumplings bland, and they wanted to charge us 20¢ for a takeout container.
author: Leigh G.

description: Decent dim sum. Decent prices. Fast service. Can't ask for more! It's much cleaner than other similar dim sum places. I definitely recommend this place and will come back.
author: Melissa C.

description: Have been coming here for well over 5 years, and never got around to doing a review until now.  Decided to pass through Inner Richmond on Clement to get to my hair salon.  A car was pulling out directly in front.  So I believe I was destined to have lunch here.today.  There are times when I am not as lucky to score a parking spot as readily as I did. This is my favorite go to spot for good take out Dim Sum when you are in the Inner Richmond district.
author: Robin A.

description:
Holy dim sum! Came here for Saturday brunch before a nice long hike at Muir Woods and it totally hit the spot. It's a hole in the wall, cash only, no frills kinda place mainly for to-go orders but there are a few tables in the back for eating.

My two friends and I ordered enough dim sum to feed an army. They are MASSIVE. We annihilated almost everything within minutes. Everything was tasty: shrimp with chive, shrimp, pork siu mai, and the steamed BBQ pork buns. The fried dumpling/potstickers were good but the steamed ones were way better. For what we paid, it was an extremely satisfying meal. Basically after eating here every other dim sum place is just gonna pale in comparison. Sadness.
author: Nivedita B.

description: If you like cheap, low quality, and probably MSG ridden food, this is for you. The shrimp dumpling and shu mai were bearable and the porridge was pretty good. Other than that, everything else I questioned  ingesting. At the end, we all got massive headaches (and sadly I didn't even drink the night before.) It was more of a fun experience getting dim sum than really eating it for the food. So there ya have it!
author: Connie W.

description:
This place is great for on the go Dim sum 
When I'm on clement I always have to stop at this place in my opinion best dim sum in SF thank you and GOOD LUCK!!!
author: Christopher M.

description:
Bottom Line - Meh. The overall star rating is deceiving. The quality was not worthy of 3 stars for sure! All of the steamed items we got were barely warm and mostly cold. 

If you want cheap food and care nothing of quality, then this place may be for you. I, however, will not be returning.
author: Rick S.

description: Amazing dim sum for the price! I am a big shumai and shrimp dumpling fan, and love that I can get 3 dumplings for $2.25. We went on an off-time (around 2) and it was busy but not crazy. There is super limited seating, but if you scope it out, you could get lucky. Definitely a good bang for your buck.
author: Natalia A.

description:
Just Cheap cheap cheap and quick quick quick.
Shrimp dumplings and pork siu mai are my favorites
author: Hyeseon S.

description:
Food:
-Perfect shrimp dumplings
-Shrimp crepe was mostly just a gifreakinormous rice noodle roll but it was only $0.9 per gifreakinormous piece so whatever
-Awesome sweet soy cracksauce on tables

Service:
-Good considering how cheap/asian-run/hole-in-the-wall this place is and nobody yelled at me in loud chinese for holding up the line being indecisive among all the cheap things I wanted bury in my tummy
author: Tian Q.

description: Must go here if in the area! Best dim sum in San Francisco, just be ready to take your food else where as there is very often not a place to sit!
author: A H.

description:
Price:
$2 for 3 large pieces of dumplings

This is possibly one of the best deals in the entire city of San Francisco. Short on cash but still want a delicious meal? Well Good Luck Dim Sum may be the answer to your prayers. Normally when I think of dim sum, I think of sitting at a table while people roll around carts for you to grab food off of. At least this is what I imagined it would be like when I brought my aunt and uncle here for lunch.Their set up is different though. Hop into the line, grab one of the menu sheets sitting on the counter, and mark what you want. When it's your turn, one of the ladies behind the counter will fill up a box with your order. There are a few tables in the restaurant if you want to crack open the box and eat in store, but they're pretty limited. Most people take their order to go. This is definitely a no frills kind of place, but the amazing food and the incredible value more than make up for it. Everything we got was delicious. The dumplings are also of a fairly substantial size. We managed to feed 4 people for less than $20! (I think I should add the disclaimer that my aunt and uncle are from France and their concept of portion size is much smaller than the American one.) This would be an incredible deal anywhere, but in San Francisco, it's unheard of. Delicious food at an incredible price. It doesn't get any better than that. The food is also made fresh in store and doesn't sit out for very long due to how popular this place is. I will most definitely be back here in the future. Of the things I tried, my two favorite were the Shrimp Dumplings and the Pork Siu Mai.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Consistent quality dim sum for a low price. We bought 6 of almost everything they had and it all tasted great. 3 for $2.25 for most items. Or $1 a piece for egg custard or BBQ pork buns. We knew it was good when an Asian lady with broken English told us she came from Santa Clara for their dim sum and this had the best in San Francisco. We took ours to go as seating was limited. I would suggest taking food with you, but not for dining in.
author: Tara W.

description:
Super mediocre dim sum in a dirty environment with rude counter help. Awesome! Just the way I like it-yeah right.
  This place always has a line and always lets me down. The dim sum is sub par at best and usually at least one or two items are served cold or Luke warm at best. The one thing it has going for it is it's cheap. Just imagine how awful the quality of the ingredients are for it to be this cheap. 
 I'd stay away from this place, and seek better dim sum elsewhere. Yuck.
author: schmoo l.

description:
Tldr: Yum yum dim sum. Good value, speedy dim sum classics to go.

This is an amazing hole in the wall dim sum place. Most of the dim sum classics are 3 pieces for $2. Other pastry type items are $.90 each. 

Line looks intimidatingly long but it moves really quickly.
Quick tip: grab a pink menu and fill out your order for maximum efficiency. Or just to know what the selection is while waiting.

The food:
*Beef Siu Mai: I usually get shrimp but was curious about beef. A bit disappointing...maybe I'm just not used to the beef flavor. It tasted a little soupy which was interesting.
*Pork Siu Mai: Really yummy, flavorful, meaty, and solid siu mai here. 
*Shrimp Dumpling (har gow): The skin was a just a tad thicker than I would have liked but it was still yummy and they definitely don't skimp on the shrimp! I think I liked it better than the siu mai.
*Chive Dumplings: These are green looking dumplings that look like they have spinach fillings. But no...it's chives. And I think they were my favorite of the bunch. Good mix of chives and shrimp.
*Fried Taro Root: I was most looking forward to this one. Had it a few years ago and this place is the reason taro root has become a dim sum staple for me. Had to wait ten minutes for it come out and was a little disappointed. The flavor was good but the skin was crispy and fluffy like I remembered. The ratio of taro:savory filling was also a tad high.
author: Christine Q.

description:
The best place to get dim sum for cheap!! Expect a wait during the weekends but it moves fairly quickly. The ladies working there are very efficient!

My go tos are:
Shrimp Dumpling
Pork Siu Mai
Shrimp and Chives Dumpling
Potsticker

Pretty basic, I know, but it's good for a reason and 3 pieces for $2 is a steal! There's not much seating inside so it's best to take it to go- good thing I live close by! :-)
author: Karmen T.

description: One of the best spot to get dim sum to go! The lines can get fairly long but the wait is worth it. Every time I come to the Richmond I will need to get some shrimp dumpling to go.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Cheap good dim sum. Enough said.

Our favs: 

Chichen Siu mai
Ha gaw
Rice balls

Lines are long on the weekends. Street parking only. Tables fill up fast. Bring cash.
author: Teresa S.

description: Sooooooo goood!!! I'm literally smiling like a gitty school girl as I eat this dim sum. Totally worth it!! Got har gow, shui mai, and egg tart. I wish I had a bigger stomach!!!!
author: Susanna L.

description:
Im a little torn on. 3 or 4 stars but ultimately went with 4. You cant beat the prices here. Some of the food that is traditionally served hot is lukewarm from sitting out. I like the hot foods though. Delicious, and pretty darn oily.

The line gets long, but also disappears quickly, but gets long again in spurts. 

I love the turnip cake, but it's just so stale when I get it. I wish this was kept heated/steamed, but I don't know if that's feasible or not. 

They have a good variety of foods. This time, my friend and I ordered 2 beef shao mai, veggie pork bun, one spring roll, deep fried taro ball, and a fried pork ball thing. 

Pros:
- Price
- Good hot foods
- the turnip cake is actually pretty good but just needs to be heated...

Cons:
- Some foods are lukewarm
- Bathroom is filthy
- Fairly oily...

Definitely will be back, and I definitely recommend it!
author: Kaje Y.

description:
The woman behind the counter told a person I was with to show their menu -- not knowing it was still needed, and as it was being unfolded in a fluster, it was brutally ripped from their hands by the Dim Sum Nazi.

Some of the other reviews were right, the service is downright rude. I saw other patrons treated in a similar manner. In this case the flow of Dim Sum had been disrupted.

The food however, makes it all worth it. Good and cheap Dim Sum, without the formality of rolling carts, you just order and take out or sit at the tables in the back.

The Dim Sum was mostly good quality, and the prices were a bargain. I'll be back.
author: M D.

description:
Finding parking?

GOOD LUCK.

Finding a table?

GOOD LUCK.

Avoiding a line?

GOOD LUCK.

Finding another dim sum spot where you can get ALL THIS for $11?

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco#6WHI9zh9pP5VNsMR12e00Q

GOOD LUCK.
author: Amy C.

description: If you want quick, cheap, good dim sum, this is the place. It's nothing fancy but will satisfy your dim sum cravings and keep your wallet happy.
author: Khanh N.

description: Excellent dim sum. Efficient, cheap, and tasty. I liked the pork shu mai and shrimp dumpling the best. Egg tart was great as well.
author: Michael S.

description:
Awesome, Fast, Delicious Dim Sum!!

Tip: On a busy day, I would bring my own pen to give yourself enough time to fill out the order form instead of waiting for someone to be done using one. Bring $20 cash for two people. Unless you speak Mandarin/Cantonese, refrain from asking complicated questions. I would circle your choice on the form and include the quantity of your order within that circle.
author: irwin v.

description: The owners do it  (with bad ingredients and unrefined techniques) because they want to save on cost; customers come here because it's dirt  cheap and they don't know any better. One should try this very efficient production chain for the experience, but it's the most disgusting dim sum you could probably have in America.
author: Lam N.

description:
The shumai,....
The turnip cake,....
Ugh...
SOOOO
GOOOOOOOOOOOOOD!!!!
I live in socal, and from time to time i could daydream about it.
Good price too, but the place is small.
I like it better than most dimsum places in socal.

Again,
So
Good.
author: Wesley K.

description:
Such great dim sum! I'm super impressed. 

I had bookmarked this place after telling my boyfriend how much I was craving dim sum. We don't ever get it to be honest, so I hesitated but he was down to get some for breakfast. Thank God. 

Upon arrival, you'll first notice how small the cafe is. The counter to your left houses the delicious dim sum and pastries they also offer. The line actually weaves towards the back where the tables are so prepare yourself for some slight crowding. The line itself does not take very long and even then, most people try to reserve one of the eight tables provided so they can eat right away. Cleanliness-wise, I'd say this place could use a good scrub down. It just looks like your typical Chinese bakery so that didn't bother me too much. 

As you near towards the head of the line, you'll see the menu up behind the ladies working the counter because they use a red board with white letters. Some of the menus will show how many pieces are sold and how much they go for, while others will provide individual costs per piece depending on the size I'm assuming. The women behind the counter are pretty straight forward, I did feel a little rushed because I didn't know what I wanted exactly. Good thing I checked this page and the reviews though because I was satisfied with my order. My boyfriend got us the shrimp shu mai, pork shu mai, and potstickers. One order for three pieces? Yes please! I myself ordered the egg yolk bun, a steamed bbq pork bun, and a little custard tart. 

This place is bomb digs and I highly recommend to anyone in the area looking for cheap, yet delicious, pick-up food.
author: Tricia M.

description:
Super cheap. (3 for 1.70) Super delicious. Super fast. Just circle what you want with how many of each and hand it to the lady at the front. 

Get the har gow and the sesame balls. Their sesame balls have the perfect crisp when you bite into it. My mouth's watering just thinking about it. 

More for take out than sit in, although they have a few tables inside available. 

Don't forget to ask for soy sauce/eating utensils if you're going somewhere without them.
author: Jane K.

description:
Shrimp Dumplings: $1.60/order. Tasty, good size, wrapper not too thick and overall isn't too greasy. 

Service here was friendly and included a smile. There are also crystal dumplings on the menu. I asked the lady who helped me what those were and she said pork, shrimp and cilantro dumplings. I gotta try those next time!
author: Maya S.

description:
I've been dying to eat dumplings and pork buns today so I made my hubby drive out to clement street for some take-out dim sum. Our usual place closed down apparently so I walked up the street and chose good lucks. 
It was really tasty. I ordered pork/chicken steamed buns and a few other goodies. Pricing is very reasonable. Service is decent-straight to the point.
The place could be a bit cleaner, but thankfully I didn't sit in to eat. I enjoyed it in my car :-) 
Will come back for sure when I crave dim sum again.
author: T A.

description: Whenever i get into the city I try to find my way here.  Son and I at sfsu for wrestling clinic so drove the 4 miles for some goodies. Well a lot of goodies.  So fresh and tasty.  I got enough for some for today as well.  Shrimp dumplings and same with chives are yum yum.  Pork buns and pot stickers are exceptionally good.
author: David K.

description:
Made a special trip to Good Luck Dim Sum on a Sunday early afternoon, and was pleasantly surprised that it completely met expectations.  My friend and I each ordered about $10 worth - I got a couple hargow, siumai, shark fin dumplings, char siu baos, and a few other assorted things.  Service could be a bit friendlier, but honestly what can you expect from a dim sum place.  They didn't pack in any sauces either, which was partially my fault.   

What you get is a  large amount of food at a great value.  Not quite as good as a sit down place, but one of the better takeout places I've tried in the area.
author: Ben K.

description: It's like walking into a donut shop. There are pink boxes lining the walls and a glass display filled with loads of goodness. You pay extra for the boxes (~20 cents). The food is all right in front of you in huge steam trays. My least favorite thing to eat is shrimp hargow and that turned out to be the most delicious item there. The wrapper is soft and not at all chewy. They have soy sauce in the tables that is sticky and not overly salty. It made the meal really delicious.
author: Christine L.

description: My brother in law introduced me to this place..and yummy yummy yum....this is a must try.  Get there early cause there is a line and for faster service there is a menu at the end of the counter and u just circle what u want and had it to the lady when ur turn is up.  Not too many seats to eat in but great for to go...so if u want some yum go grab some dim sum...lol
author: Mary B.

description: Was empty when i got here on a rainy Sunday. So I was skeptical at first but the quality speaks for itself. You see locals popping in and out getting small orders of potstickers. everything I tried was really good: potstickers with shrimp and chives, har gow and lotus leaves sticky rice right to the sweet rice cake. The prices are incredible. Will definitely be back for the egg yolk bun.
author: Kumar N.

description:
I've been here hundreds of times.  I will be back whenever I can.
My order was huge, a party awaited me in Oakland -- but I prefer to bring this Dim Sum from the City rather than the hit-or-miss experiences that I've had in Oakland.
Not five stars? No, the wait can be horrible and the parking Gestapo are constantly looking at the meters, awaiting one to expire!
And the people filling your order can often be in sour moods.  Finding a table can be tough.
Not zero stars? No, the food is worth the aggravation!
author: Henry M.

description: Hole in the wall non descript dim sum place - but reasonable prices and solid food. I drive out from the Ingleside on Sunday mornings to get the fresh stuff to go. Handy paper order form in case you don't want to point at items you can't pronounce.
author: Adrian Z.

description:
Was referred here by a friend who lives in the Richmond. Heads up its more of a takeout place than sit down. There are about 6 tables that seat 4, but the line forms inside the restaurant so seating isn't really optimal. 

Price: For $9.60, it's a steal for the amount of food you get. At a normal dim sum what ordered would be easily 2x. 

Quality: The shrimp shumai I got were not very good, but everything else was. I especially liked the shrimp and pork dumplings. The egg rolls were crispy but cold. 

Service: Super fast as other people have indicated. I probably should have read other reviews, but you're supposed to fill out a form to pass the ladies at the counter your order. Didn't know that.
author: Chris H.

description: Quality seems to be much much better than roughly a year ago. Yes still same attitude ( which is cool as it is very efficient). But the dim sum is pretty stellar.
author: David G.

description: Quality of dim sum definitely goes down on thanksgiving day , I also saw a chicken feet drop on the window and the lady just picked it up and threw it with the rest .. Absolutely disgusting..don't expect help with the orders either .. They will treat you rudely without patience if you do not know how to order your dim sum.
author: Jimmy D.

description: I've been coming here since high school in the 80's. I love the steamed pork buns and the pot stickers. I've never eaten inside just take out. Just pick what you want and pay. The ladies are almost to quick. Sometimes the line is long but it's worth it. Now, I stop by on my way home to Sacramento. Order 2 dozen pork bums bring them home and freeze them. My wife loves them too! Can't find anything like it in Sacramento! I'm amazed they are still open but hope they stay open for years!
author: Paul Y.

description: I have been coming here for many years. I have tried everything on the menu since I have been here many times. I like the pot stickers they are my favorite item as well as the shrimp dumplings. The prices are inexpensive for a order of 3 of an item it's only $1.50! You get a lot for your money for 2 boxes of dim sum it's like $25. The line can be long at times, but worth the wait.
author: Alix J.

description:
4.5** Could have been a perfect if it had better customer service :P

No, this isn't your typical dim sum restaurant where servers are pushing carts full of dim sum goodness. This is your fast food style dim sum place where you wait in line and you choose which dish you want. Good Luck Dim Sum has all the characteristics of a good chinese restaurant - It's located in an isolated part of the city where the only surrounding businesses are other chinese/asian local businesses, and the customer service is NONEXISTENT, and let me tell you why...

So each table has a bottle of garlic chili sauce and a soy sauce...well my table was missing the soy sauce and I couldn't find any available soy sauce around. I approached one of the workers and asked for a soy sauce in which she replied, "there's one on your table"...I persistently told her that we did not have one so she gave up and decided to check for herself. When she realized she was wrong, she got frustrated and decided to steal the soy sauce from another table that was using it..you can always count on truly asian business to have poor customer service. 

Anyways.. on to the food..it was DELICIOUS and the best part was that it was CHEAP. It's always a nice surprise when you pay little for your food and you get something delicious out of it. Not much variety, but great place to shed little money for awesome dim sum appetizers/dishes! so who cares if the customer service sucks, as long as you pay little for great food, it's worth it :D
author: Annie N.

description: 3 for $2.40 (egg buns $1.10) and the line moves fast! Took less than 20 min on a Sunday afternoon to get my goodies and the fun kor was to die for!
author: Christen D.

description: Very consistent with flavor and variety available. Items move out so quickly that one gets to see the steam carts roll up to the front with a fresh batch to put out.
author: Dee Q.

description:
On the one hand, you get practically zero customer service. There isn't much seating, practically no parking no matter what time go you, the menu is subject to what was made (not always the menu above), and there's always a line. Oh yeah, CASH ONLY.

On the other hand, you are saving a ton of money from other dim sum places because of the bad points above. Good Luck does not skimp on ingredients and it shows. The fresh bao is loaded with meat. The steamed dishes are cooked just right.

Forgive them for the early 1980s menu display and what can feel like rudeness at the cashier register. Join the line and order everything to-go.
author: Christine L.

description:
Very popular Chinese Dim Sum Take Out place here in San Francisco.

Mom loves this place and thinks this is a must go place when making a trip down to San Francisco. She, like most other Yelpers have said, love the dim sum here.

To avoid the long lines, call ahead and place your order.

Give this place a try!
author: Mystery M.

description:
Very efficient system these ladies got going!

There was a bit of a wait around 2pm I believe. Can't exactly recall when we're there. I recommend to bring cash because I'm pretty sure they're cash only. But not 100% sure. Even though there was a wait it went super fast because of the system they have.

You pick a pink slip from the tray and circle what you want. Makes it very easy to translate your order without having to just point (cause that would be me haha).

We got a ton of dim sum for 16 bucks and I highly recommend you over order what you think will be enough haha. We did exactly that and I almost wanted to re-write my order but I'm so glad I didn't. It was enough and then some. We had some happy tummies for our late lunch and our ride home (we live out of town).

They're sauce selection is very minimal, like 2 sauces, spicy red paste and a black vinegary sauce. I don't know if they have soy sauce packets but if you ask for some condiment cups you can squeeze in some of what they have on their tables.

Will be visiting again this weekend and I can't wait. I recommend you check the place out.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
No bullshit. Just cheap good solid dim sum. 
Come here every other week to grab a quick lunch.
All the dim sum options are good and all, but my personal favorite is the Chicken and Sausage Rice. Comes out of a huge stainless steel bowl hiding under the counter somewhere. Get that and a couple dim sum pieces and it'll fill you right up. 

Gets pretty crowded on weekends, so be prepared.
author: Nop J.

description:
I've been a cat living in the area for a while now, but I've always gotten my dim sum fix at some other places around, and for whatever reason never stepped paw into good luck. Today I decided to break off my usual routine and give them a shot. 

Good luck is tiny, and seems to specialize in only a few things unlike the surrounding places that have a massive menu of things. I always notice that there are quite a few people here so I figured that there must be something drawing them in. 

I got some shu Mai and potstickers which is usually what I get elsewhere. 

Service here is very friendly and quick, and I was in and out quickly. 

Upon trying my selections, I can honestly say that there is a clear difference. The taste and texture is much softer and everything taste much fresher. Price wise was also very affordable and a definite bargain. 

I may break from my usual place more often! Highly recommended! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
Not a bad place, some food items weren't as nice as other places, but I'd definitely return here for the ones that were good.

Turnip Cake, Ha Gow, Custard Tart and Coconut Mochi with Peanut inside, was yummy.

The bbq porkbun (Cha Siu Bao, chicken siu mai were not to my taste buds - they weren't bad, just I've had different and better in my opinion.
author: Y B.

description: This my favorite casual dim sum spot in SF! I've been coming here for over 10 years and it never disappoints. The dim sum is made fresh throughout the day and is super reasonably priced. The floor is a bit slippery and the bathrooms could be cleaner, but I'm not taking away any starts because the food and value is that good.
author: Jon P.

description: I've tried three dim sum joints on Clement and this one beats out the rest, merely because it's ten cents cheaper per order and workers have slightly better customer service which really isn't saying much.  Better know what you want before you get to the front, or you get the dim sum dumpling nazi treatment.  I prefer the Shark fin dumplings and pork suimai.  For three dumplings for $2, I doubt the shark fin dumplings have any shark fin in them.
author: Bailey N.

description:
In concept, this place is excellent. Fast dim sum to satisfy your growling tummys. But in execution, this place lacks space, cleanliness, and cooking. 

There are very few tables in the little hole in the wall and the fortunate ones who get seats take their sweet ass time eating their 3 shrimp dumplings. 

I'm also not too sure how clean this place is because you don't see anybody swinging by picking up trash or cleaning the tables. 

Lastly and most importantly, the food is insanely greasy. Even the foods that we ordered steamed came with a lot of oil. I couldn't even finish what I ordered because I felt so disgusted by the oils by the end. 

But for the efficiency and the price, I guess I can suck it up.
author: April Z.

description:
This is def the cheapest dim sum i have had, but still tasted better than i thought it would. IMO i dont think it taste better than restaurant quality dim sum, but its cheap and fast. Their is usually a long line and takes about 15 min wait from the back of the line. The taste is fairly generic in the same way frozen pre made dim sum are cooked when needed. 

This is a great place if you want a quick snack of har gow or shui mai for cheap, but does not compare to tai wu or even koi palace in Daly city.
author: Ryan R.

description: legit when you don't want to wait 2 hours and spend 50 bucks for two people at  Hong Kong lounge 1-2.  Ordered 10 things for 20 bucks, 10 things with 3 pieces per thing = 30 pieces of dim sum = THATS A GOOD DEAL..
author: Vince L.

description:
Holy crap - this is some gooooooooooooooooooood dim sum!! We ended up here after doing some major research for our trip to the bay. It was between this place & Good Mong Kok. We chose GLDS. So glad we did. We attempted to get here when they opened but that didn't work. It didn't even matter. We arrived around 130-ish and they had plenty of fresh dim sum. I had beef and pork sui mai, pork sui bao, shrimp har gow, shrimp & taro root har gow, and chicken feet. DEEEELISH!!! The prices are super cheap and the service is quick and good. 

My only regret is that I didn't buy more for when I went back to the hotel. Late nite dim sum would've been dope. That said, still doesn't negate how awesome this place is - authentic for sure. Can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Not a bad take out dim sum place. Ordered the Chinese tamale, turnip cakes, shrimp dumpling and pork and beef dumplings. Simple and tasty. It's not the best and you can't compare it to restaurant quality.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Really solid bakery dim sum. Great pork buns, good potstickers, very good shrimp dumplings with plenty of shrimp and it is super cheap. They let you purchase one piece of an item if you like. ( just one pork bun or shrimp dumpling, etc ) which gives you flexibility to try numerous things. 

Lunchtime can be a hassle, so it might be wise to go at an off hour if you don't want to stand in line.
author: Neal C.

description: Delicious dim sum and cheap! CASH ONLY so come prepared. There are some tables toward the back of the store so you can dine in if you wish, or you can get your food to go! The ladies here are helpful but not overly friendly so don't expect the greatest customer service, but they help you quickly so you can be on your way as soon as possible!
author: Karly T.

description: Living near Clement st. For about 3 months now and went to this restaurant today because of the yelp reviews and now I see why. Baked pork buns, BOMB, steamed pork buns, also very good. And cheap! Cash only
author: Maggie C.

description: Not sure what people expect,  but what it lacks in charm it makes up for in taste.   The sticky rice is delicious, shumai wonderful as were the steamed buns .  If you're there for the food at a great price then go.   If you're looking for atmosphere, you may want to pass.
author: Rachelle R.

description:
The cost/benefit at Good Luck Dim Sum is great. It is super cheap, the portions are big and they have a good variety. 
We tried a several items.
My favorite was the shrimp and taro dumplings.
I also really enjoyed the fried taro, the pork dumplings and the pork buns,
They were out of the crystal dumplings, so next time we'll have to try that.
It's not life changing, but for a quick bite if you are in the area, it's ideal.
author: Luciana B.

description: Excellent in taste, very fresh & quick service. Down side is ladies are not very friendly, doesnt speak well english & are not very accomodating in terms of how you want your orders stacked to go...bathrooms was not well serviced either
author: Junnel C.

description:
Came here 2nd time to buy take-out dim sum when visiting nearby in SF.
Food is cheap and so delicious.
Downside is that the line is SOOOOO long all the time.
It was about a 40-min wait to get to the front of the line, and maybe even longer for others by that time (during 11am-12pm hour).
The nice thing is that while waiting I could see the cooks bringing many trays of fresh dim sum out from the back kitchen, and lots of time to study the paper menu, compare with the items in the counter, and mark your choices.
Always looking forward to visiting this place when in SF!
Just need to plan to spend some time in line.   Also - bring cash, no credit cards here.
author: Riya S.

description:
I absolutely LOVE to go dim sum places. So much faster and cheaper than traditional sit down dim sum. 

I normally don't come here often but some occasions I do come here with my mom. My mom is the one that usually comes here to buy dim sum for us to eat at home. I don't think I can ever get sick of dim sum. Just so good.

My mom gets almost everything. She has four kids so are usually multiple orders of everything. We like the siu mai and the hai gow. So freaking good and fresh. 

Parking can be hard. If my mom is with my dad, what they usually do is park at Smart and Final--my dad goes to smart and final to buy whatever they need and my mom goes to buy dim sum. :)
author: Tommy L.

description:
Nothing glamorous about this place besides the food, which btw is dirt cheap, fresh and delicious!

I was able to get an assortment of food (at least over 10 pieces) including siu mai, shrimp dumplings, pot stickers, steamed pork bun and egg tart all under $10! Such a deal and they're all made fresh throughout the day. The trays were constantly switched out from the kitchen with fresh food coming from the kitchen while I was placing my order.

There are a few tables in the back, but this is the perfect grab and go lunch spot. I felt kind of rushed by the workers since I wasn't exactly sure of what I wanted. Everyone around me seemed to be locals, one lady mentioned everything is good and she comes every day...so you know it's real haha.

 Cash only--there's a Bank of America across the street or you can do cash back at Walgreens.
author: Georgina G.

description:
Yeah. I just gave this take out dim sum place 5 stars. 

Lowest possible price point for the quality offered. Seriously. 

The baked bbq pork buns are huge and made perfectly. Seriously. They even use real honey. Seriously. Real honey. 

The steam dishes are pretty good. The shrimp is even clean. Seriously. 

I normally only get steamed dim sum but I think I'm willing to venture even further at this place. This place is open at 7 a.m. I am going to get porridge here for real and gulp it down at the gym. Then I'm going to go back and buy $10 worth of baked and steamed BBQ pork buns and $20 worth of dim sum. For real. This place is the shxt.

The ladies that help you out here only sound rude but they're really sweethearts. SERIOUSLY! She even hooked it up. What a babe.
author: Margaret S.

description:
We came back for the second time this month to get dim sum for a Presidio picnic near Crissy Fields.  Last time, I ordered 50 dollars worth and the lady forgot my sesame ball even though I paid for it.  I guess she can't count to three because each price point comes with three small dim sum items.  The same lady put a broken shrimp dumpling into my box.  Be careful if the older lady serves you.  She might stiff you on the items you pay for or give you a broken item. 

Each time the younger lady serves me, I always get the number of items that I paid for.

The shrimp dumplings are particularly good here.  I used to like the taro shrimp dumplings but they add too much salt now.

I was surprised how good the fun gor is.  It's like a giant pork soup dumpling.  It's full of porky sauce inside with bits of Chinese celery.  It's really delicious.

My husband likes their lucky balls, he says it's like a Chinese donut.  It's full of red bean paste.  We also like their fried dumplings filled with pork, it's extra crunchy here.   The chicken sticky rice inside lotus leaves aren't as good as they used to be, too salty.

Cash only.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
If you're looking for a reliable dim sum restaurant for a great price, Good Luck Dim Sum is the way to go, my Yelpers. The business is small and the communication is limited so here's what to do: on your way in, pick up the pink sheet of paper on the right side of the display counter. While standing in line, circle the items you want- the top section gives you 3 pieces for each order. For example, get the Chive Dumpling with Shrimp. If you want 6 pieces, circle the name and write "2" next to it to show you are ordering two orders of three pieces each. I would also go with the Sweet Rice Chicken Wrapped in Lotus Leaves. My Cantonese friend also told me that his litmus test for good dim sum is eating the Deep Fried Stuffed Dumpling. Good Luck Dim Sum passed. You should also order at least two orders of the "Shrimp Dumpling."
Don't upset the ladies and give them your credit card. Bring cash! If you're ordering for 3 people, you should have at least $25 on you. Good Luck Dim Sum is pretty much my go-to dim sum place and it's delicious!
author: Grace L.

description:
Legitness just got affordable with this place. 

I was shocked to find the best dim sum that east side of china town has to offer comes at a price of literally just 4 bucks per person. As usual the outside of the establishment isn't much, and  the inside dinning area is small and could use a little remodeling, but none of that matters when you try their fresh pork and shrimp dumplngs. Not only can you tell the meat used is fresh. or that the outside noodle is thick, sturdy, and full of taste but the door to the kitchen is wide open where a view of the hardworking masterminds behind these culinary delights. And you must finish whatever you have with a Sesame Ball. Out of this world is the only way I can describe this. Totally returning.
author: Travis B.

description:
Great dim sum. The shrimp dumplings are perfect. A lot of dim sum bakeries sell shrimp dumplings that have a thicker wrap and I definitely don't like that. This place has a very thin and delicate wrap which to me is how shrimp dumplings should be. Prices are as cheap as can be. 3 for $2 for most items. 

Obviously there is no atmosphere. This is a no nonsense place with great dim sum. Highly recommended.

Just as a heads up. Always ask for the hottest stuff. They used the stacked steamers and the stuff in the lower steamers are generally fresher and hotter. Cold dim sum is no good.
author: Yasi N.

description:
Well, I love a deal too, just like the next person, so I do get it that Good Luck Dim Sum is a deal. Sure.  Its middle of the road dim sum, but at bargain basement prices.  Its tasty without being spendy.  Its a fun hole in the wall dim sum spot in the Clement Street area.

This is a fun stop when shopping in the area (we love to come to the neighborhood for good produce, inexpensive fish and beautiful inexpensive japanese pottery.)

What I'm less sure I understand is the hype that surrounds the dim sum here.  Five stars for Good Luck Dim Sum?  Lines around the block?  Write ups in foodie blogs?

Loving and respecting a good deal aside, this dum sum is just above average, and while well priced, lacks the ambiance, charm and fun of dim sum dining elsewhere in the city.  Its a find in the world of grab n go or hole-in-the-wall dim sum, and even a find on Clement Street, but not something that you should circle the block for.

A great deal?  Okay. But keep expectations in line: this is dim sum on the fast food side, greasy, oily, not delicate or earth shattering.  At least that's one dim sum lovers very humble opinion.
author: Rachel H.

description: The sue mai and shrimp dumplings are amazing, cheap and plentiful. Don't expect to sit down since the place gets super crowded for the 6 tables there but hey, I didn't want to sit in a kitchen anyway. It's great worth the bus ride from soma.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Totally worth the wait!!!! 

At 8am on a Monday, there was a long line already! I was a bit skeptical and hungover but was craving dim sum so I decided to wait. The line moves pretty quickly anyhow. Food is being brought up continuously from the back so you know that it is fresh and in demand! 

Prices are super unbelievably cheap! We spent $10 and ordered:

Shrimp Har Gow
Pork Siu Mai
Sesame Ball
Sticky rice with pork and chives
Turnip Cake

Food is to go so make sure to eat it while its hot and fresh. I believe it is cash only. Everything was amazing!!! My mind was utterly blown away! I was very sad that I discovered this place on my last day in SF. I will definitely be back to get my dim sum fix!
author: Sara K.

description: Been going here off and on since 2007 since my now husband lived in the Inner richmond. Comforting, cheap unpretentious dim sum, and delicious porridge. congee/ jook. I think the prices have been the same since we started going here, and we'll still make a point to go if we're in the area even though we live in the East bay now. $10 easily feeds us both with leftovers. Have tried countless other places in Oakland Chinatown and SF, and we keep going back here.
author: Debora L.

description:
This place was great. 
The atmosphere was authentic and it felt like you were in Asia when you were ordering. You can't beat the prices either. 

I would recommend the shark fin dumpling as well as the shrimp dumpling. 

The only down side is that it is cash only. 

Over all great cheap dim sum that was super authentic and very fast. 
I can't wait to come back here
author: F G.

description:
Warning: this is just an unfinished review from started on 3/15/2012. I'm just posting it as is.

I used to live 1 block away from this place. It was the first take-out dim sum I've been to. I've just moved back to San Francisco [from New York] and it still holds up.

I went back down memory lane [Clement St.] and couldn't stop myself from coming here. I had a shark fin dumpling, a crystal dumping, an order of soup dumplings and a mini lotus cake.
author: Rahil P.

description:
Dragged R here on a morning when I was craving dim sum. The place is as I remembered it from my childhood. Steam from the food fogging up the display window, rice cakes and buns stacked against the glass case, and elderly Asian gents sitting in the back reading Chinese newspapers. 

We ordered har gow, turnip cakes, chicken feet, egg tarts, custard buns and a bowl of rice with pork and greens. The har gow was very large, with thick dough. A little different from the kind I loved in Hong Kong. To me, a good shrimp dumpling has paper thin, translucent dough - thin enough to give the shrimp filling center stage, but chewy and starchy enough to complement its meaty saltiness and hold it together. These har gow are different, but standard for SF Chinatown. The turnip cakes are a little blander than my grandpa used to make them, and not very hot - maybe could have used longer on the skillet. The custard buns are of a different variety than the traditional Canto buns. The ones I am used to have fillings made of preserved egg yolk and condensed milk. When you bite into them, they ooze a molten gold that tastes both sweet and a little salty. These had more of a sweet and crumbly texture, but were still a treat. The egg tarts were the saving grace of this place. They had a wonderful flaky crust, and deep cups filled to the brim with egg custard. And the custard itself was fantastic. Just soft enough so that it didn't fall apart when we bit into them, and with no cracks on the surface, so they didn't look overcooked.
author: Elaine T.

description:
I tried the  pan seared garlic chive with shrimp dumpling. Yum! Haw gao was good as well.  I ended up buying a bunch of fried goods and steamed goods for friends and family. I found that the steamed goods have a good texture. The rice paper does not rip apart. Its a little on the thick and chewy texture.

Their baked pork buns are pretty good. Also, its only $0.85 each. 

5 star for food. 2 stars for service. Make sure you visit on off peak hours.
author: Sandra L.

description: Quick and easy to order (via writing on paper menus), and the line moves really fast. With a no frills seating environment, it's a great spot to nurse a hangover. Bring cash and get ready to try a variety of buns and dumplings for cheap!
author: Claire S.

description:
Delicious.  Cheap. Efficient.

I visited San Fransisco for one day this past summer, and I was happy to come across good luck dim sum!

Good:
Delicious dumplings and desserts!
Great variety (I tried one of each!)
Fast food
Great price. (Ex: 3 for $2)

Bad:
Service matches the price.
Unattractive atmosphere. "Hole in the wall"
author: Josephine I.

description: If you're looking for a delicious and reasonably priced dim sum this is the place. It's not like it's a big secret, this dim sum place is a well known secret to locals. I often get my dim sum here to go. You can eat it here but it's really not a place conducive to consuming food. I hate to say it but the restaurant itself is not very clean but the dim sum are made fresh daily. My favorites are the shrimp pot sticker, Siu mai (pork, beef and chicken), the rice porridge otherwise known as congee or chok and spare ribs over rice. These are my favorites but all their dim sums are good. If you haven't been here you can't really call yourself local.
author: Bob S.

description:
Typical dim sum to go spot. They do have a few tables inside. Good shrimp dumplings and pork puns. 

Sticky rice was just okay.
author: Kayhan K.

description: Cheap, fast, and tasty. Must swing by if you don't have time to go to a dim sum house. Parking can be tough. Definitely a must in the Clement area.
author: Alicia A.

description: This is your spot if you're just looking for cheap dim sum. My only complaint would be that the noodles are a bit thick.
author: Holly M.

description:
OMG. Yelp you let me down. Came here 9:30am Monday and the food (baked items/ glass case) was cold! Refrigerator cold. Not room temperature. I ordered the staples: Har Gow (shrimp dumpling), Lo Bat Go (Turnip cake), Char Siu Bao (baked bbq pork bun), and Lai Wong Bao (egg custard bun),

Food prices are cheap but the quality is horrendous.

Shrimp dumplings were hard chewy and oily. At least the shrimp filling was decent. It was the only item served warm.

Turnip cake was refrigerator cold. It turned me off so much I had to dump it. I understand they probably serve yesterday's food but at least warm it up or tell your diners.

Baked Bbq pork bun was room temp and the filling had already congealed. The bread part of the Bun was soft and yummy but the filling wasn't appetizing. 

Egg custard bun was the worst of the bunch. Super old/stale and cold.  The white bun was so hard! And the filling was all dried out. If you ever had custard buns, you would know what to look for. Soft runny center, warm and soft bread.

So alas, comes my score, cheap yes. Good food, no. I am Asian. Half-chinese.  I am cheap sometimes but having cheap prices doesn't make the food better. 

Maybe I'll try them again when I am in the 'hood but it will be a long while.
author: Eric T.

description: Used to be the crown jewel of cheap dim sum but they have gotten complacent over recent years, got a really bad stomach ache last time I ate here
author: Jean G.

description:
This is the place to go on Clement for super cheap, quality dim sum but service deserves zero stars.

You don't typically expect much service from take-out Asian joints but the RUDENESS and MEANNESS of the ladies here take it to a whole other level.  They will glare at you and say mean things about you in Chinese if you take even one second to think about your order or ask for a napkin.  I used to keep coming here because the dim sum was pretty good but recently I've found the quality to NOT be worth the meanness from the ladies anymore. Some items come cold or broken.

Skip the lines here and go to Wing Lee across the street, lines are much shorter and ladies there are nicer
author: Wendy Z.

description:
San Francisco is so different from Los Angeles.  Dim sum in LA = waiting in line for 30-90 minutes then sit down @ Empress Harbor, Ocean Star, Elite or NBC.

Dim sum @ San Francisco = waiting in line for 10-15 minutes @ a take-out place.  I used yelp to find dim sum places and most of them were bakeries/take out places.  I found some restaurants but got frustrated and went to Good Luck Dim Sum instead.

There was a long line and it moved pretty slow.  I saw towers of pink take-out boxes @ the restaurant; 20 cents for each box.  Chicken feet were sold by the pound.  This place was super busy and the kitchen constantly brought out hot fresh dim sum goodies.

I saw the order form and got confused when I saw 3 for $1.70.  I thought it meant 3 pieces for $1.70.  I marked 2 pork shiumai, 2 har gows, 2 shark fin dumplings, 2 shrimp taro dumplings, 1 malay cake.  I also marked 2 egg custards ($0.70 each) and 1 porridge for @2.00.

Can you believe I order all these?  Good luck trying to finish all of them:
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=YYqPK8TXJmm8qV-SMKBw7A&userid=W7DHyQlY_kXls2iXt-_2Ag

It was pretty cheap for $18.00 but how was I supposed to eat all those?
I am eating my malay cake and writing this review @ the same time.

A nickel for 2 minutes street parking.

3.5 stars!!  

Good Luck Dim Sum is kinda yummylicious!!
author: Maggie C.

description: .... review is long over due ... I've been going here for over 13 years, and still .... no other dim sum place compares to here.  that is all. ;)
author: Ederlyn L.

description:
Well. It has happened. I finally found a dim sum place that I hate, in SF of all the places. If you value your health, basic resemblance of edible food, service, and time, then do not go here. We were walking round the Richmond area and wanted some dim sum. 

We got cold slimy Bbq pork buns, greasy and cold fried unrecognizable dough, literally, the stuff had a pool of oil in it, and some pot stickers. Oh it comes with a nasty side of attitude free of charge. The ladies in this joint have no intention of serving good quality food or even food that's warm. The only redeeming part was the dim sum was fairly cheap, but it was so disgusting that even a dollar for any of the items served in there is too much. It's apparent that the folks who run this place has one thing in mind, and that is to separate you from your money, in the cheapest and fastest way possible with barely passable food.

One star and not gonna return. There are plenty of other options in SF and surrounding area where you don't have to regret visiting.
author: Charles L.

description: This place is the shit. The line is long but generally moves pretty quickly and everything here is dirt cheap. While the counter service format may not seem ideal, it makes sure that everything comes nice and hot out of the steamer for you to enjoy promptly thereafter. Make sure you try the chive and shrimp dumpling.
author: Teddy E.

description:
Price to Quality ratio could not be better.

This place is super affordable and the dim sum you get is totally worth it! All the steamed dumplings were tasty, moist, and had great texture. The turnip cake was delicious, crispy on the outside, moist and tender inside, but not overcooked. The football-shaped deep fried dumplings (I never remember what they're called) were warm, crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside like how they should be...and the filling was nice and savory, they do something a lil' different and add cilantro too. 

The only thing I would recommend NOT getting are the baked pork buns.. They weren't fluffy or soft, the buns were over baked, dry and almost crunchy on the top. I was expecting a nice soft and sweet and slightly chewy bun and what I got didn't live up to expectations. 

Aside form that everything else was really great!! So if you're in the area and looking for some cheap and fast dim sum definitely stop by! :)
author: Katie 2.

description:
Best dim sum on Clement St., but the dump is filthy from stem to stern. Looks like it has never been cleaned. Sticky floors, tables and chairs. Only one condiment in a sticky bottle shared by more than one table. Typical rude Clement St. counter people. Don't expect a "Thank You" from them, even for large orders.

Note that many of the deceptive photos below were definitely taken in a clean place elsewhere. They were not taken at dirty Good Luck Dim Sum.
author: Pam J.

description:
I don't get all the 5-star reviews. Today I bought shrimp dumplings, beef shu mai, porl shu mai, and baked pork buns.

The shrimp dumplings were quite good. But the rest tasted of low-quality ingredients. When I have no desire to finish a dumpling, something is def wrong. There a number of other bakeries and dim sum places in those blocks of Clement with much better baked pork buns.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Had the steamed pork bun, which was like a large char siew bao. 

The bread was dry and not moist and soft as white, steamed buns are supposed to be. 

The pork filling was equal parts gelatin and meat shreds. 

I don't know where yall have been getting your char siew (BBQ pork) buns but this is not considered good. 

Ordered the deep fried, glutinous rice ball that's covered in sesame seeds and filled with red bean paste. The glutinous rice to red bean filling is way off and it could have been deep fried for a bit longer. Red bean filling (when I did get some in a bite) was good though. 

Really can't see what the hype on this place is about. I'm glad I only paid 2.70 for the two items and a cup of tea.
author: Grace C.

description: "Ham swe gok" is the best here according to my Chinese aunt who is local. It's a fried sweet rice dumpling with minced pork inside. I get this location confused with Wing Lee. I go to Wing Lee for the tapioca skin stuff.
author: Alias A.

description: This is my mom's go-to dim sum place for a good reason. The food here is fantastic and if you factor in the affordable cost, it gets five stars from me!
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Long line, but it moves fast. By the time we figured out what our group of 4 was going to order, we were already at the front of the line.

The dim sum isn't the best you'll ever have, but the price to quality ratio is ridiculous. Every order is $1.70! You get 3 pieces with every order. We ordered $28 worth of dim sum for four people (3 hungry boys and 1 pretty hungry girl) and we had a full box left of stuff leftover. 

The winners:
Har gow/shrimp dumplings
Chive dumplings with shrimp
Steamed pork dumpling (XLB)- they make it like a bun (lots of bread), not the dumplings, so be careful not to over order 
Turnip cake
Sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves

The losers:
Siu mai- too much "mystery meat" for my liking, meat was too soft
Sausage roll- a sausage in a dried-out roll
BBQ pork bun- filling was too gelatinous

Cheap-o tip: if you are eating there and have leftovers, and don't want to pay 20 cents for a box, just ask for a bag and put your plate right inside.
author: Alice T.

description:
Growing up, practically all the dim sum places I went to were sit down restaurants in the east bay, and takeout dim sum places were never worth going to because, in general, they are lower quality and not the same experience. As a result, I tend to be pretty skeptical of takeout dim sum places, but this place is one of the exceptions I'll make. 

I've come here a handful of times over the years. They have most of the common items you'll find in a dim sum restaurant, and everything is made to take out. They do have a dining area inside with a few tables though, and they can give you a tray to take your food over and eat there.

Generally one of the problems with takeout places is that the food sits out at the counter forever so things aren't fresh. But since this place has high demand, food gets ordered and replaced fairly regularly. Unlike other takeout dim sum I've had, this place always had food that you could tell was just freshly made.

You can order from a sheet of paper, or if you're Cantonese you can just tell them what you want. I find that they're faster if you speak to them in Cantonese because then they don't have to check against a paper to make sure they got everything.

Their porridge is pretty good here. They don't give a description in English but it's porridge with pork and preserved eggs. If you choose to dine in, all the stuff they give you is disposable so you'll get a tall container with a short plastic spoon. It's not ideal but it works.

I personally still prefer the chaotic nature of bigger dim sum restaurants with tea and carts, but this place works if you just want dim sum without all the other parts of the yum cha experience.
author: Allen C.

description:
So I will start out with what I don't like - really hard to find parking, really long line, and half the time they are out of rice cake.

That being said, I really like this place, obviously even with all those cons I still give it 4 stars, that has got to say something.

** 5 stars for the rice cake**  many people don't even know what rice cake is and it is not available at too many bakeries, even in SF.  They have the best rice cake, by the way it is a sweet sticky rice usually the shape of a diamond or square.  If you haven't tried it, don't !  - because I don't want them to sell out before I get there!!  If you try it, there won't be any left for me!!!!  So keep away from my rice cake!!

** 4 stars for the rest of their dim sum, it's pretty good and pretty cheap, which is super rare to have both!!!

Service, well, let's just say it is the typical service you would receive at a place like this.... NEXT!!!!
author: Andrea B.

description:
Amazingly decent dim sum for the price! We sampled their shrimp dumplings, congee, pork siu mai, chive shrimp dumplings, shark fin dumplings, fried taro dumplings, chicken feet, cheung fun, and sticky rice with coconut and peanut. Sure, some of the items had thick wrappers, but the shrimp that they used had a nice snap and didn't taste funky. Also, their dumplings are some of the biggest that I've ever seen. Service is pretty brusque, but it is take-out dim sum offered at rock-bottom prices.

I got a little sleepy from the grease and MSG, but we only spent ~$21 for 3 people and ended up with leftovers. We made chow fun with the leftover rice cheung fun ($0.90 for a huge serving!), and they tasted exactly like Taiwanese ban tiao, which was a pleasant surprise. It may not be gourmet or delicate dim sum, but the price to quality ratio cannot be beat.
author: Alex Y.

description:
This place has really yummy dim sum. Finding parking can be a pain, but be patient because this place is worth it! Best time to come is in the morning when everything is stocked and fresh.

Some of my fav:

3 for $1.70

Shrimp dumpling
Pork Siu Mai
Shark Fin Dumpling
Chicken Siu Mai

$.90
Baked BBQ Pork Bun

$2.70
Sweet rice wrapped in lotus leaves

Open 6 days a week 7am-6:30pm closed on Tuesday
author: Anna P.

description: I wouldn't say it's my top place for quick dim sum, but it suffices for something close to the house.
author: Edgar C.

description:
My only advice: Don't come here after lunch.
I sadly made the mistake to come around 2 pm when everything was super cold and been out for hours. Since it was my first time trying this place and people warned me about the long lines, I thought I would take my time and come after lunch. Don't do it. I ordered my usuals, ha gao, sui mai, bbq pork buns, pork filled lotus leaf rice, black bean sesame balls and dry shrimp crepe (not the item I thought it was).

Don't get me wrong, we were given huge portions and the prices couldn't be beat. But since I don't indulge in dim sum very often I was still craving some of the items that weren't sold here. I love the shrimp crepe with soy sauce and the fried shrimp balls. Both of which left me wanting to go to a tradition dim sum place. If I lived in the city and wanted quick dim sum, I would definitely come here during peak hours. 

On a brighter note, I thought the ha gao was soooo good. The shrimp was large and nicely proportioned to the dough skin. As I was eating, I saw fresh batches of different items come out periodically so I wish I ordered those as they came out!
author: Anh Thu P.

description: The food is incredibly delicious! Get the shrimp dumplings. Unfortunately the service is very rude. All four employees were resentful and were also making fun of their customers behind their backs.
author: Joni W.

description: Order the egg yolk bun and it's cold. Not even eatable at the moment. They just told me to go home and microwave then. Seriously ?
author: Debbie S.

description:
Found this place on Yelp and had to give it a try. Ordered 5 orders of shrimp dumpling, 2 orders of beef shuimai, 1 order of pork buns, 2 orders of,  and 1 order of lotus buns for only $21. Food was delicious!!! I'll definitely come again.

3.5/5 cause of the long line & Seating was horrible, so plan on getting your order to go.
author: Maly B.

description:
Yummy dim sum, GREAT price. Although I've had way better, I have this place 4 stars for 2 reasons:

1. SUPER CHEAP!!
& 2. The porridge!

The porridge &chow mein were my faves.
The dark thick soy sauce they have was different, but delicious!

The ladies didn't seem too friendly, lol. But i didn't mind as long as I got my dim sum fix! 

The BBQ pork buns weren't that great, tho ): the filling was gooey and mushy, and was extremely sweet.
author: Julie X.

description:
Standard dim sum at cheap prices. I opted for this place because waiting for Dim Sum restaurants like Koi Palance on weekend mornings suck! If you're looking for a sit down restaurant with the normal full service carts and tea THIS IS NOT THE PLACE.

Sitting space is very limited and  you have to order beforehand (cash only!) and when it's your turn to order you better know what you want. The people working were all women and very rude.

Anyways, I overlooked their loud rudeness since Asian places tend to be like that  despite them yelling at me for being unsure of what I wanted and wasting time -_-

BOTTOM LINE: if you're mad cravin dim sum and don't want to wait and just want to get in and out, then this is the place.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Honestly, I could have dim sum about 2 times a week, it's so light but filling! 

Now, Good Luck Dim Sum is home to me, every Christmas morning we would have dim sum lunch at my grandparents house, and then dinner at my aunts. I loved going to Good Luck Dim Sum with my grandpa, because he truly believed that he was able to speak Chinese, yet he was far from it. We always let him show off his "dialog", because we thought it was extremely funny.

You must order early if it is for a big party, because this restaurant is very narrow between the door entrance and the dim sum display. The line will go down and wrap back around. 

Good Luck Dim Sum is CHEAP! That's another reason why we love it. 

Check out my page to find my blog!
author: Food G.

description: Came in yesterday around 3pm and everything seem to be running out. I had some of their dumpling and the layer outside was a little too thick for my taste. The bbq pork bun didnt have much meat in it mostly buns. I used to like this place but I had change of heart I guess.
author: Aniko N.

description:
Best place on Clement for STEAMED dim sum take out...

If you want BBQ pork buns, or pineapple buns go to Clement Restaurant one block away...

This place is usually busy whenever we arrive.  Like I said, we like to divide our takeout preferences between two places in the same area but this place is great for their haw gow and siu mai (beef, chicken, and pork).  We've also ordered the egg rolls (chuen cuen), custards (don tot), fried sesame balls (jean dui), turnip cake (low bok go), deep fried shrimp dumpling (hom sui gok), and a bunch of other stuff that is deep fried, pan fried, baked etc... so technically, I didn't really mean that only the steamed stuff is good...

The dim sum is pretty sizable, not wimpy, and the prices are very reasonable (cheap) so naturally you should expect a line.  One cool thing about the pricing is that you get stuff individually or by the order...

For example, say I order from the 3 for $1.60 group (e.g. haw gow, siu mai, etc..), I can have 3 haw gow for that price, or I can have 1 haw gow, 1 beef sui mai, 1 pork sui mai for that price.  You can mix and match in any combination.  There is an order form with pricing on top of the counter for you to use...

Though they can understand and speak English, I've found that it never hurts to speak to them in Chinese, even if it's "village" or "Ching-lish"...

Randomly, I tried to order something that my bro-in-law likes but that I've never ordered.  It's called a Malay cake (ma lay gow), and all this time, I though it was a monkey cake (inside joke...)  I tried to order it Xmas morning but I was told by the lady behind the counter that they didn't have any...

"That's ok, I'll wait for it..."

"Then you're going to wait a long time, because we didn't make any today..."

Oh well...

I've only been here before noon and always for takeout so I can't vouch for anything else...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Super hole in the wall type of dim sum place and very affordable. Not the best customer service, but you can't have everything. This place is pretty good too. Not many tables and can get very crowded. Best to take it to go if you can. I would come back for when I'm craving dim sum. Especially because you can order it by piece and not a whole order, which is great!
author: Julie L.

description:
Fucking service&rude staff
It is very bad experience for dim sum!
They didn't have enough food& dim sum for customers .
author: Karen T.

description: It's inexpensive but the quality is average . It's for people who just want to eat a lot and not to care about the quality .
author: Thong D.

description: Great food in quality and quantity , yet very affordable and consistent. Very busy at times,  but worth it.
author: Dennis L.

description:
The cheapest and best take out dim sum in the City! Nestled in the inner Richmond area, Good Luck Dim Sum is the perfect Sunday brunch meal....! 

Be careful that this is NOT your traditional sit-down dimsum restaurant...there are a few tables for you to sit down to eat at, but to order your food, it's in the take-out style. The line gets pretty long come lunch time, but it's well-worth the wait if you get here a bit late! 

To expedite your order when it's your turn, take one of the pink ordering sheets, circle the items you want, and write down how many "sets" of each item you want. You can hand this paper to one of the ladies getting the items and she'll get it ready for you. 

The size of the dimsum items are INCREDIBLE and CHEAP. Quality is not compromised. They have probably every "popular" and "traditional" dimsum items + a few other special ones. 

This is CASH ONLY. But again, because it's so cheap, you probably only need around $10-20 to fill your belly.
author: Rachel C.

description:
This is a pretty affordable dim sum place that leans a little towards the fast food-y side of restaurants. You order at the counter and get 3pc for ~$2. There isn't much seating, but there is a park just two blocks away that you can walk to and eat on the benches.

The dumplings, sui mai, har gow are all a little bit thicker skinned and more oily than you would get at a place where your food is made to order, rather than mass produced. That being said, I'm not afraid of a little oil and everything I got was pretty good. 

Particularly good:
- BBQ Pork Buns (no oil at all since they are not fired)
- Pot Stickers

Not so good:
- Egg Tart (very bland and not at all sweet)
author: Graham B.

description: I love this place for it's cash only, no frills, no bs style - and the dim sum is pretty good too and you can't beat the price.
author: Jakob S.

description: I ate my food so fast I forgot to take a photo.  Bottom line you get great dim sum for cheap prices. You can't beat that. Seating area inside is small and usually always taken up. 5 dollars got me a feast.
author: Anthony F.

description: I've really tried to like this place, but honestly feel that it's overhyped. My friends love it so I've given it a number of chances. Dim Sum at legit places tastes a lot better. The great thing about this place is that it's super cheap (I can get full off of $7-8), but I feel like that's reflected in the quality of the food.
author: Chris V.

description:
Meh.

The ladies behind the counter swear in Chinese, swear at you in Chinese between intermittent moments of taking your order, and the food is cold. I don't understand why this place has such high ratings! 

I will admit, it's beyond cheap and it's certainly authentic but I'll take expensive and hot over cheap and cold any day. There are so many great restaurants in the Richmond, so take a pass on this one.
author: Jessica K.

description:
This IS the place for take out dim sum. Of course you have to deal with the parking. If you have a sidekick with you (aka Batman and Robin) then drop off Robin to stand in line and order.
