Then circle the Bat Mobile around being careful not to hit any old Chinese ladies jaywalking. By the time you circle a few times, Robin is back with great dim sum.

And of course the dim sum never makes it all the way back to the Bat Cave because it is so delicious I have to make Robin feed me a few pieces while I maneuver around Gotham City. 

Liked:
- har gao (big)
- egg rolls (crunchy)
- siu mai (big)
- sticky rice


So so:
- BBQ pork buns (filling lacked much BBQ pork)
author: Steve L.

description: Probably the finest deep fried Taro dumpling I had in the city. Delicious pork filling and deep fried to perfection. Equally delicious were the tiny but tasty steamed chicken buns. The Har Gow (shrimp dumplings), made with a thin wrapping with good sized shrimps and water chestnuts inside were also amazing. Those were the highlights, the rest pretty regular taste and overall good price
author: Derek R.

description: Umm this place is NOT 4 star quality food... I came here because I was in the city and saw 4 stars and 1000 reviews but I was disappointed.. Everything here was dirt cheap but tasted literally like it came out of a frozen package in the super market when it's been sitting there for years... If you know real dimsum and have food standards DO NOT COME HERE! I WARN YOU... U WILL BE GROSSED OUT
author: Oliva L.

description:
This is not your typical dim sum where Asian ladies push carts around. Nor is it a place where you sit down and order. Think of it as the fast food version of dim sum. You basically order what you want at the front and then sit down with your paper tray of food. It's definitely recommended to find a table before you order since the restaurant is small. There are maybe 8 tables of four and it can get pretty busy during peak hours. 

We ordered almost every kind of dumpling, buns, steamed pork ribs, etc. The sauces were a little weird and didn't taste dim-sum-like. The soy sauce was really thick and dark. The hot sauce was more of a paste than the chili oil you usually see at dim sum. Despite the unconventional ordering process and strange sauces, everything was very good. I left extremely full and satisfied :)
author: Jessica C.

description:
It's good dim sum, just not piping hot since it's more of a take-out spot. Seems to be the trend on this strip. Pretty good selection of the usual dim sum staples. Hella cheap though, like I don't know how you'd eat  more than $5 pp at this place. Tables are limited but turnover is fast. Bathroom was really gross but what do you expect?

I expect to be a regular when I move to the area. Like every day I don't feel like cooking.
author: Vivian H.

description: Greasy joint in the heart of busy international neighborhood. Told me they don't use dairy (which I'm leary of), and that most things are made with rice flour. Guess I'll find out in about 24 hours...
author: Sasha W.

description: Wow! Good ole authentic hole in the wall but Zagat rated Dimsum. Must try and it's so darn cheap!!
author: Dojo A.

description:
I know this place isn't Koi Palace. All the offerings at Good Luck aren't anything exquisite, gourmet, or refined. Everything here is designed to be produced in mass numbers and served at a fast, efficient pace. If you need something quick, convenient, and super cheap, this will do the job just fine. I mean, can you really complain about an order of dumplings for under $2? We had more than enough food to feed 4-5 people for about $21!

The food obviously doesn't taste like the best dim sum in the world, and I'm not gonna waste my time describing every little flaw in the flavor of their dumplings and buns. Expect cost cutting measures like no mushrooms in the Siu Mai and Sesame Balls (Jin Deui) with red bean stuffing instead of lotus seed paste. Just shove everything in your mouth like you just don't care, and be surprised at how little it all costs.
author: Nei N.

description: Great yummy dumplings and sesame balls!  Not fancy but clean tables and floors. Found a place to get dim sum in SF! I am a happy camper!
author: Review L.

description:
I came to visit San Francisco last week and went to three different dim sum places. This was definitely my favorite! The prices are incredibly cheap. The food is fresh and ready on the spot. Im not a fan of pork buns but according to everyone from there, they have the best. 

My favorites are the shrimp dumplings, turnip cakes, pork shu mai, and deep fried stuffed dumplings. 

Tip: They are closed are Tuesdays and cash only.
author: Laura G.

description: Best pork bun in the city. The bread to pork ratio is better compared to Good Mong Kok and other places in Chinatown. The other potstickers had too much rice flour. So prob wont get that again.
author: Yash R.

description:
Came here in the daytime with my boyfriend because I was dying for some Malay cake aka Ma Lai Gao! This was the only place we came across in the short amount of time we had. 

Compared to a different Malay cake that I had, this one was mediocre. It wasn't as spongy and light as when I had it somewhere else, but it was still sweet and tasty. I warmed it up, which made it a little less dense and it brought out the sweetness! It was also relatively affordable- 4 pieces for $2. I would come back, but only to kill my craving for the cake. I have yet to find a better place! (:
author: Alisa H.

description: Long lines but goes fast. Circle the dim sum you want and hand it to the ladies. Tell them if you want one each or three per order. I love that I can eat ONE shrimp dumpling and sample so many dim sum dishes by myself. The shrimp dumpling, chive with shrimp dumplings were fresh and yummy. Roast pork bun was soft and tasty. The egg roll I hated. Thought it would be more like a spring roll but it wasn't. The turnip cake was flavorful. Some of the things were warm but some were cold. It's a hit or miss depending on when it came out. Wish they had a way of keeping the things warmer but it's still so good.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
I've been coming here for years because I really enjoy they're dim sum here. However, I also hate coming here because if the line and rude employees!

My favorites are chicken siu mai and shrimp gao. Also, they're chicken rice plate is recommended, too.
author: Jaylene L.

description: This place has a great selection and everything tastes amazing.  Additionally, their prices are super cheap.
author: Melissa M.

description:
Originally, I had thought it was dine in, but it's take out.  I'm not big on take out dimsum because I hate when dimsum gets cold.  It gets rubbery, and not as fresh as if you were to eat inside.  But the price was right, and we were able to eat it soon before it got cold once we decided where to eat. O_O 

The food was decent... Some things better than others...
author: Nhu-Quynh N.

description:
The food is at least a 3, but the prices make it the 4 stars. Nice cheap togo dim sum. 

Their egg tarts are a little flakier in the crust than Red A Bakery and tasted pretty good. I'd give that 3.5 stars.
author: Linus W.

description: Not the best dim sum but you can't beat the price. It's pretty cheap and tasty. Line can be long but it moves fast.  I ordered a full box for less than $20.
author: Vong V.

description:
Every time I come to SF I always make a couple stops in here. Some of the best dim sum around. Though beware, the ladies behind the counter can be pretty mean at times. Make sure you have your order ready or you can fill out the order sheet prior. Most items are under $2.

This place is small, mostly meant for to go orders. There are a few tables in the back, but don't expect restaurant style service here. I normally order the shrimp dumplings, pork shu mai, chicken buns, baked BBQ pork buns, porridge, and the chicken and sausage sticky rice.

Haven't been disappointed yet and I have been here several times. Definitely a must visit when you're in town.
author: Sheen T.

description:
Halleluah!!!!!
The best dimsum place I have had in soooooooo long and probably the best I have had in the city.  
My favorite. , the fried taro dumpling.. OMG!!!! Just thinking about it now makes me drool for more..... I ate some of it later in the day and it was still super crispy. The and siomai were both good and so fresh. The steamed pork buns were so fluffy and super delish!!!
The line  here is so long, and I'm not surprise at all why . Be prepared to bring cash and to wait about 20 - 30 minutes to get your order but its so worth the wait...
author: Claudine V.

description:
Cheap but lacks quality. Definitely tried better in SG & HK.
Service was below average. Ordered to eat in: carrot cakes, lok Mai gai wrapped in lotus leaf, ha gao, Siew Mai, fried yam dumplings, cha siew bao, guo tie.... All lukewarm or cold. Had to request to heat up, which she did in microwave but still, everything was disappointing to our surprise.
author: Carolyn L.

description: The small shop was crowded. Food was great. Almost every dim sum has shrimp inside, even leek pun. The price was pretty low comparing the amazing taste and good materials.
author: Sherry C.

description: When you want quick and cheap dim sum, this is the place to be. I went to City View downtown and spent $140 for 4 people. We went here and got stuffed and only spent $28.
author: C M.

description:
Great pork siu mai's (don't get beef), good egg tarts, cheap prices. To be honest, I wasn't the biggest fan of all of their dumplings and I feel like the choices are a bit limited, but that's pretty standard for take out dim sum.

Skip on the shark fin dumpling and chive dumpling. Just A-OK BBQ pork buns.
author: Jess C.

description: This chinese ladies here in the counter is fucking racist and rude, if your Chinese or white they'll take care of you, other than that good luck, I ask her bar-b-q pork bun and she gave me vegetable one I'm not fucking vegetarian, I told her pork but she gave a wrong order, she wasn't even friendly when I arrive at the counter and she was mad me and she slam my tray WTF was that..after she give my order the next lady was to me to order and she is white, and I saw this Chinese lady talking to her like smiling and everything I was what the fuck..and she even went to her table handing a water with a smile.
author: Gino L.

description: This place is seriously inexpensive, but doesn't have great veggie options. The deep fried stuffed dumpling was delicious and the Vegetable Pork Bun was just ok.
author: Jenn F.

description:
Pro: Cheap dim sum! Three pieces for $1.80.  

Con: The egg yolk bun I got was as hard as a rock. The paper on the bottom of the bun got stuck when I tried to pull it off.

Keep them in steamers!!
author: Tina C.

description: Delicious Dim Sum! Very close to Golden Gate Park. Mostly a take-out counter with a few Formica table tops. But oh my! The dim sum is amazing! Prices are phenomenal; my family of 4 ate lunch for under $20. Parking was easy. A gem!
author: Lesley B.

description:
Pretty LEGIT! 

Minus one star because they run out of things fast such as my favorite baked pork bun and porridge :( and the sticky rice in lotus leaf had very little meat. Carbs overload! You don't have to spend a lot of money for good dimsum.
author: J C.

description: Dim sum semi to go. Not a huge seating area but we were able to get a table quickly. Delicious and cheap.
author: Molly N.

description:
Decor won't make pinterest, front staff did not major in English literature, nor will they cater to your husband or baby's every whim.
If taste and authenticity at unlike san francisco prices are important, then they are among the best.
author: Hyun J.

description: I have come here a few times to get some goodies for my hubs and this place is pretty legit. Big pieces of dim sum at much cheaper prices. Variety is of course smaller as they don't ahve chicken feet etc but for dumpling or bao or dessert options, this is your go to. Line can get long and they can run out quick so before noon is key.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
I love this place because it's still relatively cheap (despite the fact that it seems to have raised its prices everytime I go in) and the food quality is pretty decent as well, given that it is made with the intention of "to-go"...however, if you really can't resist, they do have cafeteria-like dining too.

My favorite dim sum to get are the har-gow, siu-mai, and the pan-fried shrimp & chive dumplings. Everything else I find to be a little on the oily side...especially the potstickers, radish cakes, and taro cakes (-1 star).

The other thing I really like about good luck dim sum is their assortment of bao (available in both the steamed and baked version). These can easily be reheated the next day via steaming or using a wet paper towel in the microwave and it tastes just as good. Definitely an easy breakfast idea. Their tamales (zongzi) aren't bad either, but I really don't like that they use so much fatty meat in it...It makes it smell good, but there's no way I would intentionally eat it.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Amazing , if you wan my fast , cheap ,and delicious food Good Luck Dim Sum is the place to go! Will recommend to  try the shrimp taro dumpling ! Cheers
author: Ar P.

description: Delicious, cheap dim sum. Wish there were more places like this in Southern California! 3 pieces of char siu bao for $2?! Yes, please. They also have unique shrimp and taro dumplings that my own mother has never tried or seen before (she was a huge fan). Pork shumai were also pretty hefty in size compared to what I'm used to - lots of the filling. Har gow is also apparently a must (I'm just personally not into seafood). Definitely would come back here when I return to the area.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Cheap, quick dim sum!! What more can you ask for. You never see huge lines for a restaurant in Chinatown so I knew I had to check this place out. The food is flavorful, huge and soo cheap. Three pieces are only $1.70 or so. You cant beat that at all because if you were to go to an actual restaurant, three pieces is like $4. I got 6 pieces of various things because this is your chance to try stuff you never had. I got a few pieces of har gow, siu mai, spinach dumpling, and some other items. The pieces are tasty and just knowing that you got it for super cheap make them even more delicious :) The line gets very long so be aware of that. 

**TIPS**
1) Cash only!
2) Line is super long and the workers are always in a rush, so you better know what you want when you finally get in front of the line. The people in line will not want a hold up.
3) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
My friend steered us here for brunch after that late night of partying, good choice in my opinion!  It seems like people from all over SF come here just to eat the dim sum. Super fresh, make sure you order all your favorite dim sum here.  Prices are very reasonable and they have a few tables to eat inside.  Don't come here expecting any great service, just great food.  Plus you don't have to wait around for those pesky dim sum carts and terrible service.  

We came just in time to avoid the lines.  I really liked the rice, pork and Chinese sausage that is wrapped in that banana leaf.  WAS SO DAMN FRESH and DELICIOUS.  Very comforting to eat in the morning.  Totally forgot what its called in Chinese but I know its one of my favorite things, not too many others were eating this. I noticed a lot of the people in line seemed to look at me eating this dish like the had never seen it before.  Good stuff.  

Everything else was good, including the common shu mai and pork buns.  I would not order too much of the pastry like dim sums next time because they were a bit too greasy.  Even though a few bites tasted good, it probably isn't the healthiest thing to eat day in and day out.  So just be careful of that when you order here.  Again you can eat a ton of food here for like $8.  My friend and I left very satisfied and I will definitely bring other friends here if we are craving some dim sum.
author: Kenny P.

description:
Most quick/cheap Chinese takeout places in this area have good, greasy food. So when I'm choosing from the many Richmond dim sum/takeout places, the quality of communication is a big factor especially as I don't speak Cantonese/Mandarin.

The last 3 times I've been here the workers were nice and quite patient with our pointing and asking.
Only critique is, I'm not a fan of their shu mai or fried turnip cake.

Overall the dim sum is pretty good here, and with having the ease of knowing what I am actually getting, this is my go-to dimsum take out.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The Good: Authentic handmade dim sum! Their pork siu mai and crispy fried taro are among the best I've had. Shrimp dumplings have a slightly thinner rice wrapper than normal which really enhances the shrimp flavor. And their BBQ pork buns are wonderful! They don't skimp on the meat. Best of all, everything can be had for a dollar or two.

The Bad: This place is so authentic, they don't even have water on tap! I would have liked a wider drink selection. Ambiance is pretty much nonexistent unless you count the twelve cute little Asian ladies making dim sum in the kitchen.

Easy 5/5.
author: Alex L.

description:
This dim sum has extremely good quality buns and sesame balls and is mega cheap. I particularly like their baked and steamed pork buns, which, frankly, are under-priced for their quality. This place is much better quality food than the other dim sum bakery type shops on the same street or in the area. The best things to order are the food that are still in steamers because they're hot, though they will warm up baked buns for you as well.

The best thing to do here is to get a box to go because there isn't a lot of seating and the tables there are are cramped. 
The only other negatives are that sometimes they do sell out of various items, and the line is often quite long.
author: Allxie C.

description: This place fulfilled the craving with their pork buns, shark fun and shrimp dumplings. It is a small place where you order up front and everything gets placed on a paper plate for you. Cash only accepted here.
author: Robin U.

description:
Progressively getting worse and worse!  It used to be that you can call in an order and jump the line.  Now you can't even get through the phone!

I called today and someone at the counter answered.  She immediately put me on hold!  I was on hold for 10 minutes while I listen to the ladies serve the people at the counter.  This is incredibly rude and unacceptable.  I'd much prefer that you let the phone ring rather than give me a brush off.  Please, can't you get someone to answer in the kitchen?
author: Wendy H.

description:
Love this place !! Randomly found it on Yelp and it's everything the review says ... Prices are so cheap ... I got an order of carrot cake, Ha gow , shui Mai, & seafood dumplings for $5.00. I grew up eating dim sum and love it so much I am super picky. Their food is delicious and yummy. I had to take it to go and even though I was in traffic when I got home it was still really good. 

The Asian ladies were super nice too! Love it
author: Faith C.

description:
Not the best dim sum you can get, but this place is pretty good. You can't go wrong with take-out dim sum until 630 pm. I love grabbing a few buns, sumai or breads. I kind of just point and smile. 

Their BBQ pork buns are a bit sweet then I like them, so I stick to the other stuff. 

It's cheap and while you're in the area you can go to an asian market and save a ton of money on produce and cool stuff.
author: Krista N.

description: $2 for 3pc of tasty dim sum. There is a 20cents surcharge per container for holding the dim sum you want to buy to go.
author: W A.

description: This is a fantastic, but serious 'hole in the wall'. The long line bustling with regulars was a clear sign that the phenomenal Yelp reviews were accurate.  The incredibly reasonable prices made me think that they (or I) had potentially misplaced a decimal point! We had the pork pot stickers, Shu Mai , shrimp dumplings and pork buns. All were exquisite, flavorful and served quickly! The yummy food and incredibly low prices more than compensate for the subpar dining area. Take-out is highly recommended!
author: William H.

description:
This place is pretty off the charts. I mean, even with the line and me having no idea how the pricing scheme works (orders vs pieces, mind you!) I still had no problem handing them a ten and stuffing myself.

Now, keep in mind, they're selling an order (of three) pork buns for $1.70. You're probably not getting super nutritious stuff here. But that's factored into the stars.

Complains here on yelp about this place are kind of, um, unreasonable, given this is like pretty cheap dim sum. Yes they're rude, but if you're not a regular they don't really give a damn because you're slowing them down 15 people and you're buying like 5 bucks worth of stuff. I'm coloring my experience with some places I've been to in Chinatown, which fall along slightly higher pricelines but aren't as good.

EDIT: Oh, also I had to discard a pretty tough piece of tendon in my baked pork bun, but once again, you gotta consider what you're paying for here.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Walked over to treat myself to some take-out dim sum - excited to try one of the more popular spots in SF! Luckily I arrived when there were only a few people in line and was in and out in 5 min! Unfortunately I was really underwhelmed with the quality of the food...

The "shrimp dumplings" (3 for $1.70) were your typical shar gow. However the covering seemed to be old, rubbery, and hard (not sticky) and the shrimps did not taste fresh. I also did not like the chunks of garlic inside with the shrimp.

The porridge was actually pretty decent and they give you a huge amount ($2). I just have never been able to appreciate the aged egg flavor that Chinese people love... other than that - the shredded pork was tender and the porridge was very flavorful!

The steamed pork buns (3 for $1.70) were my favorite! They were soft, fresh, and filled with sweet pork! I would definitely come back here for some more! The man ordering after me ordered 30 of the baked pork buns so maybe I can try that next time!

All in all, great place to get some cheap take out dim-sum! But personally, I would pay a little bit more to get fresh dimsum!
author: Eunice K.

description: Long queue when we arrived, but service was quick and efficient. It is sort of like a take-out kind style of dim sum restaurant, but has a few tables for eating in. Food is generally good and they are big in portion especially their "gai giok", love their "sui mai" and "ha kao" (one of the best I've eaten).
author: Vun Hui H.

description: Cheap and pretty good dim sum. The majority of the items are 3 pieces for $2.10 and quite generous size. We ordered a few steamed items and I think their har gow is the best. They do have a few small tables if you want have it there but mostly people do take out. We were there around 9 something but the line were pretty long and got longer when we left. Decent eat if you are not too picky about top notch dim sum.
author: Soo W.

description:
favorite dim sum. good price. 


5 stars for food. 

pot stickers pork bun egg roll etc. delicious 

must go again
author: Tristan A.

description: Fresh dim sum, very affordable. One of the few places that actually had tables and seats inside (most were take-out only). My favorites were the turnip cake, har gau (shrimp inside), & siu mai (sweet)
author: Nora R.

description:
Good place to get dim sum to go. There is always some line at this place. The items are all made pretty fresh. The "orders" come in 3 pieces so if you want individual pieces to try different items, you'll need to specify that to them. Shrimp dumplings, hai gow (they have pork, chicken and beef), turnip cake, rice balls are all good. I also like their porridge (pork with thousand year old egg).

They appear to be cash only as I have not seen anyone pay with credit card.
author: Ali F.

description: Well, the lines are usually long, but worth the wait. I don't know any other store on Clement that does Dim Sum the way this place does it.  And that extra something is hard to describe. Maybe it is the constant flow of fresh hot items coming from the kitchen, maybe it is the ingredients or something in the way they prepare the items, I'm not quite sure, but I typically get a box full of pot stickers, those shrimp gelatins, the cilantro balls, a couple of the pork and chicken thingies with the dots on top, an occasional shark fin, and maybe an egg roll.  Friends seems to like the pork buns and sesame balls, but I stick with the fresh items.
author: Richard W.

description: Very friendly. Cafeteria-style. Perfect for a quick, cheap and casual lunch. Ordered the Pork Siu Mai, Chive Dumplings and regular dumplings. All were delicious and don't leave you feeling sluggish afterwards.
author: Christine M.

description: Seriously? The only reason why people like this place is because it's cheap. You can frozen dumplings and that is what it will taste like.  My uncle raved about this place. They will microwave it for you if you like which is what we did. Everything was small, greasy, full of dough, salty, and full of msg. Only come here if you need something easy and fast. That's all.
author: Jangalina J.

description:
Cold dumplings that tasted like they were cooked yesterday and left out all night. 

No soup dumplings either, in spite of what Yelp told me.

There are much better places within an easy walk that are far better. Will not be coming back here.
author: Trevor B.

description:
This place has cheap dim sum so that is a plus. The djm sim was ok nothing too amazing. This place is like a hole in the wall. It's better to do carry out than to try and find a place to sit. You grab a piece of paper with all the food option and circle the one you want. If you make it to go they'll put it in a pink box for you or paper plates if you dine in. The utensils were flimsy so it's better eat with your hands. 

I personally will not come back to this place because I like the typical push-cart dim sum.
author: G T.

description:
Amy C pretty much sums it all up

Parking is a war! 

Tables are non existent

Lines can be outrageous!

On the upside, quality, price and quantity is spot on! 

If you can find parking, take advantage of it! There are so many great little shops to check out after you get your fill of delicious dim sum! 

Overall Thoughts

If you want great dim sum priced right then you are in great luck at Good Luck Dim Sum
author: Eddie W.

description:
My brother had a huge craving for dim sum during our vacation to SF, and he found this place on Yelp. I am normally not a big dim sum fan, but this place changed my mind about dim sum! 

The prices were ridiculously cheap here! Everything on the menu is a winner. My brother and I stuffed our faces with $20 worth of stuff! That's a lot of food because the standard menu items were only $1.70.

My favorites were the shrimp dumplings (filled with juicy and fresh shrimp) and steam bbq pork bun.

The custard tart was not firm and the bread part kept falling apart, but it was still good.

Not a huge fan of the beef siu mai, but I think I need to get used to the taste of it. 

And we didn't have any issues with any employees here. They were fast and accurate with our order.

Will come back again for our next trip to the bay.
author: Noel K.

description:
Everything is absolutely disgusting.

I can't believe how these guys are surviving without getting into trouble with the restaurant inspections. I simply can't believe how many good ratings this place has. There's mud and dirt all over the place.

Additionally the price just doesn't make sense. I wonder what kind of bad stuff they are using in their products.

If you come here because it's cheap, you'll end up paying a lot more to the hospitals in the future.
author: Renan C.

description:
This isn't your typical sit-down dim sum restaurant; you grab a paper menu, circle what you want, and get your order either on a plate/tray or a to-go box. I ordered shrimp, pork, and beef dumplings and a pork bun; the only items I didn't personally like were the beef dumplings. Price was 3 for $1.80 which made a good, quick $9 meal split with my boyfriend. They do have tables to sit down at inside, but there are only a few and the decor is pretty lacking.

I do prefer sit-down restaurants however if you're craving dim sum and want to grab it quickly, can't go wrong the quality, price, and quick ordering system they've set up here.
author: Jamie B.

description:
Good Luck no fiii stahs fo yoouu!  I still love you and give you 4 though.  I stopped by this weekend around 2:30 with barely any line, I waited for a minute to be served.  This nice, but probably new lady (I haven't seen her before) helped me.  We paid $15 for a feast.  But when we got back home, I noticed we got gipped!  They forgot 4 potstickers....grrr & those were one of my favorites to get!  I also calculated what I thought would be the correct total for 2 vita soys, 9 ha gaw, 2 baked cha siu baos, 4 shrimp & chive dumplings, & 3 siu mai, and even the 4 forgotten potstickers & it didn't seem to add up to $15, unless there are price changes that aren't on the menu.  Sigh!  Next time I guess we'll have to double check our food.  

The dumplings and baos are always huge and cheap!  And just because they're huge and cheap doesn't mean they're crappy, the food is so yummy!  My favorite is the shrimp and chive dumplings, which has garlic in them, mmm!  The women here while not friendly according to upscale or American restaurants, seem pretty friendly.  And even if you don't speak Cantonese, language is not a barrier here, neither is bad Chinglish; what can I say, I try, but I'm an ABC x 3, so it's even a miracle that I know some Cantonese.  As always, come prepared for a little of a wait most of the time, and cash, but even a little bit of cash will totally get you stuffed.
author: Cat C.

description:
WORST SERVICE IN SF.

Talk about bad customer service in a Chinese food establishment, this is the worst it could ever get. The server/cashier BARELY SPEAK ENGLISH & was VERY VERY RUDE. Didn't appreciate customer's business & acted like you were giving them trouble when THEY messed up your order. 

Food was just OK.
author: Chyntia D.

description: You have to get here early. The food goes really fast and you won't be able to get what you want other wise. You should also be prepared to brave a crowd at the dim sum counter. As long as you don't mind those things the food is pretty good. I especially recommend the rice noodle rolls.
author: Faith M.

description:
Quick
Simple
Tasty
Inexpensive
Solid

Dim sum is good here. Saves me the trouble of having to run to Chinatown for some good dim sum.
author: T C.

description:
CHEAP TO GO DIM SUM

Shrimp dumplings
Siu Mai- Pork and shrimp dumpling
Other dim sum, I dont know in english... I'd skip on the fried "salt water dumpling" too much dough, not enough filling.


Workers here make you feel rushed to order.. but whatever. Don't care about service in these type of places. 

heard the Porridge is good and super cheap though
author: Erica L.

description: Food is good but staff is rude even considering the language barrier. The shrimp dumplings are yummy but leaves a bad taste when the staff hesitant on giving out forks and napkins.
author: Jess F.

description:
I have no idea what happened to my previous review because I saw an error in its place.

Long story short.

Dumplings are hard and dry, has a good amount of filler.
Ambiance is strange.
Place looks really dirty.

It's not good, I don't get it.

HOW DID IT GET 4 STARS?!
author: Winè C.

description:
When everyone is lining up to buy dim sum coming out of big steaming baskets and yelling in Chinese to get them, you know the place is good! More for takeout than eating in (ambience is a bit lacking), dirt cheap. My favorites are steamed shrimp and chive dumpling and baked shrimp and chive bun (which has a more sticky texture to the outer layer of bun) . Even though I am mildly allergic to shrimp, I overcome it to order these dishes as comfort food post surgery!

Also the other two worth getting is roasted BBQ pork bun (cha shao bao in mandarin) porridge with pork and fermented eggs.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
This place is a big winner in the neighborhood. It can be a little crazy in there and there's not a ton of customer service happening, but the food and prices are fantastic.

Price: 5 stars, great prices on everything.
Service: 2.5 stars, um...no. The little sheet of pink paper you use for ordering is the most helpful part. I'm not basing on these folks, I'm merely observing. The folks that work there are there to serve the food not talk to you.
Ambiance: 2.5 stars, clean enough, but not terribly comfortable and it can get gnarly when it's busy. 
Food: 5 stars, all of it's been awesome, though the porridge and the shrimp dumplings are my favorites.
author: Thomas K.

description:
A couple things I really do appreciate about this place:

-Fast and orderly service. 
You're in and you're out the door with freshly made dim sum. Caught in a long line? Not to worry, you'll be ordering before you know it! 

-Verrrrry inexpensive
Stuffed 3 adult bellies for $21. In sf?? This is insane people. Our group ordered 5 orders of Har gow, 3 or 4 orders of beef siu mai, 1 order of egg custard bun, 1 order of bbq pork bun, and 1 order of shrimp and chive dumpling. Each order equals 3 pieces. 

Do NOT expect:
A spot to dine in and socialize. Very limited space with very limited seating. One table that seemed to originally serve as a spot to sit was drowning in to-go boxes. This place is definitely designed for pick-up orders. Its quite crowded so you'll likely find yourself wanting to exit anyways. Oh well, this can be a sweet opportunity to explore china town and find a scenic spot to enjoy your treasured dumplings. 

The sad deal breaker:
All the steamed buns I had tasted of raw/undercooked flour. Had to get some iced coffee next door to wash it down. I love egg custard buns, but the ones here were dried out and dissatisfying. Oh man. 

This is my first visit. The other choices tasted pretty good so i'll definitely give it another try some day. These prices are hard to beat too. When you're visiting sf on a budget and have the serious hungry hungries, this place is surely worth a go.
author: Vaneza A.

description: Great place for some fast, delicious dim sum. Did I mention it was dirt cheap? Tons of locals, and not a lot of sitting space. Usually it's most strategic to have a friend eye the tables as you wait in line for your order. If someone leaves while you're still in line, get your friend to swoop in and hold that table! Had all the dim sum basics-- chicken rice in lotus leaves, chicken feet, shu mai, har gow, congee, egg tarts, rice noodles, pork buns, custard buns, you name it. Left very satisfied without breaking the bank or waiting for carts to come by, hoping they'd have what you'd want!
author: Evonne L.

description:
Incredibly cheap dim sum. My boyfriend and I came here to order a few items and of course we over-ordered. We ended up having leftovers for 2 more meals. The only negative is that there isn't enough seating. But it's convenient to take your dim sum to go in a pink box and enjoy later! 
Cannot beat the prices, the relatively short wait, and the fast service!
author: Siv L.

description:
This place is SO dangerous. 

You guys... I spent $9 total. You want to know how much food I got? WAY TOO FREAKING MUCH. I got 3 giant bbq pork buns, 3 giant pork potstickers, 3 crystal dumplings (best), 3 har gow shrimp dumplings, 3 other ones, and i swear something else I just can't recall because I immediately went into a food coma. 

Long wait, but worth it for the price and the food! I had two and a half meals from this $9 order. Why isn't this next door? Oh right, because I would die from being too fat.
author: Jessie M.

description: Whenever we wanna picnic in SF this is one of our to go spot when we don't wanna go to busy & bustling China Town.  It's super yummy, affordable and fast!!! I love the fact you fill out a form of exactly what you want to get!! The ladies there are friendly and efficient!! My favorites are the shrimp & cilantro dumplings so yummy!!  Everything else we tried is yummy as well!
author: oNEloVE C.

description:
This place is decent for a quick fix when you're looking for something cheap. 

I liked the egg tarts, har gao, and chicken siu mai. The porridge was too watery for me and the lady rushed me so I didn't get to order the black bean spare ribs :(. 

However, customer service here is a trip. I asked one of the lady's for two sauce containers (one for chili the other for soy sauce) the lady made it a point to walk over to see how much food we had left over before she gave me the second container... I was kinda speechless. lol 

I'm not sure when I will be back, but I know it won't be for awhile.
author: Vi Vi V.

description: Amazing dim sum! I highly recommend everything from the shrimp dumplings to the sesame buns. It's the best on clement.
author: Scott J.

description: Very good and inexpensive! Had an assortment of items today for $10. Didn't love the steamed pork buns but the shrimp dumpling of all sort were excellent. The line was 15 deep but only took about 5-7 minutes. Cash only.
author: PK R.

description: With the price you get where I really don't think I should be complaining about anything. It's my second time here the food is still decent. I'm talking about rating the food with how much you're spending I'll say it's a good spot. It's not really the cleanest place but clean freaks can go ahead and spend $20 on dim sum instead of $2.
author: Yulin K.

description: We went today following YELP tips and knew what to expect on a Sunday morning. A line. Ok, Deal. The Shrimp rolls did not disappoint. But you have to try the turnip cake. Delicious. Unique. Pork rolls, aparently according to  a local Chinese woman, World Famous. I have some photo's to add.My guilty pleasure is those soft, sweet sesame buns..... so satisfying. Enjoy and beware of the lack service during busy times.
author: Carol G.

description:
The prices were dirt cheap but the service was mediocre and the food tasted terrible. I've been eating dim sum from bakeries my entire life and this was one of my worst experiences.

The feng zhao, cha siu bao, and lo bak gou were not fresh at all and just plain bad. The siu mai was the worst I had ever had. I'm pretty sure it was made out of pork but it tasted more like jacked-up chicken breast. The gao choi gao was delicious but it couldn't make up for how badly this bakery messed up my entire morning.
author: Brian E.

description:
Sometime yesterday I toyed around with the thought of doing a food crawl along Clement Street. A sample of something delicious here, then move on to the next stop, for one bite, and then a few blocks down to another. There was no set agenda and no list...total spur of the moment.

It's quite apparent that one of the more popular quick and cheap options along this area best suited for food crawls, are the several storefronts that specialize in dim sum takeout (dubbed "Dim Sum Bakeries") with random bakeries selling sweet and savory buns next. You don't even see these kinds of dim sum bakery deli shops in Hong Kong (but they do have el cheapo efficient cooked to order sit down neighborhood eateries that achieve a similar purpose of downscaling it for local folks which are better). And it becomes quite apparent after observing the competitors and Good Luck Dim Sum appears to be the winner. It's not just by the crowds, but also the efficiency, quality, quantity, variety. It's a lottery winning combination, particularly with the target demographic consisting mostly of locals who are Chinese expats from Southern China and some from Hong Kong. It is almost like to them having their egoe$ Swedish massaged with hot stones by a professional from Thailand while offering a Mainland Chinese reflexology foot rub with a pot of lavender tea (tips included).

And places like these are also great if you don't want to be arsed waiting hours in line (particularly during Labor Day Weekend) for yum cha at your favorite dim sum joint, rubbing elbow to elbow with even more aggressive FOBs and granny types willing to run your ass over just to get a numbered ticket. Thus the next best thing is just to pick up some takeout/reheat at home, or if you are visiting the area like me, have them fill up a paper plate, then take it to the dining area and wolf it down like goats getting pellets at a petting zoo.

It all happened so fast...took a check sheet and circled my wish list (I had one entirely In Chinese) then handed it to the employee. Less than a minute later, the plate was packed with goodies, and came to an even $6. $hit, I spend $20 to $30 on yum cha easy (not to mention $1 per person for a pot of tea). No tea here (bring your own, or if you are desperate, there are craptacular boba shops in the area).

Ha gow, pork siu mai, dried shrimp cheung fun (a huge monster at that, only $0.70!!!), pan fried daikon cake. I was supposed to "sample" right? :-o

The table spaces fill up quickly, but don't hesistate to ask if someone already seated at the table if there are empty chairs available. 

Sure, this stuff is not even comparable to a sit down restaurant, but the steamed items are generally still quite hot (the deep fried stuff may be nearing room temperature like the daikon cake). At this rate, don't take the time to nibble and savor....it's PAC MAN time to gobble the stuff up if dining in.

To assist with this, use the "ketchup" and "mustard" squirt bottles at the tables. The ketchup bottle (red) is the soy sauce, and probably a tad sweetened. The "mustard" bottle is the chili sauce, and I highly recommend you use it, which will elevate the daikon cake and cheung fun to heights you never realized. Heck you are not at Hong Kong Lounge or Koi Palace, so SQUIRT dat chit all over with reckless abandon and let your inner beast run wild. I love my ha gows, but I love GLDS ha gows with chili sauce too! 

Conclusion? Blows away the 99 Ranch supermarkets that offer dim sum (in the Peninsula or South Bay) and even Dim Sum King in Sunnyvale. Probably pretty close to Mongkok Dim Sum on Noriega.
author: Ken K.

description:
Good Luck finishing all goodies you ordered too much of for a ridiculously low price! 
Its cafeteria style, bring your own cup and tea bag but you'll love it.
author: Edi B.

description:
This place is a legit Chinese dim sum takeout place. There are tables for eating but the "ambiance" is less than desirable (newspapers strewn about, yelling in Chinese, lines up the yang)

Everything here is a winner. The buns, dumplings, congee - so yum. I especially like the pork buns bc unless most places the bun is not 4 inches of bun and two teaspoons of pork. Ratio! What a concept!

Lines are crazy but before 11am you'll be in and out quickly. 

Cash only and grab a pink paper and pen on the counter to tabulate your order before getting to the front. 

Parking is a nightmare on weekends but usually a side street will treat you right. 

Oh and ladies who work here are fast and relatively calm despite the rush. Minus one star for the craziness of the crowds
author: Carmen K.

description:
Not "exactly" dim sum!

This place serves ok dim sum but its menu options are minimal. You order at the counter from a group of food visible behind the counter. There is no cart that comes around with a full menu. Just a nice lady with a few items. 

The scene screams fast food restaurant. It is mostly filled during lunch time and it very poorly lit and stale inside. Not a very comfortable or relaxing place to eat. 

Overall, I was disappointed. I was looking for more of a traditional full menu busy dim sum restaurant. This is not it.
author: Gavin P.

description:
Love this place! Once I discovered this dim sum to go/dim sum fast food I came back four mornings in a row (visiting from NYC)

Awesome dim sum for half the price you would pay at a traditional sit down restaurant and you are in/out the door in 5 mins
author: Leo C.

description:
I'm as Chinese as it gets, yet I absolutely hate dim sum. Its not that they don't taste good, its more like the experience growing up - spending the entire Sunday afternoon with my parents waiting forever for a table, then again waiting forever for the right dim sum lady to pass by, and if she's out, my weekend will pretty much be ruined and very much wasted. And the fact that I grew up in Hong Kong (where dim sum really originated from) and Sacramento Chinese food is very mediocre does not help with my dislike against dim sum.  I honestly haven't been to a dim sum place since I was like 16, until yesterday, when I randomly walked in Good Luck Dim Sum with my grandpa. 
1st thought to self: Holy crap! There's a long line! It must be good! 
2nd thought: Holy crap! Its only $1.60 for 3 pieces! 
3rd thought : Really? Holy crap its only $1.60 for 3 pieces!!

There must have been at least 8 people in line, but there were 4 Chinese ladies working behind the counter, so the line moved really quickly. While you're in line, you can grab a sheet menu which has all the items they offer and you can circle whatever you want. If this is gonna be your first time here, I highly suggest ordering a piece of almost everything, grabbing an extra menu, and put stars next to what you liked best for when you come back, because you'll definitely want to. One thing I really like about the idea of to-go dim sum is that I don't have to wait for a table, and I can order just 1 piece of something, whereas at restaurants you would have to get a basket of 3 or 4 pieces.

We bought over $30 worth of stuff, of which, I particularly liked the BBQ pork bun, flower roll (steamed plain bun shaped like a big knot), and mochi (what they call the sweet rice puff with coconut and peanut).  My grandpa said he would come back, and that says a lot since he is very picky when it comes to Chinese food. Btw, not everything is 3 for $1.60. Custard tart, egg yolk bun, mocha, lotus seed bun, etc etc are 65 cents each, and certain other items are $2.00 each or sold by the pound.
P.S. paper boxes are 20 cents extra! Otherwise they put everything in plastic bags. If you love trees and don't want your food mixed and meshed, bring containers!
author: Katie S.

description: Best cheap dim sum I've encountered! Order with paper menu and hand to a lady behind the counter. Large portions. Could be hotter and fresher but then it wouldn't be so fast and affordable. Rice porridge with Chinese donut recommended!
author: Pearl L.

description:
I've been hooked on SF Dim sum ever since I had it once in Chinatown last year, and when my coworkers told me that I could get the same amazing taste and price without the ridiculous congestion of Chinatown by going to Clement Street, I was in there like swimwear.

This place is primarily for take out, although they do have a decent number of small tables if you need to eat in. Staff isn't too friendly/chatty, but they have these super helpful menu sheets and pens so you can circle your order (therefore minimizing confusing conversation for all parties involved... SCORE!) and hand it over to the staff.

Most items are 3 for $1.60, although for the larger pieces like sticky rice it's $2 a piece. Happy Dim Sum-ing!
author: Jenn L.

description:
Great for when you're craving dim sum in the late afternoon, but for those who are looking for good dim sum, I'd go somewhere else. Out of everything I ordered, the only thing I really enjoyed were the shrimp dumplings. The BBQ pork buns are a little too sweet, and the filling was too mushy. The lotus sticky rice was a little hard, and the mix of meat & vegetables inside weren't that flavourful. Other items were just okay.

Customer service really wasn't atrocious; they just seem to rush you along. Make sure you're assertive with what you want, as they might just forget to include a few things.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Dim sum to go? THIS is the place.

Quality is just fine for my palate. And as others have remarked, the prices are insanely low.

As for the pork buns, everybody talks about the steamed ones, but the baked ones seem to have even MORE of that delicious bbq pork inside.

You might have to circle the neighborhood for parking, but my recommendation is to go with a pal who can double park while you do in for the dim sum. Heck, the locals double park all the time! And if parking enforcement comes by, your pal can circle the block until you come out with the pink box.

(Next time I go, I'm going to save the pink box and bring it back with me the time after that.)
author: Art L.

description:
Yet another recommendation of one of my friend's!  Stopped by Good Luck Dim Sum to pick up some goods to share with family in the East Bay.  Very satisfied with the har gow, siu mai, chive/shrimp dumplings, the big sticky rice ball and dan tats.  All very tasty and in general perfect portion size for price you're paying.

Note: could have just been a fluke that day, but the char siu bows had VERY LITTLE bbq pork filling.  The bread itself is quite tasty and fluffy, so don't let it trick you!  Once you bite/cut in you'll notice the absence of filling.  This is the one thing they need to improve.

Other than that, I'll be back to purchase some of the other items...
author: Christopher W.

description:
Food is cold and quality is subpar. The fact that we ate there and the food being served cold just isnt acceptable. What's even better? We found a strand of hair in the fried flour. It had been fried. Wtf. 

Ill rather spend to go Koi Palace than waste my money and calories here.
author: Josephine L.

description:
This place has awesome dim sum at really cheap prices (3 for $1.60!) This morning we came around 10:45/11 and there was a super long line. It took us about 30 minutes to get our food. 

As you come in, grab a pink slip off the counter and a pen. I HIGHLY recommend bringing your own pen; they only have a few and I saw a little kid stick one in his mouth...

Circle what you want (do not use check marks, X's, or any other form of indicating your choices - they are extremely particular about this) and put the quantity you desire next to it. If you don't do this, bring someone who speaks Chinese with you. 

Also, get a to-go box. It's 20 cents and you can use it to take home your leftovers or in the event you can't find seating inside. If you try to go back later and get a box, it will not be pretty. (People in line do not like to be cut even if your transaction will only take 5 seconds - we saw someone else try to do this and learned that lesson very quickly!)

Seating is very limited which is a bummer. Also, they are cash only. Not a bummer, but good to know.
author: Rachel E.

description:
note to self, do not ever enter good luck dim sum starving and empty stomached because i will end up with a giant pile of dim sum on a tray after circling about every single item available on the menu.  

what went on in my head "ooh, i love pork shiu mai, oh, they have chicken shiu mai too!  omg shrimp dumplings, oh, $1.70 for 3 pcs, don't mind if i do, oh man, steam bbq pork buns, i want everything!!"  

we ended up with a pile of dim sum on a tray, and all the buns literally scattered all over the tray.  needless to say, good luck dim sum totally satisfied my intense dim sum craving, all for $18.  

this place gives instant dim sum gratification.  no joke.  you don't have to sit around waiting for carts to come around, or turn on your hunter instincts to monitor which dim sum carts have what at a restaurant.  

stick with:  anything dumpling, shiu mai, sweets, and steamed bbq pork buns

don't stick with:  anything bun for the exception of bbq pork buns.  the egg yolk bun wasn't too good either.  skip that and go for the egg tarts and sesame balls.
author: Alice C.

description:
I walked by this unassuming grease trap one lazy Sunday with an appetite for lazy Chinese food.

$5 got me 3 cha siu bao, 3 shu mai, and 3 potstickers, all reasonably sized items (not the puny little dumplings you get in the supermarket freezer) and enough to satiate two people.  Extreme value.

How did it taste?  It was decent overall.  The pork buns were the least overwhelming as the filling was more sauce than pork.  The shu mai were just what I was expecting, all they need is a little soy sauce and they're good.  Same with the potstickers which I liked the most out of the group.

They have seating, but it's more like a cafeteria than a restaurant.  This place is the definition of hole-in-the-wall.
author: Carlin F.

description:
I have had better dim sum than this place. Although it is pretty cheap, the quality isn't there. We had the usual pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings, porridge, bbq pork buns, and coconut mochi balls.

The shrimp dumplings and the mochi were probably the best things there that we tried. The porridge was bland and lacked meat and 100 year old eggs. The bbq pork buns... i felt were "fake" because i think there was a lot of artificial flavoring and fat globules.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Even among high competition here on clement street, Good Luck Dim Sum stands on top. This is the perfect place to pick up a weekend lunch. Whether you're planning to eat at home, a park or sit in the (limited) seating area, you are sure to enjoy your quick bit. 

I usually get their shrimp dumplings because they are spectacular and only $1.70 for 3.

If you're in the neighborhood and want to get what locals get, come here. No it's not a "five-star" establishment, but their food sure is.
author: Ariel P.

description:
Food only the shrimp dumpling was ok. Everything else sucked especially the service. They gave us the wrong order and wouldn't replace it....blaming me. Overall sucks.

Try the restaurant next door. Chilli House...the Hong Kong Style pan fried noodles is amazing!
author: Jigs T.

description:
Breakfast, early dinner, sunday dim sum, hangover food, picnic food... I will find any excuse to come here! Before I move to the richmond district, I came here a few times randomly. Growing up in HK, I wasn't quite used to the dim sum take-out spots. Dim sum used to be the family gathering time every sunday, you have to gossip, sip on your tea, enjoy your food and chit chat your life away with your loved ones. So I'm quite spoiled with the amazing restaurant ambiance with 5 stars service. 

But let me tell ya, this hole-in-the-wall place really hits the spot for me! It's a quick fix for your dim sum cravings. Don't expect good service, spotless tables, waiter changes your plate kind of service! You ain't gonna get it here, fo sho! You come here, get in line (yes, there's a line! on the weekends the line goes all the way to the kitchen!), fill out a dim sum order paper, and when it's your turn, hand them the paper and they will fill up your box of happiness! 

crystal dumplings - chives, shrimp, delicious! 
cheung fun - absolutely my favorite! order the one with shrimp!
jook - hangover cure, rice porridge with thousand year old preserved egg and pork!
cha siu bao - BBQ chinese pork bun
choy yok bao - veggies and meat bun - delicious also! a lighter flavor bun!
shark fin dumplings - amazeballs! It doesn't have real shark fin in it, sadly!
potstickers - panfried to perfection!
siu mai - chicken, pork or beef, you pick! 
har gow - fresh shrimp with some bamboo bits, tender and flavorful! 
I wish they have chicken feet here!***

I don't have a sweet tooth so I don't order much pastry.
But you must try:
sesame balls!
dan tat - custard tarts

They also take special orders for parties! Trust me, if you bring food from Good luck dim sum to a potluck, it will be gone in no time! I've done it! I've even brought a box of goodies to the radio Alice concert in G.G park! It looks weird but everyone was eyeing my box of goodies! :p

The best part is - it is so freaking cheap! For example, one order of siu mai (comes in 3s) only costs you $1.70!!! Jook costs you 2 dollars! I hope the price stays the same no matter what goes on in the world. I always find my comfort in Good luck dim sum now! even though I had my doubts before about take-out dim sum! 

P.s - if you plan on coming here in the later afternoon before they closes at 6:30pm, be prepared that a lot of the items will be sold out! It's that popular!

Enjoy! xoxo
author: Mindy C.

description: Part of the attraction here is getting yelled at in Chinese for ordering wrong. But the dim sum here really is good and quick. Who wants to wait over an hour for a table? Nevertheless, they have a few tables here if you want to dine in but they will charge you for water.
author: Andrew D.

description: Cheap Fast food.  Greasy and not very good.  There are so many better places on the same street that I would avoid this place.
author: Helen L.

description:
Yes, they are definitely affordable and the food quality is just decent, but nothing THAT great compared to other hole in the wall dim sum places I been to.

I ordered the usual dim sum items: Shu mai, ha gow, chicken feet, chive dumplings, etc. For two people. the cost was about $13 total. 

Nothing REALLY stood out to me. We arrived around 12pm on a Sunday, and the line was not too bad. I would come back if i am in the area, but not drive here if it was out of the way.
author: Jen H.

description:
Not so lucky.

Far from a dumpling connoisseur. But the Har Gow (shrimp dumpling) was eaten and forgotten in less than a minute. What did I have again? Nothing memorable.

More optimism for the sweet rice chicken wrapped In lotus leaves. Lots of rice. Unconfirmed chicken parts. Not much post-meal optimism.

Small $3 investment to learn it's not worth three stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
My friend and I were starving and ventured out to the inner richmond for what she called her "secret dim sum hole in the wall".   It turns out, I'd been to this particular hole before!  So this review is many years overdue. 

Anyway, like I said, we were starving, and you know what that leads to? Massive over-ordering when you actually get to the food place.  I ended up with a bowl of congee and 3 orders of steamed BBQ buns, steamed dumplings, and sesame balls, enough for not one but two meals! And you know how much it cost me? $7.  

Yes, I will be back.
author: Janet Z.

description:
Saturday's Noon:

- Parking sucks within this area. It's like a mini Chinatown here. Bring coins for meter parkin
- Let me highlight this: DIM SUM TO GO with very limited tables. I thought it was a big fancy restaurant but nope. So grab a table while its empty and have someone line up for food.
- I can see why this place is so popular...it's CHEAP and GOOD. 3 pieces for $1.50. Not bad. We got 6 orders for 2 people and that filled us up for $12! They have almost everything here except for white noodles with shrimps. I only got the basic stuffs because I had no idea what's the name for everything else. 
- Steam BBQ PORK BUN: wow, 3 for just $1.50? I love the bbq pork inside, sweet and soft
- Lucky Ball: 1 for 60c. Not so great.
- Shrimp Dumpling: The dumpling skin was a bit too soggy
- Chicken Feet ($3.80/LB): The portion is big. I don't like it. They overcooked the FEET.
author: Phung D.

description: Best dim sum in town. Their egg tarts are amazing too. Ladies behind the counter are not the most patient if you are slow at all when you're up (talking 2-3 second delay), especially if you're not a chinese speaker, but the dim sum quality makes up for it.
author: Ellen R.

description:
I LOVE this place. One of the best dim sum places I've had. Cheap, fresh & delicious. 
It is not a sit down restaurants where they push around the carts. You fill out a piece of paper & tell them what you want at the counter.

They have my favorites: Chinese Chive Cakes and Chive/Shrimp dumplings. Not many places has these, and if they do, it's not as good as this place. 

The older ladies are kind of rude, but you should expect from most Asian restaurants with older ladies haha. I grew up with it, so I'm used to it and not marking them down for it. Its the norm.

I wish they were in SoCal =(
author: Janie L.

description: In the mood for Sunday afternoon dim sum and unwilling to brave the multi-hour wait required at a typical place, we ended up at this shop. While you don't get the excitement of the push carts or high touch service, you do get a good selection, large servings, and low prices. We got enough to easily feed four people for around $25. At 1:30pm the wait was minimal, definitely will try it again next time I have dim sum cravings.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
We had ventured in hoping to buy maybe some bbq pork buns and some sesame ball desserts.  Lo and behold, we got GOT by the crafty Cantonese ladies who kept pushing us to buy this and that.  

We ended up with:
1.  To-go lunch special spare ribs and rice with vegetables $2
2.  To-go lunch special chicken and rice with vegetables $2
3.  1 bbq pork baked bun (sub dollar range)
4.  3 sesame ball desserts (around $1.50?)
5.  Mochi stuffed with coconut and sweet pastes
6.  Shrimp ha gow

And whatever else they stuffed in my grandmas bag.  For 1.5 bags of items, the total came out to around $15.

The items that I had were all delicious, and the to-go rice plates are really a steal at $2.
author: Pauline M.

description:
If you're looking for large amounts of dim sum for a party look no further. I was looking to bring over some dim sum to a cinco de mayo party for a friend and didn't need look any further when I walked past this place. 

The folks that work here will not really understand your questions in english. So you should probably bring a translator if you need to ask something complicated. 

My order was 20 pork buns, 20 chicken sui mi, and 20 pot stickers (which are pork based). It seems that orders are in 7s, so they gave me 21 of each. I'm not sure I understood why but that was the deal. For that order I only spent $36 bucks. What a deal right? Cheaper than pizza ;).

Solid prices and rave reviews from the folks that ate at it at the party.

There are tables in the back of this place to eat but I wouldn't recommend it. Definitely NOT a date and normal restaurant experience.
author: Michael S.

description:
I LOVE this place.  LOVE IT!  Delicious and fresh.  You don't go for atmosphere, you go for the food.  
The prices are unbeatable.  While I tend to stay away from cash only places (too much hassle), I am willing to make the extra stop to the ATM before heading here.  $20 will get you an insane amount of food for three people. 
It's my go-to when running my weekend errands.
author: Rachel G.

description: The best item there is the Shrimp dim sum.  The other types of dim sum are bland or blah.  Their customer service is not the best.
author: P S.

description: Decent flavor but I didn't like how thick the wrappings are around the dumplings.  Seemed heavy handed and distracts from the flavors.  For simple dumplings, I still prefer Delicious Dim Sum in Chinatown on Jackson between Stockton and Grant.
author: Lev E.

description:
Food on the go.

Inexpensive and with nifty little pink slips you actually get to circle your choices without having to compete with the native speakers and get ignored, usually a consequence when I'm in Chinatown, despite my usual towering over the little old ladies.  WTF.  I'm Asian too, dammit!

Did the casual stroll with the fellow that I'm seeing and we decided to pick up a little dim sum prior to movie night.  I'm not big on large meals before sleepy time and prior to hitting the PS3 playing co-op on a full stomach is a big no-no.  Tsk tsk tsk.

Simple and non-pretentious.  We ordered close to 12 items and all under $6-7.  A deal, especially in this recession.  Our faves were the pork shumai, mini steamed pork buns, and the har gow.  The beef shumai, not so much, a little too porous like a sponge.

In addition, there are tables in the back for an actual sit down and a clean restroom in the back if the time calls.  

Located on the strip and easy access along Clement.
author: Miika M.

description:
When I walked in this place, the line was pretty darn long but boy were they fast on the go. Next thing I knew it was my turn yay! I got three Pork Shu Mai, Beef Shu Mai, Har Gow (shrimp dumplings) and Steamed BBQ Pork Buns.

The pork bun was soft on the outside and delicious inside. Overall the pork, beef and har gow were tasty good and a perfect match for the pork buns.

I'd say this restaurant is fairly small with several eat in tables. For the most part, folks ordered to go.

Their pricing is fairly simple and cheap. For 22 different dim sum varieties, which included bun items, they charged 3 pieces for 1.60, .65 each for dessert items and offered a la carte pricing for the rest.  

For six dollars and forty cents, I'm happy and stuffed as an alley cat!...
author: Gary E.

description: Nice selection of dim sum. Cheap and delicious! When the dim sum is hot it is top notch.
author: Dimitri S.

description: Cheap dim sum that's amazingly good. The shrimp dumplings taste very fresh, the chive dumpling is great when freshly fried and I really like the chicken bun, actually. I also like the fried taro dumpling but I feel like my throat is dying after eating all that crispy goodness. The siu mai isn't great but I'm really not complaining because everything else is gooooood. Seriously, come here with 10 dollars, get more food than you can finish.
author: Ruobin W.

description: The line moves fast. You can get 3 pieces of dim sum here for $2.00. Cheap but good. Nothing fancy just some good o' fashion har gow and siu mai here. You can't beat their prices and the quality here. That is where the extra star comes in. The neighborhood has tons of dim sum joint but this one is the only one with the line. Tip: you should ask for hot sauce. They will give you a to go container to pour it out.
author: Wendy L.

description:
As an Oaklander, I pretty much have my steez down in my town, but there are some things for which one must cross the bridge-- one of them being DIM SUM!

Good Luck isn't a fancy place...in fact, it's hardly a sit-down place!  A few tables are crammed into the back, and you order from a line.  It's busy (at least on a Sunday afternoon), but that keeps the food moving and FRESH.  Everything was hot and delicious.  Taste-wise, nothing was too greasy or salty, considering that it's dim sum and it comes with the territory.

Egg rolls, shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, and other nondescript ground vege-meats wrapped in boiled, baked, and/or fried pastry (you know, dim sum!) were all amazing.  My friend and I just haphazardly circled thing...it's all good.  What you need to get is the chive cake thing (from the middle-section of the menu. Trust me, I'm a doctor.

Cash only.  Prices are $1.70 for the 3-for items, with $0.70 and $1.00 single-items available.

Screw sitting inside, just walk north a few blocks to Presidio Park and eat your lunch on the damned ground!  Halfway in-between there and GG Park, it's a great little spot and a great little Richmond sub-hood (I've heard people call it Little China Town....is that a thing?).

Anyways, it's very easy to get in, get some good dim sum and get out.  No long lines/wait or dining rooms crammed full of families and screaming, dirty children, or waiting on carts with limited selection of lukewarm traveling food sloughing about.  This place is 100x better than most of the sit-down spots that appear more "quality."

GOOD LUCK!
author: Sam R.

description:
Darn good dim sum out of the restaurants. 
Their haam shui gook is the best I ever had. Other dim sum food were pretty good too.

The sad part = far from China town and sometimes they are sold out of certain things. But still a fan
author: Jade L.

description: What's the biggest problem here? I came at around 12:30 and most of the food I ordered, and I ordered a good amount, was lukewarm to cold. I mean about 80% of the food I ordered so it wasn't that great. Now the food that was hot, was really good. But if they're not going to keep their food hot, why would I ever come back? Sure, you can get the food to go and reheat it back at home but no dim sum is ever as good reheated so I was really amazed at how many people were getting food to go. Maybe I've just eaten at too many dim sum restaurants. Oh wait, I have.
author: Dang N.

description:
This place serves good dim sum for a killer price....you really can't beat the amount you get for the value. And some of the items were unbelievably good, while others merely average.  

So, while sitting at a little table next to a towering stack of pink take-out boxes, I was all set to give this place a 3 star rating, possibly even 4, until I saw one particular item on the menu: Shark Fin Dumplings.  As many as 73 million sharks a year are killed for their fins and, I'm sorry but I can't, in good conscience, recommend a place that serves up shark fin dumplings.  Its an unsustainable food source and, I think, very irresponsible of restaurants to still be serving it.  Luckily the California Assembly voted recently to ban the sale, possession and distribution of shark fins, so hopefully this will be coming off the menu soon and I can return and update my review with a higher rating.
author: Ian W.

description: They have the best baked and steamed BBQ pork buns! And cheap too. You can get 3 for $2, and they are huge filled with lots of meat. Their custard is awesome too but I usually just get the bbq buns.
author: Vol T.

description:
This is not the fancy Dim Sum you seek;
there are no young waitresses with qipao gowns,
nor waiters pouring you Jasmin tea.

This is not the fancy Dim Sum you crave;
no shark fin soup, no swallow nest,
no PETE WELLS marks this place HIS FAVE.

This is not the fancy Dim Sum you desire;
no steam carts in the aisles, no bamboo baskets,
you'll have to circle your order on a pink flyer.


Not at all, but...
this is the Dim Sum I sought,
this is the Dim Sum I craved,
this is the Dim Sum I desired,
this is the Dim Sum I thought,
"Can I order a million to go?"
author: Kuanyu C.

description:
I come here for the entertainment!  The ladies treat you like the scumbag you are when you tell them to go, but sit down (you're wasting their box which they charged you for); ask for something else after you've paid and feel the need to cut into the long line.  Don't get it twisted...they speak English and if you piss em off, she'll rip you a new a$$hole the size of my fav sweet rice bun!  Try it...it's really entertaining.

Must devour - sweet rice buns, chicken siu mai, chicken buns.  I never leave here w/o the sweet rice buns.  When I see them I envision myself mouth wide open and one of the sweet ladies throwin em at my face.  It's real good!  Chewy casing on the outside lovingly surrounds rice, shrimp, herbs (cilantro?) providing solace to my grumbling tummy.  I've never had anything like it and I crave for it...shivering, sweating kinda craving.

Where else will you find cheap, tasty dim sum served up by an all woman dim sum posse?
author: D C.

description:
I absolutely adore Good Luck, the glimmering crowned jewel amidst the little dim sum hole-in-the-walls sprinkled throughout the Richmond District. I saunter (and by saunter I mean sprint) down to Clement Street every weekend for a tradition my roommates and I like to call "Dim Sunday."

Potstickers! Shrimp and chive dumplings! Steamed pork buns! Sui mai! Sesame balls! This is one of the few hot spots left in our exorbitantly priced city where you can escape under $5 flat for a completely hunger-satisfying AND scrumptious meal. 

I love bringing out-of-towners here to experience a real SF treat as well. In this price range, it is hands-down the best dim sum in a city that touts excellent Chinese food. The items on the menu range from adventurous to safe, so don't be afraid to stop by. There's a steamed or fried (your choice!) piece of dumpling heaven at Good Luck for everyone. Leftovers not guaranteed.
author: Meredith C.

description: I walked from the Embarcadero BART (4.5 miles) with luggage and was starving.  I ordered $5.20 worth of shrimp dumplings (2 orders) and pot stickers.  I couldn't finish all nine dumplings I got right away, but they were super yummy.  A great way to celebrate a fine day.
author: Margaret W.

description: Definitely cheaper than most dimsum restaurant. Terrible service( her I mean the attitude when they face customer).
author: Stanley T.

description: My friends K and P tried this place on my yelpy recommendation! I'm real happy about that.  Please keep in mind that 's it's a total hole in the wall, but the food is cheap and very good quality for what you are paying for, and apparently the place has a good cleanliness rating as well!  I recently went back for a yummy snack.  Since I no longer live in SF, I sat in the back to enjoy my shrimp dumplings and sticky rice.  They do charge for just about anything extra (tea, cups for tea or water...) but seriously for the price of the food, a buck or two for these things doesn't really add up.   Man I miss dim sum in the city.
author: Shinny L.

description: I like to compare dim sum places by my favorite dish: steamed BBQ pork buns. Here they have a nice ratio of bread to meat, but it's very very glutinous. It didn't taste like savory meat with sauce. It tasted like sauce, with some meat in it. I will admit the shrimp dumplings are excellent.
author: Christine L.

description:
My favorites are their pork and thousand year egg porridge, shrimp dumplings, fried taro balls (anything fried is delicious, really), and egg tarts. I don't like their steamed or baked pork buns. They personally leave a strange aftertaste in my mouth, but that's not just specific to Good Luck Dim Sum. Their prices are cheap and while I wouldn't travel far to get here, if you're in the neighborhood and need a quick snack or quick lunch while you walk around, then this is a good spot to consider given their reasonable prices and relatively fast service. Their lines can get long, but it's almost always less than a 10 minute wait. 

Accessibility: They have an ample sitting area with multiple tables and a bathroom that's relatively clean and spacious (no key needed). Wheelchair accessible.
author: Mico G.

description: This is the place for the best tasting siomai in this area, simply delicious. The only negative thing about it is that they would tend to give you the old ones especially if you ordered for to go.
author: Lance I.

description: The chives dumplings are really yummy but the chicken sui mai were cold. They even ran out of the shark fin dumplings and the crystal dumplings at like 4ish. It's a nice place to go if you want dim sum out of no where.
author: Susan L.

description: The food here is good but the two ladies at the counter are so rude. Don't want to go back again and see their faces - bitches!
author: Khin L.

description: 5 stars because it is the best dim sum for the price you pay. The workers move quickly so there is not too much congestion, I highly recommend this place.
author: Shaneel A.

description:
I would rank Good Luck Dim Sum as the best of the "Ultra Affordable" category of dim sum. The food to dollar ratio is out of this country! But "what about quality?" you may ask. Well, it's meh+.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/o8mLw7SrcTPis4NcvLzsOw?select=46tCc61VPx3yNeaZ18n_Xg

Don't come here expecting amazing food or even pretty good food. Here you'll get a little more than you pay for, which is perfectly fine. Service was a little below meh, and the dumpling lady didn't give us one of the things we kind of pointed at, but not really her fault since we pointed at everything. 

Would I come back? If I needed to feed a mob, yes. If it was just me and my wife again, probably not.
author: Eli G.

description:
If you're looking for good, cheap, and fast, then go here!

I mean it. For realsies! 

The good- the seasame balls, the mini chicken buns, and shrimp bao buns!

The cheap- almost everything is less than a dollar each, if not 3 for $1.75- Wow!

The fast- there's a line on the weekends, but with the five chinese ladies working behind the counter- one never will be in line for more than 5 minutes. 

Done!
author: C M.

description: This place sux.  The lady who served me was  old and miserable.  The dim sum was cold and not even good at all.  I was eating here with anger and not love
author: Vincent L.

description: Great to go standards like ha grow, pork shew Mai, bbq pork steamed bow, taro and sesame fried balls.  Pot stickers had really thick skins, I'll pass on them next time.  Mom liked the steamed chive dumplings.  Once you get in the door, look for a checklist pile on the counter and bring a pen with you so you can get in line and make your choices. Sales ladies prefer you mark how many orders per item and circle your choices, than confuse them with the number of pieces you're looking for.  Bags are a dime extra but pretty sturdy and reusable.  Overall a solid 4 stars for quick and easy takeout and reheat at home dim sum...and lots cheaper than eating at the Hong Kong Lounge up the street.  Street parking can be a pain so get there as early in the morning as you can.
author: D R.

description:
I'm not a dim sum connoisseur at all, so I'll just write about how the process worked and some stupid mistakes I made. Hopefully you aren't stupid like me.

It was a long line with a mixed group of people. So I knew it wouldn't be THAT great. You know if dim sum or any asian restaurant is great when the customers are all Asians. That's just a theory.

They have pink menus that tell you the prices and types of dim sum both in chinese and english. It wasn't very helpful because the english was just the pronunciation of the Chinese words. I circled what I thought sounded good (all I know are the shrimp dumplings, pork bun, and siu mai).  

Now, on the top it says something like "3 for $1.60." Yeah, I thought it meant 3 pieces of something, so 1 piece of siu mai, 1 pork bun, and 1 piece of shrimp dumpling. I thought that was a great deal! Because I'm a total noob (read my first sentence) I enthusiastically circled the items I wanted and enumerated them with how many I wanted. When my order came out, I knew I wasn't going to be having dinner. My 2 orders of siu mai was not 2, but 6. Duh. And that was just the beginning. I could have fed a family of 4. 

Would I come back? Probably not. There are so many other dim sum places in SF, and I want to explore as many as possible.
author: Hong L.

description: Good luck is one of two places close to my heart for fresh cheap dim sum. The place isn't elegant and the staff behind the counter have this tired indifference but the dim sum is pretty knock on. Crystal dumpling, har gow, steamed pork buns the best I've tasted. You can see them making the dumplings in the back. Sometimes a line but always fast moving
author: Matt A.

description:
This place is nice because it's ultra cheap, tastes fresh, has great flavor, and has a place to sit.

The dining area is pretty spartan (empty soy sauce and chili bottles during our visit) and we had to "pre-clean" our table.

When we brought the food to our little corner, we quickly devoured every last bite.
