How can you complain when two adults can get full on good food for just - $13.

Winner winner dim sum dinner!
author: Richard H.

description: Poor customer service. Standing dead center at the counter, two different servers took the orders of two persons who came in after us first.  We will never return.  Anyways they put MSG in their food so no loss.  There's other places to choose from nearby.
author: Hermann C.

description:
Great Chinese food.

Each meal starts with hot tea and a spicy seaweed dish.

The cumin beef was quite spicy, but not so spicy that it overwhelmed the other favors. The meat was incredibly tender. Definitely a great dish if you like spicy food.

The rice that came with the meal was perfectly cooked. Perhaps my favorite part of the meal.

Staff was friendly and attentive, though a misunderstanding due to language barrier led to an incorrect dish. Not a problem, though, it was chicken and vegetables and delicious.

Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but certainly a great place.
author: Jonathon W.

description:
This dim sum was cheap, but OK. I got the pork siu mai, fried rice dumplings, chives dumplings, shrimp dumplings, chives rice bun, and the baked bbq pork bun. Of all of them, the best was the chives dumplings because it was a good ratio of filling to skin, the chives were fresh, and the dumpling was warm. Everything else was lukewarm. The pork siu mai were a mess, basically falling apart. The soy sauce that are on the tables helped make everything taste a bit better.

Definitely not the best dim sum I've had in my life, but I guess it was ok for carry out. Probably will not be back unless I just happen to be in the area with only $2 for food.
author: Anqi Y.

description: This is my to go place on any given day!!! The wait in line is worth the amt. of good food being served...LOVE IT!
author: Sharrie N.

description: Delicious dimsum is way better than this place. We came here around 2.30 pm and it was very cold and dim sum at delicious was hot even at 4.00 pm and it tasted better too. Not coming back here ever again
author: Rintu M.

description: Soooooooooooo good!! There's a reason why there is always a line of people here no matter what time of day you come. Everything I've tried here is good: shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings, sesame balls, bbq pork buns, and of course egg tarts! Some of the food is a bit oily, but I guess that's what makes it taste so good. The prices are amazing :) Props to the women who work so hard everyday.
author: Ji L.

description: If you're visiting the City and are craving dimsum, this is the place to go! I suggest grabbing a box and heading to one of the beaches close by!
author: Kim Celine G.

description: Not as good as dim sum in other restaurants...and I've been to dozens of dim sum places.  Here, the pieces lacked flavor, dumplings were a bit gummy, and the line for ordering was a bit chaotic.  Wouldn't recommend.
author: Native S.

description: Everything here is great!  I love the porridge and pork buns.  We drive in from Marin for this.  There is another Dim Sum Bakery two doors down and even when there are 20 people in line here no one thinks to go next door, this is too good.
author: Ed A.

description:
The dim sum here is kind of dry, also it's hyped up so they charge more than other places in the area.

It was still dirt cheap though. I got 3 shu mais, 3 dumplings, a big rice bun thing with meat inside, and an egg tart for $4.80. Unreal!  

I think if I were back in the area I wouldn't try so hard to come here, but rather just go to the closest dim sum place near me. I doubt this one is anything special compared to the others.
author: Monika L.

description: We've been eating here for 20 years.  My daughter has grown up looking forward to coming here as a special treat.  Although the prices have gone up over the years, it is still one of the best deals around.  The dumplings are large, filled with quality ingredients, and are made fresh all day.  The egg tarts are huge, and the pastry is delicious. The only minor complaint I have is that they close up shop and go on vacation together once a year.  I never can remember when that is (some time in April), and I invariably show up, dying for dim sum, only to find the place closed for a week.
author: Allison W.

description: Busy place on Clement. I've been coming here for nearly two decades, and this place has yet to disappoint. Except the last time I was there, when it was closed for vacation. :-(
author: Nancy W.

description:
Since Clement St Bakery's quality has dropped this has become my new go to place for cute pink boxes filled with yummy goodness. 

The lines get long and the ladies in the front are curt as hell but keep your cool, don't let folks cut and fill out the card and keep an eye out because some of the ladies will add extras and charge you.
author: Jade W.

description:
My grandfather loved this place so I have been coming here since I was a kid. Funny that not a thing has changed.

Tips:
- Cash only
- Go early for fresher food and to beat the rush.
- There are tables to eat inside but people typically order to-go.
- Not the highest quality, but dim sum is good and cheap. Most items are 3 for 1.60
- The ladies here are unfriendly and will probably be mean to you. Deal with it.
- Know what you want to order before you get up to the counter.
- There is usually a long, slow moving line during busy times.

What to Order:
Har gow (shrimp dumpling), siu mai (pork dumpling), char siu bao (bbq pork bun), dan tat (egg custard tart)
author: Ashley K.

description: Well deserving of their zagat rating.  Prices are very reasonable.   Quality is high.   Porridge is outstanding, if you arrive early enough ...
author: earl w.

description:
The lines were long when we got here around 10am, got longer while we waited in line. You grab a menu and circle which items you want while you wait in line. The place is really small and packed, especially when the cooks go up and down the aisle back and forth bringing dim sum. Also more pple coming in and out.....busy busy busy.

We got a pretty decent amount of food for the price, 16 bucks thats including drinks. (pork shui mai, chicken , shui mai, egg rolls, bbq baked buns, har gow, shrimp and chives bonnet, coconut rice puff, pot stickers and drinks).

The dim sum was okay to me, maybe because it was a little cold and needed to be heated. The only thing that was piping hot was our potstickers. The only complaint I had was the really really dark soy sauce...it just didn't taste right. 

If you plan to come here, come early in the morning, be ready to order and expect to wait.
author: Sandy N.

description:
this is NOT a date place. it resembles any chinese bakery. it has a couple of tables here and there. 

I came on a wednesday afternoon and I chose this day to come for a reason! Little to no line :)!

The price is REALLY cheap!!! ~$18 to completely fill two hungry people! 

I tried basically everything on the menu and I loved the pork shumai, shrimp and leek dumplings, baked bbq pork bun. 

I ate in the store and I'm pretty sure their soy sauce is weird ... some of the dishes were served a bit cold but hey, good price still!

* parking: I parked at a meter, 1 hr for $2 right in front of the store.
author: Dixie L.

description: The egg yolk bun and xiao long bao are not authentic. The egg yolk bun was literally an egg yolk with bun and the xiao long bao had a pao bun instead of the dumpling skin. Do not order lucky ball, unless you want to play baseball with it. But very cheap if you're on a tight budget.
author: Xin L.

description:
"I like dim sum, but it's too expensive", my boyfriend's brother lamented as I made Sunday dimsum plans. Little did he know, he was in for some inexpensive Good Luck.

Which is something I rarely have, because I'm always late. If you want Good Luck DimSum, show up before 2+ in the afternoon because you're going to have your heart broken. Everything you ask for will be gone, eaten gleefully by some phenomenally satisfied person who showed up at 10. That bastard ate all the taro cakes, the potstickers, the sumai, the pork buns (steamed and baked), the wonderful shrimp dishes, the lotus wraps. I drink a Vitasoy and eat whatever they have left and it's still great.

I can only imagine how amazing it would be if I could wake up. If you're more awake than me, don't deprive yourself. Just once, I'll let you be the guy who eats everything before me. 

Oh, bring Cash. Only. You won't need much of it. A Jackson can easily feed 3 or 4.
author: Liuyin S.

description:
Simply the best in the city.

I will gladly travel all the way to the inner richmond just for their tasty treats of gluten awesomeness that is dim sum.

Price is so cheap, as it should be.

I hate how people rag on the service, its not what this place is about. Its about the best for the best price. All they want is to give you dim sum and go on to the next person. They are extremely popular and sometimes it gets crazy with the amount of customers in there. Yeah you can sit in the back, but you shouldn't be expecting to much out of the busy staff. They got things to do.

The earlier you go the fresher the dim sum.
author: Pita Q.

description:
best shumai in town. Super meaty and juicy.

If your just to-going some dim sum or stoppin by for a quick bite then this is the place.
Add a vitasoy to complete your meal
author: Kent T.

description: The prices here are unbelievably cheap and the food quality is excellent! I loved the har gow flavour, easily on par with the ones in Hong Kong. Only downside is the service was rather poor and the servers would respond to your needs very slowly and curtly.
author: Sherry G.

description:
I love this place. It's best to get there early though, because the lines are crazy around lunch time. Basically everything there is delicious, ha gao, siu mai, chicken skewers, potstickers, pork buns, you name it! They always have giant trays of everything, and if they run out, the kitchen staff comes out with more in just a few short minutes. I love buying lunch here on the weekends because it's cheap and absolutely delicious.

Parking around here sucks though. It's easiest to park a couple blocks away and make a short walk, or just take the bus.
author: KC W.

description:
I absolutely adore this place.

My 3rd trip to San Fran, and 3rd time is the charm! I'm so thankful for my friend who  lives in SF to introduce us to this place...love it.

Living in Houston, I'm used to good and cheap Chinese food. But man, there's nothing like Good Luck here in Houston. There needs to be though.

HOW IT WORKS:

You line up and order what you what on a sheet of paper. The line is usually pretty long (so I've heard), but we went on a Sunday morning at like 9am, and there was really no line. Guess people are too lazy to wake up that early on the weekend, eh? You then hand your piece of paper to one of the workers there, and she'll get your order for you. You get it right there and then before they serve the next person. You then pay at the counter, and have the option to either eat in the restaurant or take it to go. Most people took their order to go, but there were about 6 tables there (4 chairs each) for customers to sit and enjoy their food. 
Con: No waiter/waitress. Pro: No tip! 


PRICES ($$CASH ONLY$$):

Everything is SO cheap. Most of the items are 3 pieces for $1.50, and some individual items are like 60-75 cents each, and the most expensive item is $2 each (but huge portion!). Milk tea was only $1! I went with my friend, and the two of us ordered a total of $15 worth of items, and we DEFINITELY over-ordered. My friend was a big guy too...and tends to have a big appetite (loves Cici's Pizza and all sorts of buffets). We still couldn't finish everything after stuffing our faces. 

FOOD:

The food was pretty delicious. I wouldn't call it the best tasting, but it was about average. (Houston spoils me). There are lots of options, ranging from congee to xiao long bao to mini hot dog buns to sweet rice cakes. And the portion is huge!

PARKING:

There's only street parking. It might be tough to find a spot, but I would just circle around...and keep circling around. Haha. Just grab a friend with you and tell him to keep circling as you run in to buy. Most people tend to just walk there, which is not a bad idea. :)

I wish I lived in SF so I can go to this place more often. Maybe it's a good thing that I don't, or else I'd end up like a piggy. 

Houston needs a Good Luck Dim Sum!
author: Molly S.

description: Waking into this place, I got a sense of urgency from the rep working there. That should have been my first red flag. This place had rude people working there, terrible tasting food, and no parking near by. Avoid at all cost. Btw, they only take cash... Not even going to waste my time on this review, not worth it guys, a million better places to eat here.
author: Rajan V.

description: This place is very inexpensive and definitely a no frills restaurant--very bare bones and small. Also, you just order at the counter as this is not a dim sum place where little carts go around. I had the pork buns (which were too sweet and too bready) and yummy potstickers. I would recommend getting food to go here, because dining in was not very appetizing for me. Twice big disgustingly dirty garbage cans (the kind that go out on the street) were wheeled through the restaurant right by my table. Having to smell stinky garbage and looking at dirty and sticky garbage cans while eating was so disgusting I had to take my food to go to try to eat later on.
author: Natalia K.

description: It was delicious. The lady who took my order was friendly too. Great experience. The shrimp dim sum was super fresh. Amazing find.
author: Ana Maria R.

description: Some of the best and cheapest dim sum in the city! Not very many tables in the back, so most people get it to go (which is still just as good). Tried a variety of items such as the pork buns, pork siu mai, shrimp dumplings, shrimp and chive dumplings. The pork buns are like PILLOWS. Definitely come here to get your dim sum fix if you can't squeeze in the whole dim sum/sit down/carts everywhere experience.
author: Caitlin M.

description: A feast for less than $20 (though bring your cash!). IMO the dumplings were better than the buns, but overall this place is great.
author: Tini T.
Lia B.

description:
Great place, very cheap.  Every time I come, there's always a line.  I was surprised it was Zagat rated.  It's strictly cash-only and take-out.

The food is great here, even better than some restaurants!
author: Wally W.

description: Like everyone mentioned, you can't go wrong with '3 dimsums for $1.70' though. However, for that $1.70 you pay, the dim sums were pretty cold and left out, even the BBQ bun. I like how its super cheap but I rather pay for some good dim sum elsewhere.
author: Mary S.

description: Good Luck Dim Sum is yummy and affordable. I love the shrimp har gow--very tasty. It's a great place to get takeout dim sum for a picnic or snack. You can definitely fill everyone up without spending a lot.
author: Lia W.

description: Me and my friends got FOOD POISONING. Place looked ghetto, I should have known. Just how I wanted to end my holiday.
author: Debbie C.

description: Great quality, reasonable price, freshly made dimsum place.  In the begining, we did not like it since the ambiance was a bit to outdated, it lowered our appetite.  But these days, we pack them and enjoy at home.
author: Sam A.

description:
We came in with a group of 8 to try this place since reviews were good. We picked a few items of everything for a good healthy pickings of everything. 75% of the food we ordered was cold and was apparently left out in the open for a long time. We were all Extremely disappointed and  kept bringing back different items for them to heat up and in a 
disgusting little microwave that hasn't been cleaned in a long time. Perhaps this is a decent place if ur ordering dim sum to go and plan on resteaming everything.
author: Howard Y.

description: i think...good luck used to be better. iono... but $1.90 for 3 pieces of pretty delicious dim sum is still amazing. and everything is really fresh because there is ALWAYS a line of some sort, doesnt matter if it's saturday or monday or wednesday before closing. i kinda prefer wing sing over this, and also the shop down the street with the black sesame (i know, not super specific..)...
author: Christina L.

description: Blink and you might miss this store front- but if you see the long line of people, then you are in the right place.  The siu mai here was huge and an awesome deal at 3 for $1.77.  But this isn't you're ordinary siu mai, these are easily double the size and by the juiciest siu mai I have ever had.  I also sampled char xiu bao, pineapple bun (without custard), leek dumplings, and har gow.  All was decent but the siu mai was definetely the best.  They also had porridge with the preserved black duck egg which I would love to try the next time I am there.  The only reason I am giving this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because after my purchased- I went back to ask for soy sauce and was deliberately ignored for a good 10 minutes- only to be handed 1 packet for my entire order.
author: Betty L.

description:
Cheap, decent quality, nothing spectacular.
Good value for the month.

Yank Sing, Cityview, etc are definitely better quality wise.
author: Ellen H.

description:
I might have to come back another time to verify this rating. Good luck dim sum has a whole lot of reviews compared to all of the other tiny dim sum places nearby and I have yet to figure out why.

Everything of course is really cheap and pretty good, but nothing stood out to me...except their selection of chinese teas/drinks in the fridge is worth mentioning. We got a pretty good variety of steamed and fried dim sum (all the staples of course). My favorite was the hargaw shrimp dumplings. The skins weren't too thick and they were nice and hot. What disappointed me was the porridge! I heard it could be a hit or miss on different days...but I had to say it was no where near as flavorful as jook time's porridge.

Overall, pretty good place for some quick...or not so quick depending on the line..dim sum but I would definitely come back. For about $10 we had enough food to stuff 2 people (plus drinks!)
author: Stine H.

description:
Decent dim sum at cheap-ish prices. The wait in line is approx 5-10 minutes long (at least when I was there). 

The woman behind the counter that helped me was really b*tchy. But that's the case with most dim sum places like this
author: Welmond C.

description: Stopped by this place the other day because I was in the are and was craving some steamed pork buns. I was not disappointed at all, the selection was amazing and the pricing was awesome. I definitely recommend this place for some good dim sum.
author: Martin F.

description: One of the few places I get dim sum in the city. Had even drove around 6am for some dim sum one day. Luckily it takes an hour to get there where I live and they open at 7am. Can't get enough of them and wished they were closer to where I live.
author: E R.

description: The food was really good, especially for the price.  The customer service, however, was absolutely horrid.  My friends and I came at a time not too busy, and they kept rushing us for the order and making fun of us in cantonese.  We did not feel welcomed whatsoever.  Would never come again.
author: Jack Y.

description: My faves here are the shrimp dumplings and rice in leaf package. The pork buns remind me of my childhood and the pork dumplings are quite large. The sesame balls are crispy and soft and rich in flavor. The Malay cakes are appropriately light in flavor and very authentic. Beware you will get fast paced service and they won't take your sub par Cantonese seriously. Cash only, great prices. A filling breakfast for one can be as low as $2.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Dim sum at it's cheapest yet finest. The dim sum here is great. It's not too oily and has a lot of flavor. You can get your order in quick and get out with your food quick. Sometimes the workers can seem rude, but it's just that they're trying to get you your meal as fast as you can. I don't mind that at all. 

The dim sum itself is a perfect size. Sometimes, the dim sum at restaurants is too small, but at take out places, I find they are too big, like the dim sum is on steroids. In this case, quantity does not equal quality. It's just quality. 

My parents are from San Jose, but my sister lives in San Francisco. Anytime they come up, Good Luck Dim Sum is a must go stop for them. I think that says a lot about this place.
author: Andy V.

description:
friends picked up boxes to go for the game and once they returned we jumped on it like a pack of hungry wolves

food is super cheap and the quality is alright.. i wouldn't come back on my own free will
author: Raquel T.

description: The line all day is worth the wait.  I wouldn't go anywhere else for dimsum.
author: Erika S.

description:
If I am willing to wait 20 mins in line to get my dim sum from this place then you better believe its gonna be good. I like ordering the Jok because they add green onions and crispy wonton strips, which other places don't do. The pot stickers are massive, quite tasty, and have a good squishy to crunch ratio. The Shark Fin is drool worthy. Just good eats all around and for cheap! Another reason why I love this place is that I don't get a headache after consuming all their yummy food, which is GREAT!

Clement + Dim Sum Bakery  - Headache = Good Luck Dim Sum!

Score!!
author: Theresa D.

description: In the neighborhood and wanted a snack.  Decided to hit a couple of these dim sum shops.  Here, we got one piece each of the taro pork, shrimp/ pork, shrimp cilantro dumplings.  Disappointed.  It was barely warm, the skin is way too thick, it was greasy and the filling in all three were very much alike.
author: Gloria H.

description: Great bang for the buck.
author: Ray L.

description: Can't go wrong with 3 items for $1.70. The dim sum is fresh, cheap, warm and delicious. We usually get the shiu mai, har gow and char siu bun. Their Sweet rice with chicken wrapped in banana leaves is very fragrant and also today just tried their egg tart which was also delicious. Altogether, for a party of two, our lunch came out to around 6 dollars. Fresh food and the best hole in the wall dim sum place in SF in my opinion.
author: Ellin C.

description:
Needing to put out the Caveat that this is by far one of the better places for take out Dim Sum, IF, you come during their peak hours during the afternoon.
If you come late in the day do not expect any where near the quality that you can expect when the kitchen is busy and trying to keep up with demand.

For me its about sticking to the popular dumplings like the Har Gow Shrimp Dumplings, Deep Fried Taro, and the Steamed Pork Buns.
But also love their other steamed dumplings and some of their other steamed rolls, and at $1.70, for an order of 3 whats not to like about well made Fresh Dim Sum ! 

About the Steamed Pork Buns, the filling is well spiced, and has a much higher quality filling then some of the other shops on the street.

This is a Take Out place for me, but if taking it back to work, or going to a park don't forget to get a small container so you can make a dipping sauce with the Soy Sauce & Chili Sauce they keep on the tables. (FYI : They use Dark not Light Soy On The Tables, if you need Light ask for Packets ! )

Again , come when busy, and buy those things that are moving quickly, and you should have a good experience if you come here for Take Out!
author: Joseph A.

description:
I was at Good Luck Dim Sum on a Saturday. There were five ladies working at the counter; I was about the 10th customer in line for take-outs.  I finally made it to the front after 30 minutes and the server took another 5+ minutes just to fill my order of about 8 items....not acceptable!  The servers were more focused on conversing with each other than attending to their customers.

The beef meat ball, taro cake, coconut mochie and shrimp dumplings were good.  The ratio of meat to bread on the baked pork bun was disproportionate, rendering the dough tasteless.  The tamale was decent in size, but it lacked filling and flavor.  They sold out of spareribs with black bean sauce over rice (sold out at noon??), so I tried their chicken/sausage over rice.  That too, lacked flavor; the rice was undercooked, and the chicken was too well done and dry.

I've had good and less-than-desirable dim sum throughout the Bay Area; this place is just mediocre.   I expect this type of quality in the suburbs, but not in the "new Chinatown" district of SF.  For take-outs, a better option is TC Pastry. You can literally drive to TC Pastry in the Sunset, pick up your order, come back to Good Luck Dim Sum and you'll still see the same people in line (no exaggeration).  The prices are comparable, but the quality, service and queue are far better at TC Pastry for a casual dim sum take-out establishment.

Pros:  Good variation of dim sum selection.  Price is very reasonable.   They do have several tables if you choose to dine in.
Cons:  Lack courtesy and speed in service.  Several of the items lacked flavor.  Parking can be a challenge depending on time of day; be sure to have at least 45 minutes on the meter during peak time!

Since there is no two-and-a-half stars rating, I am giving it an overall 3 stars for the "ok" quality food and substandard service.
author: Jean T.

description:
You really just have know to what you're expecting when you come here.  It's definitely more of a take-out place than anything.  Be prepared to write down on that paper menu what it is that you want, and you'd be all set.  

The line was pretty long even at 10:30 in the morning on a Sunday.  At $1.70 per 3 piece order, the price is definitely right.  Food is on par with other sit-down restaurants.  They have all the essential dim sum dishes, and everything that I tried was solid.  There is one exception.  The "Little Dragon" buns aren't quite right - they're typically the soup dumplings but these are more like mini meat and veggies buns.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I thought to myself, almost 300 reviews and a 4 star average? I've got to get me sum good luck dim sum.

It lived up to its expectations when it came to price, three people were fed for less than $30 bucks of what it would of been an $80+ meal at a standard dim sum restaurant.

It lived up to its expectations as it is freshly made and had a original Cantonese dim sum flavor.

Some of our food was room temperature, slightly disappointed in the lack of heat as I usually like my food piping hot, maybe we got there too late?

They had several Shiu-Mai's and a variety of bao's.

I would go back if I had some sort of time sheet so I know when they shrimp Ha-Gao's are hot off the steamer, and if I only had $0.85 cents in my pocket, that may buy me 8 dishes.
author: Dave K.

description: Great value for the price and the ladies behind the counter are extra special. I go here often.
author: Joe F.

description:
This is like crack.

I ordered so much food that the woman asked me if I wanted two forks. I know, gwailo. I ate the whole thing. 5/5 would stuff face again.
author: Ben M.

description: Good Luck Dim Sum...yes, GOOD LUCK GETTING DECENT DIM SUM HERE! The food is crap, crap, crap. I have no freakin' idea why this place has such a high rating! Upon walking in, no one even bothered to acknowledge our existence; on top of that, food is ordered at the counter and everything looks fresh and hot, but is cold and disgusting. We were so disappointed with the food that we ended up throwing everything away because we couldn't stomach it. The place itself looks dirty. Yikes. Avoid like the plague!
author: Jamie D.

description:
I've been coming to this spot since I was a kid, my parents love ordering trays and trays of dim sum here for parties or family gathering.  I have continued their tradition and any time I have parties at work, I will usually get goodies from here. My coworkers all love it, they actually look forward to their dim sum each time we have a party.  One time they were closed for vacation and I had to order from elsewhere and trust me, my coworkers were all so disappointed. 

For a grab and go dim sum shop, the taste and quality is pretty solid, even better than some of the spots in Chinatown. Give their beef shu mai, pork with veggie dumplings, sticky rice balls, or har gow a try...all pretty delicious!  I'm not a big fan of bbq pork buns in general, but I see people order those by the boxes!

Don't be intimated when the line goes out the door though, the ladies behind the counter are pretty efficient at getting people in and out of there quick.  However, they can get a bit rude and impatient so be sure to grab one of their pink menus and figure out what you want while waiting in line.  If you like egg tarts and get there early enough on the weekends, they even have a "special" egg tart made from only milk + egg whites.  :)  This is the only spot I know of that sells these aside from HK.

Closed on Tuesday, but definitely a place worth checking out if you are in the area.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Solid Dim Sum. Know what you want to order, have your cash ready, and enjoy. 

They have some special, maybe house made, really dark soy sauce that I enjoyed. Also, remember that this is a local, one step above hole in the wall place so don't expect the Ritz Carlton when you get here.
author: Karmelo N.

description:
This is your go-to dive dim sum place. We fed a hungry foursome on 20 bucks with plenty to spare, including the chicken feet that no one really ate. I'm not sure if they're supposed to taste like that, but I won't be getting them again if they are. 

Not the most high quality food or the best atmosphere, but it's somewhat clean and bright, and with food piled high on a tray you can't complain too much. 

The fried football things were awesome (3 for $1.50) and I also enjoyed the pork rolls. I'm not sure if it's good hangover food, but we ate it on a hangover and were pretty happy.  

The line is a line and it takes a while. Be prepared for that. Also, be prepared to defend your table from hungry eyes.
author: Emily D.

description: Excellent. The perfect place for a quick bite - especially if you don't know what you want to eat.
author: Audrey D.

description: No big deal dim sum. Very mediocre. Everything lukewarm. Counter service only. Bus your own tables.
author: Janet L.

description: Shrimp Dumplings are the best here!  Melt in your mouth goodness.  I miss my weekly dose of dumpling happiness here.  Go early or be prepared to be patient as the secret has been out for years about this little dim sum gem of a shop (it is even Zagat rated).
author: Sara C.

description:
Cheap? - Yes. Delicious?- no.

No luck with this dim sum.  If dim sum had a Mc Donalds/fast food version grab and go food, this would be it.  Everything was cold, mushy, lackluster in taste,  left you wishing you had the real thing, and wondering why you even went there in the first place.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Ehh....

I didn't really care that it didn't look like the classiest place ever. For me, good food trumps everything else. However, the food wasn't all that good.... Maybe it was because we got there at around noon, but everything tasted like it had been sitting there all morning. However, it seemed like they were putting new stuff out so I don't know why that would be the case.... It's all good when you wanna fill your tummy on the cheap. The food was really amazingly cheap. But I wanted really really good dim sum and this place just didn't cut it.

  Overall, if you want very cheap dim sum, this is it. But if you want really excellent dim sum, Hong Kong Lounge is just a few blocks away!!!!

   I did like the shark fin dumplings though.
author: Noelle B.

description:
I had first heard of this place when my mom decided to come here with me after she tried the egg custards brought to her work.  This place is quite small and you pretty much have to walk closer to the wall when you enter as there are people waiting in line to order.  There are also some tables in the back so you can eat your food there.  

You get a sheet of paper that lists all the dim sum they have along with a pen to make your order.  Then, you wait in line for about 20 minutes while taking half a step forward.  Yup, it's really like this sometimes.  It's probably best to show up early in the morning on some random day, but I came on a Friday at 11 am.  At first, my mom warned me about this but I thought it really couldn't be possible to wait in line for THAT long..especially after going to Clement during my younger years and never seeing a line that long on that street before.  Turns out, the line really isn't so long..it just takes a long time to keep the line moving.  

When you do get your turn (after what seems to be eternity), they'll package your food to go.  Each box that they pack it in will cost 20 cents.  I've seen one person in front of me in line bring in her own tupperware.  

We ordered the sesame ball, really fried sesame ball (called Lucky Ball there ...yah okay lol), chives and shrimp dumplings and egg custard.  The egg custard was really good and there was a lot of filling.  The sesame balls were quite popular but the chives and shrimp dumplings... I hate to admit this but 99 Ranch has the upper hand on this one.  

I wasn't particularly wowed or anything although it's pretty decent for a fast food dim sum place.  Overall, I might not come back but it's still a good place to try.
author: Deborah W.

description: Love this place because you definitely get the bang for your buck! For $10 I got a bunch of stuff and was so good! Har gow, siu mai were heavenly!
author: Nadia N.

description:
When traveling to San Francisco, I would recommend stopping by this spot to pick up some quick dim sum.  It is clean, efficient and the food is great!  I would have to say this is one of the better Dim Sum places I have tried.  You do not get the old and cold type of food you find so many times when desperate just to get Dim Sum on the weekend.

Everything we ordered was prepared fresh and the kitchen staff kept bringing more food as it moves so quickly!

As for dining in, it is a cafe seat and clean yourself style, which is great as there is usually always someplace to sit.  Everyone tends to eat quickly and leave.  Warning there is a little line when ordering your food, but it is worth the wait!
author: Fuji K.

description: CHEAP delicious dim sum, fast counter service, and rude servers. What more could you hope for to make it a more authentic visit!?
author: Brian M.

description:
I was craving dim sum in San Francisco.  I saw this simple place on clement with tasty dumplings in the window.  I ate too much but so good.  
Everything I tried was good and lunch cost only $4.50!
Granted this is not a restaurant style dim sum place to bring visitors.  But if you don't mind ordering from the counter and sitting down in the back tables or just getting to go, it's perfect.
author: Bryanna E.

description: They are just cheap.. i had shrimp dumpling, egg yulk, and baked bbq pork. baked bbq wasnt good.. shrimp was okay.
author: Janis Sung Eun K.

description:
I decided finally on just something simple. I came here and got a baked pork bun and a Lotus Leaf Wraps (Lo Mai Gai). The pork bun was an disappointment. It was cold and the grease could really be tasted. 

The Lo Mai Gai on the other hand was great. I took a bite and loved all the flavors I found. Just after finishing it, wished it was bigger.
author: M C.

description:
FAST FOOD. Don't come here expecting to get some amazing dim sum.. (I can't stand when people have such high expectations of a small and honest spot like this one here). But it's a great stand-by when you need to feed the family quickly on a lazy morning/afternoon! The quality has been the same for quite some time.

The wait can get a little crazy though (weekends), and they will run out of the good stuff if you wait too long.. But there's always a good supply of the har gow, sui mai, char sui bao staples we need.

There's lots of options on Clement, but this is one of my favorite stops.
author: Tay R.

description:
Review #444 for Good Luck Dim Sum.  I am tempting fate and taking on the 444th spot which is bad, bad, bad, bad luck according to Chinese lore.  But no matter.  I will take one for the team.  

I will keep pushing my luck by sharing my 4 favorite things about GLDS.  

1)  Their 3 for $1.50 deal is pretty hard to beat.  We made it out of there with 2 orders of har gao, 1 order of pork siu mai, 1 order of chicken siu mai--which, by the way, is the lighter and less fatty version of the pork and the one I prefer--1 order of steamed bbq pork bun and 2 orders of pan fried shrimp and pork chives for $11.  That feeds 3 hungry peeps on a recession era budget.

2)  The line was about 15 people deep when we got there.  Processing time was 1 minute per person.  I timed them because our driver posting illegally on Clement (which is the only way to do it) told me he waited exactly that amount of time when I got back to the car.  

3)  Those Chinese ladies behind the counter are fast and more efficient than ants in a colony.  The person in front of us tried to ask for a pen so she can give them her order on that pink menu sheet and she was told, "No!  Just tell me.  I remember!"  And Chinese lady did remember.  My turn came next and like a pro, I rattled off one order after another and she boxed it all up in about a minute.  She repeated my order to me in such lightning fast fashion, I didn't really understand her.  But I trusted her efficiency more than my own memory so I just agreed and gratefully accepted my precious pink box.

4)  Best dim sum I've had in a long time.  Tip: order the custard early, they ran out mid-afternoon today and go for the steamed shrimp and chive dumplings as they tend to be less greasy than their pan-fried cousins.
author: Joc V.

description:
"It's all that and dim sum"
That was the last thing Ky-Yo said before I punched him in the mouth and knocked him out.
Okay, that didn't really happen. In fact, I didn't really punch him at all but that lame joke is especially annoying on a hangover morning.
An epic hangover after a night of debauchery (SF style debauchery) celebrating the year New, with eL Capitan who we haven't seen since the stroke of midnight.

Starving and lost, it seemed like a good idea to eat!

Good Luck Dim Sum does offer great dim sum! In fact we get food here every time we are in SF and as such we are used to waiting in long, long, long lines to place our order.
 Ky-Yo speaks Chinese (or at least he tells us he does. Hmmm, no one else in our house speaks Chinese so how do we know he is telling the truth?) . . . . . 

Well, our orders are usually quite large and include things like Su Mui Xia, Sioban, some kind of dumplings. BBQ pork buns, sesame balls with something inside and dammit Ky-Yo, if you REALLY DO speak Chinese, translate what all this good food is for me!
I usually just end up pointing out what I want  . . .it all looks good to me!
Anyway, if you are in the Inner Richmond District and craving dim sum, you can't go wrong with Good Luck Dim Sum!
author: Dave S.

description:
Ugh, whyyyy did you disappoint me? I wanted to love Good Luck but I can't.

Yes, the food is insanely cheap.
Yes, the food is delicious and not overly greasy.
Yes, Good Luck is a stone's-throw away from my house, so convenient.

No, service is not fast. I came here for lunch and there were 2 people ahead of me. I've been told there is usually a line out the door, and you'll wait at least 30 minutes. But, with 2 people ahead of me, it took nearly 20 minutes! To pack up food that was already hot!
No, service is not friendly. Don't expect smiles or warm welcomes here.
No, the place is not clean. When one of the employees is hocking a loogie into a nearby trash can, it definitely takes you aback.

What I'd eat again:
Shrimp dumplings - my favorite, 6 for $1. Done and done.
Pork pot stickers - delicious, good combo of meat and veggies (chives?)

What I'd skip:
BBQ pork bun - the meat was a bit too sweet for my taste.

So darn cheap though. $11 for lunch for 2 people, and we still had a ton of leftovers.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Awesome food!  I should have asked 3 orders of everything in the steamer and 3 boxes full of pork buns.  Hahahah!  As soon as we walked in, we could tell that we were in for a treat.  The line was all the way at the back of the store but the food was worth the wait.  

The shrimp with tarot was delish!  The pork buns was out of this world!
author: G L.

description:
3/5 so cheap so good.

the line is like a perpetual tide - in, out, high, low...

yes, the ladies have a bit of 'tude. but you're not eating that, you're eating the wonderful, cheap, scrumptious $1.60/order goodies. 

stand patiently, know what you want, hand over the cash, and be on with your merry (and soon to be merrier) life.
author: Alvin D.

description:
The shrimp dumplings/ha gows are the best here! The skin is smooth, thin, chewy, and there is a big chunk of shrimp inside that's very tasty. Mouthwatering just to think about it. The other dim sum is also good, but the ha gows is really the treasure! If you want good custard, try Cherry Blossom Bakery that's also on Clement.

Service- just know what you want to order and be efficient. I don't stay to eat here. I just order and go.

It is very cheap! 3 pieces for 1.50.
author: Tes Y.

description:
Maybe I went in during a bad day, or maybe I'm just too much of a picky eater, but Good Luck Dim Sum didn't live up to the high expectations that my fellow yelpers had placed upon my first visit there and here's why.

My posse miraculously woke up at 9am on a SATURDAY morning (yes these fools don't normally wake up before 11 or noon) just so we can drive over to Inner Richmond and try this place out. We stepped into the store and waited in line for maybe 5-6 minutes. We then ordered a mountain pile of dimsum and some porridge with pidan in it -- the dim sum itself looked piping hot but the moment we sat down in the store to eat, it got cold and mushy.

The dimsum itself wasn't bad even when it was cold, and yes the price is beyond reasonable (with the four of us we only ended up paying about 20 bucks total) but the dimsum here wasn't very much different than the ones you can get in the Sunset/Irving area (although most of those places in the Irving area make their dimsum a little too oily.)

I will definitely give this place another try sheerly due to the incredible pricing, but my first experience definitely did not meet the hype.
author: Scott S.

description:
I recently went here for lunch.  It's pretty good, not life altering, but good nonetheless.  I've only ever had Dim Sum 2 times, so I don't have much to compare this to.  

I wish the food was warmer, but it was tasty.  After a recent bout of food poisoning from another restaurant I was pleased that I didn't get sick from it.  

The food was so cheep and service was quick.
author: Marie R.

description: It's been awhile since I've been here and quality seems to have gone downhill....although I will say the white mochi thing with peanut, sugar, and  coconut was still yummy!
author: M L.

description: Went here with the family on our day trip to San Francisco after finding it on Yelp. Talk about cheap dim sum!! It's less than half the price of a sit down dim sum restaurant. I LOVE dim sum, and when it's cheap, that's even better!! It's a hole in the wall place, small with a few tables and meant to be more of a take out place than a sit down dim sum place. There are some tables available. The dim sum here is not the best, but for the price, it's definitely worth it!! Don't get me wrong, this place is good and deserves a 4 star rating. Most are 3 pieces for $1.70, or 70 cents a piece for some other to 90 cent bbq meat buns (mmmm, meat buns!). My family and I got too excited and ordered waaaay more food than we could eat. I should had listened to another reviewer when they said the chicken feet was not good-- because it was NOT good. It was way to chewy and just didn't taste good. I like chicken feet and I could barely finish one. My mom tried to finish it to not let food go to waste but even she gave up. Everything else we ordered was good. We had haw gow, shau mai, BBQ meat buns, egg tarts, and some others that I can't think of the name. It was all good except for the chicken feet! We got zealous and ordered $40 worth... with 3 people who are dim sum fans eating, we still had soooooo much left over!!
author: Carol N.

description:
As everyone else seems to have mentioned, this place has pretty cheap and good dim sum. 

I will say that they are NOT fast and efficient at processing the line though. I've been here before on a weekend morning and have had to wait 2 hours o get my dim sum!!! The line was pretty long, and there were about 15-20 people ahead of us, but the people serving the dim sum served it in the slowest possibly manner. 

That said, do yourself a favor and go during the week when there is no line. If you do spot a line...go across the street to Gourmet Dim Sum (my brother is a HUGE har gaw fan and they have his stamp of approval - he actually likes it better than Good Luck's!)
author: Alison N.

description: Great inexpensive dim sum, plenty of variety with a helpful staff. Divvy place on Clement St. Plenty of delicious dim sum choices, shrimp dumplings, shrimp & chive dumplings, taro balls, sesame balls, chicken rice lotus leaves, baos.....all yummy, bring a doggy bag or get it to go to share.
author: Rhondi S.

description:
If you are looking for good cheap dim sum, this place is the right place!!! We ordered 6 or 7 dishes for less than $10!!!  Seating is fairly limited and there is usually a line, but the wait is not too bad.  

My favorites are shrimp dumplings and the big chive and shrimp dumplings.  The small items for 3 for $1.7, but the good thing is that you can mix and match!!!  

Be sure to grab a menu and start ordering while waiting in line. But then again it's always easier to just point and ask.  That is probably why the line is so long!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
If you like hair inside your dim sums, and baked with it, this place is for you.
Please do not try to ask for a refund. This would be considerate as rude and the owner would have no other choice but to ask you not to come back again

Sweaty humain hair's flavor in your dimsums. Yummy!
author: Jean-Yves F.

description:
Some things, whether you dress them up or not, always lead to the same results.

Whether you drink Cuervo or Patron, you will inevitably barf.

Whether you do crack or cocaine, you will get high.

Whether you fly coach or first class, you will arrive.

Whether you dim sum at Good Luck or Yank Sing, you will get fat

So with the latter, you are out beaucoup buxx. With the former, more money saved for other licentious times.

Get fat at Good Luck: no more than $10 for two. Get fat at Yank Sing: $80 for two.  

Pocket the $70, buy two bottles of Patron to ultimately purge yourself.

It all works out, mathematically speaking.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Negatives:
-Long line
-No pictures next to dim sum (difficult to know what each is)

Positives:
-SWEET RICE WITH CHICKEN WRAPPED IN BANANA LEAVES (My ultimate favorite)
-Dumplings
-Pork buns
-Tables for seating if you want to eat in after ordering
-Affordable price

This place is very much worth the wait in my eyes. I believe you can also call-in to order and pick up if you want to skip the long line (which I will probably do next time). The dim sum is very fresh and tasty. I suggest going early in the morning - dim sum for brunch is the best!
author: Junel S.

description: Chinese Nazi! worse service ever! dont expect any service from here! Tip: KNOW WHAT YOU WANT before go in there! If you cannot speak chinese then pick up the pick slip at the counter and circle what you want, DO NOT EVEN THINK ABOUT ASKING those bitches behind the counter any questions about the food! Just get what you what and out!
author: William C.

description: I hate the people that works there. Their attitude smells even worse than diarrhea!  They now charge you .20 cents for a box without asking you if you want all ur crap in a bag or a box? Oh and if you want forks, U GOTTA ASK THEM for it, they won't automatically ask you if you want any forks or not, WTH?? I'm ordering food, take out and you don't bother to ask if I want a fork?? Do they expect us to eat with our dam fingers?
author: Alyce l.

description: No-frills order-at-the-counter dim sum joint in the Inner Richmond. Perfect for when you're craving some shumai but don't have the time or money to spend at a sit-down place. They have a good spread of dim sum classics (shumai, shrimp dumplings, turnip cakes, sesame balls, BBQ pork buns, zhongzi, rice porridge, youtiao). Everything is SUPER cheap. Less than $10 per person will fill you up (cash only). You can order right at the counter, or circle your selections on the pink menus they have at the front. Thee may be a line, but it'll move fairly quickly (and it gives you time to decide on what you want!). Most people get the plastic boxes for take-out, although they do have some tables for eating in. Definitely very casual but solid food. Pro-tip: get a bunch of buns or zhongzi and freeze them for later!
author: J L.

description:
FOOD:  Great tasting dim sum dishes.  Love the shu mai, beef balls, and daikon cakes.

SERVICE:  Very efficient.  No dilatory carts or crotchety waitresses here.  You simply pick out the dim sum dishes that you like from the display case at the front of the restaurant.

PRICE:  Excellent value.  We stuffed ourselves to the gills, even had leftovers, and the bill only averaged out to about $5 per person.

PARKING:  Parking in this neighborhood is hellish.  Be sure to bring plenty of coins for the thirsty meters.
author: Subrosa I.

description: Amazing dim sum. The pork buns and malay cake were unreal. Even though the line is long, it moves briskly.
author: Jesse W.

description: There can be a line here randomly all the time. The Dimsum here is decent but for the price it is not so bad. Not worth the wait if there is a long line.
author: Mike T.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is a powerful mirage that will satisfy those in the hunt for a bargain meal, but will disappoint dim sum connoisseurs.  

The overflowing crowd, composed of Chinese folks seemingly knowledgeable about quality dim sum and non-Chinese folks drawn in by the little Zagat sticker posted on the window, creates an irresistible urge to line up.  The steamers full of piping-hot buns and dumplings and windows teeming with pastry options give a sense of assurance in a good experience at Good Luck.

However, the pile of dim sum resulting from ordering with empty stomachs provided few winners.  The bread to meat ratio in the cha siu bao (bbq pork bun) was overwhelmingly in favor of the bread - same story regarding the meat and chives bun; the siu mai (pork dumpling) was a congealed mass of grease and under-seasoned pork; and the lo bak goh (turnip cake) lacked the necessary layer of crispiness and flavor.  

The lone high note was the dan tat, which featured a buttery, flaky crust and soft, rich egg interior.

Would try the myriad of options available on Clement Street before returning to Good Luck Dim Sum.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I love this place!  You get 3 dim sum items for $1.70, all enormous with generous amounts of meat.  Two of us ate like kings for less than $5 each.  The menus conveniently have English translations.  There was no line after standard lunch hour (1:30 pm ish).  

The BBQ Pork buns and the Vegetable Pork buns are enormous & pretty good, although we liked the Shrimp Dumplings and the Potstickers best.  The Sesame balls with red bean paste were a delicious dessert to finish.

You trade off on ambience - there's only a few seats & food is served fast-food style, but the food is hearty, filling, delicious, and very reasonably priced.  Definitely coming back here again.
author: Bee M.

description: The first time I came here I thought their dim sum were very good. This second time around, not so much. Compared to other dim sum places' steamed buns for example, GLDS is a bit dry and not as generous in the filling as other cheap dim sum places in SF. Good Mong Kok in Chinatown for instance makes steamed buns that are a bit larger, more moist and have fair amounts of filling in them. If I was in the area and craving dim sum, I'd probably still go here, but not worth going all the way there from downtown.
author: HM N.

description:
I came here yesterday morning with my boyfriend (around 10ish). There was no wait and the dim sum were piping hot and there were so much variety (compared to if you come near the end of the day). We ordered a ton of dim sum: ha gow, siu mai, chicken siu mai, rice cake (bak tong go), egg tarts, steamed BBQ pork buns, spareribs rice, chicken sausage rice, pork and century egg porridge, daikon radish cake and Chinese tamale with green beans (zhong)...

I notice their dim sum uses less MSG than Gourmet Dim Sum from across the street. Thumbs up. Everything was delicious even though some stuff weren't the best. The chicken siu mai is not as flavorful as the pork siu mai, the daikon radish cake was mostly flour, and the egg tarts were not eggy enough (crust still flaky and custard will melty though). I really enjoyed the bak tong go, it was sooo soft but not mushy and at just the right sweetness.

We were lucky and somehow avoided the long wait. Right after us, the line just grew and grew. They constantly have more stuff coming from the kitchen so everything must be very fresh (and in high demand).
author: Jennifer L.

description: Luckily we visited there at the right moment.  There was no queue (line) and Har Kau just came out from the back steaming hot.  As we were just visiting the Russian Churches in the area, we only had Har Kau and Baked Char-Siu Buns this time.  Har Kau was excellent and Bun very good.
author: Chris K.

description:
Hmm, just searched my reviews and realized I never ever yelped this! Been coming here ever since it was 3 for 90 cents, at least 10 years ago. Now it's 3 for $1.50, and it's still a good deal.

Part of the je ne sais croix is dealing with the supremely surly ladies, who run a very tight ship in order to keep prices down. I'm not complaining!

We ordered a pile of food and the lady sizes my dad and I up and puts two forks and two paper bowls on the tray. Uh, there's four of us, we said (Jenny and my mom were saving a table). She begrudgingly gave us 2 additional forks and paper bowls only after we tried convincing her that this was far more food than 2 people could handle.

Then, realizing we probably did have too much food even for the 4 of us, I asked for a box for our leftovers. The lady refused, saying after all, there's four of you, you'll definitely finish it!!

In the end, our $10 went farther than our appetites and I ended up having to steal a box to hold our leftovers.

This place is an institution. Some of their food is stellar, like the egg tart and the coconut mochi with sesame inside.  Every cheap eats hunter should make the pilgrimage
author: Henry Y.

description:
"It's been a while.....but I still love you.....Sort of.....Not in that way, but in a different, better way, I'm sure."   -- Britney Spears.

Maybe her song didn't exactly say that....But it has been a while since I updated this review.  It's been a while since I ate dim sum.  I took a hiatus, like 3 years.  During that time, I gained and lost 38 lbs.  I ate all manners of dumpling, hamburger, yogurt, food.  I didn't learn anything, yet here I am.  4 years older, not a bit wiser, and much more bitter.

I started dim sum again early October 2011.  After realizing that my BF was never going to be a morning person, never accompany me to breakfast during the AM hours, and I am likely to starve waiting for him, I resolved to eat breakfast by myself.  In the manner I am accustomed: hastily, rapidly, a bit embarrassed, loudly, alone, while grunting out my pleasure.  It could describe any number of activities.  This morning, I'm describing breakfast.

A few weeks ago, I reintroduced Good Luck Dim Sum to my mouth.  I stood in line for over 20 minutes, pink order slip clutched in my hot little hands, and bought only 3 pieces of dim sum.  That's about 1 piece every 7 minutes.  It took me less time to snarf it down.  The lady behind the counter looked at me funny.  Since it was 7:30 am, I looked funny right back, albeit ignorantly-funny.  

Good Luck is much tastier in so many ways to the other dim sum places.  But it has its drawbacks.  

1. Their bao, gar, buns, jook, etc is made with much higher quality ingredients, more love and attention.  The rice wrappers on the steamed gar are never soggy, the fillings are dainty and well proportioned.  The meat is well seasoned and flavorful.  But, everything is smaller.  Slightly smaller sized gar, slightly smaller sized bun, slightly smaller everything.  But dainty.

2.  They have a high turn over of food.  People don't just buy 3 pieces (as I did), they buy 3 buckets.  On early Sunday/Saturday mornings, orders keep coming out of the kitchen for banquet sized foil trays of dumplings, egg custards, bao and steamed goodness.  Your piece of dim sum is probably not much older than 20 minutes.  BUT this means you have to wait about 20 minutes in line since they fill so many phone orders of banquet quantity.  I'm talking church-group sized quantities.  

3.  Efficient ordering system.  The pink paper.  It cuts down on the pointing and gesturing.  Although some people still insist on human interaction.  Maybe this person lives in isolation and has no friends, therefore they talk to as many service industry people as they can when let out of their cage.  I've heard of people who really look forward to telemarketers to call so they can have a conversation with a human voice.

4.  I can't quit this place.  I will get out of bed at 7 am on a rainy, cold saturday morning and drive my hairy butt to Clement street just to get some of the fried stuffed dumplings.  FRIED STUFFED DUMPLINGS!  If ever perfection has been put in my mouth, it would be this.  It is a savory meat filling wrapped in a slightly sweet mochi wrapper, and then DEEP FRIED.  My brain just exploded from happiness.  Sweet.  And Savory.  And fried.  In a dumpling!  If I ever lie about staying late at work, or going in early to work, it'll be because I'm sneaking a tete-a-tete with this fried stuffed dumpling.  It's a homewrecker.  In hooker heels.

Jook is ok.  Very flavorful and the best out of all 3 dim sum places that I've tried.  But.  "Mom's is still the best."  Snarf!  This is a close 2nd.  Let's just wait and see if the MSG coma hits hard and fast, I need a short nap before brunch with the kids and the parents.

UPDATE: my mouth.  Is a dry desert.  Of parched MSG-dessicated dryness.  My kingdom for a drink of water to cleanse out my system.  My kingdom.  Oh.  Parched.
author: Christina C.

description: The only thing I had liked was the har-gow, shrimp dumpling. The skin was extremely yummy and the shrimp was fresh. I recommend the shrimp dumpling and anything else that has a similar skin to the shrimp dumpling. The other dishes were not as good at all.
author: Cindy C.

description: Awesome price performance . The shrimp crystal dumplings were three for $2 and they tasted much better than that. We got enough dim sum for four people and took it to go and it was under $30. I have eaten dim sum all over San Francisco, this place is not designed to compete with places like yank sing or city view because this place is just a little hole in the wall but the food was pretty darn good and I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Doug C.

description: Authentic dim sum. So authentic it was hard to order in English! Very fresh and tasty. Dine in experience is what your expect for the price clean and comfortable and cheery. Had a solid feed for two people for less than $10. Made mainly to go. I would go back. And back....
author: Livia M.

description:
I like this place! It's perfect if you need a good, cheap snack on Clement street. The counter Staff is helpful, and were both quite accommodating even though they spoke limited English and I speak nothing but. My to-go order of shrimp dumplings and sesame balls included a packet of soy sauce and a plastic fork, and I found it was portable enough that I could eat it as I continued to shop.

I think that Good Luck is a nice compromise if you don't really want to do a sit-down restaurant and it's quite good for what it is, but I wouldn't say it's the best in its class when compared to other places to get dim sum in the area.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
05.25.14 with one other 

Waited in a short line to order and pay. The staff was friendly and helpful. 

Ordered to go which costs a lil bit more cuz you have to pay for your box and bag. 

Got my dimsum fix and it was yummy too. 

I would go back if in the area.
author: Jay R.

description:
Decent..a bit on the greasy side.
Favs are pot stickers.
author: Beth N.

description:
Take-out dim sum--music to my ears. I love that I can buy enough dim sum here to feed a family of 4 for just $20. Of course, it usually takes the same amount to keep just E and I satiated...

Most of the time, you'll have to endure a loooong wait and some curtness from the women armed with tongs up at the front, but yummy AND cheap dim sum is worth it.  Make sure you get some of the pan-fried chive dumplings.  Just don't ever get the chicken feet--I love chicken feet, mind you, but the ones here are mushy, cold, and flavorless. Blech.
author: Jen L.

description: My family has been coming here for many years since we've been visiting the city. Everything is fresh made early in the morning. The only issue is the size of the place, it's pretty small and the lines become long fast.
author: Kelli K.

description: Great pork buns overall food was really good freshly made and well prepared by an army of chefs in back. Place is a little dirty don't let it disturb you food is great.
author: Erik A.

description: Great price for the dim sum. Always go here when I'm craving for some good siopao. Although I wouldn't get their egg yolk bun. Tastes and smells like gasoline. Other than that, siopao, siomai, black buchi balls are on point. Definitely a regular since 2005
author: nick r.

description:
This is the first time I've eaten Dim Sum in a takeout box. The food was delicious and the price really can't be beat! 
I felt very rushed through my order and the lady taking my order wasn't exactly nice. Got eyes rolled at me a few times inquiring about shrimp in each of the food items as my boyfriend has an allergy. I know there's a long line, but I really don't want to pull out the epi-pen in your restaurant...
I'll definitely be returning. For delicious food at this price I'll endure the eye roll.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
I'm a tourist, people.  On the lookout for that perfect place to complete my San Francisco dim-summer season.  Stumbling upon the gem that is Clement Street, my trusty Yelp app led me to Good Luck.

I don't know if I came on a good day, or maybe it was just the natural high of being in my favorite city in the world, but I suppose it just depends on (1) the ladies' moods that day, and (2) your overall approach to the situation.  I filled out my paper, asked brief questions, and ordered a sh*t ton.  No wonder they loved me.  I took my large order to go, so I didn't have to cage fight for one of three tables.

Baked pork buns:  the meat is a bit more minced than I'd like, but the taste is absolutely spot on.  Sweet, salty, bbq porky, and generous meat-to-dough ratio.  Same with the steamed buns.

Pork siomai:  soooo good.  Siomai connoisseurs take note -- here the wrapper is perfectly adhered to a nicely seasoned filling.

Shrimp har gow:  see above.  I was lucky to get it fresh :)

Sesame ball with mung bean:  umm we call this buchi?  Anyway here at GLDS it's perfectly toasty on the outside and not too sweet on the inside.  I typically don't eat buchi but it was incredible.

Steamed sponge cake:  ehh, typical.  Not bad though.

Get your pink paper, grab a hot-commodity pen, mark your whatnot, ask questions quickly, and pay a very small amount for a very large amount, if you know what I'm saying.  See you again Good Luck!
author: Monica D.

description: I've been going here for years and this place makes my heart fill with dim sum joy and dim sum coma. The prices have increased since I first started feasting at this small steamy place but har gow for $2 and pretty much a filling meal totaling under $6 is still incredible in SF. Great place to snack at then head over to Green Apple Bookstore across the street!
author: Hugh A.

description:
I came back to America for 5 days and was expecting some hella, damn good Shumai from here. But this place disappointed me. The beef shumai here are dry and small. The food is cheap. But ALL dim sum places are cheap. I'll be surprised if you can find me an expensive dim sum shop.

And lastly, the workers there HATE their job.
author: Shirley F.

description:
For the price, the Har Gow is great. The skewered and BBQed chicken is fantastic.

Other items tend to have too-thick and pasty rice "wrappers" while others are a bit too greasy.

Still the best QPR around.
author: George T.

description: I can't say how sad I am about this place. Had a great day in SF and then came here. HORRIBLE! Walked in and the woman working the counter was staring at us the whole time. We ordered, she didn't use gloves, and then 2 Chinese woman come in and it's all Hello How are you to them and Want do you want? to us. (We are white btw) racially horrible, judging people and unsanitary. Gross. Food is good but I would never come to this dump ever.
author: Ben C.

description: This place is small. The dim sum quality is way below average, but the price is very cheap. I don't know if you can find any other cheaper ones. I can't give it five stars just because it is cheap.
author: Wilson L.

description: So good! Can be a little daunting if you're not sure what you want or what you like, but despite the staff's demeanor, they are very friendly and willing to help and answer questions, but you have to ask. Help may not be offered. The line moves quick
author: Joshua G.

description:
Here's what to expect during peak times. You walk in and squeeze through a long line of people waiting to order.  While you stand in line, you circle the dim sum pieces you want on their pink pieces of paper (menu).  3pcs for 1.60 for your basic dumplings; har gau, shu mai, shrimp-chive dumplings, etc.  0.85 for pork buns, crepes, etc.  

There's about 7 tables of 4...kind of a tight squeeze. So, if you plan on eating there, make sure someone saves a table. Speaking of... everyone is responsible for busing their own, so beware the tables may be sticky of soy sauce and or dim sum particles. The soy sauce dispenser and chili pot was practically empty. 

Onto the food. It was.... GOOD.  LOVE the har gau.  Love the shrimp-chive dumpling. Liked the chicken shu mai.  The deep fried dumpling was OK.  It wasn't what I expected. It was crispy on the outside, moist and chewy on the inside.  My friends didn't like it at all but it was OK.  The dry shrimp crepe was tasty and the baked pork bun was OK.  

Would I go and eat there again? No.  But I will def go back and pick up some delicious dim sum and eat em somewhere else.
author: Resa N.

description:
Among all the Chinese fast food places I have ever been to, this place is one of the most impressive of them all. The conventional inclination about these places is one with people overcrowding the counter with a semi-dingy ambiance where the lighting is not always the best. On the contrary, Good Luck is clean, has a well lit orderly layout, a spacious area for seating in the back, and the line to the counter is long, but everyone manages to stay in one neat, single file.

The place has been crazy busy all day so far. Since each order ($1.50) comes in threes, it's easy to get full with less than $5. Here are the things I've tried. Service is not the best, but it tends to get better in the late afternoon when it's not too crowded. 

Yay, I'm impressed:
1.) Shrimp taro dumpling
2.) Deep fried taro root
3.) Shrimp dumpling
4.) Chicken shumai
5.) Sweet rice bun 
6.) Crystal dumpling

Decent, but my arms are folded:
1.) Shark fin dumpling
2.) Steamed pork dumpling
3.) Pork dumpling
4.) Sweet rice puff with coconut and peanut

Ran out, I missed the party and just about to kick myself right now:
1.) Dry shrimp crepe
2.) Shrimp taro dumpling (On day 2)

I also observed many who ordered loads of turnip cakes, bbq pork buns, and pot stickers. I came here mainly for the taro items and find their shrimp taro dumpling a heavenly delight and a must have. Through some creative mix and matches, I was able to get two great feasts at less than $5 each time.
author: Daniel L.

description: Consistently good and affordable dim sum.  There could be a line, so try and go at opening.  Closed on Tuesdays.  Discounted pork buns usually after 2 or by 3 p.m.  I no longer live in SF, but make sure that I stop in whenever I'm in town... it's that good!
author: missy b.

description: Great place to get dim sum for take-out. I always get their shrimp and taro dumplings and the sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves. They don't disappoint. Cheap and fast service. Remember, cash only! :)
author: Fallon P.

description: Dimsum served fastfood style?! Oh my goodness! Delicious for an awesome price!!! can't wait to go again!!!
author: Debbie C.

description:
One of those places where its highly probable your stomach will hate you for the rest of the day if not longer...  Everything tastes pretty good and the variety and price is competitive but Good Luck Dim Sum has missed a few finer details... The customer service is terrible and the staff needs to be taught ethics. 

1) We arrive at Good Luck Dim Sum and are ready to order, however the staff kept ignoring us
2) The staff finally takes our orders but are extremely rude and condescending when asking what we want.
3) One of the workers there drops money on the dim sum however, she does not change the tray and continues to sell the dim sum to unsuspecting tourist.
4) What pisses me off the most was that the lady that worked there tried to overcharge us and said that we had already ordered a dim sum and wouldn't offer to exchange it. She charged me $7.10 for 3 churn fun (rice noodles) 3 ha gaw, and 3 siu mai. Obviously this doesn't add up.
5) My friend T. Lee usually comes here but even today she said the service was not up to par. I would definitely suggest that you go to many of the other fine dim sum establishments on Clement rather than this place. I am surprised they are not yet out of business!!!!
author: Casey N.

description: Maybe the best dim sum I've had in a while.  Loved the taro puffs and sticky rice.  Pork buns and shrimp dumplings were really good.  Service was so efficient it was almost scary.  Long line evaporated before my eyes.
author: Eric K.

description: Oh Good Luck Dim Sum I'm so glad you are in my sister's neighborhood. This place is as you would expect an amazing dim sum place to be...tiny with a long line and you may not understand most of the menu. I think I pointed to things and took a chance on everything my first visit here and everything is always ridiculously good! You can get 6 pot stickers, 5 dim sum and 3 pork buns for like $5 out the door. Just make sure you ask for soy sauce or any other sauces you may want. Bring your patience to wait in line and enjoy nom nom nom!
author: Sarah R.

description: Its OK.  Dim Sum are very oily.  Good portion and good price.  Prefer take out, not a place to sit down.
author: Mippy C.

description:
First time visit, arrived at 10.30-ish Sunday morning, waited in long line for about 30 minutes to get food. Was a mistake for not coming earlier, future trip must planned to arrive at least 9am!

Shrimp dumplings were absolutely delicious! Soft and thinner dumpling skin with crunchy shrimp, yumm. Hubby loved the sesame seed ball, crispy on the outside, sweet and soft on the inside with red bean paste.

Food were definitely fresh, the staff were constantly yelling from the front counter to the kitchen for more food refills. Steaming piping hot food being pushed out from the kitchen every so often as well.

Gotta come back to try more from their menu.
author: YY M.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum reminds me of You's Dim Sum in Chinatown. In fact, I think I even saw one of the same ladies from You's at Good Luck (looking just as angry and impatient at this location). Hmm, either they really get around or I do.....
        Anyway, I went to GLDS a few months ago and they had a lot of fresh dim sum. Their pork potstickers had tasty, not-too-thick skins with a nice pork filling. Their char-siu-bao was fluffy w/ a good amount of meat filling. Their baked bun was good, but not the best. .
        Good Luck tastes just as good as You's, although GL was not as quick and their taros were smaller. However, the place was clean and the dim sum was fresh, delicious, and, best of all, cheap.
author: Shana E.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum Might as well be Good Luck, why would i say such a thing its because of the taste and convenience of this place.

Why would i call it good luck well because flat out they have the best overall Dim Sum I've tasted in the city of SF. I tried everything from har gow to to their fried taro balls to their porridge. pretty much can't match it anywhere else in SF

the har gow is quite huge and moist when you get it not dried out nor mushy, But what is a must try is their porridge. Which by my chinese standards is quite delicious. for 2 dollars its quite the giant container of porridge with small fried wonton strips. Something so simple turned into something so delectable. A must try/ stop for cheap breakfast or quick snack while in SF
author: Melvin G.

description:
After dropping by here with a co-worker I was a little disappointed.

Good Luck Dim Sum had large BBQ Pork buns at 3 for a $1.50 and a clean restaurant with lots of seating.

However the buns had that strange aftertaste I've found with some places. A strange under-cooked, yeasty taste. Not so much my favourite.

The service was also very offhand, bordering on rude and irritated. 

With the not-so-awesome buns and the service, I probably wouldn't be back.
author: Meg T.

description: This is a great little place to pop into for a quick lunch.  The pork buns were so good, they made my mouth sing.  This is a little dumpy place but the food is great and prices are beyond belief.  Everything tastes so fresh as if it came from my friend's Mom's kitchen.  A friend took me here and this place is to be remembered.
author: Veda F.

description:
Wow. Things have gone ABSOLUTELY downhill over the past two years. The line is always at least 12 people long. Really, it's not worth the wait. 

All of the dim sums are now extremely thick-skinned, and either way too glutinous or hardened. Everything's lacking in taste. Not enough ginger. No delicious juice dripping from the insides. Not fresh. Not delicious. Greasy, greasy, greasy... Yuck.

It's a pity what this place has become. Good Luck Dim Sum used to be our family staple. Only one thing's stayed the same: the shitty service.
author: Colleen W.

description:
The food isn't bad.  Your typical Dim Sum to go places.  If you tried one Dim Sum to go, they're almost all the same.  

So why the 2 stars?  I was driving by Clements street and wanted to get some Dim Sum take out.  Just for myself.  I walked in there and asked to order.  The lady who picks the food for me grabs a cardboard tray to put Dim Sum on.  I told her "no, it's for take out".  Then she puts the cardboard tray away and get a plastic to go box.  It's a individual 'clamshell' plastic box to hold food.  About 5inch x 4inch x 5inch.  Not too big, just an individual take out box.  I though to myself, okay, I'll order enough to fill the box and it'll be a good lunch.  I order this and that until it was fill.  She covered it up and said the total cost was $8.70.  I thought to myself, that's kind of expensive for a box that small.  I looked up at the pricing and it says $1.70 for items of three.  Since I ordered 5 different items of three, that should be a total of $8.50.  Where does the 20 cent come in???  Apparently, that extra 20 cent was to that clam-shell box.  After you open them and eat, the plastic shell just falls apart to become two plastic bowls.  No worth 20 cents at all.  I understand the states require stores/restaurant to charge 10 cent to bags, but why is this place charging me 20 cents for a cheap container???  If I didn't want to pay the 20 cents, how are they going to pack it up and let me take it out??? 

Now, to add insult to injury, that little box of food costs me $8.70.  That's 15 pieces of Dim Sum in one little clam-shell box, with room to spare.  That's when I realize what their doing.  They're making all these Dim Sum smaller than other places.  Yes, the price per three pieces is lower at $1.70.  However, they're much more smaller.  I wasn't too happy and went to another Dim Sum place how a few blocks and spent another $7.00 on Dim Sum.  Just your regular meat dim sum, not the BBQ pork bun or anything larger.  And that filled up a MUCH larger plastic box around 10inch x 4 inch x 10inch.  And they didn't charge me a container fee.

Yes, Good Luck Dim Sum is cheaper in price, BUT, it's smaller.  They're making food by nickeling and diming.  So in the end, you're paying more money, for less weight in good.

This forum is about food as well as the price you pay for the food, quality, and so forth.  The rating I gave them is in comparison with other restaurants.  If you eat a lot of Dim Sum, you'll know the average size of each piece.  Good Luck Dim Sim's pieces are actually quite smaller than your average restaurants that serves Dim Sim.  Yes, they cost less compared to other restaurants.  But not by much.  They make up the cost by giving you less food.  That was my rating.  

The twenty cent container was a unexpected surprise cost.  If you've been there, there's not a lot of tables and seats for customers to eat in.  So the majority of the customers are taking the food out.  But they do not disclose that they charge twenty cent for a disposal container.  This is another way they are nickle and dime-ing customers.  They should just factor that cost into the pricing of food.  But they don't.  If they did factor the cost of the container on the food, the pricing will push their sales over the edge as too expensive for the amount of food paid.
author: Jack L.

description:
After a horrid night of red wine and vodka --Dimsum the next morning seemed like the best idea EVER.

We came here for an early lunch (around 10ish)...and had to wait a good 20mins to stand in line and get our orders.
