Thank goodness, my friend was nice enough to be the one to stay in line and put in our orders, and I (the hungover, dazed one) was just sitting down, saving us table (although it wasn't needed. i noticed people come here more for take-out -and most of the tables were vacant), gazing at the ceiling high pile of pink dimsum boxes. I did wanna dive into those boxes for them to topple down and for me to just sleep off my tired eyes. okay. so I'm rambling.

As i was people watching, i noticed the kitchen area, where all the good stuff were being made. And i noticed carts of freshly made dimsum being delivered every after how many minutes to the front of the store.

All steaming hot..i wanted to just grab one and stuff it in my mouth every time they replenish their front stock.

They have pretty decent dimsum at a really super duper decent price.

I loved their shu-mai...and their shimp and chive dumpling a lot!
the sharksfin is also really good....
my friend totally raves about the taro ball. (i didn't try it coz it looked scary and deep fried)

I'd definitely go back and get so much worth of dimsum for my next craving.
author: Monica H.

description:
If you're an experienced dim sum-mer and you NEED your dim sum fix then this is a great way to satiate yourself. 

All the dim sum is made fresh on site (i got a sneak peek) , the staff are friendly & very efficient and it's basically set up for takeout, although there are 7-8 tables that line the room but you really cannot expect much for atmosphere. Their menu is simple with about 30 items to select and prices are about $0.60 - $1 per piece. Their char-siu bao (steamed pork bun), har gao, chive dumpling, siu mai, taro puff are all top notch- you can taste all the flavors- ginger, green onion, soy etc.. Their sticky rice in lotus leaf w/ pork/ chicken are a must if you are hungry. This one is bookmarked for my grab n' go dim sum fix.
author: Akash D.

description: SO CHEAP! I came here with the boyfriend and we ordered so much food. The bill came out to be $9. IT WAS AMAZING. Will be coming back for sure. Parking is a little bit of a hassle though. It's right off of Clement Street and they had a lot things going on during that Sunday.
author: Heather R.

description: While the proper way to eat dim sim is to sip tea and select tiny portions from a cart, I prefer the San Fran method. It's all about cheap good food. Forget the decor. There are some tables, but it's basically a take-out buffet.  If you can't speak Chinese, Cantonese to be more precise, don't panic. The servers are bi-lingual. You can even point, but you might get some stares.  Regardless of how you order, most of what you order comes in threes, and the prices are cheap. The standard stuff, char siu bow, har gaw, and siu mai, is really good.  We love this place, and a box of warm dim sum when visiting friends is always appreciated.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Never coming back here. 
Food wasn't even that good. We waited 45+ minuets to order. Yeah, it was cheap, but by the time we got to eat the food was all cold. The ladies at the counter, though I'm sure were tired from a hard day of work, were extremely slow, EXTREMELY. Go across the street for equally 'good' dim sum with no wait and no hassle. 
I guess for me it was nothing but Bad Luck Dim Sum (that was corny but i just had to) :P
author: Benny C.

description: Here now for early grab dim sum with friends and boyfriend we have it to go for the road to Sonoma Lake. Fast and quick service and cheap! Got a dozen of pork siomay, half dozen of pork bun and a dozen of chicken siomay and half dozen of sesame balls!!!
author: Ty N.

description: This place is so good. Some of the best in SF. They run out of shrimp dumplings so go before 1. Rude staff, no decor...as usual. Try the taro.
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Long lines are the best. It means the food is fresh because of the quick turnover.

This place is best when the food is fresh. In fact, sometimes it doesn't matter what you order, as long as it has freshly come out of the oven. I like watching the tourists and hipsters come in and get confused about all the choices and options. Best to just point and nod your head. I would recommend almost all the meat dim sum dishes as they are pretty decent for the price. The desserts are average.

Great place to grab some grub on the weekends when you roll out of bed pretty late (like 12noon). Sometimes parking is tricky though.
author: Katie Y.

description:
Love the way I basically have a Seinfeld-esque soup Nazi experience with the staff when I'm here.
LOVE the dim sum. 
Love the cheap prices (3 for $1.60, yes thank you).
Love that it's a hole in the wall and kinda dumpy. But whatever.

Love this place.
author: Liz K.

description: I came with 9 other friends and we all order different things to try out. The only good thing there is the shrimp dumpling. Other kinds of dim sum are just below average. Food is not as hot as it should be. Service is bad. The ladies have absolutely no patience with customers at all!!! The worst part is their restroom :( :( :( look and smell horrible!!!! I would not recommend this place.
author: Kate N.

description: Price is right. For $13, three of us were STUFFED! Lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice was king. Is it better than other dim sum, no? You have to wait in a hella long line. Fun people watching, though you have to fight to score a table.
author: Andrew K.

description: So good and so cheap! They're constantly making fresh batches of goodies since it's always packed with people buying boxes and boxes to go. Don't expect to eat in, as seating is limited, but you can buy 3 big pink cake-boxes to go for like $20. GOOD TRADE-OFF, I MUST SAY. Some of my faves are their egg tarts, steamed char siu buns, har gow, fried sesame buns (the meat-filled mochi things), and the white sugar cake things. I cannot guarantee that's what they're all called, but you'll figure it out. When in doubt, just get everything. It'll come out to like $20 anyway.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Get my quick dim sum fix from here! So cheap and so good.

Wish they had Har Cheong on the menu.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
While I love dim sum, this is definitely not the place to go get them. The lady behind the counter was rude and grouchy. Yo lady, I understand you've been standing all day, but can you at least ask nicely instead of demanding what I would like to order? She almost scared me away, but I had to feed my dim sum cravings after being deprieved of it for months while away at college!

I ordered 3 pieces of pork siu mai and one square piece of turnip cake. I was so excited to eat a piece that I didn't even care if it was still hot from the steam baskets or whatever. But that was not even a problem cause the dim sum and turnip cake were cold as fuck. It wasn't even warm... what a disappointment.

Needless to say, it was not a good dim sum experience.
author: Annie S.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. Yes, I've only been here once and yes, we kinda scarfed down our lunch, but I'm pretty sure I'm going to want to come back here every time I visit SF. Good Luck Dim Sum is located in New Chinatown, which I didn't even know exist, and that's why you get a local friend to take you there. It's definitely not a touristy spot, and I hope it stays that way (even though, by virtue of me writing a Yelp! review, I'm condoning more gringo tourists to find it). There are maybe 5, 6 small tables, each sitting four comfortably, so most people get their dim sum to go in styrofoam boxes. Dine-in's no fancier: you get your dim sum piled onto paper plates, eaten with cheap chopsticks or plastic forks. Hey, if that means I get to eat a buttload of delicious dim sum for less than $8 a person, I'm willing to eat off the plastic tray for all I care. And that's why I love this place: It's cheap, it's fast, and it's good. Did I mention it's cheap? Seriously, I'm from San Gabriel, where dim sum is dime a dozen (figuratively speaking), but I've never seen three people fed fully on less than $25, as what happened at Good Luck. The best thing is, the dim sum were actually very good. I can't even remember all the different dim sum we ordered. Here's a partial list: 
Har Gow (shrimp dumpling)
Beef Siu Mai
Shrimp Taro dumpling - this one was suuuuper taro-y (ie. gummy)
Chicken and sausage rice - something new for me, and absolutely delicious
Chinese Chive Dumpling
Fried Sesame Ball
Custard - a must for me every time, and they do it hear perfectly; glistening yolky goodness

Good Luck Dim Sum is a truly blissful dim sum experience, and a must try even if you're just in SF for a stopover. Don't tell everyone, though; I don't wanna wait in line too long for my next dim sum fix.
author: Mariel L.

description:
I wish there was a dim sum take out in my area! The dumplings here are huge and yuuuummy!  They have the basic dim sum dishes mostly, so if you are looking for the dim sum extras such as baby clams, vegetables, noodles, etc. go to a sit down dim sum spot.  

I could be wrong about that, but I didn't see it on the checklist menu.  Portions are really big.. 3 of us overestimated and ordered way too much and ended up taking a lot of it home.  My only gripe is, even though we ate there, the food wasn't very hot.  We walked around this area and saw a few of the take out dim sum's, Good Luck had the biggest variety as well as the big crowd. Don't be turned off by the long line.. it moves quick.  Our meal was $18, can't beat it.
author: Mai T.

description: This is my favorite hai gow take out place!  I prefer this place for hai gow over any other deli.  I've tried their siu mai's and they were pretty good too, but nothing out of ordinary.  All their dim sum are $1.70 per order (3 pieces).  I also get their pork and thousand year old egg jook here for $2.  They give you green onions and fried wonton on top.  Everything I have had here were good, but their hai gows are my favorite.  Should I say hai gow a few more times?  Hai gowwww :) yum!
author: Lynn L.

description:
This was my second trip to this place and I will never go there again.  The food is awful.  The potstickers cold and bland, shumai just a gaggy lump of chicken, no ginger,or seasonong.  Why its Zagat rated is way beyond comprehension. 
The staff is beyond rude, I needed to get something for the leftovers, and couldn't get anyone's attention, so I tried to get a little foil (which was in a roll, out in the open) to wrap the things in and had two women screaming at me in Chinese and obviously berating me.  My first trip was not that much different, as I didn't understand the ordering system, they were rude then.   
If you want extraordinary dim sum, go to Ton Khiang on Geary.   They never fail to please on every level. Pricier, but a better experience.
author: Therese M.

description: Found this place just trying to figure out where to eat while in the area.  What a great find!! Paid only $10 and fed 5 of us. Well 3 were kds but still.  Can't find a place like this where I live.  Even though the price is cheap, the food is pretty good.  Not one of those you get what you pay for kind of places.  It gets busy but the line moves fairly quickly, especially if you already know what you want. Definitely gonna come back if I'm in the mood for dim sum and I'm in the area. :)
author: Winnie-Anne B.

description: This place is cheap as hell and really good. You can see the large team of people in the back busting out all of the Dim Sum, it sells so quick that it's all fresh.  It's super casual and quick- the line gets long but it goes pretty fast.  they ask you to pay $.50 for a to-go box which I think is funny and it doesn't bother me, but some dude in there was really pissed about it lol. Could be a little cleaner. Can't beat the prices- my husband and I paid $8 to feed both of us hungry eaters lunch. I will be back.
author: Emma H.

description:
Bad service, no smile, good food though. A bit too oily, dumplings not too tasty, but the bbq pork steambun is a must!!

Do not touch those pink boxes too... those ladies server will give u the dirtiest stare.
author: Dizz T.

description: For years, Good Luck has been one of my go-to places for quick and cheap dim sum on Clement Street. It's nothing fancy, but its clean enough. While parking can be tough at times, it's always easier and cheaper than Chinatown.  The baos here have some of the most light and fluffy bread, though the filling is only ok. But the bottom line is that it's quick, it's tasty, and it's super cheap!  Nothing wrong with that!
author: Chris Y.

description:
This place is awesome. Here's why:
Most of the dim sum comes in groups of three for $1.60, and there is a big variety of foods here. There is a long line. Yes, this makes it awesome, because if there's a long line, you know there's a great feast to be had at the end of your wait. If you don't know what a "sesame ball" is, you will get a surprise by what you order. 

Caution: if you don't eat a lot, don't order more than two or three things off the menu. You will end up with way more food than you know what to do with!

More caution: the quality is what you'd expect for the price. It's tasty, but it isn't the world's best meat or anything.
author: Sterling D.

description:
So good!!!! If I lived here I would come here everyday of my life. We went pretty early in the morning and ate there. There were tons of people ordering to go. The staff were efficient and fast. Not the most friendly but the food made up for that. 

I love all the pastry boxes stacked around the place because it reflects how busy they get. The pastries aren't too plentiful here but the real goods of dumplings have a big variety. We had the normal shrimp, pork, and veggie dumplings that are better than cart served dim sum. Also had some folded dumpling thing that was slightly too herb tasting. The best to me was the rice porridge with the fried Chinese dough. The porridge had the right blend of meat flavor AND the perfect consistency. I really wish I could eat this daily! Come try it and eat some for me!!
author: reviewer m.

description:
For those who have seen the Soup Nazi from Seinfeld..this is the same thing! You do what is normal and you get what you want.....if not..you get yelled at.

So here is all the process for all you newbies to the store...If your a newbie to Dim Sum go somewhere else so you don't crowd the line asking...WHATS THIS? WHATS THIS?!? (Which the ladies will get pissed off)

You go in and you grab the pink sheet of paper...You then proceed to marking how many orders you want...and make sure its legible and circle it so they see it.... When they say NEXT!!! you hand them the slip....You tell them if its to-go or for here..I made the mistake of not telling them and they gave me a lashing for having it for here when they placed everything in to-boxes....

Best Dim Sum outside from eating it at a restaurant where they are pushing a cart of Dim Sum.....

So bottom line...Stay quiet...fill out form...hand them the form...pay money...get food and GET OUT!!! ENJOY!!!

UPDATE!!!

#1 FOLLOW ALL THE STEPS ABOVE
#2 DO NOT STEAL THEIR WALL OF PINK BOXES..
#3 CLEAN YOUR OWN TABLE!!!!!

I went today with friends...and there were at least 3 tables where people left complete messes....COMMON!!! do you really need to eat like a slob AND leave your mess?!?! The ladies arn't going to clean it..that means the next following customer is...JERKS!!!!

While eating today I heard this guy go whats this? the ladies went crazy on them!! remember if u don't know what your ordering GO SOMEWHERE ELSE TO LEARN!!!!

they provide the paper and the pens for a reason...USE IT!
author: Brendan L.

description:
I went to one of mine and Yelp's favorite Dim Sum Places to buy a dozen of the Steamed Custard buns. For $.60 each, these suckers are "huge" with bulkness and oozed with the custard fillings. 

The only problem, is that I only ate "one" and the rest of the hungry Fantastic-4 ate the rest of the eleven. 

"It would be nice if I had another one!"
author: Matt G.

description: Super yummy for togo fast food dim sum. Will be back. Fast and cheap yum yum!
author: Janet D.

description:
Had to return to my first takeout dim sum joint. I showed up on a Sunday after hitting up the museums. Sadly, the line was ridiculously long. Close to a 15 minute wait. This white guy behind me was shouting and showing off to his buddy about this dumpling and that one by making huge hand gestures that basically invaded my personal space and nearly touched my chest a few times. That for 15 minutes was hellish.

I don't blame GLDS for that, but with the huge following, more and more people who previously wouldn't come here are and making it into a less than spectacular place. 

They ran out of a bunch of things. No scallion shrimp dumplings for me :( Things run out I bet because Americans come in here not knowing that they're ordering in multiples of three. Therefore they end up getting 27 of one particular dumpling (instead of 9) for their huge fat family. Really unfortunate.
author: Susan D.

description: One of the very few legit har-gow places in the city. Staffs keep brawling at each other but I guess it's just the way they talk. Turnip cakes are really good; so is crystal dumpling. Pork suimai is legit.
author: Joelle K.

description:
I used to come here every Sunday with my dad and my brother as my mom was out grocery shopping nearby.  The food is still as good as I remember it to be, and cheap too.

I loved the shrimp dumplings and the steamed pork buns the most.  Siu mai was also good and I really liked the egg tarts.  

A lot of people give lower ratings because of the service, but really, many Chinese immigrants are incapable of being kind to strangers.  They're also incredibly cheap and might give you just one fork for two people, or no napkins at all.  A lot of the time you even have to ASK for forks or napkins, or they won't give you any at all.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Complaints always about the long lines especially on the weekends.  But great take out dim sum is hard to find and this place is definitely worth the wait.  O.K. probably not the 45 minutes wait on a Saturday afternoon which is aptly named "Good Luck" getting your order in a hurry.

The same three Chinese ladies seem to work behind the counter every day taking your order.  They're a bit curt if you don't know how to order (a la The Soup Nazi) and if you start to ask too many questions about the food items.  For the most part, they work at a good even pace to move the line along fairly quickly.  Pink menus are provided for you to circle your dim sum purchases to make large orders easy to fill.

Generally, one order of dim sum are three pieces (better group price than individual orders.)  So make sure you say "One Order" for three pieces or "One Piece" if you prefer a more limited experience.

Best take out jook (rice porridge)  I've ever had, although "The Slanted Door" at the Ferry Building makes a darn good jook too.  This place serves (optional) it with green onions and that crunchy fried stuff that other places do not offer.  The jook consistency is always smooth and creamy, not lumpy and watery like some other inferior versions.

Love the shrimp dumpling and the shrimp/scallion dumpling.  This dumpling is fairly large (2" diameter) and is lightly panned fried on the top and bottom to give it that crunchiness.  My favorite!   

The chicken bun is also my favorite along with the rice ball dim sum they sell.  Great alternative to the pork buns and they're easy to eat on the run.

For more of a hefty rice filled meal try the rice wrapped in lotus leaf (a dim sum staple) or the chicken & vegetable over rice.  Everything's reasonably priced and that's why I love living in San Francisco.
author: Doug I.

description:
We went here after a day at Golden Gate Park based on Yelp reviews.

The food is really inexpensive but the quality is very low. The steam pork buns have little meat and my friend bit something hard and not chewable in hers. We tried several dim sum items and none were anything special. The shrimp shu mai was bland and we tossed all but the one we tried.

We left hungry and would never return. There MUST be decent sim sum in the city better than this.
author: Mike S.

description: Cheap and great food doesnt make u feel fat after either. The women here are nice and work fast.
author: Markus N.

description:
Wow, I love Good Luck Dim Sum!  You can't eat there and no there aren't any carts. There are like two small tables in the back so grab it  to go.  Also try and know what you want before you get up to the counter.  The prices are cheap and you are paying for the food only.  There aren't waitresses, you aren't paying for fancy decor, you pay for good food and that's it.  To me, that is enough, I'd rather just pay for the food then sit in some stuffy establishment, get really awesome service and eat some mediocre lamb.  I should note they only get four stars because I kind of like the carts.  I like being able to see what my options are ahead of time.

On their anniversary they had 30% off all food.  I got 3 boxes of dim sum for $18!!  Awesome!  

The first time I went I had no clue what I was getting into.  I ordered a puffed pastry like item that didn't have anything in it.  Yes, this is how cultured I am, Chinese puff pastry like item.  I even studied Mandarin for a year and I couldn't order properly.  If you are a newbie to the dim sum world, read up and if possible bring a Chinese friend (or a Chinese aficionado) with you, makes life sooo much easier.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description: The line here is always soooo long, but they have a new system with taking a sheet of their menu and circling what you need. Affordable and delicious! Stop by if you're craving a quick dim-sum fix!
author: Amanda C.

description: I'm a quality over quantity type of girl and this place is just the opposite. This place isn't like your traditional dim sum restaurant. There are no carts being pushed around with stacks of little tin cans. It's more like a cafeteria line but the Chinese ladies with broken English serving you aren't wearing hair nets. The ladies are also rude and impatient towards me needing some time to decide what I want. All the dumplings comes in three counts for $1.90. This lady throws everything on a paper plate so they all get stuck together! She gave us these small paper boats and forks to eat our food. I'm sorry... Call me bougie if you like, but I'm not big on eating out of paper boats if it's not coming from an amazing food truck. I kept asking her for an extra paper PLATE but she insisted that I eat with the paper boat she's giving me. I wish I spoke her language so she can understand how I felt and give me a paper plate. I don't care if she had to charge me for a paper plate, JUST GIVE ME A PLATE!! I gave up trying to make her understand me and ate my dim sum out of the paper boat. On a positive note, I like how the shrimp in their Ha Cao stays in the dumpling. That's it.
author: Trish T.

description: Good dim sum, shocking service for non-Asian customers.  Servers look right through patiently-waiting gwai lo as if they were ghosts, preferring to serve the 'real' customers waiting behind them. Payback, perhaps, for 19th-century discrimination?  Or simple cross-cultural rudeness?  As a long-time customer (gwai lo all look same, why recognize?), I'm fed up. Won't go back unless I'm the only one in line.  Even then, I wouldn't be surprised if the servers ignored me.  I'm not Asian.  Why would they notice I was there?
author: Paul S.

description:
Service: they're Chinese and know they have good food, what do you expect?
Food: har gow is really good, but sometimes the dim sum gets cold because it's been sitting in steamers that aren't steaming =( The sui mai was not good, it was just made with pork... The P/F shrimp dumplings were ok the wrapper was thick, good but not a fav. 

I will definitely come back for the har gow.... I just hope I'm lucky and the dim sum is hot this time.
author: Jen L.

description:
This is ONE of my favorite spots to hit up in SF!  When I used to live in Daily City I would stop on by almost every morning to pick up some fresh Dim Sum to each on the drive to Petaluma.  The prices are AMAZINGLY cheap and the quality of food is 2nd to none.  In fact, every time I go over the Golden Gate Bridge I make it a point to pick some Dim Sum up from this place.  The place isn't fancy but there is ALWAYS a line of people waiting to place your orders.  Some of my facvorites are beef Siu Mai, Pork Siu Mai, Churn Fun (Rice Rolls), shrimp dumplings, yellow spong cake, don tot (Egg Custard)... HECK IT"S ALL GOOD!

Ohh... parking sucks BUT that's how it is every where in SF :(
author: Mike M.

description:
This place is super fun. There's no seating, so people basically just wait in line, point at things they want, step outside, stuff their faces, and get in line again.

The value for your money is really good.

The facilities and staff seem clean.

I generally don't like spending too much time in China Town -- but if you have to go, this can be a fun experience -- a good place to bring your tourist visitors.
author: Ian S.

description:
I love this place...cash and carry dim sum.  It's unbelievably cheap and delicious. And it's Zagat-rated (no offense, Yelp!)

Our Favorites:
Shrimp Dumplings
Chive Dumplings
Chive & Chicken Dumpling
Steamed Chicken Buns
Sesame Balls

Don't be intimidated by the staff...they are actually helpful and artful in arranging the dim sum in the takeout cartons!
author: Mo M.

description:
I just ate my weight in dumplings for $7 and I am extremely pleased.

I was hesitant to try dim sum to go since my favorite thing about dim sum is waiting for the carts to go by and taking one of everything. But I had an unbelievable dumpling craving at 1pm on a Monday afternoon and only 30 mins to spare so I powerwalked to Good Luck. Seems like the lunch rush dies down around 1 so there were only a few people in line. I ordered shrimp dumplings, steamed pork dumplings, siu mai beef, and a pork bun. Everything was delicious. A little on the greasy side but it is take out after all. The price is the best part. All the basic menu items are 3 for $1.60. Pork buns are $.85. I  over ordered since it was my first time but you can definitely leave satisfied for under $5.
author: Mary L.

description: Their Dim Sum taste very good. My favorite is the pork and chicken siu mai, not so much on the beef siu mai. All their various dumplings taste good. Same goes to their bread buns with fillings in it.
author: Robert S.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum may be the real reason why I moved back to SF *waves to Kerrie*

But that's not the shocking news. Can you believe that this shanty of a restaurant has an "A" rating from the health department? With how I twice found long strands of hair in my shui mai, the service is rude and Kerrie once got a fork that was obviously recycled from the trash (it was covered with crud) you'd figure that Good Luck Dim Sum either: 

1. Bribed the health code inspector with dim sum

2. Intimidated the inspector just like their customers, by yelling out obscenities at him until he ran away

3. The health inspector got laid that day

Even if there was feces in my shui mai, I'd still eat here. Good Luck Dim Sum gives me a reason to get out of bed in the mornings and a reason not to kill myself after I watch the Raiders lose another game. The food is just that amazing! 

I love you Good Luck Dim Sum, please don't ever leave me! *waves at Kerrie*
author: Dan T.

description:
My favorite take-out dim sum place.

It's far from glamorous, but Good Luck Dim Sum is consistently good and cheap and filling. I am especially happy on those days when my mood tickles for some GLDS, and I find the line at only four or five people deep. I used to live in nearby Laurel Heights, so I definitely got spoiled by my proximity. Now, it's become a special treat to visit.

Yesterday, my latest visit was quite lengthy. The line extended nearly to the back. I suspect some tourists were in line. Word is getting out? My usual order includes chicken sticky rice, har gow, siu mai, steamed pork buns, egg custards, and sesame balls. I noticed that the boxes are now 20 cents each. Good. I usually bring my own containers anyway, being all crazy that way, so now it makes me look even smarter!

It is closed on Tuesdays. I have been disappointed more than once by this fact. And the prices, though they've risen maybe 10% over the past few years, are more than fair. I approve.
author: Randy M.

description: Coming here and seeing only 5 people in line is a miracle! Usually there's a line all the way to the back of the restaurant. Very reasonably priced dim sum and tastes great!  I love the shrimp and chives dumplings, har gow, and siomai. BBQ pork steam buns are such a steal too!! Basically everything is great. I usually get a box of custard tarts to go. Love love love!!
author: Danielle R.

description:
Walked around Clement yesterday in search for some kick ass dim sum... I turned to my iphone Yelp app and decided to go the the spot with the most reviews.  Ended up in the back of a long ass line.  It was helpful that they had printed menus for you to check off while you're waiting to be served.  The guy in front of me kept bitching about  how the old woman ahead of him beat him to all of the sesame balls so he had to wait 10 extra minutes.  

The dim sum was just okay.  I ordered the baked pork buns (didnt seem fresh to me) and the potstickers (I like mine with a crispy bottom, which these werent).  My favs were the deep fried dumplings (very guilty pleasure) but the best I've had so far.  What made it worth the wait were the sweet rice coconut peanut balls.  OMG, I wish I ordered 20 of those.  So fresh and by far my FAV!!!!
author: Lauren S.

description: Ohh yes fresh fresh fresh hot Shrimp dumplings and stickey rice . This place is totally worth waiting in line for. They make there Dim Dm on site and it is fantastic. Happy ever time  I leave this place. u
author: P C.

description:
Whenever I go to Clement, this is place is usually what I look forward to. Dim sum is best for lunch, so I recommend getting it fresh in the morning or noon. It's especially crowded on the weekend mornings and noon. One of the best things about this place is that you can buy a load of dim sum for a mini party or the family. I advise you to grab the paper menu and mark down your order, otherwise it will get a bit difficult.  

A lot of the items are $1.60 for 3 of each. But also items not within that range but still fairly cheap. If you don't wanna wait and sit in a fancy and expensive restaurant, this is the place for you. Really casual, cheap, and the quality of the dim sum is pretty good for casual dining. You can also sit in and eat too, but it's definitely different from other sit in dim sum places since it's casual.

What I like:

-Pan Fried Chive dumplings
-Fried taro root 
-Shrimp Dumpling or Har Gao

I'd say the downside would be that sometimes they run out of certain dim sums and they make you improvise. Then they bring out a new batch, which may have something you possibly wanted before. Some of the ladies might seem mean, but that's just how their facial expressions just are. We're there for the food, not to see them smile, although it would be nice. 

Overall, a great place for ordering to go or to get quick yummy dim sum.
author: Victor Q.

description:
Cheap, good and sometimes fast .....that is a good start. It's about the food and that is it! No frills kind of place. Wait times are about 10 -20 mins. on a Saturday afternoon. Spartan interior, basic counter service where you get a tray of food to take to your table or a bag to take away.  Simple prices, most standard dim sum are  3 pcs. for $ 1.60. The chive dumplings with shrimp  and pork siu mai were excellent and 1 order each of those plus a sweet chicken sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf is plenty as lunch for one. Potstickers, large, cooked just right and plenty filled. 
If you are out near the park museum hopping or biking, this is a good midday lunch  detour to keep you going.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Absolutely amazing dim sum, BUT....

1. You must either come here at lunch time.  If you come in the late PM the dumplings etc will not be fresh.  They will be soggy and be coming apart as they've been sitting in the steamer too long.
2. If you find yourself here in the PM, I'd order something small and sit in the inner part the restaurant, and wait and watch what new dumplings come out.  Then go order those.

If you follow the above, you''ll ensure you will be eating fresh amazing dim sum.  

Prices here are probably the cheapest I can find in the area.  You can take it to go (although I don't like how they will just pile things up in one little paper tray carton) or eat it there.  If you do, find yourself to an empty and clean table (not the cleanest place) and enjoy yourself.  Free hotsauce and soy sauce (you have to ask for vinegar).

Make sure you bring water/drink if you don't want to buy one.  Free forks, if you want chopsticks you have to ask.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
One of the best dim sum i've ever eaten. 
Yes there's a line every time
Yes they only accept cash
and Yes they are not the nicest people

BUT if you just want delicious dim sum to go, with no frills, this is the place for you. 

I almost didn't want to write this review so no more people will find out about this gem of a place. Now, the lines will be even longer.. darn.
author: Lily S.

description:
If you're looking for authentic, greasy, piping hot dim sum served by adorable yet slightly grumpy Asian ladies, look no further than Good Luck Dim Sum.  If you're looking for white-washed high falutin' dim sum, then you're better off paying $40+ at Yank Sing...but you'll get no respect from me.

On this particular morning, I was looking for the former.  Most items are 3 for $1.60.  Some larger items, such as the baked BBQ pork bun, cost more...like $.85.  They have little juice boxes of lychee juice, mango juice or chrysanthemum tea (my personal fav from childhood) for $1 or so to help wash down your grub.  Basically, my boyfriend and I got freakin' stuffed for less than $14.

You can take out, or eat in.  All the tables are accessorized with soy sauce and chunky hot sauce, the usual dim sum accompaniments.

Personal picks: shrimp dumplings, chive dumplings, Malaysian cake, steamed BBQ pork buns (really carmel-ly :D)  

Why no 5 stars? Because their custard buns are a tid bit tough...
author: Sherry C.

description:
Rave all you want about this sh*thole, it's disgusting

The women who "work" there are beyond rude, they are demeaning. I resented the dirty look and smirk I got, when I politely asked for a plastic fork.

A plastic fork!  I hope that didn't eat into their profits!

The dim sum itself was cold, and nowhere near as good as some other places. I'd rather eat at Panda Express at a strip mall in Fairfield than return to this joint

With all the dim sun joints in The City, there is NO need to patronize this place. Not for the food, nor for the VERY dirty tables and floor. Gross
author: Ted K.

description: Service was terrible. The lady behind the counter kept on rushing me to order. Food was cold! One of the kitchen help brought out the trash can from the back in the restaurant right next to the table where we're eating. Totally disgusting!!! Never again.
author: T P.

description:
*There are no dim sum carts here. This is primarily a take-out place with long lines/waits. 

God forbid you touch one of their pink boxes! So, my friends and I ordered way too much food and we had to take it to go. Yes, we ordered 4 boxes too much. So, we grabbed 4 boxes without asking the dim sum ladies. After that all hell broke loose. THREE ladies, independently, came up to us to yell at us about the boxes. They EACH opened up every single box to make sure there was a lot of food inside the boxes. Apparently, we are supposed to ask them first before taking the boxes, because, otherwise we would have to pay for them. My friends and I hypothesized that they were being so cheap because old asian ladies come to take pink boxes all the time - do we look like old asian ladies?? 

In any case, here's the drill : Get a pink piece of paper and pen from the counter. The 3 for $1.60 means that you can get 3 pieces of X dim sum for $1.60. The top three chinese characters with $1.00 next to them means: coffee, tea, and soda. The dim sum is huge. Each dumpling is twice the normal dumpling. I didn't expect that. However, they were all lukewarm, a little soggy, and tasted pretty much all the same. The oily bread was really, really hard. I ended throwing them out. 

Try a different place, you might actually get hot food!
author: Stacy T.

description:
Even though my husband loved this place...this is my review!  I am just convinced that I don't like Chinese food.  I love dumplings so I thought this would be a safe bet! I ordered the egg rolls (just in case) and I'm glad I did because you can't go wrong with egg rolls!  After looking at my chicken dumplings, I'm convinced it isn't chicken (clearly I have no proof of this but my picky eyeballs).  I couldn't even make myself take a bite...too scared!

Anyway, this place is CHEAP! Cheap is actually an understatement.  We ordered two trays full of food (enough for 3 meals, at least) and our total was $13!
author: Vanessa L.

description: $1.70/3 pieces. They didn't have two items on my favorite dim sum list (peanut dumpling and bean curd roll).
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I call it emotional ping pong.

YAY - It's Saturday!!
BOO - It's raining.

YAY - I want Dim Sum!!
BOO - Yank Sing is too touristy.

YAY - I found another place!!
BOO - All the way in the Richmond.

YAY - Found it!
BOO - No parking.

YAY - Walking up, no line!!
BOO - Shit, didn't look inside, 25 people deep.

YAY - Smells amazing!!
BOO - The shouting is giving me a headache.

YAY - Almost there!
BOO - Did that chick just throw chicken feet across the room?

YAY - Holy crap it's cheap!
BOO - Food coma here I come.

Do yourself a favor, get it to go.  Pretty good dim-sum for the price.  

The pieces are a little larger than the standard sizes too.

AND THEY HAVE CHINESE SAUSAGE ROLLS!

Yay!
author: Archie R.

description:
I wanted to try Dim Sum in SF, Yelp gave me "Goodluck Dim Sum" with a very good review. I came there at 3PM, so there were only 2 customers. I wanna try some of many kinds, I ordered two pieces of each for to go. They gave a very uncomfortable look. Then I asked them for soy sauce and hot sauce. They just gave me one little pack of soy sauce. I repeated for a hot sauce. They ignored me and packed food for another customer. I don't understand what attitude they served. It's unendurable for customer!

I still thought maybe their Dim Sum was very delicious, but it's too bad. No taste special. It was far away from qualified Dim Sum of Elite and NBC in Rosemead, CA. 

I never wasted my time at their Dim Sum again.
author: Natalie M.

description: Delicious cheap dim sum. Can't ask for anything more. This was the first time I have been to a dim sum place where you wait in line and fill out an order form of what you wanted. I guess it was pretty efficient because we weren't in line for a long time even though there were a lot of people there. You can get stuffed with this mid-to-high quality dim sum for about $5-7. Worth checking out!
author: Kevin H.

description:
I am from a Chinese family in Australia and my mother makes all sorts of dim sums and this is probably one of the best value for money dim sum place I have eaten at.

Definitely worth trying if you are in the Richmond area! Will be back there to try different dim sums! Not to mention the great service!
author: Steven T.

description:
I have 1 unfinished review...
....From 2 months ago...

Has it really been that long? 

Thank goodness my memory is good! So from what I can recall...Like a cheap Asian, I could practically sniff out the epicness of this place while staring at a list of Dim Sum reviews on Yelp early Sunday afternoon.

This place has a solid rating for a reason. It's not gourmet by any means, and the format for ordering food is rather confusing if you have no idea what you're doing. Luckily, the ladies behind the counter have a working knowledge of English and they'll bark out their demands while you puzzle over the list of dim sum they offer. 

It's a really tiny hole in the wall joint and there isn't a lot of space for seating inside. Most people here seem to order to go, which seems like a good choice if you live nearby. Either way, you grab a little pink sheet of paper with their menu and find a golf pencil. You circle what you want and indicate the quantity somewhere off to the side if you want more than one order. It can be a bit confusing if you don't know your dim sum, so beware! After you make your choices, you show your paper to the Chinese lady behind the counter and she'll grab a pink box and shove your food up in the hizzay. So if you eat in, or take out, it all goes in the same packaging. 

The food very much reflects the people in the place. Hardcore. The three of us ordered about everything on the menu, and the lady was able to calculate it all by hand. Jeez...that's reinforcing a stereotype right there. Their buns and dumplings were very solid. As in greasy, filling, and quite tasty. No delicate little flowers here...

I was pretty happy with most of the food here, however I was a bit disappointed in the chicken feet and their pork spareribs in black bean sauce. The chicken feet seemed to be cooked all mushy and the flavor was a bit off. Both the chicken feet and pork spareribs had these weird bone splinters. Like they had bought discounted chicken's feet...the ones that were broken from the genetically retarded chickens from KFC or something. 

I'd probably give this place more of a 3.5 stars...their cooler drinks were a bit expensive for what they were. Asian juice boxes should not be a dollar each! However the overall price of this place is pretty freakin' cheap. It makes me feel very happy deep inside. Meow. 

Also...if you're a vegetarian...I'd watch out how the food is prepared. As I was enjoying my dim sum and commenting on how heavy the food felt, my eyes rested upon a stack of boxes in the corridor to the kitchen. It took a while for me to comprehend in my food-coma-induced-haze...but there it was...LARD. 

Delicious.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Omg! I loved the wonderful little treats here! I wouldn't have guessed, based on appearances, that this place was going to have such fantastic food.

I especially loved the pork buns and the very friendly customer service. :) Also, they have a sauce they make themselves that customers were raving about while i was there - and it was GOOD.
author: Jason B.

description: If you catch this place at the right time the dim sum is AMAZING for the price.  If you go at a slow time it can be pretty bad.  I find it hit or miss, but worth the gamble!
author: Courtney C.

description:
All I have to say is EWW!
I visited Sunday afternoon. Long, long, line and I was starving. Men kept coming out of the kitchen with carts of hot, steaming batches of deliciousness to replenish (or so I thought). 

When it was my turn, I gave the surly woman behind the counter my pink form with circled requests. I said "for here." I actually just wanted to have a few pieces there, dipped in chili sauce scrumptiousness, a bit of tea, then take the rest with me. So I asked her for a box. "NO BOX FOR YOU!" she yelled and furiously shook her head. I started laughing, but realized she was serious. (Fyi: You do have to pay extra for the to go pink boxes and I was willing to do so.) 

Not sure if my request really pissed her off, but in a wild frenzy she totally piled all the dim sum onto a single plate. This created a dim sum MOUNTAIN. She had also added six pieces I did not ask for. Shumai was rolling down onto the counter. It was completely ridiculous. The man behind me quietly told me to take a few plastic bags with me. Counter lady then shouted, "HOW MANY FORKS? I laughed and said, "Ummm, just one!" Then she screamed, "YOU EAT FIRST, THEN COME BACK!"  I wanted to run away but decided I was too hungry to leave. 

I went to go make myself some milky Lipton tea--they were out of cream. I sat at a dirty, grease covered table and all the chili sauce containers had been scraped clean. Btw, in order to even begin eating, I had to pack up some of the dim sum into the plastic bags and store it away in my purse like a hobo squirrel! Final note; everything I consumed was cold, chewy (in a bad way) and super slimey greasy. So sad! Shrimp har gow, pork shumai, barbeque pork bun, pork pot sticker. I also tried chicken shumai ( what I did not ask for).

Yikes! Never again!
author: Jen J.

description:
Best congee for under $2 in town.  Their pork and preserved egg congee ($1.60) is thick and flavorful.  They must have cooked the congee for a long, long time.  The shredded pork is very tasty and they add preserved eggs, fresh scallions, and fried won ton strips.  They don't have the fried Chinese donut that goes so well with congee, but the won ton strips are a nice substitute and included in the price.  I like to pick out one or two orders of dim sum to go with the congee.  

The har gow (shrimp dumplings) are good though pasty.  I was annoyed that some of the skins were already broken.  All their dumplings are pretty solid, such as the crystal dumplings and shark fin dumplings ($1.20 - $1.30 for three) though not out of this world, five star worthy good.

The steamed chicken and Chinese sausage and rice dish ($2.20) makes a satisfying and cheap lunch.  I've tried to make this at home and it doesn't turn out as good as theirs (and neither does my congee).  They also sell cheap steamed and baked buns.  The lines here are legendary but they move fast.  The best time to come to avoid the lines (and find free, easy street parking) is at 7 AM when they first open and the items are fresh too.   They have a few tables if you want to eat it there.  Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Great prices, no skimping on the dumpling size, and great tasting food...how could you possibly go wrong?  Whenever I'm on Clement street, I always have to stop by here and grab a yummy treat.  I usually order the shrimp dumplings, sharkfin dumplings, crystal dumplings (clear wrap with pork, shrimp, and chives), and a dozen of baked bbq pork buns.  And what does my bill come up to...under $20!!!  Skip the long lines and overpriced dimsum at restaurants and head over to good luck dim sum and get some more bang for your buck!
author: Kristen T.

description: This isn't a fancy dining place, but it is a great place to order dim sum to go. It's not really meant for sit in, although there are tables. Expect a line, but it shouldn't last too long. It's fast food, the Asian way, and probably cheaper and more delicious than your typical burger and fries meal. I love dim sum, and this place is one of the places that satisfies my need for it.
author: April D.

description: Best dim sum To-go on clement st! Dumplings are tender and tastey - definitely way better than the wing lee one!
author: Elizz H.

description:
I came here without realizing it was a to go dim sum place so I was a bit surprised when I walked in and saw there was very little seating. There was a fairly long line that soon extended through the entire length of the restaurant. The restaurant was well lit but the floor and tables were not particularly clean. One thing to note is the customers are responsible for cleaning up after themselves, service is practically nonexistent. Also, there weren't many drinks available.

When the food came it only came with plastic utensils and cheap paper trays that you get fries in but this is a take out place. As for the food itself, the dim sum was tasty but, as others have pointed out, only lukewarm. The dumplings were chewy and a bit doughy but the flavor was right. However, the shrimp crepes were quite mediocre with very little shrimp. As for the sweets, the lotus bun tasted good but the bun was hard and cold. On the other hand the fried sesame balls were actually on the warmer side and not overly oily. The egg custards were also nicely flavored but again they were cold. The pricing seemed fairly average, maybe on the cheap side but not anything to write home about.

Overall, this restaurant is a place to get some relatively cheap dim sum but not really great in any particular area.
author: Ray Z.

description: Ordering is stressful when there are lots of people at the counter and no discernible line but overall the dim sum (and price) is very good. :D They have a pretty clean bathroom too.
author: K G.

description:
Great dim sum. I come here often. Even though I don't speak chinese, I just fill out the paper and write what I want. Otherwise, I'll have a language barrier trying to order. That's what happens when you're ABC.

Long lines but great Dim Sum here. Try the shark Fin Dumplings. BBQ pork buns are really good here. 

Can't go wrong with the su mui. 

Service? Well.. What do you expect. It's like a little chinatown in this area. You won't get A+ Service, but honestly, you just want the food, so go at it!
author: Christopher J.

description:
I think this place is overrated. As a southern Californian who has eaten my fair share of dim sum, I found this place to be profoundly mediocre. The shrimp dumplings were average, the pork balls are only decent, and the pork baos are what you would find at any Chinese food place. I will say that thanks to its relatively fast turnover, the food is not old. 

On top of the average food, you'll only get good service if you're white or speak Cantonese.
author: Teddy N.

description:
I've lived with Good Luck dim sum for over a decade now. The same ladies that I remember from so long ago still work here like they haven't aged at all. I didn't realize it won so many awards from Yelp and Zagat.

I didn't eat lunch today so I came here for an afternoon snack. No line but a lot of the selection sold out. I just got a pan-fried chive dumpling, 2 shrimp dumplings, a steamed BBQ pork bun, a stick rice ball, and a minced meat dumpling (fun gou).

The chive dumpling has the best crisp of any place that makes it. The filling was pretty average and good tasting. The shrimp dumplings were a little smaller than I am familiar with at sit-down yum cha restaurants but for the value you are paying, this is acceptable. The shrimp is pretty fresh. I haven't had the sticky rice ball in possibly over a year, I couldn't even remember what it is called in Canto. The ball is a little worse than the last time I had it since the rice quality is a bit worse but the size is still the same thankfully. I love the minced meat dumpling here. This time, I thought there was less filling than usual since the taste of the wrap/skin overtook the meat. The BBQ pork bun was on the lower end of the spectrum, too much dough/bun and not enough cha siew filling. 

Most of the tables have soy sauce spilled from whoever sat there last. You are to bus and clean your own table. People, please be courteous and pick up after youself! I didn't have to fight for tables late afternoon but a clean table was actually hard to find. The chili sauce was empty at most tables too. When there is downtime, the chefs and employees will gossip and just chatter about life at a table or across the room. It's interesting to eavesdrop if you can understand.
author: Dominic T.

description:
This is one of the few good take out Dim Sum restaurants that I know of, however, the only problem is the wait. The portions are really large and the prices are very very reasonable. Just don't be caught with too much dim sum because it can go bad after a day or two. 

Be ready for a wait of 30-45 minutes on a saturday or sunday morning. There are seats and tables to eat inside the restaurant as well, but the line snaking inside the restaurant may make it feel cramped a bit. Not sure if they accept credit card or not because I paid with cash.
author: Michael C.

description:
Came here with some friends on New Years.  Man was it packed.  Note to self, come before noon.  The line was all the way to the back of the restaurant and easily took half an hour to get to the front.  Everyone in the store was commenting on how long the lines were and that they've never seen it so long, but they still stood in line.  that's how good it is!

3 items for $1.60!! Nothing really beats that.  Their Haw Gaw is huuge and super tasty.  I also really enjoyed their Chinese Chive dumpling. mmmm. *drool*
author: Jacq L.

description:
Love, LOVE good luck Dim Sum.  Prices are a steal and the dim sum is mouth watering. 

Definitely recommend the baked pork bun over the steamed pork bun:  The baked pork bun is only $.30 more and much larger and yummier than the steamed bun.  Unfortunately, last time I went the felllow in front of me brought out their entire stash- 50 baked pork buns to go!  I was just about ready to pour a bottle of soy sauce on his head but decided that assault of a chinese elderly man in a dim sum restaurant may render me banned for life.

And talk about the service... damn those chinese ladies scare me more than my mother did when I was a kid.  No matter WHAT i do when I get in there and no matter how much I try to behave myself, I always seemed to get yelled at when it's my time to order.  Ugh.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
There is an awful lot of hype and some outstanding reviews about Good Luck Dim Sum.  I really don't know what the fuss is all about.  I finally had a chance to sample some items here over the weekend, and I was truly not impressed.

Let's start with the har gow or Shrimp Dumpling as they are called here.  Good dim sum shouldn't be about the skin that houses scrumptious fillings, but at Good Luck I found some of the thickest dumpling skin anywhere in the City.  The filling was not impressive either because besides some firm, crunchy shrimp I found a lot more tapioca filler and chopped bamboo than the worst places in Chinatown.

The Fun Kor had the same problem with a thick outer skin and a mediocre filling of chopped pork, chopped pork cartilage (those aren't water chestnuts like you think they are!), chopped mushrooms and lots of cilantro.

The baked barbecue pork buns fared slightly better, but yes those are whole chunks of pork fat in the filling.

The only item I did enjoy were their lotus paste buns with a quality steamed white bun and lots of the sweet lotus paste filling.

Yes, it's cheap here because you're paying for lots of rice flour and water for their thick dumpling skins and tapioca starch for their cheap fillings.  If I'm standing in a long line for quality dim sum on Clement Street, you'll find me at Wing Lee Bakery but not here.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: First time here this past Saturday 7/26 and really, really liked this place. Small mom & pop shop with good food, err Dim Sum. My wife and I wanted dim sum after we left the De Young and this place is pretty close. Shared a table w/some strangers and had a great conversation and good food. If you're in the area you need to check this place out.
author: PETE Z.

description:
Authentic dim sum and unbeatable prices. But if you're looking for a traditional dim sum place with carts this is not the place for you. 

You have to order at the counter and take your food to one of their 8(?) tables. You can take one of their lists (in Chinese & English) and circle what you want or just order by pointing at what you want when you get to the front of the line. We got a glimpse into the kitchen and the chefs crank out the dim sum at an unbelievable speed. 

The only thing I wouldn't order again is the pork bun. My husband and I tried the baked ones. Then my family tried the steamed ones during a different visit. We finally figured out why we didn't like these. The pork is too sweet. Everything else at this place is good.
author: A L.

description:
I don't get what all the hype is about this place.  Don't get me wrong, the dim sum is pretty darn good, but it's frickin Zagat rated....multiple years.   

San Francisco and Oakland are full of these hole-in-the-wall, take-out dim sum places.  These places are usually no frills, and all about providing dirt cheap dim sum in sizable portions versus quality.   

This place is by far, the highest quality of hole-in-the-wall take-out dim sum places. I'd go back here again and again.  But Zagat rated????   It's no Koi Palace.  

Bottom line, if you want cheap delicious, no-frills dim sum without having to go to a sit down restaurant, this is the place.
author: Lee H.

description: Great affordable place. The shrimp and chives dumplings are a must!! Be sure to stop by early b/c they run out of a lot of stuff by like 4 pm.
author: Xing L.

description:
Cheap and Delicious. That's what it's all about here. You don't come here for the ambiance and surroundings. It is after all a large pepto bismal pink room. I don't think that would be anyone's ideal surroundings. 

I have lived in the Sunset for most of my life so I had the chance to try alot of dim sum and this ranks up there. I definitely don't come for the service...the women behind the counter are surly at best.

There is almost always a line out the door so the dim sum doesn't sit around for long.

Awesome congee..I love porridge.
Lots of dim sum with shrimp
Good Sui Mai
Har Gow
Yummy in my tummy sticky rice with chicken
author: Maria M.

description:
Cheap food and RUDE service! what more can u ask for.

Popular place for low priced (most items are 3 for $1.50) Dim Sum outside of Chinatown. Service is fast and to the point, so don't expect much pleasantries. There's a system of pink half sheets of papers to circle your menu choices, but sometimes there are no pink papers available. VERY Important: if the price is 3 for $1.50, then ONE order has 3 pieces. Therefore, if u write 3 on the pink sheet, that means u are ordering 9 pieces.

I will not mince words, these women can be VERY rude, mean and angry looking. Often impatient and constantly sighing when helping customers. ALWAYS with a long face and murmuring nonsense (swearing in Chinese). Usually native Chinese speakers are attended first, while ignoring other customers in line and making them wait. Only one woman is half-pleasant (only when the others are not around, she has short black hair and timid demeanor), the rest are ALL angry and bitter old women. IF u decide to shop here, my advice is to don't get upset, think positive. These are just minor annoyances in life. Like Bobby McFerrin's song says, "Don't Worry, Be Happy".

Most Dim Sum is best when hot, so the ideal time to buy is during midmorning when the food comes out of the kitchen. Many of the steamed dumplings are good (shrimp with taro, etc.). I specially like the fried taro dumplings and their baked BBQ pork buns, it has a good amount of tasty chopped pork meat inside. Most people order to go, but there's also a few tables if you want to eat inside.

The steamed dim sum in the round metal steamers are made fresh daily (the employees get to take home the steamed leftovers at the end of the day). But the fried and baked dim sum on the glass display could be from the day before. The women control the flow of dim sum that comes from the kitchen by yelling what items need restocking. If you only see a few pieces on the glass display early on the day, those are OLD. When you see a whole tray or more than half tray full, then those were made fresh that day.

In this area of Clement street, Wing Lee Bakery (a lot nicer to customers) and Good Luck Dim Sum are the most popular shops.
author: Luis C.

description:
A really solid 4 star. I can't believe I'm a native and this was my first time here. 
No more Yank Sing for $60 this place has dim sum that is just as good without the tab. 
The line is long. Parking is kinda of a pain but any where you go to get dim sum it's the same wether is downtown or in Chinatown. 
It's worth it though- the staff is friendly and treats you well despite you being their 458 customer by 2pm, they dont rush you either. 
 The dim sum is really good, incredibly inexpensive and it's a casual place.
author: Tasha A.

description:
Hands down my favorite take out dim sum joint in the area!

This place has a wide variety of your typical dim sum fare at bargain prices.  Most items are 3 for $1.60.  I typically "splurge" and often order enough food to last myself for 2 or 3 meals.  Total damage: a little over $10.

My usual order starts with the dim sum staples: 1 order of sui mai and 1 order of har gow.  I'll typically throw in a don tot or two (egg custard for my non-Canto speaking friends), order of fried taro, a few other orders of dumplings like the pan fried dumplings (delish!) and a bao or two.

My only complaint is that the line is usually long.  And a word of advice: bring your own pen to mark off the order sheet because the little pink box of pens is usually empty!  Stop stealing pens yo!
author: Matt S.

description:
Authentic, inexpensive, and derrishhhus. The resturaunt is not much to look at but in the case of Good Luck Dim Sum  you should not judge a book by it's cover.

My only complaint is that I wish it was open later.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Not worth the wait. I think people mistaken this place to be good by the looks of the long line you have to wait in to get your food but I call this place SLOW! I've never been to a dim sum restaurant where I have to wait until 15 minutes? AND there are 4 ladies behind the counter -_- I came in on a saturday afternoon and I couldn't believe how slow it was going. The ladies are neither polite either though I understand they are trying to get the line moving.

 I hate the way they have people fill out their little pink forms for the food when its a complete waste of time. People end up asking "What's in this? What's in that?" so Good Luck Dim Sum would be better off labeling their food instead of having people fill out the forms. Plus its such a complete waste of paper and time. 

They charge $1.60 for their 3 items here and I could swear it was $1.50 just a few days ago. Maybe I'm wrong but darn it if I just missed the cut! 

Their shirmp dumping was just A-OK to me, nothing special and I've definitely had better. No worth the wait in line nor the trouble to find parking here.
author: Connie C.

description:
The lines are long which gives you plenty of time to ponder what you want. The prices are ridiculously cheap which means you can try nearly everything and never get your bill to $20. (Two of us sampled widely with food left over and had two cokes for well under $15)

I ate here at 10:45 on Saturday morning and didn't need to eat again until dinner and even then I couldn't manage much. Now that's some serious value!

A run down of items sampled:
Chinese Chive Dumpling - Excellent
Lucky Ball - Skip
Shrimp Dumpling - Excellent
Pork Siu Mai - Excellent
Pot Sticker - Very Good
Chive Dumpling w/ Shrimp - Excellent
Steam B.b.q Pork Bun - Good
Sausage Rolls - Skip
Egg custard tart - Good

Good Luck is a must for any dim sum lover.
author: Miriam W.

description:
So. Fantastically. Cheap! (and really good too...)
Really, you can get a decently sized lunch here for a little under five bucks, and depending on how much food you want for lunch, a lot under five bucks. 
Today my friend and I got one order of the Chicken Siu Mai and two orders of the Shrimp Gow, which were both really very delicious and enough food for the both of us. What I usually don't like about the Siu Mai in other places is that is has a little sour taste to it but this one was actually really nice. 
I'm going to go back and try some more of their sweets, from other reviews I have heard they are worth it.
Really worth trying for a cheap, quick, lunch.
author: Anna B.

description: Can't beat the price for decent dim sum. Locals come here for a quick cheap meal to go. Only tourist seem to stay in. Don't expect quality customer service if you do.
author: Min S.

description:
Dim sum is very greasy, really nothing special.
Don't waste your time here, too much attitude. Over rated.  I share the same experience as some the of one star reviews. 
The Emperor Wears No Clothes.
author: A C.

description: The dim sum was pretty good, I'm feeling lucky!
author: Scott M.

description:
Cheap and good dim sum!!!

I really like that they have a sheet with the menu printed. You can circle the dim sum you want and hand the sheet to the ladies behind the counter.  This really helps with language barrier issues. 

Their dim sum is also very fresh! In the ~15 minutes i stood in line, I saw a little Chinese man come out from the kitchen about 3-4x with a new batch of freshly steamed dim sum.

We got a TON of food for $12.60. When i say a ton, i mean enough to feed 4 people (even though there was only 2 of us). Don't worry, we didn't eat everything in one sitting. :P
author: Jennifer C.

description: I wished I had good luck here. The menu said shrimp, taro dumplings, so I thought the dumplings contained shrimp and taro. I don't eat pork and was surprised to learn after the fact that the dumplings contained pork. I wondered why the menu didn't specify this. Also, the counterwoman had a terrible cough and would have been better off with a face mask.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Don't go here.  Don't get in line. Please.   I don't want anyone blocking my way to the counter.   Any more people going here will only make it more impossible to pick up the absolute best dim sum carryout in San Francisco.   And in this town, that's saying something!  What do you get here?  A big selection of, frankly delicious, Dim Sum standards, ready to go!   Typically, this is the point where I describe my favorites - but here it's ALL good.  Shu Mai, crystal dumplings, chive dumplings, mmmmm. Two giant carryout bags full (plenty for 4) for about $23.  Oh, and be sure to grab some chicken and rice for lunch tomorrow.  (yea, because you won't be hungry enough to eat it today after all the other stuff you bought.)
author: Eric S.

description:
Alright, so I'm giving this place 5-stars because have not seen decent cheap dim sum enough to become jaded and critique dim sum to-go dishes...

The ish was good. And If you can split it with a friend, pay less than 10 bucks each, AND leave stuffed with leftovers....well thats a huge win in my book right there. My recommendation is to get a big donut box full of your favorite selections and take it for a nice picnic in the park. SOOO good.

My favorite? Fried Taro. BBQ Pork Buns. Sweet Rice Balls filled with beef. Beef and Pork Shu Mai...who am I kidding, everything was bomb, and thats not even half of what we ordered. Most selections were 3 pieces for 1.50, some things were a la carte (.50 for a piece to 3.00 for a big thing), and you could probably try everything on the menu for around 35 bucks. Apparently I missed the memo you are supposed to get Porridge though--next time.

Hurray for a cheap dim sum diamond in the city! On the real though--how are there like 10 to-go dim sum places all next to each other on Clement?! How do they survive!?!
author: Samantha R.

description: Decent tasting dim sum - but super cheap price. Don't expect things to look pretty or taste extraordinary. It is a small shop, minimal seating (recommend you take out), and expect a long ass line.
author: Daniel K.

description: 60 cents for a chai sui bao seems ludicrous to me, so I had to grab one and eat it as I strolled down the street. The texture of the pork and bao itself were excellent, though overall it was a little too sweet for my liking. The hunt continues for the best bao in Richmond...
author: Tresna L.

description: LOUSY customer service. The ladies are not very friendly. But the dim sum is fantastic! The line is usually long and not a lot of sitting space.
author: SF S.

description:
I have been going here since I was a kid. My dentist is about two blocks away from Good Luck Dim Sum, so after every visit to the dentist, I eat here. There's nothing better than eating some delicious dim sum after getting your pearly whites cleaned.

Anyway, about the food. Good Luck Dim Sum is definitely a hole in the wall - a tiny little place stuck in between two. Usually, there's a long line of people getting as much dim sum as they can. Prices are relatively low compared to other dim sum places I've been to (especially in SoCal - I have yet to see a place like this there, or maybe I haven't looked hard enough). Although the prices are low, the quality of the dim sum makes it seem like it costs so much more. 

I usually get the shui mai, the one with the shrimp, and the one with the chives. My bad for not remembering most of the names for these delicious little things, but what I remember is how they taste. 

If you choose to dine in, they put all the dim sum in a little tray, like one of those trays they put hot dogs in. Good Luck Dim Sum makes you feel like you're at home - sitting down in one of the tables is usually someone making some fresh dim sum. While some people may be appalled to see that, but I have no problem with it. I seem to find it a bit comforting...but then again that's just me.

Anyway, 5 stars. This is my all time favorite dim sum place. Everytime I visit Clement St., I always eat at Good Luck Dim Sum.
author: Patricia D.

description:
Holy moly... At the time of consumption, I was torn between giving Good Luck a 4 or 5, thinking "there's always gonna be something better out there, right?"  Now, having moved next to Oakland Chinatown and trying out their popular dim sum take-out spot, I can confidently say that Good Luck Dim Sum is the bee's knees! I still can't believe the great quality of har gow I got from this place for a TAKE-OUT dim sum joint.

Quality... check! Lots of food for cheap... check! Winning over my stomach and heart... double check! Oh how I miss not living near you...

P.S. I rarely write review updates (this is my first) and I rarely give out 5 star reviews... Just a little side note to help with your decision to check this place out :)
author: Ongie C.

description: I'm more for the traditional sit down, carts come by, and you pick what you want at a leisurely pace kind of dim sum, so even though the food is good, I'm just giving 3 stars. This place was PACKED around lunch time on the weekend, and you just stand in this long, long line (while another person or persons in your party reserves one of the very few tables in the place) and then order what you want at the counter. You then take it to go (those take-out boxes are not free either!) or eat it there, if you were lucky enough to snag a table. My family eats a LOT so they weren't able to give us everything we ordered at once, nor did they have it all -- what's dim sum without the porridge?! Anyway, you basically are given a tray piled with the food, so it almost looks unappetizing when you're ready to dig in. And this might be weird, but it tasted better later that day when we reheated it for part of our dinner!
author: Kathy L.

description:
Excellent prices for decent dim sum, emphasis on decent and price. The shrimp dumplings (haw gow) is very good and I do think of them when I want large quantities of take out. I have not tried everything but that item stands out. The shui mai is good. My vegetarian coworkers gooble down the vegetarian egg rolls... but I agree that it's probably better when it comes out fresh.
Rude service. They run out often especially later in the day. They will tell you call ahead to order for large orders... but be warned... I ordered 24 orders in Chinese of the shrimp dumplings for my sister to pick up. When she arrived, she was told we never put  in an order. They thought she did not understand Chinese but she knew enough to understand one of them telling the other that they gave away her order to someone else earlier.
Expect long lines at certain times of the day also.
author: jane f.

description:
Ok, so I've returned to Good Luck nearly 20 times since writing the original review, lol. They deserve 4-stars. 

Once you get past being shoved and elbowed around at the counter (by some of the customers that are elderly Chinese women, jk, but not jk), and the overall hole-in-the-wall-ness, get into the groove by your 3rd visit, this place is great :) Even the counter gals seem nicer.

Note: On my 15th visit, I overheard someone placing an order for "pieces" rather than "orders" (orders come in 3's). Doh! You can circle the item and indicate say, 2 for pieces ... but just tell them clearly, or you might get yelled at when they stuff the box with "orders".
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
Now that we live on the south side of the city and my parents live on the north side, we have a Christmas morning tradition of dropping in here to pick up a veritable dim sum feast before opening gifts. We will leave home around 9am, easily find parking nearby...and there's still a 40 minute wait between us and our food. My tip: go EARLY. If you stop in at the normal brunch hour on the weekends, bring an energy drink because it will be a while.

But it's SO worth the wait. My Chinese "grandma" (aka my parents' next door neighbor who fed me a few times a week during my childhood and forced my mom to brew up some awful-smelling herbs and rub me with Tiger Balm when I was sick) recommended this place to us a long time ago, and it's by far the best dim sum we have had on the Clement Street corridor. If you can, eat there because all food degrades during transportation. That way, you can get the full effect of the flaky egg custard crusts, the gentle pop of biting into the har gow, and the tenderness of the spareribs.
author: Sara Y.

description:
My go-to place for dim sum! Love everything here.
Try out the black sweet soy sauce on the tables, delicious!
The only drawbacks are the ladies behind the counter are grouchy as hell. They are doing you a favor by selling you their delicious dim sum and they know it. Bring cash, know what you want to order, speak loudly and clearly, don't ask for extra napkins or bags or forks, you'll be fine.
author: V V.

description:
We were in search of a good dimsum place and YELP pointed us in this direction.

At first glance, this hole-in-the wall did not hold much promise as we were not even in Chinatown as I imagined we would be.  Our cabbie told us we were in the 2nd Chinatown, and that there were 4 Chinatowns apparently.  Um, who knew?

Anyway, it's a small place, with long lines of people buying all sorts of dim sum, and taking them ... TO GO!  There were about six small tables in the back of the restaurant, and we had no problem finding a place to sit.  I guess the locals knew something we did not.  It is better to enjoy this yummy food OUTSIDE where the views are awesome and the air is fresh!

Still, love the selection, the super cheap prices, the yummy food, and most of all ... the DIMSUM NAZIs who handle that dim sum counter with frightening efficiency!  One lady even had the gall to come to our table (fortunately before we started our meal), count the number of plates, plastic forks and spoons + napkins we had, and decided to take away 2 spoons, 1 plate and a couple of napkins (leaving us with 2 napkins each).  I was so caught open-mouthed and completely taken by surprise that I just looked at her ... then at my girlfriends ... and just burst out laughing!  OMG ... are you serious?

So my GF had to walk back to the counter and beg for the spoon back so we could enjoy our shared porridge.  Another GF was terrified of cuting into her Chinese sausage bun because she was afraid of breaking her spoon and the possibililty of not being given a replacement!  We had so much fun laughing about this really strange customer service, and had to figuratively draw straws on who would walk back to the Dim Sum Nazis to buy a take away box.

Looking forward to more visits to GLD on my next SF trip.  And next time, I will bring my own plastic cutlery! :p
author: Caren L.

description: This was the first time I have been here and I was impressed. The dim sum was tastely and pretty inexpensive (about $1.80 per each order) . I really liked the pork sui mai and steamed pork buns. The potstickers I ordered were not as good. Sui Mai is my favorite I thought the sui mai here was decent. It wasn't too greasy and it was very tasty. The steamed pork buns were large and the pork was a little bit too sweet, but I still enjoyed eating them (if you don't like the spongy texture of the steamed pork buns, try the baked ones). I also ordered egg rolls, which were decent. Service just okay. Overall, if you are looking for some cheap, decent dim sum, this is a great place. For the price, I have no complaints.
author: Brian G.

description:
Usually I am not a fan of take out dim sum. I do not usually believe its good unless it arrives to me in the little steamers being delivered to me in a little cart with Chinese ladies convincing me everything is good. But my mind changed today. This place for dim sum is surprising very very tasty and whats even better is it is super CHEAP (on top of not having to pay for tax & tips). This place is LEGIT!

Har Gow (shrimp dumpling)- I"m usually very particular when it comes to this. This is one of my favorite dishes I HAVE to HAVE when I eat dim sum. The skin was not hard like some other places I've had when taken to go. It was chewy and soft and really delicious. And the ingredients were tasty and fresh and didn't taste cheap like most other places.

Siu Mai (pork dumpling)- I think it taste like most other places for it. I'm not a big fan of siu mai but it wasn't bad either. And trust me I've had REALLY REALLY bad siu mai. 

Potsticker- typical potsticker filled with an overload of meat

Fried chive w/ shrimp dumpling- even though I got it to go you can still taste the fryness in it. It was also very tasty just like getting it at the dim sum restaurant. The skin was good as well. 

Porridge- How can I complain? $1.80 for a pretty decent size of pork with preserve egg porridge! I couldn't even finish it!

So I got 3 har gows, 2 siu mai, 1 potsticker, 2 fried chive w/ shrimp dumplings, 1 porridge all for $6!!!! Now how can you complain about that!

I will definitely go back again! I definitely recommend!
author: Annie L.

description:
Ohhh... I have not been here in a while.  

I love take out dimsum from here...  Just order and go home and enjoy!!  They have really good typical dim sum fare, and jook/congee/porridge (whichever one you use)...I eat for about a week from the take out I get here.  Yeah, I'm a hoarder of food!

Cheap as hell too! 

But always, always a freakin' line!
author: Fannie S.

description:
I had to get up at 7AM to go somewhere with some friends, and this was one of the only dim sum places open so early!  We stopped in to get a quick bite to eat and ordered the usual: shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, shrimp & chive dumplings, bbq pork buns (steamed & baked), sesame balls, and egg tarts.

They only had the split open top steamed bbq buns, which I was never a fan of.  The split tops are the worst (in general, not this place in particular).  Everything else was okay to pretty good.
