The egg tarts had too much crust in my opinion, but the egg custard was super custardy, which is a win in my book.

The woman helping us over the counter was a little impatient and slightly rude to us, and we were the only people in there ordering.

On a side note, this dim sum place doesn't seem to do any baking, so there's no sponge cake, no "pineapple" bun, etc.
author: H. L.

description:
Hands down best dim sum on clement. In fact, best dim sum I've ever had.  Great prices (3 pork buns for 1.60). 

Line is usually long around lunch time (out the door) so beware.
author: Calvin D.

description: The Dim Sum is so cheap and delicious. They are a fast togo and eat in place. The food is so fresh. It's a little hole in the wall easy to miss but once you go in you are blown away. This is the dim sum place to go in San Fransisco.
author: Lauren S.

description: My favorite Dim Sum place in SF, I NEVER miss an opportunity to go here when I am back home in San Francisco.
author: Rob G.

description:
After spending a couple of hours with my parents on a leisurely Saturday drive along with coast, we were desperate to get away from them, and desperate to find something to eat.  As usual, we were pretty skeptical of finding parking on Clement Street on a weekend, but the parking gods smiled on us and we found a spot right in front of GLDS!

We popped right in and the ladies behind the counter, at first gruff, got friendlier the more we ordered.  We got chive dumplings, sticky rice in lotus leaf, deep fried taro balls, har gow, sesame balls and some congee that I figured I'd save for a work lunch this week.  Well, we ate every thing except the congee.  I ended up polishing it off last night around midnight.  

So much for saving the congee for a work lunch....

Delicious and cheap = good!
author: .Hon H.

description: For the price and the quality, you cannot beat this place. It has great Dim Sum and it was great asking the ladies working the front their recommendations and trying the shrimp dim sum that I would have never had. Brought some of my German friends who wanted some good and local grinds, and they got it at Good Luck Dim Sum
author: Jonathan G.

description: Seriously one of the best dim sum places I've found in SF. And I have been to my fair share of places all around the city. I find myself craving their fried meat dumplings, sweet rice buns, and pan-fried chive dumplings... And their shu mai is tasty. I'm normally a very picky eater but almost all of the dim sum here is mouthwateringly good, not to mention that their pricing is so low for what you're getting. I'm not a fan of their lotus wraps, however, too bland and not very flavorful--that's my only gripe though! Pick up a milk tea down the street and you're set for a perfect day in beautiful SF.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
I've had better, way better.  Don't get me wrong, the dim sum was decent and authentic, but not out of this world 4 stars & higher good.  I thought the har gau had good flavor, but the skin could have been thinner.  Good har gau skin is see through and light but it shouldn't fall apart when you pick it up. 

Good Luck Dim Sum is obviously overrated and it's got awesome ratings because let's face it...you can feed a hungry family of 6 under $40.  I'm Chinese and I know when I see a long line of Chinese people, it's either free or cheap.  In this case, the latter.
author: Amy L.

description:
Good dim sum for CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP.  

The soy sauce is kinda funny though.  It's sweet and oily or something.  They have regular soy sauce at the front in packets, you just have to ask for them.  My girlfriend and I went here and ordered some har gao, shiu mai, and pork buns.  I posted pix of the HUGE plate of dim sum they gave us and 2 cokes that cost $15.80
author: Matt N.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is amazingly cheap ( 3 pieces for $1.50?!?!?!). Crazy Right? The procedure is simple:

1. Walk in.

2. Wait in line a little.

3. When it's your turn, be decisive on what you want, because the ladies who work behind the counter are VERY pushy. And choose wisely, you can have the steamed bun, or the baked bun (Or both, it's your decision).

4. Get your stuff.

5. Pay.

6. Eat there(Not worth it, low amount of tables), or eat in your car. Or ever better, go home and eat.

As for the food, it's basic Dim Sum fair. You got your Char Siu Bao, Har Gow, Shu Mai, Pot Stickers, etc. The food is good. the baked goods are greasy (That's a plus for me) and the steamed food is soft and moist. The only problem are the pushy ladies who work behind the counter(No offense, ladies), could be a bit nicer. 8.5 out of 10.
author: Evan B.

description: Dim Sum items were very large and SUPER cheap!  It was average dim sum though.  Egg tarts were good.  I've had better steamed and baked bbq pork buns.  But I would def come again since it was such a good deal.  You really get your monies worth here!
author: Lizzie C.

description:
Yes, it's a hole in the wall.  Yes, it's dirty.  Yes, the servers look grumpy and they communicate with the kitchen by yelling across the store.  BUT, this is probably among the best dim sum around.  That's why the servers don't need to smile.

For some reason, Good Luck seems to always have a line.  The line is filled a cross cutting representation of the area.  There are many local people who clearly don't speak English and I guess Good Luck bring them fond childhood memories.  There are local people who have discovered that Good Luck has some awesome items for food and so they return time and time again. And finally, I've noticed tourists in line.  How do tourists find out about Good Luck dim sum?  I have no idea, but they always look so excited to experience SF.

I'm the type who loves the pork buns in both steamed and baked forms and this bao typically my favorite from Good Luck.  However, after many years I decided to try something new; porridge.  I've always resisted because it's basically rice water.  My recent discover is that Good Luckss porridge is "good food borne of necessity from people who have been making it for generations."  Lets say that I was pleasantly surprised.
author: Nathan E.

description:
Cheap and Good Dim Sum - not the best but very decent. 

And that's why you always see the long line at this place everyday. Even right when they open their door in the early morning.
author: Dom G.

description: Good and cheap - not worth a line as there are plenty of places on Clement, but this place has garnered a reputation.  Service is border line rude, however, you are not coming for good service.  Am tempted to ratchet back to 2 stars and would easily give it 2.5 if that were an option (Yelp overlords, please give us half stars!!).  Limited menu options, but for good, quick and cheap dim sum, a-ok!
author: Richard D.

description:
you dont get it, this place is magic. if your complaining about the noise and lack of organization...learn chinese and it will help. I myself dont know chinese but i also dont mind the chaos, here is why...

the food is "fucking" awesome. I say "fucking" because on most days...id procreate with the food there. if my child could be part pork bun and part human...id be most satisfied. 

go in there with $5 and eat like normal, go in there with $10 eat like a king, and go in there with $20 and eat like a biggest loser. 

this place is awesome. just a note to any stoners out there...dont go in there stoned, you will hold up the line or suffer from a panic attack...so smoke after. 

UGH THIS PLACE IS AWESOME! 

PS: Tip those ladies they are the middle man between you and your food! make friends!
author: Patrick K.

description: I honestly love this place. I end up here a couple times a month. Cheap and delicious. The line can be a bit long, but it's worth it. Their shrimp dumplings and shrimp/chive dumplings are my favorite, as well as the siu mai. If you're eating to go, get some of the soy sauce on the tables to take with you - this food is not complete without the soy sauce.
author: Olivia H.

description:
OM NOM NOM.  What better way to celebrate an ROTD for a dim sum-centric review than by reviewing another dim sum joint?

Anyway, this place has 300+ reviews so I doubt anything I say will be groundbreaking, but for cheap, fast food, and decent dim sum, this is your best bet.  You can get a drink and eat 'til you're full for right around $5 -- how great is that?

I preferred Ocean even though they were more expensive because they were more of a sit-down place and had a wider selection of dim sum (including some great veg options), but Ocean is long dead and gone and Good Luck is now the place to go.  Some notes:

Har gow: Okay, but nothing special.  The shrimp/taro dumplings and shrimp/chive dumplings are better options at the same price.

Char siu bao: Not bad, but Gourmet's is better.

Luo bo bing: Much less greasier than Gourmet's.

Chive dumpling: OM NOM NOM.

Yu jiao (deep-fried stuffed taro): Not bad.  Ocean's was better, but like I said, Ocean is gone.

Overall: Much less greasy food than at Gourmet Dim Sum, and even though the atmosphere is spartan it's not as much of a dive as Gourmet.  Food at Good Luck tends to run cold on chilly, windy days because they leave their door wide open.  They could do with shutting the door, turning up the heat, or zapping some items in a microwave or salamander before handing it to you (the way Gourmet does for you without you having to ask).

In conclusion: OM NOM NOM.
author: James L.

description:
This is not really a sit-down place.  There are no dim sum ladies with carts.  There is usually a long line (sometimes out the door).  The ladies behind the counter are kind of rude, but I forgive them because the food is on the cheap side and the portions are big.

I mean, big.  The siu mais are too big to fit in your mouth in one bite.  That's kind of awesome.

Beware of the oil and grease.  It's all over their food, and all over their tables and chairs.  That's why this isn't a sit-down place.
author: Jenny L.

description: We made the mistake of coming here after 5:30p.  Yeah...should have known better.  Dim sum was cheap, but they were just pushing the leftovers of the day.  Everything was cold and dry.  There weren't many selections.  And she kept trying to sell more than we asked.  Maybe not representative if what could have been, but now we have a bad impression of the place.  May come back, but then there are other places to try.
author: Scott T.

description: Dim sum was pretty good even though it was cold when I got them late around 4-5pm. The tables were pretty dirty though -typical Chinese dim sum/restaurants.
author: Carmen L.

description: The dimsum is ok. The service is terrible: the ladies behind the counter don't even smile nor did they even ask, "What do you want?". The size of the dumplings are huge. The only item that I liked was the shrimp and chive pan fried dumpling: it was really full of chives. The siu mai was ok. They only have a salty dark soy sauce and a red chili sauce in individual solid plastic bottles (red and yellow mustard and ketchup bottles) so you can't see how clean or old or contaminated it is! :(  No vinegar available. Yes everything was luke warm and not hot. The fried red bean sesame ball tasted like it was a day old since the dough was dry and didn't pull apart well. :/
author: McKenzie L.

description: Best shrimp dumplings on Clement! Their shrimp and chive dumplings are unmatched in size, taste, or quality - I grabbed orders from 2 other shops today to compare them. I remember their egg tarts being good as well but I usually just get a box of shrimp and chive dumplings with a few shu mai for the bf. I like a little more variety than I find there, and prefer the jook at Gourmet dimsum, so it's not a one stop shop for me but if you're in the mood for dumplings this is the line to wait in.
author: Krystle S.

description: Good Luck Dim Sum is a great TAKE OUT restaurant. This place makes  quality dim sum that is very affordable ! You can get a several different pieces for under $10. Expect a small line when you arrive but it moves fairly quickly. We enjoyed all the different dumplings, pot stickers and mo chi. If you don't mind dining in a hole in the wall, there are tables in the back but it seems like most people were getting their dim sum to go.
author: Kevin B.

description: I like a good hole in the wall or greasy spoon but this place is just a greasy hole.  Just say NO!
author: BUS B.

description:
Many moon's ago I went to this place to Yum Cha... and haven't went back until recently... and they still have bad services, very rude, wouldn't bother coming back here for another year or so...

That 1 star goes to the cooks for making good Dim Sum nothing else goes beyond that .
author: Jay K.

description: In case you did not know - bun w/o any filling is called flower bun.  But really, this is a reminder for myself because I seem to forget every time. And just incase, you are reading this, yeah YOU, you know who..YOU ARE AWESOME! Keep cheesin' and dont forget to take home some of the sweet soy sauce!
author: Michelle B.

description: Went for lunch on a Sunday - Very busy. Line moved pretty quickly. Very little seating, but the food was great. We piety much stuck with the items recommended on the yelp highlights
author: Matt T.

description:
Okay, so I live pretty close to this dim sum place and decided to walk in and grab some to go.  Yes, everyone is right, get here early or else you'll have to wait.  When I got there, I was about the 20th person in line.

Honestly, I've had dim sum at MANY places in Socal and Norcal and this place was not all that great.  I think the best thing about it is the low price.  You can get an assortment of dim sum, mix and match and pay relatively little compared to dim sum restaurants. But with the lower prices comes lower quality and I wouldn't go back here again even though they're Zagat rated and even though Yelpers love this place.

I tried about 8 different things.  The chicken sticky rice wrapped in the bamboo leaf was good and the egg tarts were good, that's about it from what I tried.  

Oh, and if you order xiao long bao, keep in mind that they are not the expected soup dumplings in a bamboo basket, they are the thick doughy regular buns but just smaller.  I made the mistake of ordering six.
author: Suzi F.

description: Favorite dim sum on the planet.  Can't be beat!  So fresh, so delicious, and totally reasonably priced.  Parking can be a b*&%$, and there can be a line, but it's worth it, trust me!
author: Marie B.

description:
The BEST take-out dim sum place EVER.  

If it wasn't for Melly Mel, I would've never known about this gem of a restaurant on Clement Street!  You can't go wrong with ordering anything here.  Everything is tasty!  But what they are known for is their Ha Gow...and at $1.80 for 3, it's a great deal!  Normally at sit down dim sum places, you're paying $2.50 plus for Ha Gow that is not as good as these.  And....if you get their Jook...that's also a $1.80 for a pretty good size portion, enough for it to be one meal!  

If you don't know what you want, above their glass case of pastries are printed menus on reddish pink paper.  Grab one of those, and just put the number of orders of an item you want, next to it, and hand it to one of the ladies.  They put everything together and you won't have to be worried about their English competency.  And when they have your food ready, you can either take it to eat at home, or take it to the back of the joint and eat at one of their tables.  No waiters, so you gotta to clean up after yourself!

Oh.....one more thing.  Cash ONLY!

Tip 'o the day:  Don't come here in the afternoon trying to order Ha Gows.  From what I hear, they sell out pretty early b/c they're just so damn delicious!!!
author: Daniel M.

description:
Stumbled on this place over the weekend and boy was it awesome! Total hole in the wall with limited seating, completely cramped, two way line traffic with old Asian grandmas pushing their way through and, of course, awesome food. 

Looked at the menu and saw a price of $1.70 and a list of delectable items below and assumed that was per item. Cheap! So I proceeded to order two of everything that sounded good and my mouth dropped when she proceeded to put 6 of each item in the box. Double checked the menu and it was $1.70 for 3 of each item!! Needless to say I stopped ordering at that point, paid (cash only) and went off to the park to see what this place was all about.

The stuffed bun was amazing as was the shrimp dumpling and har gow. It was completely filling and delicious and kept fresh when I finished the rest for dinner later.

Highly recommended the surprisingly fantastic hole in the wall. I will be back!
author: Jon B.

description:
Really cheap dim sum that is very tasty! They have tons of variety and usually at least a 5 min line. The ladies arent super friendly and cant really speak much english, but hey the food is amazing and so are the prices. The har gow is as good as the pricier "Tea House" dim sum places. The chicken siu mai was subpar though. The pork siu mai and the egg custards made my day, they were that good, definitely recommended!

Pros:
- Great food
- Cheap
- Quick

Cons:
- Not so amiable servers
- Hole in the wall place
- Limited Seating
- Cash Only
author: Kevin L.

description:
Yeah, I'll agree with the other Yelpers that the service isn't that great... but then again I never expect anything special at a dim sum restaurant! 

The food is delicious and cheap. I had a big order for an event and they packaged it very well and it was amazing and the price was ridiculously low for the amount of food I got. 4 stars for the sesame balls and pork buns!!
author: Jen Z.

description: Stopped here on the way to Ocean Beach for a snack.  Pretty damn good.  Quick service and also inexpensive.  There were a few tables if you felt like sitting and eating but it was definitely more of a take-out joint.
author: Lydia L.

description:
This is my spot  to go to on a weekend morning, early morning or you end up in a crazy long lines that takes forever with a bunch of Asians yapping loudly around you. 

Pink paper and pen works best if you don't speak Chinese. Otherwise, point and order by number of "pieces" or "order". The ladies aren't friendly but I have realized they do pay attention to the customers. One of them, the meanest one of all, surprised me one day by saying "haven't seen you in a awhile". Amazing.

Secret to avoiding lines on the weekend during their busy times... Call in your order if you speak Chinese or go really early. and take out is a must!

Regardless of the rude ladies and busy lines, I love the haigow (the dumplings skin isn't so thick like other places on Clement), beef Sui Mai, and the duck egg porridge. Yum!
author: Jeannie L.

description: Ok, I have been reluctant to try this place because of the horrendous lines that stretch inside or outside the restaurant. Finally this week, Monday to be exact, I drove all the way from San Jose to Clement to try out Good Luck Dim Sum. No lines and the food was all fresh. I had one order each of xiu mai, fried taro dumplings, baked bbq pork bun, and a Coke all under 5 bucks! This is extremely cheap and really good! This place knocked my socks off then some overpriced seafood restaurant. The fried taro had a nice crispy texture and it was filled with so much meat inside, loved it! Parking was easy and I needed to put enough quarters for 30 minutes because I was in and out of the place in minutes. I even ate there and checked my meter, had a few minutes left! I would definitely come back but why are they closed Tuesdays? =(
author: Danster L.

description: For the price, there's nothing better!  You get 3 items for $1.70!!  Come on!  If you're fattys like us, then you'll order $12 worth of food and feast to your hearts content!  Sometimes we spend the little extra for the baked pork buns at 90 cents each, but even that is soooo worth it!  Sometimes the food is a bit chilled, especially if you pick it up and bring it home, but just notice the price, and you realize very quickly that it's still totally worth it!
author: Kari E.

description: dim sum and dumplings are great because they are small and round and soft and in addition they are also edible so u can chew on the roundness and swallow the softness and digest the smallness and they make for a really enjoyable petting experience
author: Charles Y.

description: Yelped it and found this little spot. $1.60 for three items. Great bang for the buck. There are tables, but most folks take it to go. It's a small joint, so if you do decide to eat there, you'll be accompanied by hungry, anxious people waiting in line. The kitchen is in the back where they prepare the food and they bring it up front; they cart it right by you. Basic process: Grab a paper menu, circle your items and be patient. It takes a while. It's tough because the longer you're in the line, they more stuff you want to circle. $2 for jok. Not bad. Overall a great experience. Don't expect much in terms of service though, which I didn't. If you're looking for some inexpensive, somewhat above average Dim Sum, this place won't disappoint.
author: Peter D.

description:
Good luck to you if you eat here.  

One of the clerks coughed incessantly while she packaged food and operated the cash register.  That's 2 health code violations right there.  Go home, lady, and come back when you're healthy.  

On the plus side, there is a nice dining room to eat in the back, and they have $1.50/3pc specials, so two people can snack here for under $5.  

On the minus side, besides the aforementioned unhealthy clerk, we have the taro roll.  Not so tasty.  I like the ones at Wing Lee much better.
author: David D.

description: Big, generous dim sum, and super cheap.  Not the best, but the best value in the city.
author: Gregory N.

description:
$1.80 for 3 baozi? Sweeeeet!

The food is excellent quality and the portions are generous, the only real downside was i was waiting in queue for about 10 minutes. But still, definitely worth it for people who take their street food seriously!

Jia you jia you.
author: Ash S.

description:
this is my favorite take out Dim Sum on Clement, they always serve fresh  made foods , very good service and you cant beat the prices! the quality is about as good as it gets for this type of business, I have nothing to complain about here

a very fast paced atmosphere, the line moves pretty fast, you can tell this is the number one Dim Sum on Clement just by the crowd, people always line up here and thats a very good indication on the quality

 I highly recommend this place! you get a lot of food for your money, very reasonable prices
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
Cheap and very tasty.
The ladies are usually pretty impatient. But that's just dim sum for ya.
author: arthur l.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum gets a solid four stars. 

I'm a fan of good dim sum, and this place gets the job done. 

I plan to eat in, rather than out, at some point. I'm a bit iffy about it, though, considering the unfriendliness I've witnessed.
author: Paulina F.

description:
I'm fairly sure Good Luck employs some kind of tractor beam, because even when I'm hungry in the Inner Richmond and know I should try something different, I always always end up back at Good Luck.  It might be because it was the first dim sum I ever had in San Francisco or it might be because I am painfully and blindingly white, but I really do think that Good Luck is the best dim sum experience that I've had in this city so far.

Today, my boyfriend and I had the shrimp and chive dumplings, the chicken siu mai, the crystal dumplings, the vegetable pork bun, and some chicken sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf.  And tea.  It was $10.  In fact, every time I've gone it has cost about $5 per person and I've left stuffed, so I would say that's fairly standard.

Things I like about individual items: The sticky rice is almost unbearably good - the flavor is very rich and the texture so creamy!  The fried taro dumplings are some of my favorite things to have there.  I had them once and I can't stop thinking about them - the skin is thick and chewy, and the filling is rich and nutty.  And it's fried!  What's not to love?  The veggie and pork bun has a lot of ginger in it, which adds a whole new dimension to the typical meat-on-starchfest that is dim sum.  And the BBQ pork bun: because sometimes you really do want a meat-on-starchfest.

Things I like about the food in general: I haven't gotten anything there that wasn't incredibly flavorful and rich, but they manage to do so without an off-putting amount of oil.  Even the predominantly veggie-based fillings glom together perfectly, making it really easy to enjoy every component of every morsel in every bite.  The wrappers are tasty, too, be they soft and fluffy or smooth, thick, and chewy.  And whatever brand of soy sauce they use is rad (I know that's probably an ignorant thing to say, but I've had a fair amount of dark soy sauce and this stuff is better - I swear!).

Most people don't like the ambiance of eating there, but I have to say i really do.  If you can manage to snag a table, sitting there and gorging yourself in the comfortingly shabby dining area and watching everyone talk, eat, yell, and otherwise bustle around you is a very good time.  It's not a fine dining experience, but I don't really think it's supposed to be.  I think that Good Luck is exactly what it has set out to be, and for that I am always happy to shell out my $5.
author: Becca S.

description:
Went there yesterday to get dim sum to go and it was FANTASTIC! It's a little hole in the wall where everything is fresh at the counter. It takes them a little longer than necessary to gather up your order though. While you stand in line, you're  supposed to fill out a slip of what you want and then just hand it to them making the job much easier, but it still takes long---

After waiting a bit, I get up there with about 7-8 things with the total coming to $14!!!! what a steal!!! The customer service is what you would expect--- just have your order ready and there shouldn't be any problems. Anyway--- I get back and start eating the food and it was very flavorful and very yummy! The baked bbq pork buns are freakin delicious. The har gow were awesome! We also had the shrimp dry crepe thing and it was delicious.. One thing I was looking for on the menu was the chicken and sticky rice wrapped in the leaves, but I don't think they have it. 

But overall, great place with cheap and delicious dim sum!!
author: Chi T.

description: Great dim sum at great price.  I just wish the ladies behind the counter were a little bit nicer.
author: Swati K.

description:
My new favorite Dim Sum place! I read the reviews on Yelp and I thought Id give it a try. I first expected to be seated and have the rolling carts where I get to pick and choose our items. I was a little dissapointed at first when I found out it was an express place. 

It was so busy there and the food just kept coming out, so we knew that our food would be fresh. The portions are generous and its very cheap. Items are 3 for $1.60. We ordered lots of dumplings and steamed buns and egg rolls. All kinds of things. Evereything was delicious. 

We ended up taking our food to a beach by the Golden Gate Bridge. It was the perfect lunch. I will definately go back! The only one thing I did not like about this place was the loa
author: Bernadette B.

description:
Ive decided after 2 tries....This dump spot sucks. They totally try to hustle you. Here's pretty much how it goes: 

"NNNEEEEXXXXTTTTTT!!!"
" Hi, Can I have 4 shumai?" 
"Four? How about 6, 6 only little more." 
"Okay 6"
 " And 2 pork buns" 
I watch her as she puts 4 in the box. 
"Ummm. I said only two thanks." 
"But pork is good too."
"Um no thanks just two please." 
Then comes a big dirty look in my direction...
And one egg roll. I watch her as she puts two in the bag. " No only one please" 
Another dirty look. 
Then she charges me $5 bucks and pushes the bag at me.
Overall, The pork and shrimp shumai is good but I think it may have given me bubble guts. BBQ pork buns are good as well but I really didnt like the customer service and after a few visits I have decided to go to another dump spot.
author: M K.

description:
Best place for delicious dim sum at ultra cheap prices! $3-5 gets you a tasty fulfilling meal. There's always a line of at least 10 people here so be ready to wait for 20+ minutes depending on how slow the other customers are.

This is a dim sum to go, but they have tables on the inside for eating. It's pretty plain and somewhat dirty depending on the previous customers who sat there. The soy sauce is pretty tasty here, but the container is pretty sticky... My advice is to get the food to go.

The service is okay as long as you know the procedure: line up, grab the pink sheet, mark a number on what you want, give it to the lady, lady gives you your order, pay and leave. Screw that up and get yelled at for being an idiot. 

The dim sum are tasty, authentic, and fresh. Their siu mai and haw gaw are awesome. Their chinese sausage bun... not so good.
author: Steven B.

description:
Alert:  Chinese guy (well, American-Born Chinese guy) rating a Chinese establishment with his crazy high standards.

Food = 3.5.  The dumplings were good, fresh and tasty.  Portions were pretty standard for dim sum.  The sticky rice was just okay.  I am used to a homemade version with more goodies inside besides rice and meat.  Good Luck Dim Sum also didn't have any rice noodle rolls (cheong fun).  Maybe they didn't have it that day or maybe they don't have it at all.   All in all, if you didn't grow up eating dim sum every Sunday, Good Luck Dim Sum will blow you away.  If you're like me, this place is pretty good but not epic.

Service = 4.  The ladies work fast to deal with the long lines.  For English speakers, there is a sheet that you fill out and hand over to make your order.   Like any Chinese-owned establishment, they seem to treat you better if you speak the native tongue.  

Atmosphere = 2.  The place is small and the dining area isn't equiped to handle too many diners.  The latest Department of Health inspection resulted in a 94.  Woot!
author: Eddie L.

description:
Decided to try this spot even though I love Clement Restaurant. 

Got a bunch of stuff under $10, enough to feed 2 people. But bfriend and I decided we like Clement Restaurant better.

Here, the potstickers were cold (he ordered it, not me), and the egg tarts were just dense and cold. Dumplings were not bad and I like that there's seating but I would go elsewhere for dim sum.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Still good, [but] I discovered their secret to getting everything to taste good: lard.

so if you're a vegetarian, there's a very good chance that not a single thing here is vegetarian
author: Mark A.

description:
With the slew of other hole-in-the-wall walk-in dim sum places peppered along Clement street, it's hard to decide where to go.  It almost seems like all the walk-in dim sum spots have lines, leading you to think, 'Well, it must be good there's a line of Chinese people there.  Chinese people!', but alas, you fail to remember, it's Clement Street.  There are lines of Chinese people everywhere. 

Amidst the confusing abundance of dim sum, Good Luck Dim Sum is a solid choice.  Despite their lack of selection, the delicious morsels they do offer tastes great and aren't overly oily like many other dim sum establishments. The prices are hard to beat, charging a modest price of (as low as) $1.50 for 3 pieces!  I've had a full dinner here, feeding two people for less than $10.

Parking? It's Clement Street.  Parking can be rough.  I've had bad parking days and I've had excellent parking days.  It's never horrible.

For people who don't know dim sum very well or are just  feeling intimidated by the idea of ordering from a pushy Chinese lady...

At the end of the counter, there is a sheet of paper (usually pink).  Grab one of those along with a pen and start circling what you want along with the number of orders.  When it's your turn, just hand it to them and they'll take care of it.

I've never eaten in.  I usually take mine to go.  The eating area is a bit grimy, not unlike other establishments on the block.  So, be wary.  

There or to go, either way - enjoy.

Some recommendations: 
Sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves
Deep fried stuffed dumplings
Chive dumplings with shrimp
author: Darkie L.

description:
I didn't know how good this place was until one day it was closed and I went down the street to try another place. 

The ingredients are fresh and the service is fast. There are long lines because of all the dim sum goodness going on here. You can get a really big meal for 2 for $20. Make sure you ask for a to go cup and get the sweet black soy sauce that makes this dim sum unique.
author: Mark B.

description: This place have good dim sum and I love their rice porridge. It's so yummy. I had their siu Mai, shrimp dumpling, etc. the line here can get very long.
author: Serena Z.

description:
Don't be fooled by this whole in the wall. Easy to miss when you're strolling down clement. Nothing about the decor will catch your attention, in fact it might even stir you away. I was introduced to this place by my manager. 'Cheap and delicious jook!' was all he needed to say to get me I intrigued. $1.80 for pork and preserved egg congee. Perfect pit stop for breakfast when heading to work and the cure for that banging hang over. It's $1.80 worth spending, I prefer going into work looking like shit rather than going in looking & feeling like shit.

Go early or you'll have to stand in line with the line-cutting Chinese folks. GOOD LUCK with that. Hah.
author: Jenny K.

description: Make sure you know what you want when you get there and how many of each item/serving.  I went here after good reviews but I felt a little overwhelmed and rushed because I wasn't sure how many servings of each I wanted to order (three of us were eating). Cash only. 20 cent charge for containers, small seating area. Food was good, we just took it to go back to our hotel eoom to eat.
author: Lauren T.

description:
If you don't speak their language, you will be HATED.

However, if you just want some extremely cheap Dim Sum, go here. For 4 people and a ton of Dim Sum, it was $13. Like, a ton.

Some was ice cold, some was just steamed hot - cross your fingers you'll come when it's all fresh.
author: Zach S.

description:
after 8 years of eating here...
the ladies remember my fat face..
they smile...
i know what they're gonna ask me
they know i have my order together
they know i know one order means 3 pieces
i know to have my money ready
i know how to answer their questions quick and easy
"to go"   "for here"  "yes, one order each"  "bag is okay - no box" 
without being snobby and in the nicest way possible: don't come here with questions, weird requests or stupid substitutions.
what you see is what you get. you put it in your mouth and let the magic unfold. relax. 
it's all great stuff. better dim sum than many if not all of the sitdown dim sum restaurants in the area
if fat Chinese cops come here, you should too.
love love love it. 
i dunno why but I feel compelled to custom-make them some pens for their pen tray so that it never runs out and people can work on their order ahead of time.
author: Tomas V.

description:
Easily the best place for Dim Sum on Clement (Barring Wing Lee's pork buns, those school Good Luck's buns any day of the week). You're going to be waiting in line for about 5-10mins, but you get to pick up a little pink sheet. You place how much of each you want from it and then you give it to the ladies. But be warned - the ladies are easily really mean. If you don't speak fluent Mandarin or Cantonese, or make the mistake of thinking they can't speak English, you're in for the rudest surprise of your life.

Barring that, you're easily in for some of the best Dim Sum. The Siu Long Bao, Siu Maai and anything else tastes AMAZING, but I recommend going to Wing Lee's for better pork buns.
author: Ari F.

description:
Like Jessica K. said "How the hell did this place get such high ratings?!" I mean seriously, I was borderline disgusted by the view I was seeing. The woman behind the counter was yelling and cursing in Chinese and etc and when she walked by me while I was in line one of them had the nerves to shout to me "EXCUSE ME! EXCUSE ME!" Bitch! You can walk around me! I didn't budge one bit just gave her a "are you fcukin kidding me" look. Because this place was insanely business and the crowd did not stop coming! Thanks but no thanks, I'm not coming back here. 

In all honesty, the food wasn't bad but just the sight of someone handling my food with their bare hand is not something very appetizing to me.
author: Jeremy M.

description: The lady behind the counter was very nice. On the other hand, I had lint on one of my dim sum. This place is cash only. But all you need is 5 dollars for 2 people. I will go again if Good Mong Kok Bakery is closed.
author: Deme M.

description:
I've been searching for a dim sum place that has a good combination of price and taste; Good Luck has just that! They have a variety of dumplings that anyone can appreciate.

I've been here several times, around 10:30am on a Saturday and the line has been very long, guessing a 20min wait. But its SO worth it! For  $26.00 we were able to feed 4 people, a wonderful brunch. They have thick soy sauce at the tables and chili pepper sauce that you can mix in the paper boat/tubs they give you. 

The ladies working behind the counter can be very standoffish, not willing to take the time to help you, rude, etc. If you don't like people like that, just be ready by having all the items you want circled on their menu (pink slip of paper they have sitting on the counter).

To-go boxes cost $0.20. Can't wait to be back in SF for some more Dim Sum!
author: EM P.

description: This place is another testament to the non-existence of good dim-sum in San Francisco city. I tried a number of items. The har gow was probably the better of the lot, but in general, everything tasted the same, like MSG. The skin on the dumplings were prone to rips and tears as well, which I tend to associate with bad dim sum. Not really worth the trip unless you are really craving dim sum and unable to wait at a restaurant (prices are actually relatively similar).
author: Nicole L.

description: This place is the physical embodiment of the word cheap. The food is cheap both in price and quality. The decor is of the same nature. So it's a give and a take when you eat here I got the baked pork bun when was filled with the lowest quality pork and sauce but then again it was also 90 cents. I don't know any other place in SF that can fill you up for less than $1.
author: Pamela I.

description:
I would rate this place as middle of the road. Does it seem dirty? Yeah. If you are willing to look the other way as you do with most other places on this block of Clement, then it might be worth a try. I don't speak Chinese so I can't attest to people cursing at/around me - but can say that not speaking Chinese is not in my favor at a place like this. Thankfully - there's a pen and paper ordering system.

I find the food to be good (when hot) - but I am not a dim sum expert either. I refuse to wait in line more than 10 minutes for this as I'm not sure it's worth more than that in aggravation.

I usually just pop in here for a cheap snack when I'm running errands and there's not a huge line. After all, I'm a sucker for a decent egg roll.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Most items are less than a $1 each (or an order: 3 for $1.60)
flavor is pretty good compared to restaurant quality, but MUCH better bang for your buck. They use a menu-circling system so you can pick out what you want while you wait in line. Service could be a little faster though considering there were 4 people behind the counter. They should consider a subway-type system to streamline their order preparation...

Parking might be a bit tough around the streets there, mostly metered, some only 30 min limit. I think it's CASH only.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Dim sum really hit the spot for a quick weekday lunch.  We ordered pork siu mai, turnip cake, steamed BBQ Pork buns, Chinese chive dumplings and custard tarts.  All were good and we knew were fresh because we peeked into the back room where workers were busily shaping and steaming buns.  I had never had the Chinese chive dumpling before.  It was a large round bun that was pan-fried after it was cooked, to give it a crispy bottom, similar to a potsticker.  You don't have to order three of the 3 for 1.70 items because they will mix and match if say you only want 1 or 2 of one item.

It came to about $7, a bargain  for sure!  I sometimes get nervous when ordering from dim sum places like this because the ladies behind the counter are all business, so I fill out the pink paper order sheet while waiting in line.  Then I read or hand them the sheet, and get out quickly and with no negative vibes.
author: Christine S.

description:
im from hawaii, and this is the best dim sum i've EVER had!! and its SOO cheap too!! seriously, EVERYTHING is good here. they do so much volume that its always fresh. you can't go wrong at all. 

although fair warning- weekends here are nuts. while there are 4 or 5 workers processing customers, the line does not move quickly. however, it is worth the wait. if possible, i would recommend going on weekdays where the line is at least manageable.

also i think that if you have a big enough order, you can call ahead. i did this once, and while it was still difficult to attract someone's attention to tell them that i had phoned ahead (its significantly more difficult if you dont speak chinese), it was still faster than standing in line, since my order was already ready in the back.
author: lisa l.

description:
If you're searching on Yelp and this restaurant came up first, BEWARE!!!  I saw at least 4 tourists stand in line during my 20 minute meal.  I'm guessing Good Luck Dim Sum came up first on the yelp search.

I normally don't write reviews until I have made an informed decision/comparison with a large sample size.

I have been raised on dim sum.  My standard of comparison is dim sum from Hong Kong, where dim sum is cheap, tasty, large, and fresh.

I normally get my dim sum from Good Mong Kok (in the original china town).  The reason why I go here is because I enjoy eating dim sum at home where it is quiet and clean, allowing me to focus on the quality of the food.  The reason why I decided not to go to GMK today is because it was raining - GMK does not have any tables to sit at.  Also, I wanted to try some other highly rated yelp dim sum "restaurant".

Good Luck Dim Sum has NOTHING on Good Mong Kok.  I urge you to try GMK.  Their dim sum is the closest I have had to Hong Kong dim sum.  The price is the same at GMK as well.

Here is why I thought GLDS was below my standard:

Cha Siu Bao/Pork Bun - The filling is made mostly of paste and lard.  Perhaps 20% was made of real pork.  You might like how mystery paste and lard taste, but you're totally getting ripped off with 20% real bbq pork filling.

Har Gao/Shrimp Dumpling - These are tiny in comparison to GMK...maybe 20% smaller.  GMK uses more real shrimp for filling.

Fried Triangle Pastry filled with beef and taro - Again, this was filled mostly with taro paste.  There was SO little ground beef.  This is NOT normal.  You're getting ripped off with filling.

Dan Tat/Egg Custard - This was ok...a little small..but still ok.  I'm not really a dan tat connoisseur.

In general, most of their dim sum was filled with fillers...this is NOT good dim sum.  If I had to compare, I would say that Good Luck Dim Sum is even worse than the dim sum offered in the South Bay...that is PRETTY BAD.

PERHAPS this is one of the better places in this area, but the original China town has better restaurants.  I give this place 2 stars:

1st star:  Cheap - $1.50 for 3 pieces
2nd star:  Place to sit + "tolerable to average" dim sum + hits the spot when you're craving dim sum

If you do decide to go to Good Mongkok instead of Good Luck, be aware that there are NO tables at GMK.  You'll need to stand somewhere along the street or eat at a park if you want to eat your dim sum while it is still warm.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
I was in SF this past weekend and had a craving for some Dim Sum. I didnt want to go into China Town and deal with all that madness so I went to my yelp app and found Good Luck. 

Almost everything you read is true. It was a sautrday and the line was about 15 min long. It didnt bother me, it gave me time to go over the menu multiple times. A woman in line helped me on how to order. (when you go in get a menu and a pen. circle what you want and how many).
The servers arent the most personable. But they arent waitresses at a white table cloth restaurant either. They get you your food quick and for the most part pretty accurately. They do move you in and out with little dialogue. 

There are several tables (probably 8 total) but you will have people in line RIGHT NEXT TO YOU as you eat. It wouldnt bother me (i took mine to go)but I can see some people getting annoyed. 

The dumplings were actually quite large. Bigger than other places I have tried. They did have the Shark Fin dumplings when I was there. I LOVE me some shark fin!! Everything was fresh, the trays were constantly being restocked as I stood in line. The Steamed Pork buns were a little cold, but still super tasty. 

Most items were 3 for $1.60 so you cant beat the price. 2 people can eat for around $10!!! 

All in all it was a very good experience. I will definitely go back!
author: Christopher C.

description:
The lines are long, prepare for a 30 to 40 minute wait.  They also charge for take out boxes. The prices are so low it does not matter. 
Last time I was in the shop, they had a delivery of 6 50 pound bags of sugar. So if you wonder why everything tastes so sweet. It is the sugar.
author: Bob b.

description: Tried a number of their dim sum and baked goods at a family friend's lunch - pretty good!  Noteworthy items include the har gao, egg custard tart, and red bean pineapple buns (very fluffy).  The siu mai, leek dumplings, and BBQ pork buns were only so-so though, so I'd skip those if you just want to sample a couple things.
author: Eric F.

description: we used to go to Lichee Garden but alas no dim sum there any more.  I tried but did not care for Yank Sing - too much like the stuff we get here in Ohio.   We tried a couple of other places but then I saw this place written up in Fodors.  Yum.  It was fabulous
author: Vickie B.

description: ordered some basic buns (custard buns/ bbq pork buns) and some sui mai and har churn. I was expecting for some pretty good stuff, but it didn't taste that good. It was really greasy, the buns were dry. I was pretty disappointed especially since a colleague had recommended this place to me and I really wanted a good bbq pork bun.
author: Christina L.

description: This place discriminates against americans. I tried to order food at the counter and the women did everything they could not to serve me until they could see I was getting pissed and threatened to speak to the owner.
author: Greg M.

description:
This is good if you want 'good value' dim sum!  I came here earlier today to pick up dim sum to have for breakfast.

Yes, the line was long....the ladies took forever to prep the food into the to-go boxes... and I spent probably 30-45 mins before I left the place.

I picked up the usual suspects:  Shu Mai, Ha Gow, Loh Bat Goh, Dant tah, and Noh Me Fan....  see if you can interpret that.... =)

Their food is reasonably priced and the quality is just 'decent'.    I come here so that I can have breakfast for the next couple of days....  nothing more.

Value proposition!  If you have time, take a visit on the weekends, but, get ready to wait!
author: Edward L.

description: The portions are HUGE here! and it's so CHEAP! My boyfriend and I discovered this place courtesy of Yelpers. It seems like their shui mai is made of mystery meat and usually I would be grossed out but it's actually really tasty! Their har gow has a lot of shrimp packed into it so that's a plus! I LOVE THEIR TARO! You know the one with the flaky, fried outside and taro/meat filled inside? MMM, it's ridiculously good here! Although the place is really sketchy and dirty, their dim sum great for the price you pay!
author: Ly D.

description:
HOW is it possible I have not reviewed this place yet?

It is really quite simple:

Delicious dim sum + GIANT PILE OF FOOD - iiiiiitty bitty bill = 5 Stars.

Excellent black soy sauce if you eat in. 3 Steamed Bao = $1.50
author: Katie B.

description:
this is my go to place for quick and convenient dim sum.  

sometimes, i just want to avoid the hour long waits for a table at our selective dim sum restaurants in the area...good luck dim sum has been around for awhile and has always hit the spot.  don't get me wrong...the lines here can be ridiculous also...but most of the time, you're in and out...and it's super affordable.  dim sum orders come in threes...and the pieces are huge.  

the also have rice porridge with donuts available behind the counter.
author: Jen W.

description:
2.75
Cheap dim sum of average to below average quality but decent variety. Must of the dim sum is 3 for 1.60 while the specials are in the $2 range. They have lotus leaf wrapped rice and pork spare rib rice on the day I was there. They also have a decent selection of baked goods and also the rare white sugar cake. The mushroom chow mein I got was quite oily though. The shrimp dumpling and sui mai were nothing special. Either way I was kinda disappointed in this place. Its an ok place to get a quick snack but I probably would not come back as there is much better dim sum places and other restaurants out there.
author: Robert Y.

description: Great for a little hole in the wall take out dim sum place.  Quick too.  .  Not much variety as far as vegetables and seafood but still really good. And super cheap
author: Gabriella C.

description:
Cheap and delicious. The service could use some improvement though. Most of the Chinese ladies there are grumpy as hell. However I do appreciate that they can understand english and are able to wait on non-Chinese customers.

Things to try:
Shrimp Dumplings
Taro filled Dumplings
Sticky Rice Buns 
White Sugar Dessert (this is roughly translated - looks like a triangle of white jelly)
Chive Dumplings
author: Vanessa T.

description: Delicious, cheap dim sum. Like others have said this is the best take out dim sum place I've found in the city.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Yeah, it's cheap but ... I still don't get why this place has four stars.

The food was cold and most of the items were not good at all.
author: K H.

description: after I have Good Luck Dim Sum as shrimp ball and beef meet ball, I don't want to eat another Dim Sum restaurants' shrimp ball and beef meet ball any more.  Those two things so tasting.  Also,  sweep rice ball,  if you come from Taishan or Kaiping,  it taste as same as home make.   if you go to San Francisco,  go to Good Luck Dim Sum to try it.   The price is very good. 3 orders Dimsum just cost $6 dollars. To me very full.
author: Ju H.

description: SLAMMIN. $11 for 2 ppl for a smorgasbord of fresh, super-yummy dumplings served by friendly and helpful folks. Simply fab.
author: Danielle P.

description:
It's decent, passable dim sum (not really that great but I've been eating dim sum all my life and my standards are unduly high) but it still gets a generous rating of 4 stars because that rating is supposed to represent that I'm a fan, and that I am -- due to the combination of this place's convenience and price.  I can pop in and order a whole box of dim sum, enough to last us 2 days for  a measly $8.  Eight friggin bucks -- it's such a bargain for edible, decent dim sum when you get that hankering for your favorites.  

Are you going to get world class dim sum?  Nope, but it's a quick dash in and instant gratification for my comfort food -- takes me back to my childhood days and so never fails to make me smile.  In short -- it gets the job done.
author: Liz K.

description:
Cheap and delicious dim sum. I'm new to the city so had no idea that Richmond has its own little Chinatown! Definitely a nice surprise...now I don't have to trek all the way to Chinatown and fight the crowds.

They've got all the staples but here are my favs:

-Deep fried stuffed dumpling
-Shrimp dumpling
-Pork siu mai
-Turnip cake
-Baked BBQ pork bun
-Chinese chive dumpling
-Sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves

Check the menu picture for prices but basically it's sectioned off into 3 categories:

-Pick 3 for $1.50 (certain items only)
-Others are $0.60 each
-And then they have misc items that range from $0.80-$3+

Definitely will be coming back to Good Luck & Clement St in general!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
I'm usually not a dim sum person since I don't eat meat very often and it's also hard to find any really good places. But good luck dim sum is actually a place my hubby has been going to for a while. I would go once in a while and now we go whenever we're in the city. The dim sum is very cheap compared to other cities and it's fresh. Our favorites are the steam chicken buns, shrimp dumplings and beef shu mai. It's just a hole in the wall and lines can go all the way out the door, so be sure to arrive when they open. Sometimes they run out of favorites if you come in too late.

Note: This is a CASH only place!
author: Petra S.

description: I came here around 3pm and both the selection and food quality were poor.  Granted, this is not an optimal time of day for dim sum, but even with that under consideration, the quality here is subpar.  The only things I liked were the shrimp dumplings and (chives?) fried dumplings.  The siu mai were especially poor, as they were cold and soggy and appeared to be undercooked.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Yum, yum, yum! Friends that live in the Richmond directed me to this wonderful place, much to my good luck and fortune. This was my first experience with dim sum and you know nothing compares to your first time! 

Haven't been here during peak hours so I'm a stranger to the long lines I see in the featured photos. I'm an incredibly picky eater (technically a supertaster) so I have peculiar requests. Imagine my joy when I saw that they had chicken buns which are a rarity! The service isn't the friendliest or most approachable but I guess once you're inside you're on their turf so just take your order to the grassy knoll in front of the library and enjoy. 

And how could i forget.... SO AFFORDABLE!! Seriously, two can eat a meal's worth for under $8.
author: Allie M.

description: I love this place. It was recommended to us a couple of years ago and we go here every summer we are in the Bay Area. The women behind the counter are great and I love those pink takeout cardboard boxes (takes me back to my childhood). We get a little bit of everything and it HAS NEVER DISAPPOINTED ...  You can eat there, but getting it to go and hitting Crissy Field picnic area is the best -- to enjoy the view of the Golden Gate and people watch. The custard tarts are good and so are the pork buns and the steamed dumplings!!! My mouth is watering just thinking of this place!
author: Jeanette W.

description:
My girlfriend found this place on Yelp and she warned me about the 3 ladies that guards this place.  I didn't take it seriously, but man they are pretty cold.  The food was really good for the price.  The Chives-Shrimp Dumpling is BOMB!

Although I felt like crap and very stupid after interacting with the ladies, I would definitely go back for the food.  At least I can laugh about the service.
author: Tony N.

description:
Just OK.  It is cheap.  The service is very nice.  I hit them up just before closing, so my choices were limited.  As it was, I was able to get about 8 different items.  

All of the items were OK.  My favorites are the Pot Stickers and Shark Fin dumplings.  The pot stickers were kind of doughy and a little low on flavor.  The shark fin dumplings were not as flavorful as others I've had.   The pork Siu Mai were pretty tasty.  The beef and chick Siu Mai were different, but not as good.  

Maybe it's because I'm used to them, but I'd prefer You's Dim Sum on Pacific to this place.
author: Curtis A.

description:
Yes, I'm basically repeating what everyone else has said, but with this many reviews some summarizing is good!

1. the line reminds me of China so do call ahead and order what you want.  you can then bypass the line and just pick it up at the counter. 

2. my top picks- har gow shrimp dumplings, chive shrimp dumplings, jook porridge, steamed bbq buns and egg tarts. 

3. the lotus leaf sticky rice and shu mai is not as good as other places. it could be just a preference thing, but i like some shrimp in my shu mai instead of just a mouthful of beef or pork.  the sticky rice is not moist or flavorful enough

4. If you are a masochist or would like to experience the joys of standing in line, please do remember to grab a pink menu paper and mark off what you want or be prepared to be glared and yelled at by the asian ladies behind the counter. again, if that's your thing then just ignore.
author: Dianna W.

description: If you like Dim Sum, you will love this place.  Nothing to look at in the interior, but the food is fantastic and the people seem really nice.  Everything we ate was good and the price is really inexpensive.  Best of all, a lot of the Chinese locals were there on the morning we arrived and they were buying the dim sum by the box full.  If you go, bring an appetite.
author: Gregory E.

description: I don't really love dim sum. I'll be honest - I typically feel like dim sum restaurants are unsanitary. Not sure why... Maybe it's reminiscent of when I backpacked through SE Asia. However, I gave it a shot and was pleasantly surprised. My partner and I split way too much food, which came to $7. Everything was yum.
author: B B.

description:
We expected this to be a hole in the wall place, but the format of the place took away from enjoying the food.  By the time you get it all to the table it's just not that warm, and loses some of its appeal.  It's too bad because some things really did seem good - pork buns, sticky rice with chicken, spare ribs, lots of the dumplings/pot stickers.  But the nasty dirty tables, long lines and waiting in a cramped space as people keep trying to get by, and most important - cold food - just took away from it.  Yes it's cheap, but, oh well.  Lots of places in CHinatown are pretty cheap, but in our estimation they are  more enjoyable.

We love appetizers, but it would've been nice to have some other options - any sort of Chinese vegetables for example, or a little more with meat.  The menu is limited, and we honestly didn't know what some things were.  We certainly didn't go here with expectations of it being like a sit down place, but it still underwhelmed us.
author: D R.

description: This place has the worse customer service. Each server takes forever to fulfill an order. They don't care for your business. I ordered 5 items, 2 weren't available but my server didn't even tell me. Just because they Zagat rated they don't have to treat their customer like shit.
author: Bob C.

description: I absolutely love and appreciate this place. I crave Dim Sum on a regular basis and Good Luck satisfies my craving every time! They have great variety and you get so much food for such a great price. This is my go to spot when I need my Dim Sum fix!
author: Juliane M.

description:
ManTao-Man here.
SCORE 100 from SFHD!
I saw it the green paper on the door!
May be it's The Only Dim Sum Place in SF got perfect 100. 
You'll never know about dim sum, it may be 62 tomorrow.

I want to Thank the lady in the counter speaking Chinese to me.
Yes, I look Chinese sometimes.
I think she said that can I help you in Chinese.
Or, "WhatTheHell you want?" ....  you never know what they really sayin'.......... but, 
No, she wasn't like that.
I thought all old Chinese ladies speak very loud.
But not her.
She was very soft speaking Chinese lady that I think it's rare.

By the way, my home town has a Chinatown. it's not a big as SF but clean, even tables in the restaurants are not sticky at all.
I have been missing a steamed pork bun from there.
The steamed pork bun is different that I couldn't find in SF.
Well, i don't think I am that crazy for dim sum, so, I didn't really research enough to find so I am sure there is in SF but, hell, find a particular kind of dim sum is find a needle in a haystack. 
There are so many different kind of Chinese here.
You can't tell which is which.
can you?

instead, I just have going to japanese market to get a frozen Japo steamed pork bun. it's not too bad actually.

But, I found one last night.
It was a luck.
I just went to New May Wah for grocery shopping and I saw a small dim sum place cross the street calls Good Luck Dim Sum.
I said, "GoodFxxx. I got to try that.'

It was almost closing time for the place so the lady gave me 4 instead of 3 for $1.50.
The small steamed pork bun was the one that I have been looking for.

I am going back again.

Btw, Vivian C. said, "You're absolutely right, most old Chinese ladies scream.  For no good reason too.  My grandma is one of those screaming old Chinese ladies.  You really found a one-in-a-million quiet old Chinese lady.  It's like you found a unicorn. Good job!

But anyway, YAY for good dim sum! hurraaah!"

The place is scored 100 from the SF health dept.

Ari C. said, "The place is scored 100 from the SF health dept.
That is impossible! Chinese place with a perfect health score??"

Yes, I saw it. The 1st 100 score dim sum in the city!!!!!
author: Nobu K.

description: I like this place a lot, good and tasty food, super cheap too. Chicken sticky rice wrapped in lotus leave was real good, no lesser than dim sum in Hong Kong. I do not care much about service or plastic trays and plastic forks and spoons. We eat tasty dim sum and pay lesser than any other dim sum restaurants. It's the main thing.
author: Thames D.

description: Best prices you will see for a place that has better parking and awesome dim sum!! Only a 10 min wait as well!  Quick, cheap and delicious, new favorite place besides the service.  I came here with my boyfriend and we ordered a ton of food, the people would not let us pay for large size box for the food we had leftover and wanted it take it back home.  They gave us a small box and we ended up having to carry a few pieces, not ideal when driving back!
author: D R.

description: This place is a hoot - even with a short line you may wait forever while they prepare huge to go orders and then have a clever old lady cut in line in front of you. I've been going at least 2 times a month for several years now and none of the women behind the counter acknowledge me as a regular - that's not a complaint, it's simply the culture of the place - my goal is to get them to laugh once, and I keep trying (and failing).  The dumplings are amazing and amazingly cheap, one could feed the Von Trapp clan for under $20.00 and have left overs  - just look the other way when they drop their tongs on the dirty floor and pick them right up and start using them again.  ummm...
author: Mateo L.

description: Great dim sum, and you can't beat the prices. Don't fear the long line- it moves quickly and is well worth the wait!
author: Audrey H.

description: The dim sum is cracking. The wait on the weekends sucks. The line reminds me of the DMV. The best time to come is after work on the weekdays
author: Christopher L.

description:
I would've given this place four stars for their cheap shrimp/shrimp-chive dumplings (3 pieces of shu-mai for $1.50!). That was quite a sell.

But, minus one star for the sweet soy sauce, which tasted like it was hoisin watered down with a bit of soy sauce. I've eaten Chinese food plenty a-times and never have I come across such a sweet, thick sauce. Didn't dig it. Also, they didn't offer any red vinegar which I can't live without. I suppose next time I will BYOSS and BYORV, for real.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Best dim sum in the city...hands down. It's cheap, it's delicious, and they have an awesome selection. The shrimp dumplings are my favorites with their steamed pork buns right behind. You may grab and go or enjoy one of the tables in the back. They also have a couple other menu items you can order if dim sum doesn't happen to be your thing.

And for those of you up early in the morning, they open at 7am. Hot steaming dim sum may not be in the cards for you that early in the morning, but it is the best time to go if you like a dumpling for breakfast. Also, it's best to bring cash to this place, as I am not even sure they take credit cards.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
OMG I'M IN LOVE. I have never had such good (luck) dim sum at such a good (luck) price. You will never ever find such great prices in Orange County or anywhere else that I know of for that matter. My heart is beating fast just thinking about this place. Let's break down everything the 4 of us ordered:

1. 2 orders of ha gao (shrimp dumpling)
2. Crystal dumpling
3. Stuffed deep fried dumpling
4. 2 baked bbq pork buns ($.80 each)
5. Steamed bbq pork buns
6. Deep fried taro with pork
7. Turnip cake
8. 2 leaf wrapped sticky rice
9. Fried dumplings
10. Siu mai
11. 2 bottles of water
12. Egg tarts

All this food for $24 flat. With a few leftovers. We had 2 trays filled with a mountain of food. The baked bao was so good with a sweet glaze on top. The ha gao was bomb. OMG, the deep fried stuffed dumpling! Sticky rice was huge. The egg tart was nice and soft with a flaky crust. I was not disappointed in anything that I ate. And the soy sauce on the tables are thicker and sweeter. So delicious. 

Don't speak Chinese? Just grab a paper menu and circle everything you want to eat. 

I heart San Francisco!!!!!!
author: Linda Y.

description: There are many reasons you should visit this area of SF if you`re a foodie. "Good luck Dim Sum" isn`t one of them. Very average luke warm steamed dumplings served over the counter to go or to eat in. Yes, it`s cheap, but that`s where the deal ends.
author: rick b.

description: Told us the har gow was 3 for $1.90 then turned around and charged is $2. No buggy we didn't complain it just 10 cents..ate it later to find that not only did they turn around and over charge but she gave us ones with beef filling instead of shrimp. Wtf false advertisement and gave us the wrong order!
author: Jewlz L.

description:
I will qualify my review by saying I'm a white guy with only a rudimentary idea of what Good American Chinese Food is (as opposed to what Chinese people get at the same restaurant, and food served in China).  I have had terrible "Chinese" food at the Tonga Room, and liked what I had at House Of Nanking, only to see it raked by Chinese reviewers. 

 Sigh.

I happened upon Good Luck Dim Sum while driving along Clement with a friend, no prior notice.  I ordered what looked good ("two of those, three of these and um, oh!  Two of those").   Everything was much better than any dim sum I've had elsewhere in San Francisco, enough to make me curious about Yelping Dim Sum and trying places that get the highest raves to see how things balance out.   I'll get back to you.

Do they really use lard?  Well bless their souls!

I especially liked the pork buns, which actually had some barbecued pork in them.  Even the shrimp dumplings were nice, with a good flavor of shrimp, but no so much so you began to wonder why...

We then went to one of those old palaces, upstairs off of Grant (with my cousin's 20% off coupon) and started with dim sum, and wow--how awful.  So, in one week I had the best (I've had) and the worst (I've had) and it hasn't been that long since we ate at a little place on O'Farrell which I thought was very good, but not quite so much so as Good Luck Dim Sum.

Yelpers who hate anyplace that costs more than what they think they would have paid in 1935 should like Good Luck.  I walked out with what I thought was quite a bit of food, and I the bill came to $12.00.

I didn't find the staff to be all that rude.  They were moderately busy but didn't rush me, although they also neglected to offer any advice or suggestions, or ask questions.  All in all it was a pleasant and efficient experience, in and out and with good food.
author: Paul T.

description:
Three dim sum for $1.50?  Why so cheap?  Because there aren't any old Chinese ladies with a cart bringing them to you at your table.  Instead, you have three crabby Chinese ladies barking at you and waiting for you to make your order already.  If you aren't ready, prepare for a mean, tired look.

But cheap bastards like me are always ready for super deals like this.  The problem here is that if you've never had dim sum, you won't know what to order.  It's probably best to just point at what you want and hope you like it.

I had a feeling the place was pretty good because I saw a bunch of white folk waiting in line.  Hey, if white folk can eat it, then it's gotta be pretty good Chinese food right?  That is to say, it probably isn't too exotic.

For less than $5, you can get a decent amount of food.  Yeah, dim sum doesn't exactly fill you up, but if you get enough of 'em in you, you'll be happy.  Maybe not satisfied, but happy.  Heck, now that I think about it, maybe buying a bag of potstickers at Trader Joe's for about the same amount might be an even better idea.

But I digress.  I'm a fan because although there could probably be better dim sum in the city, I doubt you'll get it at these prices.
author: Giovanni N.

description:
Thanks Good Luck Dim Sum.  Now I know how to make a Milk Tea....

Lady hands me an empty cup w/ a bag of LIPTON tea bag.
Me: "this is not milk tea..."
Lady: "GO GO make your self.  GO GO."
ooooo I see.  There's hot water you make Lipton tea and add 1/2 & 1/2.  Whala!  there milk tea.  Sadly no lid.  

I can't say the food is superb but for what you pay, it's dayam cheap & good.  All the sizes are big and filling & who doesn't like GIANT sesame balls?
Shrimp Dumplings - 4 Stars.  About the best in here.  Yes the wrap is thick and sometimes it falls but the taste is pretty good.
Sesame Balls & Egg Tart - 5 Stars.  This is comparable to any place.
Chives Dumpling - 4 Stars.  pretty good.
Chicken Sumai, Fried taro root, Long noodle, Taro shrimp dumpling, all just okay.  

Again Cheap but Decent, You can't go wrong.
author: Cynthia S.

description: This dim sum is too fast food for me...my roommate loves this place, but this isn't the dim sum that I grew up eating...the REAL dim sum.  You know, the kind in carts being wheeled around by Chinese ladies yelling at you to try different ones?? Well, this place has the yelling Chinese ladies, but it just feels a little grungy in there for me...
author: Jessyca M.

description:
My momma tells me dim sum makes you fat. Well, MOM, bring on the lard. If eating dim sum is wrong, I never want to be right.

6 shrimp dumplings, 1 order of bbq pork buns = $4.50. What a great way to start off the day.
author: Enji L.

description:
Great place to order dim sums, thinner dough and very reasonable.  You can't beat the price!  3 pcs for $1.60!!!  Had beef sui mai (bit salty), shrimp with chives, shrimp, chicken bun.  Went on week days, no long line.

-CASH ONLY-
author: Maki M.

description: A lot of bang for only a few bucks.  I went here for a late lunch and got to avoid a line.  I ordered some pork dumplings, some mystery dumplings, and deep fried dumplings and an egg tart & a soda can which came out to 6$ and some change.  As for the taste, pretty good.  Not the best things out there, but hey, for the price, I'm more than impressed.
author: Anna V.

description: Best dim sum bakery in the bay area. Period.
author: Alex H.

description:
YUM.  i was hungover as eff but still enjoyed this place immensely.  my friend and i loaded up on a ton of diff goodies and ended up spending less than $12 combined.  we had so much we had leftovers for snack later!  the chive dumplings are phenom and the porridge (a quart for only $1.80!) was the best hangover cure i've had in a long time.  

long line but moved quickly and oh so worth it!
author: Sara H.

description:
Cold dim sum and pretty dirty inside. The plastic trays are the dirtiest thing I've ever seen. There are lots of choices for dim sum in inner richmond and it looks like 4 stars for this place are the result of the Cheescake Factory White Yelp voters who don't know any better. Now I'm on a mission to find a real 4 star dim sum place in the city.

They do not serve dim sum from the cart. It is an order at the counter kind of place.
author: Eric M.

description: their pot stickers are ok went there today and their shrimp bonnets /  ha gow are good too. their sui mei is good the beef ones and the pork ones are ok. their custard tart is good  .their baked pork buns are good.
author: Nellie J.

description:
This is a real neighborhood gem. At first glance the menu is slightly confusing because you read "3 items $1.60" so it would appear that you order 3 pieces of various dim sum dishes, for $1.60. This is not the case - each order is 3 pieces, and each order is $1.60. So far so good - very reasonably priced compared to a sit-down tea house.

Flavors and textures were delicious and authentic - it's what you would get in Hong Kong or Taiwan. The usual stuff like turnip cake, siu mai, har gow were excellent. But what I really enjoyed was seeing the old school faves - bai tang gao (sweet rice cake), ma la gao (sponge cake), and dan ta (custard pastry). Like a trip down dim sum memory lane.

My one complaint would have to be their order management process. They had 3 or 4 people behind the counter, handling each order individually and wasting time bumping into each other. This caused the line to back up. I think it would be much better for their customers (and their business) if they organized their set up so that one person handled certain items (i.e. 1 person for the things behind the glass, 1 person for things in the steamers, 1 person for everything near the window) and processed quickly.

I would recommend this place to friends and definitely come back.
author: Richard Z.

description: Super cheap place to tame your dim beast. The flavors was pretty good but some of them are pretty dry. I'd still prefer the "push cart" dim sum style, but if I ever need to tame the beast, "Good Luck Dim Sum" should be able to help you
author: Vanessa D.

description:
Dirt cheap, tasty food, and quick service. What more can you ask for? 

As a child dim sum was the focal point of every weekend. And while this joint isn't the sit down place that I am used to envisioning in my formative years, it's nice to know that this place exists and I can always get a taste of childhood on the quick. 

Truly, everything is pretty good here (I've prolly had 90% of it). But if you had to have one thing, make it the pork sui mai!
author: Douglas L.

description: Know what u want... Smile despite the attidude (although there is no risk for snapping back, chicken siu mai is already ready already!)
author: sonia m.

description:
Oh My Dim Sum, 

I'm actually pretty speechless when it comes to this review.  Lunch for two for under 10 dollars in SF? Who knew!  We got a bunch of selections in the 3 for 1.50 menu.  The dumplings were delicious and the chicken buns were mouth watering.  The soy sauce they have at each table is also amazing, I had no idea that soy sauce even comes that thick.  

I even ordered some food to go to surprise the boyfriend with at home.  I thought it would be cute to put it all in one of Good Luck's cute pink boxes, but when I asked for one they said no, which I could only think was because of the small amount of food that I ordered to take home.   

Being the only draw back I am in no position to take away any stars, I anticipate many many return visits to come.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description:
I pulled an all nighter last week, and luckily decided to hit up Good Luck.  The line was like 8 deep, and moved quickly.  while I was there, the cooks brought in 2 new deliveriesi of shu mai and some shrimp dumplings.  picked those off and a couple steamed buns.  

out the door for less than $8.

yeah it was not clean, yeah it would loud, and hot as balls in the line, but their food is good.
author: Pablo E.

description:
$16 and you get a lot of good food. What is wrong with that? Nothing.

We got 3 baked charshu bao, 2 order each of har gaw and shu mai, 1 order of pan fried leek dumplings, 1/2 lb each of chicken feet and steamed pork ribs and 1 order of haam sui gok.

We liked almost everything, especially when we took the food to Presidio and ate them while enjoying the view of South Bay.

The only thing we thought was not up to par was the ribs. They were tough. But my dogs loved them. They did not say one bad thing about them.

I'll definitely come back again.
author: Steven P.

description:
Food is very good. 
Price is even better. 
But definitely the most hole-in-the-wall joint you'll ever eat dim sum in. 
The Good Luck part comes in when needing to share your 20+ items, with 3 other people, to be put on more than 1 plate... flimsy paper plate... the ones you use at a picnic....when you're on a tight-ass student budget. 
But that's ok,  we'll let it slide in the name of eco-friendliness.
author: C T.

description: Great price for dim sum.  $12 last me and my husband 3 meals.soy sauce is so good.   Ghetto restaurant but whatever food was great.
author: L K.

description:
I have never been a fan of dim sum. BUT, i took a chance on Good Luck Dim Sum, and omg, where has this place been all my life? It's absolutely delicious here. 

It's dirt cheap, quick service, and most importantly delicious. It was ridiculously packed when I went (not surprised, though) and my friends and I were lucky enough to grab one of the few tables located in the back. 

Definitely try it out, and if you're driving, allow yourself 30 minutes to find parking. Parking sucks there.
author: Shannon A.

description:
What I love about Good Luck Dimsum, is that you can feed a family of four for lunch for a mere $9. That's what I call a steal. The sticky chicken rice wrapped in lotus leaves is really good, and only $2 a pop. My favorites are the pork shu mai, ha gao, and char siu bao. You get three pieces for $1.60 for most items. Other specialty items like egg custard are $0.65 each.

Be prepared to queue up on the weekends, especially in the late morning hours. It takes about 20-25 minutes to get through the line.

Oh, and you don't need to get a pink box for $0.20.... they'll stick them in plastic bags for you so don't freak out.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I went back and forth on this review... on one hand getting cheap eats at a dim sum place where you can get 3 items for $1.50 is similar to getting food at Mr. Chau's... Asian food on the cheap, some will love it and some with more refined palates will not like some items but as my friend said best... you get what you pay for.
