We ordered a boatload since this was my first REAL journey for "dim sum" outside a sample or two so we ordered Sweet Rice Bun, Baked BBQ Pork Bun, Steamed BBQ Pork Bun, Shrimp Dumplings, pork shu mai, beef shu mai, har gow, chicken siu mai, Hom Sui Gok, Chive dumplings w/ shrimp, Steamed Pork Dumplings, seasame ball, custard, and a egg yolk bun. We got all this which included two orders of certain items and two drinks for $16.60.  Recession budget... accomplished.

CONS 
The steamed bun seemed overly doughy. The Siu Mai (pork, beef, chicken) tasted like mystery meat. The sesame balls we were only able to eat a couple bites of, the filling just didn't mesh well with us. The other items, besides the ones listed below, while not terrible were nothing special, just food. They run out of food fast so you have to make sure you get there early as two items we had to substitute something else for. Service was slower than we heard, only 5 people in line and it took 21 minutes to leave. Parking is TERRIBLE. 

PROS 
Contrary to some, the food was hot and looked mostly appealing, and this is even after calling ahead, stood in line for 10 minutes (we'll talk about that later), and drove about 7 minutes to the spot we ate at. The pieces were HUGE compared to other dum sum I had seen. Chive and shrimp dumplings were excellent, nice mix of shrimp and not just chives and a micro shrimp. BBQ baked bun was a good mix between sweet and salty. The sweet rice bun made me rediscover my inner 1/16th Asian side. 

We heard all the comical or honest reviews about this place having rude workers however I don't think they are rude as much as extremely busy. It just reminded me of my visit to NYC with food vendors and shops where they're trying to move you along so the line can get shorter and have no time for small talk. Piece of advice... fill out your pink order form since we witnessed what happens to anyone who dares try the twice menu over routine... not pretty. I stand 6' and weigh on the higher portion of 200lb club, played football, went to bars with drunk idiots but never felt as intimidated as I felt glaring into the eyes of those tiny Asian ladies. =) I had to laugh since I almost felt like Seinfeld did with the infamous "Soup Nazi" episode: 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J02RdkvI6zo&feature=related 

Although we called ahead when coming in we didn't know do we stand in line or just step to the counter but the stern looks by the ladies just had us jump in line since we saw only 5 people in line. While one lady was very short another suggested something else and wished us well on our trip so maybe bark worse than bite. =) 

So overall on the fence with this place... a few items we really enjoyed, some we did not and with soo many dim sum places in the city not sure this is a "must have" as others feel but it definitely gave us our money's worth on the experience alone.
author: Mike D.

description:
Yelp has ruined this place.  It used to be the best place in town to get cheap, fast, and good dim sum.  Now the line is continually 20 deep with hipsters and tourists googling "har gow".  

It's still cheap and good (best take out dim sum by a good margin) but now you're talking a 30-40 minute wait if you go within 1.5 hrs of generally accepted mealtimes.  

Please if you still decide to go at least adhere to the correct procedure which is to get a paper menu and circle the items you want, writing the number of orders of that item next to it.   Items at the top of the menu come in "orders" of 3 each so if you write "3" you will get 9 of those.

Don't try to do anything dumb like ask detailed questions of the staff or screw up the standard procedure in any way.  It's obvious English is not the go to language in this place, you will not get an acceptable answer to your question and you will make a super long line even longer.

Five stars for the food, minus 2 for the wait.  Hopefully this brings down the average and this place gets less busy.
author: Steve W.

description:
My boyfriend brought me here during my dim sum craving phase a while ago and we came pretty frequently after that. It hits the spot. 

Before I moved to the Bay Area I had no idea there were so many dim sum takeout places and that they outnumbered sit down places with carts. 

This place is CROWDED. But the line moves pretty fast, and then if you're not actually "taking it out" its really a free-for-all finding a table. Sometimes it's just easier than others. Once, we got our food and just stood there looking pathetic and hungry and another couple offered to share their table with us. 

So just be prepared for anything! and try not to go at peak times...which might be all the time...
author: Abbey S.

description:
Let's be honest, you don't go out to Chinese food for the atmosphere, unless of course, your idea of a great setting is pushy waitstaff, less-than-cleanly decor, and signage written in black magic marker. The restaurant world has yet to bridge the gap between the Pacific-rim food that made California famous, and the lower-end Chinese food which, in the case of Good Luck Dim Sum, is motherf**king incredible.

Once you brave the line that snakes out the door, order one of the huge variety of dumplings and either take them home or try your luck with a table out back. I had the crystal, shrimp/chive, and pork/chive dumplings with a pork bun on top and a bottle of water. The whole thing cost me-- ready?-- $7.50. So, to recap, there were 12 items there (each order of dumplings contains 3 pieces), for less than $8. Incredible. The better part is that the dumplings were succulent, savory, and full of flavor. While there are many great styles of Asian dumplings-- soup dumplings, Japanese dumplings, et al-- for Chinese dumplings, Good Luck Dim Sum is my new go-to locale.
For a quick jaunt to the Far East, if you can find parking, this is worth a morning trip.
author: Ross S.

description:
The line for dim sum here is always unbelievably long. IT'S SO WORTH THE WAIT THOUGH. Everything here is CHEAP & amazing.

When I used to be able to eat shrimp, I'd get so much ha gow. I miss it!! The skins were always so perfect, and the shrimp was crunchy and delicious. The egg tarts are really reallly good. They usually run out of the white ones by noon, so you really have to get there early if you want some of that! I think they use egg whites to make them? I haven't had them in the longest time, but I've been to other dim sum places who had them.. and omg LET ME TELL YOU, I've never had any better than from good luck dim sum.

I never eat there because I don't think that it'd be fun just to have so many people lining up and all next to me. :( You don't get in line outside the door, you have to go inside and get behind all those people!
author: Erica A.

description:
Let's be honest and blunt about this place...ready?

(If you're the kind of person who needs to sit and analyze a situation, warning, this review may not be for you)

1.  One of the best Dim Sum spots in the city, takeout or sit-down.

2.  The food is extremely affordable, my best friend and I can usually get full off of say 6-8 dollars COMBINED.

3. The Lady behind the counter is fast, calculated, and precise with her movements, watch out, sometimes she ends up standing behind you and you didn't even blink.

4. Fast lines, great dim sum, and cheap prices. 

5. Take your dim sum to GGP and play frisbee all day, that's how we do it usually.

ENJOY
author: David M.

description:
Best dim sum on Clement St.  Everything is great there.  Always hot and fresh.  The size of the items are probably average, but great flavor and excellent pricing.  Cutthroat competition on Clement pretty much guarantees that.  Although the line can be long, they always keep it moving and the ladies that work there are helpful, though businesslike.  You need to be prepared with your order sheet or you will test the patience of everyone in line behind you.  Typically a 5-10 min wait in line, sometimes faster.  It can get backed up if the kitchen runs out of popular items.

There are a few small tables in case you really want to eat there, but honestly, the majority of folks are taking out. 

Cash only, so be prepared!
author: Byron Y.

description:
met some friends here on a sunday around noon for a brunch-ish meal.

PURE INSANITY, that line and ladies taking orders are not for the meek or faint of heart.  it'd be easy to think the one you're dealing with thinks you should get out of her face.

it's pretty affordable, median quality dim-sum.  I do have a high bar set as i grew up in the bay area and my family used to go to dim sum regularly in S.F. and Oakland.
author: Carol S.

description:
"Does your dim sum use glucose base or rice base flour?"
I couldn't stop my self from laughing.
The things you over-hear.

not "THE BEST DIM SUM" on clement. but you can vote it
"MOST UNIQUE SOY SAUCE".

if you like sweet soy sauce, you'll go crazy over this spot.
if you don't like soy sauce or you want red vinegar  you'll hate it.

they are actually very engrish friendly, and actually have a lot of patience.
author: kevin h.

description: Not exactly the best service...but for good cheap and fast dim sum...i will put up with bad attitude...
author: Sue L.

description:
Don't get me wrong. When I say "woohoo as good as it gets" as yelp states, I mean it in reference of the price. 

Seriously, as a broke ass college student a few years ago, this place is GOLD!!!

A meal to get you nice and full in UNDER $5!!! And the food is GOOD too. Dim sum is dim sum, it's either good or nastaaayyy. And this place is good! 

Must try!!!
author: Stephanie P.

description: I was introduced to this place by a co-worker who oftens takes our orders and picks it up for everyone at the office. It truly is one of the best dim sum places that I know of. So far, I have tried the beef, pork, crystal, and shrimp. I love it all! :)
author: Alyssa B.

description:
it's not so busy here in the mid afternoons. even parking is available.  they have dim sum starting at 3 pieces for 1.40 while most items are 3 for $1.50.

- the  shirmp dumpling (3/1.50)had nice pastelike shrimp and whole shrimp within the delicate skin. quality is equal to or exceeds most dim sum resataurants.
-chicken bun(3/1.50)nice doughy "skin"  with semijuicy chicken inside. very good.

there was some white guy making a meal out of a chinese tamale (2ish). i know these are filling. there's room to sit down here also.

friendly bilingual service.

tea/coffee(1)
author: Victor G.

description: Love the idea of this place - instant a la cart Dim Sum, mix and match single pieces, ordered at a counter in an authentic looking hole in the wall - but the food was really disappointing, especially after reading all the great reviews.  Rubbery, not very flavorful, and most definite not fresh (but what do you expect, the stuff sits in warmers all day).  Stick with the places that make it fresh and bring it out on a cart within minutes.  Two stars for convenience and low price, plus fried taro root and fried sesame ball w black bean paste were good.
author: Paul M.

description:
I use to love this place until recently.

Pros:
*  good prices. 3 for $1.60 for most items.  And if you don't want 3 they will charge you accordingly
* great turn over on the food.  So most things are nice and hot.  yum!
* every once in a while I can find parking in front or very close by
* they stay open late (for a dim sum place) so if you are craving some at 6pm you may still be able to snag something
*easy ordering system.  pick up the sheet and mark what you want and give it to one of the ladies.
* you can call in your order and pick it up in about 30 minutes.  I normally call as I am leaving the house and it's ready when I get there.  

Cons:
*non-existent service!  The ladies here do seem to hate their job as another poster states.  They bark at you!  
* I've caught them talking in chinese about the customers.  I may not look like I understand you, but ladies, yes I do know when you are calling other customers stupid or deaf.  
* my last encounter involved the bigger, rounder lady sneezing in her hand and then grabbing one of the items from the glass case without washing her hands.  I threw those items away.  
* a customer dropped her food and the ladies yelled at her about her being an inconvenince.  Hello, she was trying to balance her food and a cane.  

I really liked this place and it is a solid 4 star for the food but a 1-2 star for the service.  I can easily drop $30 in the place and just hate to spend the money to be ridiculed and barked at or have to listen to them talk about other people who do not understand them.  I just believe if you have something to say, say it to my face and not in another language.  That's just lame and cowardly and I will call you on it.
author: Dima L.

description:
I don't think I've ever been so stuffed in my entire life...from $15 for 2 people. There's nothing like here in Vancouver -- but, oh how I wish there was! This is pigging out at it's best -- a tonne of food: bbq pork buns, shrimp and chive dumplings, the deep fried taro (best I've ever had!), the egg tarts. So stuffed we were that the egg tarts came with us and made for a nice "light" snack later in the afternoon. 

Good Luck will be taunting my dim sum dreams for ages to come I'm sure!
author: Crystal H.

description:
Parking in the area is a so hard to find, but it's worth it to have a good inexpensive meal.  

There was a long line, but it moved quickly.  I don't speak Chinese (even though I should), but they make it really easy for you by having these pink menus that you can circle your order on.  It works much better than pointing.  

The food is always good.  And though you lose the experience of the carts that you would get at House of Banquet or Peony in Oakland, I really can't complain about the prices.  

Too bad I live a little far away or else I would frequent this place more.
author: Nita K.

description: Line was long super busy and crowded, but boy was it well worth the wait. Bought a bunch of dim sum and total came out to $26! Shrimp dumpling was my fave! Litterly bought 18 pieces and ate every single one. My sibling like the baked pork buns and steamed buns. Simply put, wonderful and delicious food!!
author: Joy M.

description:
This place is the SHIET!

PROS: inexpensive, delicious, authentic
CONS: long line (but moves quite fast), small, busy atmosphere

Crowded? Agree! But you have to understand, it is crowded because this place is that good! I bought food that could feed a family of 5 for only $25 max. The Chinese ladies who work here seem like they are rushing you, but don't take it personally; they just want to be as efficient as possible. Every time I come here, I notice a diverse group of customers across ages too. Ditch the mediocre dim sum at fancy restaurants that just jip you for your money, and get your moneys worth, a full stomach plus more here!
author: Margareth H.

description: sticky dog pod rice was awesome. The pork bun was like my first sexual experience- akward, messy, and I didnt even finish.  At least it only cost me a couple bucks.
author: nathan z.

description:
We love everything about GLDS. Most importantly the CHIVE DUMPLINGS...they are, by far, the best dumplings that they offer (and so hard to find at other dim sum places). 

The other thing that we love are the "colorful" folks that you'll meet here. For example, on our most recent visit over this past weekend we encountered: 

-"The Bathroom Bandit"- while waiting in line to use the restroom, I reached out to open the door to enter the restroom, when a woman swooped in and closed the door quickly behind her. I was aghast in disbelief and could do nothing but wait for the bandit to exit... 

-"The Cutter"- Remember middle school? Remember those crazy kids that cut in the lunch line and everyone shouted, "Cutter, cutter!" So you'll need to beware of "the cutter" while waiting in line to place your order. While I was experiencing the "bathroom bandit", my tall & hunky husband experienced "the cutter". Be aware of a very short Asian woman when waiting to order- 'cause she'll swoop right in front of you when you're glancing over your shoulder to see what commotion is happening behind you in the bathroom line. 

-"The Plastic Cutlery Police"- After exiting the restroom, I quickly spotted an empty table and nabbed it (a big victory at GLDS). My husband proudly arrived with a tray overflowing with dumplings and 2 little paper trays & 2 plastic forks. Problem= he had asked for 3 trays & 3 forks since there were 3 diners in our group. He returned to the counter to ask for 1 more set of "serving pieces". The place was jam-packed with people (as it always is) and the line formed a solid wall down the center of the restaurant- the "cutlery police" woman left her post at the steamers and came back to our table to find that there were, in fact, 3 diners. She quickly issued the third fork & paper tray. Don't even think of asking for extra cutlery at GLDS...they just won't have it!

We've never left there without a big laugh!  Even with the cutter, the bandit and the cutlery police :-)
author: Stacey M.

description:
After reading all these reviews, I never knew what a popular dim sum place this was. I came here yesterday with my mom...my mom wanted to go there early because she said that there is always a line. Well I thought coming here by 7:05am (they open at 7am) would be fine. There was already 6 people in front of me (don't people sleep in on saturdays anymore?). Eh, only 6 people - no big deal...about 25 mins waiting in line is pretty crazy! People come here early early in the morning and they get huge boxes of dim sum here. One lady was also assembling pre-orders that was going to be picked up at 8 am. 

We picked basically an order of everything. And for those who don't know what to order - they have these convenient pink sheets that you can mark how many orders you want. By the time we got up there..they had no more shrimp dumplings (har gow) and no more shanghai dumplings. But we got the sui mai (they have chicken, pork, and beef), a variety of the buns, and some other dim sum that they had there. Most of the dim sum was 3 pieces of $1.50. Everything was pretty good - the buns had the perfect amount of filling and dough, and the dim sum was really fresh. And while we were waiting in line, a bigger line formed behind us. Just be prepared to wait- even at 7 in the morning you can't escape the crowd all looking for some yummy dim sum!
author: Betty S.

description:
I ate so much dim sum from Good Luck, and was filled to the brim.  It cost me $6.  That makes for a happy camper.  The line is always long, but they keep it moving...and you'd better know what you want by the time you're to the front (I mean, you've had 15 min. in line to figure it out, it shouldn't be too hard).  

I came here with a coworker who highly recommended this place...otherwise how on earth would I be able to decide which dim sum place on clement is good without going to every single one?  No need to take a gamble, come to Good Luck. 

I'd probably give this place 5 stars, but I really have nothing else to compare it to in the area for easy take-out dim sum.  Once I eat around more, perhaps I'll feel more confident throwing the extra star in there.  

my favorites included the chive dumpling with shrimp, deep fried dumpling, pork shu mai, and BBQ pork bun.  the egg custard was good, but i've had better.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: The best Xiao Long Bao dumplings I've had since Ding Tai Fung in China!  Even better then Joe's shanghai in NYC!
author: Tom N.

description:
if there is a line with Chinese people, it's a line you want to get into too.

1) Super cheap, but it doesn't lack on quality

Must dos:
1) Ha Gow
2) BBQ Pork
3) Sticky Rice Balls
4) Egg Custards

If you can yell in Cantonese, please do not write/order on their pink slip of paper if you have a small order. 

I droved all the way from berkeley and I will go back (this is my 2nd time with friends)
author: Virginia C.

description: What can I say? Among the cheapest places on Clement to get Dim Sum, and their selection is great (I recommend their chicken buns in particular). Definitely a place to stop by during a visit to the city.
author: Taylor W.

description:
This is what fast food should be. Fast, cheap, and deeeelicious. 

For $3.50 you can buy 2 baked pork buns and two large egg rolls (i love fried crap). You can have them in thirty seconds, and I recommend eating them while you walk (slowly) down Clement St. 

If you are a pork bun fan, you HAVE to come here :) Would recommend to anyone who has $5 in their wallet and is a fan of greasy, yummy, melt in your mouth dim sum.
author: nina B.

description:
GLDS rocks for the most part; from the Har Gow to the Taro to the sesame balls and egg custard, all great!  However, the steamed pork buns are a little on the doughy side.  Other than that, this is the best walk in, chow down and bail for under $20 bucks spot in the city!
Expect long lines and an ~ hour wait... the counter ladies do their best and can get edgy at times, but, that's probably because I don't speak the local language and butcher the names of my dim sum orders...  If you don't want the local tude, then head to Yank Sing's for great dim sum at 5X the $$$.

Bottom line:  This place is your best bet for dim sum in the city - great!!!
author: Toneman's S.

description:
Good, solid dim sum.  Of all the take-out dim-sum spots along Clement, this one is the best.  It's not amazing, fancy, dazzling, or even excellent, but it's damned good.
All the standards work well, the pork buns are, well, pork buns (I'm not a big char siu bao fan) and the noodles are nice and light and gooey.
We like to ride bikes over (PUH_leeze stop complaining about parking.  This is the city.  Get used to it!) and hang my little pink plastic bag on the handlebars, head over to the Garfield statue in GG Park (near the Conservatory) and have a little picnic feast.   People almost always come over and ask us where we got the delishus-looking lunch.  I point them towards Clement and say Good Luck!
author: Rob B.

description: Good Luck is not a sit down restaurant! it is a place for cheap, filling, tasty and huge pieces of dim sum. Some of the wrappers are pretty thick and everything tastes similar, but the pieces are enormous and the food is very fresh, not surprising given the crowds and high turnover. The menu is limited but has all the stand bys. Service is as to be expected in this type of busy place - brusque and brisk. The line is long on the weekends but moves quickly.
author: Kelly C.

description:
We're from LA and I personally have to say that Dim Sum back home is far superior.

If this is the best San Francisco has to offer, then I'm sorry to say, but we'll have to pass the next time around.
author: Mark D.

description:
Delicious and affordable.

I can survive on $6 a day eating here and I can eat alot.


Just try to avoid that one lady that will yell at you and give you the evil eye.
author: Evan W.

description: Loved the fried sesame ball w/ bean paste. Yum.
author: Katie P.

description: Long line, but yummy cheap dim sum!! I wish I could recommend something, but I have no idea what the food I ate were called. If you don't want tea, make sure you specify at the BEGINNING. They serve it to you as if it comes free, BUT it is $4 or $5 per person for ordinary tea!
author: Ela A.

description:
I should probably start by noting that I don't like food where I can't see what's inside.  That goes for dim sum, dumplings, eggrolls, spring rolls, empanadas, Russel Stover chocolates, etc.  I like to know what I'm eating.  

My man went to Asia a few years ago and came back RAViNG about the dim sum.  He was dim sum fan before, but after that trip he's been on the hunt for comparable dim sum in North America.  

Being the good +1 that I am, I've tried way more dim sum than I really wanted to - all in hopes of helping him recreate that magical dim sum experience he had in Asia.  

Today, we tried Good Luck Dim Sum in the Richmond. I got two chicken shu mai, two chicken buns, and two shrimp dumplings.  All for 3 bucks.  And a custard for dessert.  

I enjoyed the chicken buns.  They were the least greasy of the group.  The chicken shu mai gave me the willies.  The meat tasted weird.  Not exotic weird. Just weird weird.  The shrimp dumplings were pretty slimey.  I took a bite of the custard.  It tasted like a hard boiled egg.  Not the sweet treat I was hoping for.  What can I say?  I'm just not a big fan of dim sum.  

Anyway, I'm giving this place 2 stars.  If you're a big fan of dim sum, you might disagree with me and that's ok.  That's why you get to write your own review.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Came here hungry because I read good reviews about it...even waited in line for 30 minutes.....but I was really dissapointed. Ordered 10 different things I didnt know what to expect, but since there was a line I figured it was going to be good shit.  When we got our food I was ready to feast on mysterious meat, but instead all I got was cold & old dim sum....

That mysterious stuff is only good when its steaming....not so at good luck.  We threw away all but 2 half eaten pieces.
author: Veronica P.

description:
With each visit, I have to write an update.  Now it's 1 star for the attitude! :-/

We came back here last week, this time before going to the Academy of Sciences.  If you read below, you will see that the first time, my beef was with the clientele, but this time I actually had to deal with the women who work there.  

Short line this time, we got our food quickly, and sat down.  I picked up a fork and saw...greenish black crap that looked like the stuff that comes out of a shrimp vein (poo?).  I wiped most of it off, but decided to go back up and ask for another fork.  She gave me two.

Me: "Thank you!"

Her: *frown*

Then as we were eating, she TAKES THE TIME TO COME BACK TO OUR TABLE and say, "FOUR FORKS FOR TWO PEOPLE???"  

"There was black [shit] all over this one!" (as we held up the poo-fork)

We got the stink-eye the rest of that meal.

Look ladies, I appreciate your tasty food and cheap prices, but are you soooo cheap that we get all this crap for taking a couple extra forks, even when there was poo on our first one?  Do you dig through the trash so you can wash (not very thoroughly) all the used forks that people throw away?  Apparently, it doesn't matter that we tipped you enough to buy multiple BOXES of plastic forks.

ROTD be damned, you guys suck.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
Here's what i'll say...

The food is BOMB and the PRICE IS CHEAP. There is no getting around this fact. For an insanely low price you can leave with enough dim sum to feed a small army(or just you and your girlfriend) Everything that i tasted with shrimp in it was outstanding... a little oily, but outstanding. 

The people that work here seem a little rude and the line to order your food takes a while if you go during lunch, but pay no mind to these minor nuisances... what you get at Good Luck Dim Sum is the best bang for your buck Chinese food around...

I'm seriously considering having GLDS cater my wedding.
author: Greg G.

description:
I love dim sum!!!

I don't even live in the city anymore and yet every time I go home I have to visit this place to grab as much dim sum I can fit in my luggage.  

Its a whole in the wall but the ladies are super nice.  They are a little pushy when ordering but that is because many do not look at how the many units of food are in each order.  You need to fill out a piece of paper with your order.  

My whole family loves this place, the chinese ladies even hit on my dad (in chinese) and say he's good looking, which my mom comments with 'yes he is!' 

My favorite part is looking back in the kitchen and seeing all of them working so quickly to get out the yummy yummy dim sum

My favorite is the dried shrimp crape, which isn't a crape at all but a giant white noodle rolled to make another giant noodle.  They are the best in the area, and when this place is closed I've been forced to try new places.  My other favorite is the sweet rice bun, now these are a ball of rice, but its not normal rice its flavored and filled with bbq pork and super yummy!!! I've looked everywhere in the city for these when my favorite place closed in Chinatown.  

Love love love!!! But please don't be put off by their hustle and bustle. They are nice, and are just trying to get their job done quickly.  But the food is worth it and when you're nice and patient they can be very sweet ladies.
author: jenny W.

description:
Let's get something straight here. I can forgive a joint for poor customer service and language barriers as long as their food made up for it. However, I am not forgiving to a joint that sucks AND is rude as hell!  I'm sorry but maybe we came at the wrong time of the day (3:30 in the afternoon?) but this place doesn't even come close to a one star! As an LA native visiting SF, I had hoped that with a four star rating and 400+ reviews that it would be a safe bet for us but we were soooooooo wrong. For starters, all the dumplings were cold and the edges of the steamed dumplings were hard. Again, maybe it's because we came 2 1/2 hours before closing but all I know is had this been even one of the worse dim sum places in Alhambra or Monterey Park, 3:30 or not my buns would not be cold and hard like that. If you're looking for some good SF dim sum, you may want to keep looking because this place was horrid and I'm only talking about the food!

As far as the service goes, the lady charged us  $.10 for an extra paper plate. My bf gave her a quarter and told her to keep the change since she seemed so hard up. She acted like we were asking to use fine china or something.

In the end, I was completely unsatisfied but I got over it really quick because we only spent 7 bucks.  I thought about giving the dumplings to a homeless person but I don't think he would eaten it either. We were better off splitting a chowder bowl at the Wharf.

Let me reiterate....this place is yuck yuck yuck and it serves crap crap crap!!!!
author: Agnes D.

description:
don't listen to me, i'm not a huge dim sum fan.
good value.
author: Bennet A.

description: Given that my friends and I had to wait in line for a considerable amount of time, the food was surprisingly lukewarm/room temperature.  Clement Restaurant dim sum about a block away is infinitely better, though it does have less seating.  Truly a disappointment.
author: Andy J.

description:
4.5 STARS! THE BEST TAKE-OUT DIM SUM EVER! It's so worth the 25-30 min wait in line on the weekend.

*Har Gow (shrimp dumpling): YUMMY--the wrapper is not too thick and not too thin and is filled with huge tender shrimp! 
* Jiaozi (potsticker): the BEST I've ever tasted. Their potsticker is FILLED with delicious pork and cabbage. The best part is it's pan fried to PERFECTION. The bottom is crisp and the rest of the skin still has a bite to it. 
*Shrimp and Chive Dumpling: Ok, the wrapper had a good texture and filled with tender shrimp and vibrant chive. Only ordered this b/c they were out of the shirimp and taro dumplings. :(
*Cheung fun (rice noodle roll): HUGE. I think one of these babies can be a complete meal in itself. 
*Wu Gock (deep fried taro dumpling): MmMmMm...so light anf d crispy outside and the taro is oh-so creamy. Oh yeah, the pork filling is quite tasty also. 
*Ham Sui Gok (deep fried dumpling): YUMMY! Nice and crisp outside and the sweet rice is so ooeeeyy gooeey. I love the sweet/salty contrast to it. 
*Dan Tot (custard tarts): Just ok, I had better. The crust wasn't as flaky as I thought it would be. And, the custard was a little too eggy for my taste. 
*Jin Dui (sesame balls): OMFG, SO GOOD! I was lucky enough to eat it while it was still warm. When you sink in your teeth into this baby, it's crisp and gooeey at the same time.  Then, as you get into the bean paste---PURE HEAVEN! I think I can eat a dozen of these with vanilla ice cream!!!! 

This will definately be my go-to place for dim sum! Can't wait to come back again...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: This is place is a one buck fuck type of place. They got the grade A dimsum going on. Grade A dipping sweet soy sauce. Their Har Gow sucks though but who the fuck cares about that when you can get a fat plate of Pai Gwut Fan (spareribs over rice) for like 3-4 bucks damn throw some of that sweet soy sauce on it, Its a done fucking deal.  One lady is a bitch, and the others are sweethearts. I think the people that experienced bad service at this place has dealt with the bitch. I moved back down to Socal and every once and awhile i dream about Good Luck Dimsum.
author: Rod S.

description: If ya yeaning for cold dim sum...pls try out this store...sucks big time!!!
author: Nicholas S.

description:
I'm giving this place a high 3 stars.  

The food here is outstanding.  I couldn't agree more with all the other reviews.  The dim sum here is not only cheap, but tastes great!  So why only 3 stars?  Well the service sucked!  I think customer service is a really important factor at businesses, and when it sucks it just brings the  business down.  

I even think the lady who rang me up charged me an extra 2 bucks, but I let it slide cuz $16 for all the food my boyfriend and I ordered would have cost me $40 at another restaurant.  The food here tastes really good, and you really can't beat the prices, but the service just sucks.  Just get your food and leave, and you'll be all good lol.
author: Crysthel C.

description:
"If this is what you call cheap..."

I now get the FoodMaxx commercial. They don't call there food cheap, they call it low price, because the quality is still there.  This goes as well with Good Luck. 

Just because it's not your ordinary place to go and eat dim sum, doesn't mean the quality is not there.  The quality of the food still taste like quality restaurants or I would say even better than most.  

The more popular items are usually the fresher items... Some you might get warm because it's not on most peoples list of what to get.  So if you want fresh, go with the common items... If you want something unique regardless of freshness, try the shark fin xiu mai.

You can't beat the prices... Usually at dim sum places, 3 pork buns are 2.50+, this place is only 1.50 and it's much bigger and also taste much better.  

This is about 4.5 on the food alone.  The -0.5 came from just some items being a little too cold for my liking.
The other 0.5 was the line was long.  But well worth the wait =).

If you don't care about anything else but the taste... This is probably a must hit up spot.  They have some tables inside if you don't want to take it to go...

Cash Only
author: Phung N.

description: Best Har Gow in town, for my dollar. I also love the fried stuffed dumplings, with just a bit of filling in a sweet, crispy, chewy shell. The hint of cilantro is delicious.
author: Teal H.

description: This place is good for take-out dim sum though there is seating. I wish they had a more comprehensive selection of dim sum - it's mostly potstickers, haw gau, siu mai, and some pastries. The service is pretty rude - I had a question on the menu and they scowled at me and angrily tapped on the display where the item I was asking about was sitting.
author: Amy M.

description:
All my previous Dim Sum experiences involved carts. This is definitely a diversion from that typical experience but after tasting the food, I didn't feel that it was much of a loss. This is Dim Sum with a fast-food essence. Limited seating and over the counter service.

Aside from the good food, Good Luck Dim Sum's prices are amazingly cheap. My friend and I are big eaters. Despite all the food we ordered, we got extremely stuffed with a total bill of $13.75! That's unheard of here in SF. :) 

The food highlights are as follows: Pork dumplings (Siu Mai) and Pork buns (whether with veg OR bbq), Rice Porridge (with green onions, hold off on the fried wontons), and Deep Fried Stuffed Dumpling. The food is solid but if you can manage to get a fresh batch of dim sum food from here, it's gets even better!
author: Beck P.

description:
Now if you're thinking dim sum with the little carts and the Chinese ladies trying to explain to you in their best English what they have, then this is not  it. But if you want incredibly affordable and beyond tasty dim sum, then stop in at Good Luck Dim Sum.

Ordering procedure:
1) Get in line
2) Grab a pink menu and pen
3) Give your order to the women

Most items on the menu are 3 for $1.50!! They do have some items like the Baked BBQ bun for $0.80/piece and you can buy Chow Mein by the lb for $2/lb. Again SUPER AFFORDABLE! 

I couldn't tell if they had warm tea for sale, as they didn't seem to advertise any, just soda's and a variety of Vitasoy drinks. Which is funny since dim sum is meant to be served as a "tea time" meal.

There are tables and chairs that you can sit at that does have soy sauce and hot sauce. The seating area was relatively clean and you bus your own table. 

Again, really tasty and cheap dim sum. Not much in the way of ambiance, but the aforementioned makes up for it.
author: Rana A.

description:
It's good, inexpensive and I can feed my family for $20.00 or less.

1. It's always hot
2. It's always big and loaded with ingredients
3. It's where the locals get theirs.

As far as unfriendliness, I don't recommend going without knowing what you want. If you don't know your dim-sum, then just listen to what other people order and try it. It's all pretty good.

Favs: Chive rolls, Siu-Mai, Shrimp Dumplings, Baked Pork Buns, Fried Shrimp Dumplings, and Fried Chicken.
author: Edward P.

description: growing up in the Richmond I knew this has been the go to spot for cheap dim sum but when the hell did the hype spread?!  wow line is horrible on the weekend. ordered $100 worth of food a week ago to pick up today and still waited 30 mins. friendly staff until you ask for the sweet soy sauce to go. flipping a switch on the concept of bringing soy sauce to go...damnnnn. also heard there's a change in ownership lately. hope that doesn't mean nickel and diming their customers now...
author: M T.

description:
This place is totally hole in the wall. An entire array of dim sum items behind a glass counter and two ladies movin' things along. I didn't expect that the dim sum would be good, but the chicken buns were right out of the oven and warm and surprisingly good. The dough was slightly sweet and light, the chicken dumpling thing inside was slightly slimy and grey in color but it was really tasty (found out later there were mushrooms which made it grey). 

Great for take out 4 buns for under $4 great grab and go lunch
author: sophie p.

description: Co-Workers from a former employer would special order from this place and have me pick up early in the morning, since I use to live close by.  It's good and cheap.
author: Demanding T.

description: I have been there 3 times every time I go they are so rude to me not sure why. I am just ordering. Not sure if it's the language barrier. They are also not as good as they used to be what I bought hardly had meat and they where cold and they made my stomach hurt, right away. They are also more expensive than they where lady year. I went there 45 min before they closed so that could of been a factor of them being cold ..etc, either way that doesn't change the rudeness.
author: Bianca S.

description: Long line, especially on the weekends - no parking, unless you're lucky - customer service not all that great - cash only ... but well worth it for cheap and good dim sum.  Take out recommended.
author: Mare R.

description: Best dim sum????  Well, it's good, but is way way overrated... I will not say MUST HAVE.....  Cheap???? Nah.... Market price for this kind of store....  Worth to stand in line for more than 15 mins?  No way Jose....  There are a few within 5-10 mins walking distance....
author: P. C.

description: Long line that's hit and miss.  No frills take out or dine in.  Self service seating for 20.  Recommend spare ribs rice if you can get it, not too much goopee stuff in Their ingredients.
author: Clay W.

description: Thanks to yelp & my baby niece- Jeanne C.  Found this 'hole in the wall' type of carry out place. On the way home from vacationing in Seattle & 2 stops in San Francisco. Food was tasty, price is excellent. $28 / 4 people. From the outside, I would probably gone inside but w the great reviews, we decided to go a little out of our way for it. This will always be our 'go to place for dim sum' whenever in SF now.
author: PY P.

description: Love the dim sum shrimp dumplings, steamed buns, Sui Mai,pot stickers And their secrete sweet soy sauce, my mouth waters just thinking about it. only bad, their people skills blow, they act like you have to take their attitude and when you ask for a to go box, they make a huge deal of it, after all it's not like they are docking their pay for it..I live across town and don't need to go out of my way to get crapy service.
author: Poo B.

description: I really, honestly, don't understand why everyone's crazy about this place. Perhaps I have really high standard for Dim Sum. Okay, so the food is cheap, but to be honest I don't think it's that great. It tastes like any other dim sum place on Clement. They really don't have that much variety in my opinion. Does it really worth the wait? I usually come here on weekends morning/brunch time and the wait is CRAZY! at least 30 mins wait. Not the cleanest restaurant, but I don't expect much from a cheap, to-go place. Also, very typical Chinese restaurant services, i.e. rude/ no service. And yes, it does help if you speak Cantonese because they understand you better.. but at the same time, sometimes I wish I don't understand what they are saying in Chinese......
author: Doris H.

description: Good luck in the bathroom. Good luck keeping it down. Good luck tummy. Good luck Dim Sum! Cheap food and a great variety, but with the extra choices in food came some bad decisions on our part. I would pass on the crepes, steamed croissants, salty pork wrapped in leaves, and coconut peanut butter dessert next time. (We ordered too much because other items were pretty good) If you are curious about an item try it because just about everything on the menu is under $2. Super Cheap!
author: Willie M.

description:
My friend and I went to Good Luck Dim Sum for the first time today and got take-out for two. We got egg rolls, steamed BBQ pork buns, pork pot stickers, vegetable and pork buns, and pork dumplings. It was all delicious! I highly recommend this place. We were well fed for under $5!

But...the service is horrible!!! The woman behind the counter was so rude and we felt the need to get out fast. If she had been more patient and friendly we would have stayed and gotten more food. We were the only people in the place but it was clear that she did not want us there. I don't expect a warm welcome from most places on Clement St. but she was cold and mean. She only smiled after we dropped a tip in the tip jar.

Good Luck Dim Sum is awesome for food but the service is very, very poor. I'll try it again and post an update.
author: Erica G.

description:
Chive and shrimp dumpling, shrimp gao, pork siu mai, potsticker and a steamed bbq pork bun for $3.10 YUM

I like the Wing Lee Bakery up the street, too, but dim sum at Good Luck seems less greasy to me.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is one of those places that you hear about through word of mouth. It's one of those places where you would be fortunate to know about it if you grew up in the city (specifically in the Richmond District). It is the quintessential hole-in-the-wall place that you have to know about.

GLDS is on Clement, surrounded by many other asian food offerings.. let alone many dim sum options. It's storefront looks like any other. But there is a reason that this place always has lots of business.

They have some of the cheapest, best-tasting dim sum that SF has to offer. And because they have so much turnover throughout the day, their stuff always seems to be fresh. The atmosphere and seating are nothing to write home about. In fact, most people take their goodies to go. I recommend taking it to GG Park on a nice day.

A bit of advice: When you walk in, there are pink menus near the front. Take that and a pen and decide what you want. Write it on the pink menu (by circling the item and indicating the number of sets you want). This speeds up the process.

Another bit of advice: You can also call in orders for pick-up. You won't have to wait in line and you can be in and out of there.
author: Pete C.

description: Very long lines, I guess if you don't like sitting at a dim sum restaurant then this is the place to be.  We always order the sparerib rice and drench it with their sweet soy sauce
author: Helen L.

description:
The best take out dim sum in San Francisco.

Outstanding cheap eats at a value price.  Shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, potstickers, taro cakes and pork buns are HUGE... and flavorful....

I would rather go take out here than to sit down and pay twice the price for average dim sum at a restaurant.

On weekends, lines are loooooooong!!
author: Raider J.

description:
I'm a little shocked by the overwhelming "best dim sum in SF" types of reviews. 

It was ok, nothing spectacular and I think there's better dim sum to be found in the city. 

The shrimp har gow was a gloppy mess filled with flavorless meat that was heavier on the pork than shrimp. 

What I think was a pork bun was very flavorful, chock full of ginger and scallions. 

Then there was this rice ball-like item that consisted of sticky rice with lots of treasures. 

There are definitely hits and misses, but overall not my best dim sum experience.
author: Lee H.

description:
Now I know why they call it Good Luck Dim Sum.
Good luck getting hot food: Most of it is served COLD.
Good luck getting friendly service: these people are just plain RUDE!
Good luck getting what you order unless you point to it.
The prices went up, the portions are smaller.
Do yourself a favor and go to Wing Lee or one of the many other places down the street.
author: Richard M.

description:
When I arrived at San Francisco 3 years ago, I went to a journey to find the best dim sum place in San Francisco. At that time, I knew there's a big population of Chinese in the area so I assumed the dim sum should be wonderful.

Three years later, I still think Good Luck Dim Sum is great. Not only because it's cheap. No. I don't review it based on the price. The taste is also great. I especially like their shrimp dumpling. You may go to a pricier dim sum restaurant and find out if it's only a waste of money because here, not only that you can get it cheaper but also less time to wait.

After all, yes, this is cheap if you ask me.
author: Cliff T.

description:
Finally I had some halfway decent Dim Sum in San Francisco!

This is sort of fast food style dim sum with a few tables and counter ordering. Like any cheap, hole in the wall Inner Richmond establishment there are no frills. You will not be greeted by imitation statues from epic periods of Chinese History or zirconia-encrusted lucky cats. Hell, the people taking your order don't even use a calculator to total up your bill. That's how you know it's authentic. Hard-core.

Between my group we practically ordered everything. In fact, instead of circling what we did want, we should have just circled the entire menu. The food ranged from really good to decent, but nothing disappointed. The chicken feet were huge and must have been from the KFC farms. Mm, growth hormones. Anything with pork was particularly good (spareribs!), as were the shrimp filled ones.

I suppose it was a sign when we looked in the back of the store and saw huge vats of lard. The food was so deliciously greasy that I wished I had some hot tea to control it. Nevertheless, after I got over my grease bubble I had a very satisfied stomach.

Get some goodies to go and you won't be disappointed. I just hope you have a hearty stomach.
author: Ryan V.

description:
100th review -- both for me and for Good Luck Dim Sum. How lucky. =D

I've lived in SF for nearly a dozen years in the Inner Richmond, and I've probably been to Good Luck Dim Sum more than any establishment in Northern California. How is Good Luck different than the dozens of take-out dim sum joints on Clement? Why is Good Luck my unquestionable SF take-out dim summery of choice?

Three words: "Char Siu Bao" -- their steamed barbecue pork buns.

Scientifically speaking, pork buns are the true measure of dim summery. Try a dozen different Chinese buns, and you might find buns like these:

#1. Buns hard as rocks!
#2. Buns too tough to chew!
#3. Squishy, soggy buns!
#4. Meatless buns!
#5. Fowl buns!
#6. Misshapen buns!
#7. Grotesquely huge buns!
#8. Tiny buns!
#9. Waaay overpriced buns!
#10. Tasteless buns!
#11. Cold, frigid buns!
 
And then you try Good Luck's #12. Mmmmm, nummy, perfect buns!

NICE BUNS! -- FIVE STARS!

Okay, okay, silliness aside, they're also pretty hot buns.

=D

In ten years, the price has gone from $1.10 for three, to $1.50 for three. Now that's just amazing.

Beware, bun-lovers: the lines here are insane. There are lines at eight in the morning. Saturday at noon, you're easily looking at a half hour to 45-minute wait for take-out dim sum.

Now here's the trick! If you've got a large order, you can call in advance and say, "I'd like your hot buns tomorrow at noon," and when you show up, your buns will be waiting. Skip the line, while everyone else gives you dirty looks. Now this is where you pay, open up one of Good Luck's hot pink boxes and enjoy a sample of one of your hot buns in front of everyone...

I'll leave you with some favorites:
- the Rice Porridge is great for breakfast and dirty cheap at a buck and change.
- Chive Dumplings are an undiscovered squishy culinary treasure, seriously.
- I've yet to find any restaurant that serves crispier Chinese Egg Rolls.
- And if your mouth still craves some fun, grab a handful of Good Luck's Sweet Rice Buns. =)
author: Perci N.

description:
Ridiculous.

How else do you describe a SF restaurant selling really tasty Dim Sum in huge quantities for a few dollars?  OK, it barely qualifies as a restaurant, it's more of a take-out/diner kind of place.

Five of us ate there on a Saturday morning - and I mean ATE - for $32.  We had a half dozen pieces left to take home with us after that, too.

We parked on the street a block away with no trouble.

The order line was longer than normal (according to a local I was behind) and it does move slowly.  But it was worth it.  I think we were ordering 30 mins after we stepped in line.  If you know what you like, you could call in your order and it'll be waiting for you.

We tried some of everything except the chicken feet and porridge.  Been there, not a fan.  The shumai, the pot stickers, the steamed buns, the custards, the egg rolls, steamed dumplings, the sticky rice and chicken, the Chinese long donuts... are ALL very good.  

Did I mention it's cheap??
author: Don G.

description:
My favorite Dim Sum place... unpretentious and dirt cheap, with excellent food... what more is there to ask?

Totally lost among all the other chinese restaurants around, you really have to know it's good to get in there because, well, it looks small and not fancy.
But if it's the price to pay to get that good a dim sum, let's make all restaurants crappy looking!

The super bad service by old chinese ladies half screaming at you goes so well with the rest that I find it hilarious, and I love it!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
(all dialogue in mandarin)

ME: my friend wants the steamed shrimp dumplings, not the fried kind.

OAL (aka old asian lady working the counter): we don't have fried shrimp dumplings!

ME: yes you do. right here. we want those other there.

OAL: why didn't you SAY you wanted THOSE?!??

ME: i just told you. 

OAL: *mutters something to herself in cantonese* 

OAL: I KNOW. I HEARD YOU. $3.40. 

OAL: next time, BE MORE CLEAR. DON'T WASTE TIME. I HAVE MANY CUSTOMERS. SEE THE LINE?!? OK???

ME: umm, ok. thank you, auntie! 

*sigh* 

(decent take-out dim sum and it's the best on clement street, but certainly not best take-out dim sum in the bay area)
author: May T.

description: Get there in the morning!  The turnip cake and shrimp and chive dumpling are so tasty.
author: Heather R.

description:
The best dim sum I've had at these prices, and with a few fairly simple improvements, I'd give Good Luck 5 stars.

The dim sum here is delicious and fresh, and they have a pretty good selection.  The freshness of the ingredients (important for dim sum) is especially impressive.  The in-house seating leaves a little to be desired, I'd only eat there in a pinch and recommend viewing this place as more of a takeout place.  At first the table area seems fine, but then you realize it's self-serve, hard to get even a glass of water to go with your meal, and the dim sum line often extends chaotically into the seating area.  There's usually a long line here, and the serving crew tends to be a little grumpy if you don't order according to some cryptic system they've devised.  Kind of like the Seinfeld Soup Nazi in that respect.  

However, the dim sum here is so great for the price, it overpowers Good Luck's shortcomings.  It's that good.  Also worth noting is much of it is freezable, so you can buy a bunch of your favs here at one time, freeze it and microwave it later, and its probably still cheaper than the store-bought cardboard imitators.
author: Jack H.

description:
We went out to get the food for camping/hiking on this weekend coming up. So this dim sum place was close enough for us to grab something light and easy to eat. 

We got shrimp dumplings, egg custard bun, and stew pork something and one soda just $10 for two of us. It was cheap but decent food. I tried some other quick/togo Dim Sum places around this area as well, i'd say this is the best so far. 

When i ate shrimp dumplings,  can you believe it ? 3 dim sum for just $ 1.50 and yes i tasted the shrimps. I wish i could give a half star like 3.5 stars to this place but this one just lost my half cuz when we asked  for not taking all the stew pork ( a whole to go box ) but instead we just needed only half, the Chinese lady wasn't happy though but i wasn't surprised cuz this food is cheap.

I don't mind enjoying my fast-fast dim sum service.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: Great value for fast takeout. We liked BBQ pork buns, turnip cakes, fried donuts, egg custards. Sticky rice + chicken wrapped in lotus leaves were a tad too sweet. Also a bit disappointed by the hot tea option - it was just a Lipton tea bag in a paper cup. This is a good place to pick up one or two items when you crave dim sum. The dishes are not of high quality. If you're looking for a fine, complete dim sum experience, go else where.
author: C W.

description:
I know it's a hole in the wall, but their dim sum is excellent.  So what if you miss out on the big round tables and the parade of waitresses pushing their carts like an assembly line.  

My husband thinks dim sum is bizarre. I guess it would translate to a procession of Stepford Wives carrying trays of toothpick-impaled weenie dogs to me.  Anyway, he thinks getting bits and pieces of appetizer and eating them while the regular meal never arrives.  He could deal with buying it all at once much better.

I admit, waiting in line is a drag -- worse than waiting in line at See's Candy's where there's always a couple of people ahead of you who want to pick their box of candy piece by piece.

BUT the dim sum is great and cheap.  I made a quick stop after a doctor's appointment and eat some deep fried stuffed dumplings (3 for $1.45)  shrimp dumplings (3 for $1.55), and chive dumplings with shrimp (3 for $1.55).  Then, I got 6 sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves (thems the big 'uns for $1.80) and salted pork wrapped in bamboo leaves ($1.90) for my lunches.

Great food for cheap!  They have just about everything you could want in terms of dim sum without paying a lot and going hungry still.

So that you guys know what a deal it is... I'm typing out the prices... it would be cool if other people compiled other dim sum lists too!
___________________________________________________

3 for $1.45
fried sesame ball
deep fried stuffed dumpling
egg roll
deep fried taro root
flower roll
crisp white sugar cake
___________________________________________________

3 for $1.55
shrimp dumpling 
shrimp taro dumpling
steamed pork dumpling
pork siu mai
fun kor
malay cake
beef siu mai
turnip cake
steam bbq pork bun
shark fin dumpling
chicken siu mai
vegetable pork bun
pot sticker
crystal dumpling
chive dumpling with shrimp
chicken bun
___________________________________________________

each $0.65
custard
sweet rice bun
sweet rice puff with coconut, peanut
chinese chive dumpling
lotus seed bun
lucky ball
sausage rolls
egg yolk bun
___________________________________________________

dry shrimp crepe $0.80
porridge $1.80
salted pork wrapped in bamboo leaves $1.90
chicken feet $3.50/lb
mushroom chow mein $1.80/lb
black bean sauce sparerib rice $2.30/lb
spareribs with black bean sauce $3.80/lb
bake bbq pork bun $0.85
sweet rice chicken wrapped in lotus leaves $1.80
chicken and sausage rice $2.30
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I think this was the place Seinfeld used as his inspiration for the "soup nazi" sketch.  The Dim Sum is GREAT!!!!
The service is well.....less then polite.....outright RUDE!  The food makes up for a the lack in personality and manners.   Will I go back? YES!
But me no speaky no Engrish next time!
author: Patrick F.

description:
My friends think I am very American.  I only roll out the Cantonese for serious dim sum ordering.

So, you have heard all the other 400+ reviews about this place.  Super cheap, very good, and then there's the DIM SUM NAZI (DSN).

I actually can translate the interaction between the DSN and customers.  So, for all you people out there that weren't sure if she was totally rude or not, this is the one interaction that had me a bit scared to order incorrectly.

little old lady(l.o.l)- pointing at case- "i want these cakes"
dsn- "i don't see cakes"
l.o.l- "these cakes"  she is pointing at the egg tarts again
dsn loud and impatient- "no cakes.  those are tarts, not cakes. do you want TARTS?"
l.o.l- i want 10 cakes
dsn- rolling eyes and sighing- grabs the tarts

of course, we are served by the DSN.
i asked if we had ordered a certain item, and she barked back- yes!!

it is a certain kind of gluttony to see all your dim sum for four hungry people on one tray.  it's not so obvious when you order off the carts and the empty little bamboo steamers disappear.

surprises:  siu mai & potsticker - rubbery heavy balls of meat
the fried frizzy taro balls were a dream- best i have ever had
the jook was amazing- so creamy and the only thing that was super hot!! (A+++)
chai sui bao- fluffy and sweet

this really is a take out place- i would recommend taking items home and re-steaming them traditionally for best flavor- no microwaves! 

boo- we got a $54 parking ticket- san fran- it was labor day!!
author: E T.

description:
I was fortunate to hit up Good Luck Dim Sum bright and early on a Sunday morning, witnessing the mad rush to get one's hands on the super fresh dim sum. I had never been here before, so I was unaccustomed to the procedure of figuring out what you want beore you order, circling the desired items on a menu. My inexperience became quite evident when the person working there started to box up an ungodly amount of food...I guess that when it says "3 for $0.XX," that means for every item you circle, you get three of that for the price shown.  Whoops! The line was quite long, so we didn't bother to downsize our order...nevertheless, we ended up with a large box full of dim sum goodies for around $10. Nuts!

It's not the most amazing dim sum ever, but it was tasty enough given the rock bottom prices. I liked the various shrimp dumplings (plain shrimp and the shrimp and chive), though the wrappers on the dumplings were  quite heavy and kept falling apart. The fried taro ball was tasty, with ground pork inside. Steamed BBQ pork buns were alright, neither impressive nor offensive. Turnip cakes, ehhh, too dry, I guess. Egg custard tarts...wow, so wonderful and custardy fresh! Then there were the sweet rice balls with coconut and peanut filling...GET THIS!  It's like a snowball of sweet, crunchy, flaky love. Definitely the highlight for me!

GLDS is a hit and run type of place, so don't expect restaurant service or fancy digs. There does appear to be some order in the madness, so pay attention to what other people are doing and keep your eye on the fresh stuff that comes out. Despite the chaotic atmosphere, the food is cheap and decent. No wonder Good Luck Dim Sum is a neighborhood favorite for many Yelpers. I just might be back if I'm craving dim sum and can't wait til the next Yelp Dim Sum event!
author: Steph P.

description:
$9 for dim sum for 3 people. No, not $9 per person, $9 TOTAL! Sure, this might not be the norm, but you'll definitely be more than satisfied for less than $5 per person. This is not a place where carts come to your table. It's a get in a really long line and order type of place. The ladies here can get a bit impatient with you once you're ordering, so figure out what you want while you're waiting in line. Otherwise, NO DIM SUM FOR YOU!

We had bbq pork buns, har-gow, shu-mai, lotus seed buns, shark fin dumplings, and 1lb of mushroom chow mein, which we found out could only be ordered by the pound. Not half, not quarter. It was only $1.80 anyways. I also got some Vita mango boxed juice. All this for $9. Mind-boggling.

I know why this place is called Good Luck Dim Sum. Good Luck finding no line to order here. And Good Luck not over ordering because everything is so cheap.
author: Connie C.

description: I rated his place 5 star strictly only because of their steamed and baked pork buns are to die for and really inexpensive! great place to run in a grab a dozen fresh made pork buns... Not a place to dine in my opinion...but wonderful to pickup and bring home. My 2 year daughter loves them!
author: Kandice S.

description: My girlfriend and me were obsessed with this place. We always ordered bunch of stuffs which we barely end up finish all of them. Writing a review for this place reminding me of the time when me and my best girlfriend came here. Since we both now are busy and have different lives. We rarely hang out. But i hope in a near future we will make up our time and come to this place again. :)
author: Helen M.

description:
Amazingly fresh dim sum. And cheap too! I decided to swing by here Sunday morning and was rewarded with the freshest, largest potstickers I've ever tasted. Plus, the siu mye was great. I'm not a big fan of pork and chicken buns, but these ones are about as good as you can get.

People have complained about the service, but they don't come much whiter than me, and I was (a) able to figure out how to order, and (b) served without attitude. Next time I'll bring my own pen, but how hard is it to fill out a ticket and hand it to a lady? I'll also order more of the shrimp dumplings. I only ordered one to taste it, and I wish I had ordered more.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Our friends had friends in town, and to be truthful, we had stayed out late, very late, for several nights in a row.  With a group of 8 or so, we hit up Good Luck Dim Sum, knowing that its greasy goodness would be an excellent hangover cure.

Oh, how I love dim sum...  fried sesame balls, pork buns, shrimp dumplings, pot stickers...  I eat them all with relish.  We had a few squeamish folks in the group, so I ordered with reckless abandon to make sure everyone got something they liked.

Now we all know that dim sum is best fresh and hot, and at 11 a.m. Good Luck Dim Sum did not disappoint.  Not only did everyone have a fab time (eating family style is the best), but our bill came out to $10 each, including the tip.

Hair of the dog?  Gimme sum dim sum!
author: Nicole G.

description:
I used to live on 8th Avenue in the Richmond District, and Saturday mornings usually started with a stroll down to Clement Street for some cheap dim sum grub at this place. Think soup nazi with chinese women. This is not a place to get a tutorial on all things dim sum. Here's a "how to" for a pleasant and seamless dim sum experience: 

1. Grab one of those pink slips of paper and a pencil, and circle which ones you want and indicate how many of each. 
2. Once you're at the front of the line, politely hand it over to the next available woman. 
3. Pay in cash only. Be prepared to fork over $3 if not $4 dollars. 

$5 is an obscene amount of dim sum for one person. You're likely to spend around $3.50. I gave myself a food coma off $4 once. Never again. There's only so much har gow one can consume before it starts to hurt.
author: Marie M.

description:
In my quest for the perfect dim sum in the Bay Area, I've tried all the obvious options, like Canton, Koi Palace, Ton Kiang, etc. When I saw all the reviews for Good Luck Dim Sum on Yelp, I had to see what all the fuss was about.

I stopped in this Saturday, around 10:30 in the morning; the line was sizable but not as bad as when I left about an hour later. Be prepared to wait or go early, first bit of advice. You order at the counter, so it's not like the typical dim sum experience with trays and table service.

The menu is simple enough, and you can also watch what they are bringing out that is piping hot and order that. Hard to go wrong here, and the prices are so unbelievably cheap I question how they stay in business. I'm talking eating for two people, fully stuffed, for easily under $20.

Some of the better items we sampled included the Chive Dumplng, the Shrimp Dumpling,  the Pork Siu Mai, and the BBQ Pork Bun, but I noticed a bunch of regulars ordering the porridge... hmm...

After you're done, walk around the Clement Neighborhood, you'll need to digest.
author: Nish N.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum is pretty tasty for a take out dim sum place that is just so soo cheap so if you're on a budget. Go here, buy some for your friends and they'll think you're pretty awesome!

Before I moved to SF, I'd go here and buy all sorts of baos and dumplings for the road, and then fall into a deep dark MSG coma at my friend's apartment.  I do really like dim sum, but it's just so heavy sometimes, thus reserved for the weekends and days of random gluttonous shambles.  

My only gripe is... for some reason, I think the women who work behind the counter always seem really pissed off, and that puts me off a little bit. Also once I ate some plastic in my dumpling and that scared me a little bit.  However, being that it's so cheap and beats lots of places in Chinatown. I'll give it a 4 stars and run by there for fast dim sum the next time I'm on Clement again. 

Oh if you sit there and eat, their soy sauce is really really thick and unappetizing. Bring your own bottle of soy or take your items home. EEK!
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
There is ALWAYS a long line here!!!!! Never do I walk pass it and the ladies behind the counter are just standing there, NEVER! There are times when I just wanna get some cheap dim sum, sit down, and eat. This is the place, after a "little" wait...

Everything here is delicious and big. Just the way I like it. Siu mai, har gow, (the two typical dim sum items), Baked BBQ Pork bun, sweet rice cake.. Almost everything I've had here is great.

Parking is a bitch... Come on, it's Clement! Thank goodness I live a couple blocks away so I could just walk here..
author: Juliane N.

description: This is the best take out dim sum place I've had in SF.  There are a LOT of nasty ones.  It's not perfect but for the price, it is awesome.  Get in, get out, get stuffed with dim sum.
author: Erika C.

description:
This is by far the best take out Dim Sum ive had in a long time.  The shrimp dumpling and the chive dumpling both had really good skins, nice and chewy, not too thick.  I hate it when those dumplings skins are too thick, because then they are usually too soggy or hard.  the pork dumpling was nice and hot and had shrimp in it.  Just the right size for all three of those dumplings.  I always think that when a place has dim sum that are big, it just means that they are bad and them make up for it in size.

I also got an order of 'man tao' (plain bun).  Very very good.  Nice and chewy with a hint of saltiness.  

All of that was only $5.90.  I am definitely going to come back... even if that means standing in line for 5 minutes.
author: Janet S.

description:
Food:  D-
Value:  D
Service:  F
Decor:  take out dim sum counter with a few tables
Return Rate:  Never
Best Time To Go:  Never

Upon reviewing Ton Kiang's review, I came across three other yelp reviews and decided to go for a "dim sum run" to all four restaurants.   Since I was only in town for the weekend and in the city for the afternoon, we ordered everything to go and ate in the car.  Don't get me wrong, some meals taste better at the restaurant.  The service, the tea, the carts, etc ... do not change the flavor and the dough of the dim sum.  So, here is the review for the first lap of the run at Good Luck Dim Sum:
 
We only have one life and eating bad dim sum should not be a part of it.  They should call this place "Bad Luck Dim Sum."  If you're homeless or on a college diet, then $1.55 for three pieces of dim sum will take care of the hunger pains.  But, I'd rather eat Top Ramen at 10 cents a bag.  Once you've had good dim sum, you cannot go back. 

Here is what we ordered:

* BAKED BBQ PORK BUNS:  D

* STEAMED PORK & VEGETABLE BUNS:  F (too doughy)

* HAR GOW:  D

* BEEF SIU MAI: F (bad aftertaste)

* SHRIMP AND CHIVES:  D- (too much chives and not enough shrimps)

For lap two, please read the review for Golden River Restaurant.
author: Susan H.

description:
Spareribs over rice for $2.30!
Congee with pork and preserved egg for $1.80! 

There was a line at 9:30 am already! The layout reminded me a lot of You's Dim Sum in Chinatown. They have a lot of dim sum and all the baos you can think of. If you don't want to wait in line for dim sum in a restaurant come here instead. Every dim sum you can think of is under $2 per order. Restaurants are at least $2.50 for small orders. So save some time and money and come to Good luck dim sum!
author: Tracy A.

description:
i love good luck dimsum because it's SO cheap but still so yummy :)

i normally get their chicken siu mai, potstickers, sticky rice in lotus leaf, and baked bbq bun. all are pretty good! easy on the hot sauce though, super spicy! (even though it's just sriracha).

the sui mai and potstickers are 3 for 1.60 i think. and the rice and bun are 85 cents each?

BEWARE OF THE WORKERS THOUGH! they can be super grumpy if you don't order efficiently. it's best to pick up one of their pink papers and fill em out before hand so you can order as quickly as possible!
author: Bianca W.

description: Really? 4 stars? I also see this place being recommended in many travel websites. I wonder why. I live around the neighbourhood and wouldn't bother going other than the day that I wake up early and other dim sum places around are still closed. Sure it's cheap, but the food quality is also pretty low. Their dim sum is alright-ish if you buy it right at the time they open and eat it right away. Otherwise, ugh.
author: Bobo V.

description:
File Good Luck Dim Sum under all-you-can-eat buffet, that's how delish and cheap it is.  I gotta feeling it's not my little secret w over a hundred reviews up (damn u people), but I still gotta give em props.

It's a to-go place for sure.  They yammer at me in Chinese, impatiently and repeatedly ask "what else," but I've been there enough times... I'm Teflon baby!  I'ma git wot I want and I'ma take my damn sweet time ya heah?  No buck ten broad w tongs is bullying me around... not again... anyway...
author: Gilberto Y.

description: This place can be a little scary the 1st time there....long ass line, hella cramped, loud, semi-slippery floor, English 2nd language...BUT DAMN, they're good!!  I got a whole lotta dim sum for like $12.  It's a good deal and the dim sum is good quality.  There's definitely a few similar spots in this area but these guys are legit.   The length of the line and it's diversity should be a good clue.  I had 8 people in front of me and waited about 15 min...iPhone quality time!  The menu is pretty standard.  The stand outs for me was the shrimp dumplings and the taro!!
author: Ramon L.

description: Great dim sum, probably the best on the Clement St strip.  Shrimp dim sum are particularly delicious!  Cheap - $1.80 for 3 dumplings.
author: Pig E.

description:
Forget about the service, decor or ambiance - this place is all about the food and value for money. OK - this is not the best dim sum I've eaten by a long shot (the best is in Sydney!!) ....... but if you can ignore the non-existent service and bare-bones decor - and just weigh up the quality/quantity of food against the very reasonable $ you fork out - this place deserves four stars.

Here's my advice for the totally uninitiated:
- Treat the ladies at the counter with the same indifference as they treat you (believe me, they'll respect you more for it.... don't waste your energy trying to butter 'em up)
- Pick up one of the order forms sitting on the counter, get in line and use that time to mark down what you want and how many ..... don't wait to get to the front of the line and 'ummmm' and 'ahhhh' while deciding on your order.... the ladies at the counter will shred you to pieces and devour every second of your obvious discomfort. If you hand over a completed order form, then you give them less of a chance of ridiculing you!
- Avoid the law-mai-gai (chicken rice wrapped in lotus leaf) - it's hard, flavorless and skimps on the filling. Definitely stick to the steamed dumplings, pork/chicken buns and desserts - all are pretty excellent for the prices they charge.

Good luck getting your dim sum!
author: Melissa S.

description: Really 3.5 stars and the paper and pen idea is great.  Thinner dough adn more stuffing and overall good.
author: R C.

description:
cheap dim sum but not at the expense of the taste!

I ordered the shu mai, har gow, and nay hwang bao. 

their soy sauce is very interesting, its thick and sweet, not like regular soy sauce where its liquidy and salty. But it definitely complements their dim sum VERy well! thumbs up!

i enjoyed their shu mai and har gow, there wans't any odd ingredients added (i once had corn added to my shu mai at another restaurant O_o). it tastes great with or without the yummy soy sauce

The nay hwang bao was not too sweet! it was a good portion too. the egg yolk was not crumbly and not overly sweet. 

Though i found a placard on their wall, stating that they received 5 stars in 2008 by YELP. and this is the first time i seen such placards! I'm not sure if  it was legit or not .. but either way, it deserves at least 4 stars by me!
author: Linda L.

description:
WTF!

I could not believe the crap I ate at this "restaurant." I had to do a double take on my out to make sure I just ate at Good Luck Dim Sum. I've heard/read nothing but good things about this place (SF Chronicle Top 100 Bargain Bites) but what a DISAPPOINTMENT.

In reading some of the other Yelp reviews, here are a few things that I might have done wrong:

1. Ate at the restaurant. All the food was cold despite spending a brief stint in the microwave prior to reaching our table. Everything had lost that nice crispy fried-ness and lukewarm grade D mystery meat is not good. Lesson: take to go and heat in your own microwave.
2. Ordered the pork shu mai, shrimp dumplings, taro cake, sausage roll, pork spareribs. These pass only the baseline grade for dim sum for the reasons above and because they lacked any freshness and flavor. 
3. Went on a Sunday afternoon. I tried to order char siu bao (BBQ pork buns) - my staple dim sum choice and my favorite. They were OUT!! Again, WTF.

One saving grace, the chive cakes were decently crispy on the outside and had a pretty good flavor.

Folks - save your money and go to Chinatown (not the ultra-touristy parts) or even elsewhere on Clement. Or even spend a little more money and reacquaint yourself with what fresh & quality dim sum tastes like (Koi Palace, Yank Sing , Ton Kiang).
author: Carolyn F.

description:
Oh thank g that they've reopened! And so quickly. I missed it so much! I needed to have my cheap (but really good) jook fix! 

As far as I can tell they repainted the dining area, got new tables and chairs, a new display case right next to the steam table and that's all I can see. I'm sure they had to do something for the kitchen as that's where the fire or smoke damage was the worst. I wonder if they hired someone to high pressure clean the bathroom? 

Also I think that whoever did their building inspection before they reopened told them that they couldn't pile all the dim sum boxes that close to the door making it really cramped in the entryway. Which is cool as it feels like you don't have to elbow your way past a grandma or two.
author: cyndi L.

description: I BEG THE DIFFER ON ALL OF YOUR OPINIONS! Cheap, not any longer. But let me tell you why I will NEVER set foot in the place again. I have never been treat as such by any establishment. My wife & I walked in & 2 of the  servers where setting up. The younger of the two was just a worker, I believe the older lady with the deep voice is owner & operator. Man, did she have a bad night or what? I know in the PAST I didn't go there because of her Charming personality. This morning was absolutely the epitome of this lady. Sorry, they were relatively cheap to eat & I feel for the slave workers she commands. I guess I'm not SFMTA, who she treats like her brother, but then again who knows how she would treat him. Maybe the sfmta guy is taking care of her TICKETS! Now for the explanation of why I won't patronize them! She asks What do you want, instead of saying, Good Morning, What would you like. It's not that hard. She asked my wife who is fluent in Cantonese if we wanted the crispy won ton skin in the congee, my wife didn't quite hear hear raspy voice & asked her what she said  & with her SARCASTIC ASS VOICE ASKED i SAID DO YOU WANT THE WON TON SKIN. My wife said yeas & onions in one of them, then asked her one pork bun & she grabbed one with her tongs & slammed it down onto the plate & it bounced off the plate onto the steamers that steam the har gows & shui mais. It was then I said "DON'T TREAT US LIKE THAT IN ENGLISH & SHE HAD THE AUDACITY TO YELL BACK AT ME TELLING ME NOT TO YELL AT HER IN ENGLISH. I SAID FORGET IT, WE DON'T WANT YOUR GARBAGE & WALKED OUT. HER SLIPS OF PAPERS AREN'T FOR CONVENIENCE, IT'S BECAUSE THEY CAN'T DEAL WITH PEOPLE! For all you out of towners who go there to buy your Dim Sum, save yourselves some aggravation, they are not the best nor cheapest. I suggest a place Mong Kok over on Noriega & 32nd ( google them) they are much nicer & their stuff is beyond GLDS.
