This GLDS charges for everything including the box, you shouldn't have to pay for when you buy something, what a rip off!  Caveat Emptor
author: david c.

description:
Okay, so the line is long and slow since everyone is ordering 2 dozens of BBQ buns takeout, and seeing the dim sum strolling through just made me hungrier, especially after some 'workout' at the church.

And for $1.50 for 3 pieces of dim sum, I just cannot imagine how these people make a living. So the dim sum were so so other than they  were pretty big. We also had the congee and it's the only thing that was so hot that it burned my tongue. 

Cost wise, for less than 9 dollars, two people, totally stuffed! Now I really feel ripped off by some of the upscale and expensive restaurants that I have been to...
author: T L.

description:
My cousin picked up a styrofoam container full of dim sum for my party.  Pork buns, shu mai, and dumplings of some sort.  The pork buns were the best.  Even though he bought them at the end of the day just as they were closing they still tasted good.

I love pork buns.  Soft chewy bread and sweet and salty pork stuff inside.  Super cheap and super yummy and apparently all their dim sum is good luck.  I can only attest to the fact that they ARE because my party was a hit and though the last half of the night was a drunken haze I remember the shu mai and the pork buns vividly.
author: Jay H.

description:
I've been going here for 10 years, and it's been declining steadily and now has reached its nadir. I went today, and they served us cold dumplings, cold egg rolls, cold fried shrimp. Every table in the place was filthy with rings of chili sauce, spilled tea, remnants of food. They never did get around to cleaning the tables, even after we pointed out there weren't any clean ones. Resigned to our dirty table, we asked for some soy sauce, and they gave us teriyaki sauce. They knew it was teriyaki sauce, but thought we might not notice? Nothing was edible, it was claggy and gelatinous and, well, like cold grease. It was, frankly, disgusting.  If I could give it no stars, I would. 

I have been going there out of habit,  but now I won't be going back. I'm on the hunt for some better all day dim sum.
author: Caterina F.

description:
Perhaps I was there on a off day!

In agreement, the food is cheep-cheep. No frills, pretty standard fare. 

I ordered a few different things, but didn't end up eating much of it. The temperature just ruined it for me. The food was cold, not room temp, or kinda warm. The shrimp was crunchy, the pork filling off the steamed bun was gray-ish. So I gave up. It wasn't a huge investment ($4) but it ruined my appetite. I was sure I was going to become violently ill. Thankfully that didn't happen. I was so pissed at myself for not going to Ocean....or the other place on the corner.
author: Ahna P.

description:
I have been coming here since I was in college at USF.  The dim sum is fresh and cheap as hell!  The Sui Mais are off da hook as are the ha gaw and the bucci balls (sesame balls).  But he best bang for the buck is the sausage, chicken and bock choy over rice bowl.  The lines are off the hook on the weekends but worth the wait. get there early!

This place is great to buy in bulk for party appetizers!
author: A P.

description: They rock the house with their dim sum. I love their beef siu mai. It is so delicious! Anyhow, you have to prepare yourself with a long line. You can wait for 35 minutes at times. Unbelievable, huh? It is worth the wait. They run out of their dim sum very quickly as well. Cheers!
author: Gina Y.

description:
I always say "Good Luck" means good luck getting it fresh, even in the morning, but hey, that's why there are microwaves.  Yes, it used to be a little better but it's still my go to spot for yummy yummy dumplings, especially the chive with their chewy/crispy wrappers and the crystal dumplings.

I do have to say that some of these reviews are good examples of Why Yelp Sucks.  It's a dim sum bakery!  Not an episode of Seinfeld or a romantic little bistro!  At any rate, the ladies have always been nice to *me.*  Although you do eventually have to say "there is no 'and then'!"  or you'll end up with about 20 pounds of dim sum and nowhere to put it.
author: jette s.

description:
A Simple Pleasures Sunday* in San Francisco:

9am Drink a cappuccino at Peet's

10am Park Vespa at the top of Arguello St.

10:05-11:45am Hike to Baker Beach and back

11:55am Drive Vespa to Good Luck Dim Sum 

12:10pm Arrive, order Shrimp dumplings, Chive and scallop dumplings, Pork and vegetable buns. Shell out 5-7 bucks.

12:15pm Sit on the Vespa in the sun, eat.

12:35pm Go home, nap

...............................................

*A Simple Pleasures Sunday won't blow your mind, it'll sneak up on you in the middle of said activities, you'll stop and think about how great it is to live in SF and additionally, you'll return to work Monday morning not feeling like a drone.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Trade service, friendliness and cleanliness for price and you've got Good Luck Dim Sum. It's order at the counter not table service where speaking Madarin will get you far and not speaking it will get your vegetarian pulling shrimp out of his dumpling.

Vegetarians would be wise to bring kind meat eating friends who will taste everything for you which is easy since all orders tend t ocome in threes.  The price can't be beat.  Dim Sum for 3 including 3 sodas totalled $13.40!! My cohort kept insisting I heard it wrong, she must've meant $33.40 but no, in her only smile of the mulitple order encounter, she only wanted $13.40.  

The cheap prices are much appreciated but the bathroom, accessible with a key attached to a disgusting rusty can, makes gas station toilets on the interstate look appealing.
author: Sean S.

description:
I was craving dim sum the second i woke up this morning. There are such good reviews on Good Luck Dim Sum, why not rush down there and get myself a yummy brunch.

I decide to go without showering or anything - throw my hair up in a ponytail and rush down there.

There was a line... but I thought maybe it would go fast. It didn't. But I was already at that point where, I had put in too much commitment, I need to finish this line.

Apparently, (not sure because it's chinese new year) but people were buying VATS of food. They were buying 50 lbs of food to serve 20 people. I ordered my 8 things, and the lady looks at me like I have 2 heads - like what are you doing here. Mind you, I speak Chinese too... 

I had ended up waiting an hour. Getting a parking ticket cuz I had only put in money for a half an hour. And when I got home, I realized one of the things, she had gotten wrong, AND she didn't give me everything I ordered.

The food is OKAY. It is by no means great. But really not worth the wait. Check out some of the other take-out dim sum places in the area instead.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
My favorite dim sum places in the bay area are ton kiang and hong kong east ocean.  But if you want some CHEAP!!!! no non-sense yummy take out dim sum, this is a great stop.

The lines are usually long, but the ladies behind the counter move the orders really quickly.  I'll usually stop in and then buy  2-3 full boxes of dim sum then pick up a lemon or lime at one of the nearby produce stores to make as a dipping sauce combining the soy sauce and lime juice and siracha. I'd then rush home to put the dumplings and baos in bamboo steamers to keep the dim sum warm... make some jasmine tea... then call friends over!  30 bucks worth of dim sum is a nice way to unite 6-7 friends on a sunday brunch if you are not in the mood to wait for a table at a hectic dim sum restaurant and fork over 100+ bucks.  Here's perfect answer to recession!

Good Luck was stumbling across GOOD LUCK DIM SUM while on Clement St.!!!!  yum yum dim sum!!!!
author: Alex D.

description:
Sorry to say, it must have been an inauspicious day when I tried Good Luck Dim Sum, because I ended up standing there for at least 10 minutes just to get some lo mai gai and an order of gao choy gao, (they were out of the combination bao, and the cha shu bao... who the hell runs out of cha shu bao?) all of which was lukewarm, flavorless and completely grease-caked. I was starving, and yet didn't even finish my lo mai gai, it was downright nasty.

Staff seemed to be functioning in some sort of slow-motion total chaos, as they'd sort of move around one another behind the counter, taking bits of pieces of people's orders and yet not really accomplishing much of anything. I'm hardly one to complain about "poor service" in Chinese restaurants where most things are under $1.50 (hell, I gave D&A Cafe 4 stars...) but there's a difference between brusque efficiency and just being dour and discombobulated. Good Luck was most definitely in the latter camp the day I visited.

There's so many good reviews here on Yelp I figure they must do things right at least some of the time, (maybe earlier in the day rather than in the afternoon? maybe 10 years ago?) but when I went it certainly wasn't one of those occasions. Maybe I'll try it again sometime when I'm feeling, er...  luckier?

Until then I think I'll stick to Wing Lee, Alex Bakery or Clement Restaurant.
author: Ian K.

description:
Definitely the best take out dim sum I've had in SF.  Quality almost comparable to some fancy sit-down places.  The shrimp dumplings are flavorful and not packed with a lot of fillers.  The egg custards, particularly when warm, melt in your mouth.

It's my favorite dim sum to bring to work to introduce my colleagues to good dim sum.
author: M Y.

description: reeeally yummy and cheap dimsum! they have really good har gow, spare ribs, sticky rice with chicken, shrimp and chives, siomai and taro puff.. arguably the best dimsum in town!
author: Claudine C.

description:
Chinese restaurants always have such horrible service, but they always make up for it in their quality food.  So with this place, you can just go straight for the food. It is a win win situation. 

I havent eatin at a regular dim sum restaurant in a while because of this place.  The quality miiight be a step down, but hell, you're always dunking things into soy sauce anyhow so no one can tell.  Plus you'll save a ton of money and wont have to wait for your water (that never comes when you need it!)

A good sized meal that'll make two hungry dudes stuffed will cost you no more than 8 bucks. aw gya!
author: Michael N.

description:
Amazing bang for the buck here -- go early though for the tastiest, freshest experience. Toward five PM things start getting noticeably more rubbery.  The ladies can get a tad impatient, but some days it's like being in line at the DMV, so I think they definitely merit some slack.

My favorites are the Crystal Dumplings, the (non-BBQ) steam pork buns and the shrimp dumplings; however there are many tasty things on the menu. I usually try one new thing every time I go - I've had some things that either my palate couldn't handle, or just sucked, but frankly, it's easy to be adventurous at $1.30 per order . . .
author: Karsten P.

description:
You won't get a smile from the server ladies.
 - they'll get fussy if you order too slow
You won't get free water with your order. 
 - you'll get charged for your cup of boiling water
You won't get a clean table.
 - it'll be stained with pepper sauce

If you're lucky, you'll get a ton of good dim sum for less than five dollars. Gluck.
author: Jae K.

description: Please don't go to the Good Luck! Parking on Clement is harrowing and difficult to find not to mention extremely expensive, the dim sum is soooo good and affordable that you'll make it a habit and I'll have to wait even longer on line, running the risk of my forming drool pools that people behind me may slip on, though the longer the line, the even fresher and tastier precious little hearts run out from the kitchen and piled steamy and euphoric when finally I get to the counter and pointing, adding to the list, paying (it always seems that they are undercharging!) and blissfully overindulging.  Again, spare me your presence, though it would add such delectable torment to the antici . . . . . . . pation!
author: Roberto L.

description:
Cheap, fast, no frills dim sum served all day. Yummy. Blocks from my house. Perfect.

On weekends, expect long lines, but the trays of fresh ha gaau (shrimp dumplings) and other treats are carried over almost every two minutes. It's worth the wait, and did I mention it's cheap? The steamed shrimp dumplings with chives are awesome.

I love the pissed-off, I-mean-business-so-hurry-up-and-order women behind the counter. I especially like ordering in my broken ass Cantonese...shocks them to see a Mexican-looking woman ordering and asking questions in Cantonese...ha!
author: Cristy J.

description:
2 Stars: Meh. I've experienced better. 

That's my exact sentiment as I ate the food. With such high reviews, I was pretty excited to try some dim sum in San Francisco. It didn't taste terrible but it didn't really get me excited after I took my first few bites. In order to get a decent sampling (plus I was super hungry), my friend and I ordered pork shumai, chicken shumai, shark fin dumpling, hot steamed pork dumpling, chicken & sausage fried rice, and pork bun. Some of these we got 2 orders. The grand total was only $19.35 which is a great price. But I guess you get what you pay for. 

I've been to about 5 dim sum restaurants in Los Angeles and they are all superior to this one. I guess I owe it to those 5 LA dim sum restaurants to rate them a 4-star now.
author: Kenny A.

description:
I was first brought here by my great-aunt, a Chinese lady who's been living in the city for years.  I bow to her and my other aunts in the city for Chinese food expertise.  

From my own experience, though, I will concur with many of the others here.  Best cheap dim sum in the city.  $1.65 for 3 har gow (shrimp dumplings) can't be beat!
author: Randal T.

description:
Wow.
Holy Bad.
Honestly, I have no idea where the rave reviews of this place are coming from.  Sure, it's cheap--that, and only that, is the reason it gets two stars.  Otherwise, I'm flabergasted.  I literally ended up throwing away the vast majority of my food.  I can say that I have NEVER done that in a decade of comprehensive dining out...take it for what it's worth.
author: Austin F.

description: I had no idea you can eat so cheap in San Francisco - and still get good food!  Honestly I don't know how this place manages to stand out from the Clement crowd, but it does.  Fresh, piping hot food at dirt-cheap prices.  The sweet rice bun is a must-try.
author: Kristen S.

description: Probably the best deal in terms of Dim Sum. You'll get the regular stuff, har gow, sui mai, bbq buns, etc. 3 pieces for $1.50. Can't complain when you can get a cheap lunch for under $5!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Great dim-sum! Will go out of my way for the baked BBQ pork buns here. Speedy, albeit a little-bit-pushy service but they seem to deal with a lot of people who have decision-making problems rather consistently and they keep the line MOVING despite this so you can get your food faster. Understandable that when the powers of tasty and affordable combine, you get a consistent line out of the door. I've been to the other dim sum stops on Clement and always wish I had just gone to Good Luck, it's the best.
author: Tessa M.

description:
We've eaten more Chinese food with our friend Sam in the last two weeks (since coming back from Tibet) than in the previous six years of San Franciscocity. 

The dim sum here is fast and good. Try the coriander dumplings for something light and fresh. And the steam buns for something fluffy and strangely sweet. Finally, skip the eggy custard dessert and get the banana flavored thing. As far as desserts without chocolate and from Asia go, yum.

Also, food for 3: $12 total.
author: Tyler S.

description:
My coworker and I had a really late lunch last Friday and happened to randomly pick this place for lunch since we were in the neighborhood. My coworker and I were playing Santa and Elf all day for our company delivering the Christmas presents. At around 3, we were definitely starving! We stumbled upon Good Luck Dim Sum, I thought, you can't go wrong with a name like that, right? Apparently, I spoke too soon!

Before starting this review, I read the other reviews for this place and I don't understand the high rating this place got?! I agree with most people that GLDS is cheap but I would never go back there again!!! I think that the price is THE ONLY positive feedback I have for the place. The food was average tasting, I've definitely had better, and the worst part is...the service SUCKS so bad! I hate giving my $$ to establishments that don't deserve any kind of business. The people working there are definitely Dim Sum Nazis!!!
author: Barbra C.

description:
It's small but they managed to put some tables in the back.
The ladies are kind of rude but who really cares. 
It's crowded so you know it's good! 

We got a few pastries, ALL the dumplings, the congee (rice porridge), turnip cake, sticky rice in the lotus leaves, and thats all I can remember. Everything was so good. All of it was under 13 or so. Its soooooo cheap and delicious. 

We came here after we left an expensive fancy smanshy 5 item dim sum place a few stores down that edited their newspapers to say that they were the best in san fran ): Good thing we did though! This place isn't a place to sit down with the new in-laws but it is definitely a good casual place to get good dim sum.
author: Dai-Trang T.

description:
Good Luck has been my go to for quick cheap dim sum.  I've never lived in the Richmond, but still have managed to regularly pop in for siu mai, fried meat dumplings, shrimp dumplings, a bunch of other stuff, STEAMED PORK BUNS, and a box of rice milk.  Their steamed pork buns are awesome.  There are tons of places to get dim sum around there, but Good Luck has it down.  No other hole in the wall spot can compete with them.

I love making a day of it and perusing Green Apple for hours afterward.  I think I know what I'm doing on Saturday.  I don't know if I can wait that long though.  Mmmm, Good Luck.
author: danielle p.

description:
You don't need to speak Chinese, you just need to understand Chinese dim sum culture.  Use your elbows.  Point.  Yell!

4th visit update !

::: One thing i wanted to mention...the tables are very dirty and the soy sauce containers look as though they have not been cleaned in about 10 years or so - also, NEVER, NEVER use the bathroom--unless you want a glimpse of how they really make the dim sum..not really that sanitary to say the least- i guess you get what you pay for - it is cheap!
author: Pug P.

description:
Oh-MAN!
After the long queue waiting, finally we got a chance to try.
I feel like there food  lot.  esp. Shrimp dumplings, Fun Kor :D
With  the great taste & quality and affordable price.

Great for taking out/ 
Not recommend for the new dating or  seeking for  the romance scenery obviously a lot of hunger people who want the seat to chow out and go  including me LOL
Anyway we ate all the dumplings there with to go "egg yolk bun".
author: Tan S.

description: wasn't the best dim sum, i have had better in east San Jose. price was rite but some of the pork buns were off on taste ??? don't know what it was. spend some extra bucks get something better unless you are in a hurry.
author: Louis B.

description:
A few weeks ago, I fell upon the Yelp review for this place, and since then, I'd been craving dim sum like none other.  Given the distance, traveling out to SF for good dim sum in the morning is not readily feasible, but a few times in the last weeks, I had the opportunity to go out for breakfast in the city, and of course, Good Luck Dim Sum came to mind immediately.  Afterall, with so many yelpers raving about this place - - it just HAD to be good.
"Best dim sum'....?

So two of us walked into this place at 9 AM one morning.  Small store, with perhaps 8-10 tables at which to sit and eat, and a counter upfront with several Asian servers.  I don't think they were Chinese, as many Chinese people seemed to be entering and speaking in English rather than Chinese.  
It's a pretty dinky place, but it did look clean.

You grab a piece of paper to order when it hits you - - these prices are ridiculously low!!!  3 siu-mai for only $1.50?  "Wow, if this is good.... I could eat like a king every single day," I thought to myself.... as I circled this, that, and everything else.  Compared to what we'd normally eat, it was a small order, but we both had our doubts as to whether or not this place would really be good.  Both of us have had the world's best dim sum places, and a small little place like this would have a hard time measuring up... so we'd place a small order and then if it really is that good - - we'll clean out the place.  So goes the plan, anyhow.

Alright.  Presentaton is really important in my mind.  I know when I cook something, I don't want to just slop it onto paper plates - I want to present it so that the dish is enhanced.  At Good Luck, they seem to have some major ISSUE with using those cheap styrofoam containers..... use the smallest possible to pack in as much dim sum you can without wasting any space at all.  Just stuff it in?  We told them we planned to eat here and they threw it onto a plate.  Dim Sum house with no hot tea?  Well, they do have it but it's tea bags... they give you hot water, you make your own tea.  What on earth!?!!?

Finally we sit down.
Take a bite of this.
Take a bite of that.
We both remain silent for awhile before we look up and simulataneously ask:  "What do you think?"  Given the expression on our faces, it was clear that neither party was impressed.  AT ALL.

There are not many things in the world that are worse than COLD Dim Sum.  The entire point of dim sum and the carts is to serve it piping hot.  Something this greasy cannot be tasted COLD or lukewarm!!!  RULE #1, people!  We can barely finish the small amount we order, and totally disappointed, with me mumbling, "But the yelpers said it was the best dim sum in CA.... I don't get it."

I am nothing if not forgiving, so in Good Luck's defense, I will add in that once I got home, I eyed my little styrofoam container with the suspect food in it and decided to nuke the hell out of it to taste it again - - hot.  Amazing what a little heat can do, folks.  The taste improved tenfold, and if it had been steamed hot -  I suspect it would have been even better.

OK - so the dim sum in itself is pretty good.  Not great, and not even CLOSE to being "the best" in any area, but pretty good.  But for the really nasty and unfriendly service (even when not busy) and serving it cold, not to mention being so cheap with their containers - -  I ding this place 2 stars to give it a final 3-stars.  I didn't have any of the buns so will overlook the "best buns" comment, but "best dim sum" it is not.  It is, however, good dim sum that is conveniently available for takeout, and as cheap of a meal as you can get anywhere in SF.  Worth going to?  Sure.  Just be sure to go home and NUKE it.  Don't eat it there, whatever you do!!!
author: Grace K.

description: I'm not a dim sum expert but this is off the hook! Fancy digs it's not. The focus is on the food--chive dumplings, shrimp dumplings, baked bbq pork buns, pork shu mai. I'm still working my way through the menu. 3 for 1.85! or .65/each on others. I sit and eat some and take the rest home, after I go across the street to the fish market and New May Wah.
author: Tracey B.

description:
There is a cryptic message about being closed for "kitchen renovations".  When I was there a couple of weeks ago during New Years they had lins out the door.  I hope they really do reopen.

The lady who approached after me had a reaction kind of like this: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xbVw7entkxg
author: Aaron T.

description:
Very delicious, and very cheap. It's definitely best for take out, but you can sit in their tables in the back. It's not your typical dim sum place where carts roam around--it kinna reminds me a bakery where you order your stuff, sit down/take out, eat. 

Try getting there early in the morning when the dim sum is fresh. Oh, and parking kinna sucks in the area.
author: Grotius H.

description:
Awesome for take out lunch.  Shrimp dumpling, chive shrimp dumpling, and baked pork bun are amazing in flavor and cheap!

The line takes forever to move, and I'm really not sure why.  I was waiting behind 10 people, and it literally took 15 minutes until I could give/get my order.  

The last time I came here, it was 4pm and there was no line!  And then after I got my dim sum, I realized why; they just served me stuff that was literally sitting out since god knows when.  So it tasted pretty gross, and gave me an upset stomach.

Good luck dim sum - please close your doors no later than one hour after your last batch of dim sum is cooked for the day!
author: Ali G.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed Good Luck yet, but at least it is my 100th Yelp review!

This is hands-down my favorite place in the entire city.  It is dirt cheap and delicious. I dare you to find fault with it. 

What I love about it is its complete lack of pretention. I love its "fuck it" attitude. My husband likes the simplicity of huge bags of rice and other supplies just out in the open and in your way. It doesn't have retrievable cool factor. I have yet to see them treat regulars any differently than anyone else. Their food is just fresh and delicious if you come when it's busy and slightly less so when they are approaching closing time.

The shrimp is perfection, sweet and crunchy goodness. A newer discovery of mine is the frequently sold-out mushroom chow mein-- good enough to make me a vegetarian.
author: Katy W.

description: Craving dim sum, my friend and I found this place from Yelp. We got in line and ordered our food. When it was my turn, I was looking around at what they had, the lady wasn't patient and looked annoyed. I felt rushed so I just tried to order quickly. I got my food and sat down with my friend. You gotta clean the tables yourself, the soy sauce is really sweet, it didn't taste like soy sauce at all. The dumplings are really big, it was barely warm and the dough around it is thick. The food is really cheap, one order of dumplings (3 pieces) is around $1.60.
author: Lyly T.

description: The absolute best to-go dim sum I've ever had, and I've tried ALOT of places. Whatever you get is going to be fresh, perfectly seasoned, and delicately textured. I waited in line for 30 minutes on a Sunday afternoon. No one seems to mind. You'll be very full off $6.
author: James P.

description: My bf and I love to com here and pick up hella dim sum to snack on. We'll spend $13 bucks and leave with a ginormous box of dim sum. The line can be super long and if it isnt (like end of the day) everything is almost gone. So far, everything I've had has been super tasty. They have amazing shrimp dumplings, chive dumplings, baked bbq pork buns, two types of dan tat oops egg tart and my favorite, fried taro!
author: Amy S.

description:
Best Dumplings on Clement Street.  I gave this place 5 stars for a few reasons.  

1. The place is super clean and you don't get that fishy smell when you walk in.

2. The dumplings are sooooo good. They have a variety to choose from like Beef, Pork, Shrimp, Green Onion, Deep Fried or Non Deep friend.  They also carry BBQ pork, and Chicken Bun steamed or fryed.

3. CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP

If your on a tight budget and your looking for an alternative to fast food come here. Its right across the street from Walgreens although parking can be a bitch.

THANKS FOR THE HEADS UP RENMIN
author: Robert M.

description: Amazing congee. Truly high quality. The rest is pretty good, but really cheap. I particularly liked the steamed bbq pork buns, very tasty.
author: Eric F.

description:
there's just something mystical and enchanting not to mention f-cking delicious about these little packages crafted by Chinese miracle workers (also known as dim-sum angels) on Clement street in San Francisco.

I highly suggest visiting this place, the que long enough to give you that much needed time to overhear some very necessary insider information - "dim-sum chit chat". Because of the cramped nature of the divey dim sum store, you will be forced to talk to those who chime in on overheard conversations, yet do not be alarmed after standing 15 minutes in line you will have countless new friends.

Regardless of dim-sum line protocols, these little guys are gifts from god. Not giving any recommendations on what to order, that's for you and the lovely people of the beloved dim-sum line. enjoy.

@jayanddee
author: Jeremi D.

description:
Dim Sum = good
prices = good
Good Luck Dim Sum = awesomness to the 10th degree
author: Krystle A.

description:
Normally, I'd only award three stars based on food quality and service, but the price at this place is excellent, so it gets four.

As previous posters have commented, the line can be a bit annoying, but seems to move quickly.  Customers were a mix of well-seasoned order-ers (who knew what they were doing) and a handful of newbies that slowed down the process.  

My request for 4 dozen shrimp dumplings was filled quickly.  As a side note, these babies freeze quite well.  I was tasked with flying some Dim Sum back to a friend in Pittsburgh, and they traveled well.  Other highlights are the Lotus-wrapped sticky rice with chicken (a mean in itself for probably $3).  I haven't tried anything here that I haven't liked.  The ladies in the back seem to be churning out Dim Sum on a continual basis, however, nothing seems very "hot" and fresh, but I think that's the nature of Dim Sum.  The steamers seemed to be working at full-force.  The exception are the steamed BBQ pork buns, these babies are fresh every time!

I totally recommend braving the 2-Clement (or courageously trying to park in this 'hood) to try out Good Luck Dim Sum.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Sadly this place has gone down hill since the "remodel"???? They were closed for about a month and I assumed it was to remodel but they opened back up and looked exactly the same. The food is definitely not bad but much more bland. More chili paste helps everything

Maybe they cleaned out all of the grease from the steamers. Could that add flavor like a grill does....hmmmm

Anyhow , I still come here at least twice a month so if you are in the hood...give it a try. Definitely best on clement street which is saying alot. My 3 and 5 star combine for 4 Stars :o)
author: John D.

description:
Cheap Good Dim Sum, nuff said 

I bought 45 dollar worth of food and it made two of my friends and me, completely full.  Usually in a normal Dim Sum place it would take us about 100 to fill us up.  

This place is DIRT cheap compare to south bay dim sum places and the food is just as good.  Only downside is that sometimes you might get a cold batch, instead of the hot ones.  But for this price I am not complaining!  I feel like I am eating in China, it's soooo cheap!
author: Seung O.

description:
My "friend" took me to this place when I came up there. I heard this place can get really crowded at times but luckily, it wasn't that crowded when we got there (yay!).

They had so much good food I wanted to try!! but I had to save my appetite for other foods. =[  The pork siu mai (spelling?) was really good! I can eat a ton of those! They had lots of other good food too.

One of the ladies gave me and my friend an evil look. Just because we're not chinese!!! (well my friend is partially but she doesn't know that!) =(  We didn't even do anything wrong! ::goes mopes in the corner::

But yea other than the evil looks from the woman, the food was really good =).
author: Peter N.

description:
Surprisingly, a dumpy place where they throw all the food together like leftovers if you ask for take-out, offers great flavored, high quality dim sum, that are dirt cheap. Yes, dirt cheap. It's not a place you want to sit down and enjoy your food and chat with your friends. You stand in line and get pissed, get your food and still pissed because they look like junk on the plate, and eat your shrimp dumplings feeling speechlessly satisfied. 
Everything I tried tasted just as good as any great dim sum places I've been to in NYC. No complaints for the line, since the food is good. The only complaint is that the food is not warm enough. So try your best to be lucky so you get there when everything is steaming hot. Maybe that's why it's called good luck dim sum. Good luck! Maybe you'll get the best shrimp dumplings in town, if you are lucky enough.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Great dim sum - 3 Steam BBQ Pork Bun for $1.55!!! I love it. 

What I love better is the custard ($.65). I get cravings every now and then for the custard and if I don't see a horribly long line I dart in to get my fix.

The long lines aren't an illusion, they are there for a reason. Cheap dim sum that is oh so good.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Reading some of these reviews, you kind of notice the bad ratings are from people who are complete and utter morons. They're the ones that base their ratings on their take-in dining experiences. 

The whole place is no bigger than two bedrooms and yet they think of the place like it's some fine dining place. It's not. Sure it has tables for people to sit at, but come on, you don't sit and eat there for the experience, you sit and eat there to eat the food. 

This is more of a take-out place than anything. And it's definitely the best take-out dim sum place I've been to outside of Chinatown. I'll go to great lengths to get great food, but when parking is a huge factor in the location, I'll probably pass which is the case in Chinatown. Parking isn't so bad here. It's a lot easier to find parking on Clement than it is on Irving. I stay in San Mateo with my girlfriend most of the time and whenever we feel like dim sum on the weekend but without having to sit down and wait, this is where we go. Definitely my favorite take-out dim sum place. Go here or go queer(which isn't necessarily a bad thing, just felt like rhyming)...
author: Calvin L.

description:
Giant dim sum for next to nothing.

So it's not the nicest place to eat but did I mention it's cheap? For $10, you can feed two people for a day. No having to wait an hour for a table is a big plus too.  So if you have an urgent need for dim sum ASAP, this is the place to go.
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
I live in Daly City & it takes forever to get to Clement St & find parking during the weekend, but it's well worth it. Here's what I love about Good Luck Dim Sum:

-Cheap food
-Quick Service 
-DELICIOUS DIM SUM (I usually come out with a BIG order since I only come here once a month or less)

Only think that would make me give it 5 stars is if they took debit or credit. Other than that...I love the food.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Good dim sum at super dirt cheap, bargain basement prices...I go here when I want to treat co-workers to some good ol' dim sum breakfast...they open very early in the morning, so I would get up at the crack of down & smell all the aromas in there ...
I truly "heart" their shrimp dumplings too :)
author: Elle F.

description:
When I was in college, this was the place that turned me on Dim Sum. My compliments to my friend Christine for introducing me to Good Luck Dim Sum. 

The interior is not the greatest, so if you live close enough, eat them at home or walking down Clement Street. Don't let the interior stop you from ordering, there food isn't Yank Sing, but it is delicious. If I am on Clement Street, I will usually get some.

As to price, it is cheap, really cheap! You can get nine dumplings for less than four dollars and be very satisfied. Make sure you have cash, they do not take cards. When I used to host events in college, I used to order like 300 pieces for less than sixty dollars, which I think is impressive.

The food is tasty, a little bit greasy and without a digestive green tea, I don't suggest more than nine pieces. I have been known to over-indulge on Dim Sum and I feel it is my duty to tell people not to. My favorites there are the hao gao (shrimp) and the siu miu (the pork). 

If you are hosting a big party on a limited budget, want to have a snack on Clement Street, or even a meal, Good Luck Dim Sum is a great place. Thinking about it makes me really miss living in the Inner Richmond.
author: Christopher W.

description:
i'm chinese, i dig chinese food. 'good luck' is... no good. The food is too greasy and there is WAY too much fat in the pork buns. when you bite through an entire cube of fat... you lose your appetite.

i'm wondering why people love 'good luck dim sum' so much. is it because the name is comforting and easy to remember?

don't let marketing fool you! 

Wing Lee, across the street cost about 10 cents more and tastes MUCH better. And no, i don't work for either one, i'm a graphic designer at a museum.
author: Charmagne L.

description: So I am a vegetarian at this point in my life.. & I have come to terms with it. I enjoy it and being a veggie in 2010, for the first time in my life, wasn't about abstaining from meat.. I actually haven't been desiring it at all. This all changes whenever I walk into Good Luck Bakery and remember how perfect, soft & tasty the pork buns are here. This is absolutely the best buns in SF if not ever.. Thankfully, they have a variety of veggie friendly treats as well. Don't miss this place.. It is a must stop for all my visiting company as we pass through Chinatown.
author: Phil J.

description:
I've been coming here for over 10 years and the place hasn't changed much - from the sparse eating area to the pink menus.  More importantly, what's kept me coming back is the fresh and delicious dim sum.  They have the best har gow in the city!  Prep while waiting in line and mark off on the menu what you want so that you can just hand it to the ladies...saves me (and them) time.

Lately, we've been serving their dim sum for football Sunday...yes, dim sum.  And it's been a hit!  So, instead of wings, try the chive dumpling with shrimp!
author: Abby N.

description: Wow, yummy! Hubby really wanted to try dim sum, after reading reviews we chose good luck dim sum. Sooooo glad we did. Cheap and sooooooo good. Will stop again before vacation is over. The language barrier was a little hard but we managed!
author: Terri C.

description: Don't go close to closing time.  Went there on a Sunday around 5:45 pm (45 minutes before closing) and it was slim pickings.  The food was kinda cold and chewy.  I was hoping they'd at least hook it up, but it didn't happen.  Too bad.  Went home disappointed with the quality but will be back... just not when they're closing up shop.
author: LW K.

description:
I was shopping for some seafood on Clement street when I got a craving for sum dim.  I walked in the first place I found and boy was I surprised to see such a long line! I figured, they must know something so I stayed. I wasn't disappointed. 

1. The best shrimp dumplings I've ever had. 
2. The steamed pork bun is really good, as far as chinese pork buns go. (The best are Filipino siopaos)
3. The sesame balls are good. Oily, but I still love them anyway. 

I'd go back if I was in the hood, but I wouldn't go out of my way. If I REALLY had a craving for  pork buns, I'd go Filipino.
author: joanna c.

description:
Delicious and cheap!  Although it doesn't look like much from the outside, it is truly a gem in the Richmond (kind of like the steamed buns... yum).

Pretty much everything is good.  I especially love the cilantro shrimp and the steamed vegetable buns.  My boyfriend loves the steamed pork bun and the pot stickers.  Then there are many wonderful baked goods to choose from... I especially love the lemon cake.

We went to a potluck after work a few weeks ago.  I didn't have time to cook anything so we brought dim sum from good luck.  Everyone loved it.  In fact, it disappeared almost as soon as we put it out!

The service isn't great, and you definitely want to take your food to go, but for lunch under $5, you can't go wrong!
author: Zoe H.

description:
I dunno why I'm writing this review. Cuz everyone knows it's good. The dim sum speaks for itself. And the old ladies who CUT IN FRONT OF ME IN LINE already frequent it.

Seriously, what is up with the continous edging in, while I'm dutifully waiting my Asian-but-clearly-not-Cantonese-speaking-ass in line??? It just bugs! And my main gripe is that the counter staff doesn't care about these line terrorists! Man!

However, if the dim sum here wasn't so gratifying, I would never brave the lack of parking, the running-out-of-stuff-early and the line terrorists.

My all-time faves are the Hum Siu Guk (sp? deep fried mochi ball with pork inside), Char Siu Bao (steamed pork bun), Jook (rice porridge) and Steamed Taro Dumplings (with taro and shrimp inside). Mm-mm-mm.

Come here and be prepared to exclaim: "Excuse me! I was next!"
author: Rey T.

description:
I liked this place, me and 2 friends (big eaters) went here and got a very filling meal including a drink for 28$.  28$ for all of us. and we had a ton of leftovers.
it was pretty good too! great pork buns!
author: Natalie K.

description:
My first time going to this restaurant which is recommended by a friend. 

14 dollars can buy so much dim sum here! We ended up taking some to go.
 
I have to say the way they take order is chaotic and unorganized. But It does not take away stars of my rating, for now. I will go back a few times and maybe revisit my review.
author: Al W.

description: Their dim sum us seriously the best in that neighborhood. All the rest are mediocre. Their shrimp dumplings are soft and yummy. My favorite is their taro dumpling sooo crispy and tasty. Highly recomend!
author: David L.

description: The best dim sum in San Francisco although the selection is limited to the dim sum essentials such as Hargow, Siu Mai, Egg Tart, etc. The line can sometimes be wrapped around outside the door depending on the time you go. 5 stars!
author: Lou T.

description: Ever since I moved to SF, I have been in love with Dim Sum. I use to go to the Clement one, but Good Luck Dim Sum is little bit cheaper and tastes better too! There are no frills and thrills with this place. You wait in line, order your food, pay and out you go.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Some one said Dim Yum, I have to say Dim YUCK!!!!  I have never been so disappointed with a such a highly Yelped place. The food was greasy, cold, and really really yucky for lack of a better word.
My friend and I went there for dinner last night, we are both big Dim Sum fans (I have even gone to China and ate at the places like this). We ordered our favorites and sat down to chow down. After the first few bits I was already feeling sick. The chicken bun was ok, but I was not completely convinced it was chicken. 
I give this place a big thumbs down!
author: Tre B.

description:
My advice: go in, get out. If they give you the wrong thing, do not question it. Plunk your cash on the table and get lost. 

It's a bit intimidating for people not used to this kind of service. I didn't find the staff either helpful or not. They are just indifferent. Go in knowing what you want and you will be fine. If you have no idea what dim sum is, then this will be a scary ordeal for you. With a long line of people stuffed into the tiny cramped space, they do not have the time to open up all the steamers to have you make a decision. When in doubt, just try it. If you don't like it, well, it only set you back like $1.50.

For the most part, the dim sum comes in sets of 3s. It's not the best I've ever eaten, but certainly not the worst. At a sit-down place like Ton Kiang, you will easily pay $20-$30 per person. Here, you will pay about $5-$10 and feel adequately stuffed. You do, however, get what you pay for. It's not great, but it certainly is edible. And lets face it, sometimes when your out-of-town buddies visit and want to try this crazy thing called dim sum, its sometimes easier to get them started on something cheap and easy before they hit the big time. Most likely they won't know the difference anyway.
author: Sabine S.

description: Very disappointed.  Small, take-away bakery with a few tables.  I got there late for lunch...I feel like everything was made earlier and sat and waited until we showed up.  Basically, everything was old and dried out.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Awesome for the quick "dim sum" fix...epitome of "cheap eats" and they are not forgoing the quality is what is pretty awesome.

I love dim sum & had some of the best from here to HK...and must admit the quality of this place makes it better than the 10+ other dim sum places on Clement.  Don't expect to find the assortment of Yank Sing (one of the last local upscale dim sum restaurants) or May Flower...but here are some that probably most will enjoy.

Favs:
-har gow (shrimp)
-fun gor (shrimp, ground pork, cilantro, veggie)
-shark fin dumpling
-porridge (old school style...pork, 1000 yr old egg (i toss that), green onions, fried crunchies...in a yummy rice broth...eat all at once & hot as, gets too watery if you refrigerate)
-shrimp/chive dumpling
-pan fried radish cake
-sticky rice & chicken wrapped in a leaf
-steamed pork bun
author: C L.

description: Awesome place for a cheap eat.. Decent quality of Dim Sum, $4.80 and I stuffed myself... Mind you there's always a line. A bit of a language barrier though and attitude received because of it... but oh well. Very limited seating and of course parking but what can you expect..
author: R C.

description:
I read mixed reviews here on this place.  Hmmmm, well here I go...

I personally rate 4 stars for the dim sum, I think it's a good take out dim sum place, at least on Clement Street, but I know I've had super better elsewhere (too bad I can't remember from where).  If I come here it's usually in the morning so everything I get is hot and fresh.  The service is not that good, the ladies behind the counter seem tired and not happy with their jobs and it would probably be helpful to them if you know what you want before it's your turn to give them your order.  There are pink menus laying on the top of the glass display so grab yourself one and look over the items to decide and be ready when it's your turn.  For a potluck item idea go here and get their pork potstickers, they're huge and meaty, and they go fast at parties (don't forget to get soy sauce packets with them).  I don't eat in because I feel cramped in this place and feel weird being looked at by others standing in line.  Expect a long line (especially on weekends) so definitely get your food to go.
author: Emy B.

description: The service here sucks... their always talking in chinese, they freakishly yelled at me my order back, i am only there for the food when my parents are at the supermarket across the street
author: Jimmy D.

description:
I've been getting dim sum from here for the last 5 years or so.
I think that speaks for itself :)
author: Anthony L.

description: Best fun gor (shrimp and pork dumpling) ever.
author: Jaime C.

description:
You get what you pay for!

My husband and I were in SF early today (by 7am) and this was one of the Dim Sum places that was open and ready for business. We ordered some Dim Sum at their front counter area. It was okay....but it fed us well for $5. The place is clean and the ladies were nice.  We were not completely satisfied with the quality of it. The pork dumpling was a little weird but the pork bun was hot and yummy. I chowed down on two of those!
author: Monica L.

description:
I'm sorry, but i have to disagree with all the yelpers here with the dim sum served here. Yes they are cheap, $10.40 fed two bigs guys. We ordered the Chicken w/ Sausage Rice with rice, 3 beef siu mai, 3 har gow, 3 sticky rice buns, 3 fried balls with stuffing inside (ham sui gok... not sure what's it called in English), and 2 strips on shrimp rice roll.. yes it was a lot of food, but the foods not all that great. I had way better at TC pastry and Clement Dim Sum Bakery and Restaurant up the street. First of the Chicken w/ Chinese sausage with rice was cold and the rice wasn't fully cooked. the ham sui gok was cold.... and they microwaved it to heat it up.. who knows how long those things have been sitting there. UGH. Everything else that came out of the steamer was fine, but not up to par to my standards.... i've been eating dim sum my whole life and i know good dim sum. 

They should really clean this place up as well, not clean at all.. the table was sat at had soy sauce and hot sauce all over it... they should wipe the tables down each time someone eats there. If you want up to par dim sum go to TC pastry on irving, or clement dim sum bakery up the street.. trust me you'll find better dim sum.
author: Brian P.

description:
I'm giving this a 5 for what it is and what it is supposed to be.  Great, cheap dim sum to-go place with seats inside if you can't wait to get home and eat it.  Its nice and affordable after going to other places over the week that clean out your wallet.  

This isn't the typical sit down restaurant where the carts roll by and you pick what you want.  You usually don't come here for nice decor or friendly service.  It reminds me a little of my parent's donut shop with the tables and boxes stacked up to the ceiling.  

You come for the dim sum and for most things being 3 for $1.50 you can almost have a meal for two and keep it under $10 total.  Actually...that might not be completely accurate, but close!  There's always a pretty long line in there but the ladies behind the counter move fast.  They know how to get people in and out of the door quick.

I like stopping by here any chance I get!
author: Tom Y.

description: We went looking for Char Siu Bau. When we got there around 5:30pm they were out of them. They only had chicken or pork with vegetables. The price was 3 for $1.70 so I got a few of both of those. The lady offered me cold Char Siu Bau for me to steam at home, so I bought some of those too. We tried the hot chicken and pork with vegetables, and didnt care for them. The Bau was more bready then I like too. When we got home I steamed the Char Siu Bau. We didn't care for them too much either. They put too much jelly sauce and not enough meat.
author: May P.

description:
3 steamed char siu paos and these aren't the miniature ones at the dim sum restaurants.
3 shrimp dumpling har gaos
3 chicken siu mais
3 bak tong go (sweet rice cake?)

All for $5.90, I can't complain.

Enough for breakfast and lunch
author: Tim L.

description:
I can't believe that it took me 5 years to come back to this place.  I used to frequent it while in college and living down the street.  

You can't go wrong.... super cheap, great variety, fast service, and YUMMMYYY!!!!!!!!!

Order: 

- siomai
- shrimp dumplings

I go crazy when I go there and order a bajillion. 

So good... So good...
author: Genevieve J.

description:
The best dim sum.  Inexpensive tasty treats!  Among my favorites:  pork siu mai, baked bbq pork buns, custard tarts.  My least fave: parking situation.

An ideal stop before heading to an unplanned picnic.
author: Scarlet L.

description: This is my FAVORITE place for dim sum. It's soo good and you know it's an awesome place when it's always full. I've been coming here for thee longest time. And I am never disappointed. Man, I want some right now!!
author: Julie Z.

description: Been coming here for years now. Same good taste. I like the Chinese Chive dumplings and the lucky balls especially. Sam poor service. Rarely get a hello, rarely get eye contact and never get a thank you. Well, there is one woman who smiles and does greet and say thank you-one, but I hardly ever see her. Yet, I keep coming back, mostly because my sister who lives in Texas asks me to bring it every time I visit her. Can anyone recommend a good dim sum place like Good Luck that has better service? Oh, in the Richmond? Thank you!
author: Sarita E.

description:
Coming from highly non-experimental parents (my dad will seriously only eat chinese food) I have to say that this place is hands-down THE place to go. Mom and dad only get their dim sum from this place. For my aunt who lives in Taiwan, this is one of her favorite places in the world (literally) to get sesame balls (jian dui). My personal favorite: pan fried shrimp and chive dumplings, although you can't miss with any of their fantastic treats. 

Watch out - you gotta be super fast on the uptake. If you don't respond to one of the counter ladies as soon as she gets to you, the chinese lady behind you will steal her away. They also are in desperate need of a customer service etiquette lesson.
author: Karva S.

description:
I wouldn't say that Good Luck has the best dim sum in San Francisco.  However, I do like eating here on a weekend even though this place is more catered for people buying dim sum "to go."  

What do I get here?  I get the Shrimp dumplings, siu mai, taro cake, and shark fin dumplings.  These dishes are tasty enough to get by me.

Now since it is a dim sum "to go" place, the line on the weekend between 11 am to 2 pm is quite long.  Maybe 20 people at any give time in a small place.  

Why do I like eating here?  Probably because I like the craziness that goes on here during the weekend...I get to get all my dim sum at once on the table...And then I can pick and choose which one I want to eat next rather than having to order the shrimp dumplings and wait 15 minutes to then be able to eat my siu mai...
author: Alan T.

description:
My favorite To-Go dim sum place!  Beef Siu Mai is the best!  I can eat a dozen of them..in one sitting.... SERIOUSLY..hehe - :)

The ladies that work there are sometimes rude.  I understand some of what they say - and cannot believe some of their comments.  If they are yelling...don't worry...that's not directed towards you...they are yelling to the cooks in the back to make more of a certain item!  haha

If you can deal with the lines..the ladies' gibberish -- good place to go for take-out.  ---one more thing...if you want to bypass all of that...phone in the order--probably better for large orders.

**Dim Sum -- a little piece of the heart**
author: Lise T.

description:
good luck dim sum, where the 'good luck' really means, good luck getting someone nice to take your order.

that said, the food is INCREDIBLY delicious and inexpensive. 

and yeah, it's casual. people wear pajamas in there.

the seating is limited, and staff rarely bothers to wipe tables, remove trash, or sweep. but please don't let this dissuade you from getting some of the best dim sum in the city...

TO GO.
author: Andy P.

description:
The lines are out the door and the prices are great !!  It's like going to Costco for Dim Sum as they are all the popular Dim Sum dishes at bargain prices..

The service is not the best, but what else do you expect ?? This is the a #1 recommendation to anyone who is looking for good, cheap Dim Sum....
author: Bobby H.

description: What's the big fuss about this place?? The dim sums are not that good, and the service is just horendously terrible. Why bother to stand in a long line and endure lousy services with bad attitudes and stinky faces! Totally not worth it.
author: Angela C.

description:
Bottom line: very good tasting food cheap.

Counter service, and a long line, but $24 (including 6 drinks, so really 18) including tax for a hefty meal can't be beat. I'm not a chinese food expert, but to me everything tasted very good and what you expect for dim sum.
author: Fred S.

description: this has been my family's favorite dim sum bakery in the city for years!  i live in oakland, and even then, i will drive out to the city just to get some of their great dim sum.  forget wading through the tourists of chinatown when clement street has plenty of great dim sum to offer!  the shrimp dumplings are amazing, and even though i am not a big fan of shrimp, i never turn them down.  one of the best parts of going to a im sum bakery is how cheap it is!  you can order enough food for two or three for under ten dollars!  ordering is easy: just grab a paper menu on the counter, circle what you want, and write the number of how many.  easy peasy!
author: Cristina S.

description:
I've been a customer of this place for years, ever since I moved to Bay area, it is a perfect place to enjoy dim sum without worry too much about my wallet. The decor may look very simple and serving may look very fastfoodish, but the quality and variety  is not less than some of the other fancy-decorated Chinese restaurant on clement. Where you could end paying much more than from Good Luck Dim Sum.
It is also a perfect place for ordering food for parties. I ordered from them several times for parties at home and all my friends love them.
author: Shiqi Y.

description: This s a great place for dim-sum. There were 3 ladies serving and they did a great job at serving it. The dim-sum was super fresh and the prices were so cheap. We got about enough for 3 sit-downs for 4 people for under $30.
author: Origami Z.

description: The only redeeming aspect about this place is the price.  The dim sum is okay.  The BBQ pork bun was seriously lacking in the meat department.  I was rather disappointed in that because that is one of my favorite go to for dim sum.  The line is long but it does go really quickly.  The people getting the food is quite rude.  You can still get through customers quickly without the rudeness.  In their broken English, half the time I don't really understand what they are saying even though I'm trying really hard to understand.  I grew up with my parents speaking broken English; I thought I was used to it.  It doesn't help that they don't give a crap what you're saying on the other end.  I was really excited so I ordered quite a bit.  So when she told me she didn't have a dish and something pork I said oh okay thinking she was asking me if it was okay to sub another similar dish for that dish.  It's pretty hectic there, there's three people serving and asking at least three customers in line what they want. When I asked her if she got the chicken and sausage dish as well, she yelled at me rudely "I TOLD YOU ALREADY I DON'T HAVE THAT."  And to add salt to the wound, rolled her eyes like I'm the one with English problems.  Anyways I liked that it was like $14 for two people and we were completely full and had left overs.  But even if I lived here, I wouldn't mind paying a bit extra for people to not treat you as if they're doing you a favor by taking your money for their food.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Long lines but really solid good. Siu Mai was a little bit undercooked, but everything else was delicious. Staff are not the most friendly in the world, but they are efficient.
author: Mimi S.

description:
I love dim sum because it's: cheap, unique, and fast. Since I was 15, I've been trying places all over SF. Good Luck Dim Sum is the best. 

To receive five stars for dim sum the restaurant must be:
1. Constantly serving fresh dumplings (not soggy, and not luke warm)
2. Have a line for dumplings regularly
3. Have several options
4. Cheap (no Castro 3 dumplings for $3!!!)


Well Good Luck Dim Sum meets these requirements, and accordingly, is my favorite spot.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description: Fantastic! Enjoyed a feast for three for $20. Chive & shrimp dumplings were the best I've ever tasted.
author: Nicole J.

description:
Okay! Char Siu Pao is the best!

$10.50 got me 6 Char Siu Pao, 3 Sesame Balls, 1 Lotus Pao, 3 Shiu Mai (I don't really like them because it's too big), 2 Egg Custard, 3 Ha kaw.

Man. If you are on a budget, $10 will last you a whole day! Need to work on customer service :)
author: Haris G.

description: This is my go to spot for take out Dim Sum.  The prices are fair and the food is good.  I don't know how I would feel if i wasn't Chinese though because the women in there are mean!  I understand the personality of these women because I had a grandma with a similar no nonsense attitude.  Know what you want when you get to the counter because they dont have time for BS.  They will not sugar coat anything and they will give it to you like it is.  The best deal in SF may be their Pork and Thousand Year Old Egg Jook for only $2 per order...  Can't be the price and the amount you get.
author: Sam L.

description:
I'm no Dim Sum expert.  I sort of profess to be a wine expert of sorts, a part time burrito/taco expert, and occasionally a California Cuisine quazi-expert.   But not Dim Sum.  
I love Dim Sum though.  And though I rarely eat it, it is a cuisine I crave.  Good luck is not for everyone.  It is bare bones, and not fancy.  My wife, for example, not a fan of the flavors.  But she does not really love Asian foods (aside from Sushi, and lately--and happily for me--Indian food), and she has never loved Dim Sum.
This all being said, I thought this was pretty damn tasty Dim Sum.  And CHEAP.  
Check it out.  Take out is probably the best option.  There will be long lines---yadda yadda yadda.  The point is that we live in a city where there are a lot of options for food worth checking out.  This is one of them, in my opinion.
author: Blake W.

description:
We frequent this place for on the go breakfast often...and let me tell ya- these ladies are all about efficiency- NOT about friendly customer service.  On some mornings, they don't even look at you, they just demand to know what you want RIGHT NOW!  I tremble in fear, thinking that they will bite my head off if I take too long to decide!  Then as I pay, they flash a smile at me and tell me and the kids to have a good morning...Talk about multiple personalities!

Overall- good on the go dim sum place.  I really like the way they make their "lop cheung bao" a.k.a. Chinese Sausage buns- slightly sweet bun.  They are my favorite and a must try here.
author: Judy K.

description:
I think the other reviewers have said it all about Good Luck Dim Sum... excellent dim sum fare without the associated price tag.  

They have a good selection of dim sum dishes, although there were definitely some missing, like "niu bai ye," "yu to jiao," and a few others.

Get there early on the weekends, as you'll be waiting in line for awhile.  The service isn't the most efficient, but I think it adds to the "authentic" charm of the place.
author: Tony O.

description: I had a bad experience eating dim sum from this place, let's say it did not agree with my stomach. There are better dim sum places on Clement. If you're not pressed for time then I would go to Tong Palace or the restaurant next to China First. Otherwise just stick with Wing Lee.
author: Lawrence F.

description:
As I bit into my fifth piece of dum sum, I couldn't help but wonder, "Did I misorder?"

I came here with a friend on a weekday afternoon, promising her cheap & well-made dim sum.  While our order was fantastically cheap, I can't help but admit I left a tad disappointed that my dumplings tasted a little like freezer burn.  

The only item that truly blew my socks off was the steamed barbeque pork bun--the sweet, gooey innards were an aromatic delight, and that chewy doughball was steamed perfectly.

Overall:   A good pit stop if you're in the neighborhood with a few extra minutes, but not worth a crosstown Muni ride that includes one transfer.
author: Ann M.

description:
3.5 I thought that overall goodluck dim sum was pretty good but nothing special, especially given clement streets huge selection.
The shrimp dumplings, pot stickers and st.eamed pork buns were wonderfull.  this place is dirt cheap and at least while we were there the line moved relatively quickly.  The lotus ball was pretty nasty; the coating was excessively bready and the custard tart and sui mai were only average.  I think well be back but next time we'll mix and match with Clement restaraunt.
author: Sesily M.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum has been a staple in my Clement street diet for over 2 years now. The food has always been both excellent and cheap. 

However, unless you enjoy the dive atmosphere, I highly recommend NOT eating there. Every time you touch anything in the whole place, it just seems to be sticky. This includes chairs, tables, napkins, counter tops, chopsticks, and change from the register. 

In fact, for the OCD crowd, if you must eat here, I highly recommend a full body condom. Don't worry, the food is well worth it. You'll thank me later.
author: Frank B.

description:
Good and cheap! What else could you want in a dim sum place? The dim sum we got was fresh, tasted great, and priced super reasonably. Almost wanted to spend more just because I couldn't believe my order was that cheap. 

It's not a sit down place, go with a friend to claim your spot at the few tables (one of them is inevitably taken by a pile of boxes). The lines are also super long usually, so grab a menu and discuss your order while you wait.
author: Roland C.

description:
We bought some late lunch here today and it's sad to say, will be our last time. Over the years we have patronized this popular dim sum restaurant, but what I witnessed today, was the tip of the iceberg so-to-speak. 
I'd ordered my items and was being served by one woman, when another server came along to serve others @ the counter. 

She was holding tongs in her left hand, and proceeded to loudly expectorate (cough up) thick green sputum into a napkin she grabbed w/ her right hand. As I stood & watched the large, green evidence sitting on the edge of her lips, I looked @ the other customers who didnt seem to react @ all. Did they see this? How could they not see this? Did they accept this and it simply meant nothing to them?

NO HAND WASHING! She just tossed it out & carried on serving people. 
I was so grossed out, it's since made me sick to think about it, I keep seeing the vision of her standing in front of everyone and so casually hurling sputum. 

What has happened to health standards???? Dont they care?
I was in the midst of my money exchange but if that had been my server, I wouldve refused the service. 
On the otherhand, it's likely this is commonplace activity and I just happened to see it today. 
"Where have all the standards gone, long time passing".......

This is another reason I've begun to limit my eating out more and more. 
How many hands has our food been passed through in a restaurant until we get it? I grew up in big metropolitan cities filled w/ all cultures so I'm very comfortable exploring places but this was one of the worst experiences today.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Tasty, impressive dim sum even...

MUNI-like, not so impressive ambiance and "soup nazi" service.

The end.
author: Lara D.

description:
I know I am not allowed to compare where I am and where I was.but I can't stop it.

In good luck dim sum, I could  eat great great dimsum for 5 bucks and I could be full.everything was great.

I always thought Hei la moon in Boston is great but I find it is not comparable at all. I  Hei la moon can be 3 star if it was in SF. 

san francisco.  I t  is a town for gourmet. It is expensive place to live but it is all worth it.

I always want to come back there.
author: tamama s.

description:
my #1 dimsum store! 

i absolutely love this place...the only bad thing about it is that it's located in the heart of Clement street so parking sucks, and theres always a long ass line, but the food is well worth it.

the prices are like any other dimsum store...3 for $1.30 or so..very worth it!
author: M W.

description: Went in the other day just to see how it was compared to the other Dim Sum shops on Clement.  The service was odd at first because the lady just seemed to not notice us for a minute as we awkwardly tried to get her attention.  Then we ordered the 9 pieces of dim sum and were on our way.  This place is no different than the others on Clement.  Just had more attentive service at the other ones.
author: Jesse C.

description:
My husband and I decided to try every dim sum place on Clement street and decided this had the most awesome food.  Atmosphere is definitely a hole in the wall with linoleum floors and only 6 tables but everything I've eaten there has been awesome except the sweet rice wrapped in lotus leaves (just not my cup of tea)
I love the shrimp dumplings, the pork siu mai, the shark fin dumplings, and the sesame seed bean paste balls.  The pork buns are good but there is a small bakery on Clement and 18th (?) which makes much better ones.
Biggest drawback is the line which is always present unless you go at the end of the day.  But then it's not as fresh.
Good side to the line is that everytime I stand in line, I meet someone who is great to chat with!
author: Holly L.

description:
The dim sum here is a must try.

The ladies working behind the counter are as nasty as can be, so figure out what you want before getting to the front of the line, and circle your choices on the pink slip. If you ask questions, they will roll their eyes and spit out an unintelligible answer, even if you ask politely in Chinese (personal experience). 

You can eat there, but I strongly discourage it. Get the dim sum to go and enjoy it in the comfort of your own home. Don't be intimidated!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Balls. Big smushy, tasty Sesame Balls. 

Yep, that's my #1 motivation for going there. Oh and the Shrimp Dumplings.  I walked up and down Clement looking other dim sum places, thinking there *might* be something as good or better. I was wrong! 

Good Luck Dim Sum is great for a quick and tasty meal.  If you need fancy wait service with waiters, carts and such, you may want to go to the official Chinatown on Grant Avenue.
author: Joanne D.

description: Too bad there isn't one closer to me! Yes, it's dirty. Yes, they're rude, but it's still awesome! Prices are cheap and the food is delicious! The usual stuff is good: har gow, siu mai, law mai gai (rice wrapped in banana leaf). However, even the simple stuff is good. I'd like to porridge and the rice with black bean spare ribs. I bought enough dimsum to last me breakfast for the whole week and it only cost around $25 for two people. This place is a winner!
author: Angela L.

description:
I came here with high expectations after reading all the 4 star 5 star reviews. After searching through yelp, there aren't that many dim sum places with such high ratings. Plus, having a higher rating than Yank Sing must have meant something.

Unfortunately, this place didn't live up to my expectations. It was decent dim sum, it was better than a lot of the other cheap hole-in-the-wall places I know in SF... Which, unfortunately, isn't saying much either. It's very cheap (about 50 cents a piece) and it will fill up two people with just 10 bucks. Regarding the flavor, every other dim sum tastes the same and after a while I don't know the difference any more between a shrimp dumpling and a pot sticker. And the sharks fin dumpling doesn't taste anything like sharks fin.

Personally, what I feel is that this place has so many high ratings NOT because its exceptionally good in terms of quality of the dim sum and outstanding taste, but because its mostly NOT what other dim sum places tend to be -- too greasy, heart-attack inducing, expensive, and/or just plain nasty.

So, if you wanna fill yourself up with some average tasting dim sums that aren't what I listed above for less than 10 bucks, come here. I'll move on to the next dim sum place with a good rating.
author: Shongi H.

description:
Yes, the prices are cheap... but so is the quality & service. While my bf waited in line for 10-15 minutes, I watched several carts of steaming hot dumplings delivered to the front of the store. My mouth began to water because they looked so fresh and delicious. Then my bf arrived with a crazy amount of food and hurriedly I stuffed the chicken siu mai into my mouth only to find out that it was cold and stiff as a rock. Then, I realized just about everything except the mushroom chow mein was that way. 

To top it all off, I needed two small boxes for my leftovers. So I go to the front to ask for the boxes. The lady comes to my table to inspect how much left overs I have and insists on giving me only one box, suggesting that I put the noodles on the bottom with the dim sum leftovers on top. Uhhh, okkkk? I'll just pretend she's trying to be eco-friendly with her plastic to go  containers.

Anyways, the dim sum was OK, nothing special but I guess you get what you pay for, so in that case it was worth it.
author: kat a.

description: Best Dim Sum in San Francisco in my opinion! Great Hagao, No Mai gai, no mai bow ( not sure of spelling), egg rolls and the sui mai.  Everything is really good.
author: Karen H.

description: This is my go to for a quick dim sum lunch. Sort of take out style but there are seats if you want them. The women behind the counter have their good and bad moments for friendliness but the food is always good.
author: Mike R.

description:
Their dim sum is great....you choose what you want on a piece of paper and they have a great variety.

However, the long lines and sometimes shortage of items might knock off some points....and the bitchiness of the workers might make you run for your life.
author: Mark B.

description:
Ok you remember that Seinfeld soup nazi episode everyone?

Well replace the soup with dim sum, and replace the soup nazi with three Asian ladies.

In other words the dim sum is like mad good. And this place is always busy on a Saturday afternoon. So you better have your paper order ready (they take orders by having you circle items on a menu paper) or your gonna get a lot of evil stares. And apparently asking for extra napkins or boxes or any sort of extra service above and beyond them taking your money and giving you your dim sum is blasphemy.

But don't worry about all that. Just fall in line, get your order right, and be efficient and you'll be on your way. The extra high pressure ordering environment is just part of the charm!

I love this place. The dim sum is excellent, get the:
1) chives, spinach and shrimp
2) shark fin
3) beef
4) sesame bun
5) pork bun

They are all really good, with the first three on the savory side and the last two on sweet the sweet side.

Oh did I mention that stuff is ridiculously cheap? Each order (3 of one item) is usually under $2. We've come here multiple times and have fed 3 people for under $15.

Ok stop reading and go.

Oh also, if you come here on the weekend parking on or around Clement blowZ!
author: Varun ..

description:
if you don't have the $$ to go to Yank Sing, come here. i've eaten at a few dim sum places in the city, Yank Sing being one of them. and hands down, they're the best. but the next best is Good Luck Dim Sum which is kinda crazy since they're so cheap. 

the shrimp, chive, and beef dumplings are all amazing. so are the egg rolls. granted, you're not gonna get 5 star service. the asian ladies behind the counter look ridiculously unhappy, so be ready to order when it's your turn.
author: Maria A.

description:
This place is literally 5 minutes away from my apartment, so on the weekends when I feel like walking there (obvs I'm sinfully lazy), I am all about the dim sum. And as much as I love the shrimp dumplings, overly fried egg rolls, sour and surly service (it's part of the GL experience), and long lines, I must say this--can you puh-lease put a list of what is in the dim sum?

As a pescatarian, I am unable to eat meat. Upon one of my visits, I ordered the shrimp taro dumplings, assuming there would be no meat in it. And I don't know if they gave me the wrong order or what, but after my first bite, I found my mouth full of ground beef/pork/some kind of meat that really shouldn't be in my mouth (that's what she said... heyo!). Just imagine my dismay. I understand that their English may or may not be limited and that they may or may not give a sh*t that I don't eat meat, but please! How am I supposed to unnecessarily buy more food than I need if I don't know what's inside the dim sum? Help an Asian sistah out.

Thusly, my experience at GLDS has the potential for even more greatness--but if they could please put a brief summary of what's within the doughy goodness. It could be like a "describe yourself in 3 words" ice breaker, but without the first-days-of-school awkwardness.
author: Bel P.

description:
This is my new fave place for cheap eats. Perfect for something quick after shopping at May Wah or if you're ever on your own in the Clement area. Yeah, it ain't Koi Palace but you can't complain when you can stuff yourself for $5. Most of the dim sum is $1.50 or $1.80 for 3 pieces, an absolute bargain. I usually get it to go, but you can also eat inside if you like.

Some people complain about the women behind the counter, but I appreciate their speed and the line is long enough that you should be able to make up your mind by the time you get to the front! They even give you the opportunity to mark up a slip of paper with your order to save time and avoid any language difficulties.

Here are my reviews of the dim sum items I've tried.

Har gow (shrimp dumplings) - these are my favourite here, not too far off from a higher end place. The dumpling skin is not too think, and you get a generous serving of tasty shrimp inside each one.

Siu mai (pork) - these are a little greasy but are very flavourful and a good size.

Lo bak go (turnip cake) - usually my favourite dim sum item, i would say that they are only average to slightly above here. Still they are way better than the ones you buy in the store and are dirt cheap for $1.50.

Wu tau kau (fried taro dumpling) - again, a little greasy, but what do you expect - they are deep fried! very tasty and large too.

Lo mai gai (sticky rice with chicken in lotus leaf) - these are awesome. I think they're only $1.80 and are almost a whole meal! They even taste good if you re-steam them the next day.

The only dim sum they don't have which I like is cheung fun (rice noodle roll), which is a shame but not worthy of deducting a star. They have a bunch of other items on the other menu: bao, chicken feet etc which i haven't tried cos I can't really eat that much!

Overall, excellent place for cheap, solo eats, or to take home for several people. The only downside is the lack of seating, during busy times you really need to hover around tables like vultures to ensure getting a seat.
author: Jeremy H.

description: Tarty but all to go food. Dirt cheap! Not a huge selection but still good. Parking sucks and not much space inside.
author: Daniel N.

description: Good dim sum to go but the ladies in there are so bitchy. Doesn't really bother me but it is funny to watch. They have no hot mustard packs to go and they get pissed when you ask. I purposely ask them every time just to get under their skin.  Yeahhhh beyotch!!!
author: John K.

description: Giant amazing sticky barbecue pork buns. Who cares about the rest of the menu.
author: Lynn B.

description: Cheap fresh dim sum - what more can you ask for?  Nothing fancy - mostly the basics.  Last time we got har gow, potstickers, pork bun (steamed & baked), sesame ball & custard tarts.  All were good & freshly made.  Where else can you get your fill of dim sum for less than $10?
author: Kim S.
