description: This is the freshest dim sum to-go place on Clement.  3 pieces for $1.55.  It's a dime more than competitors but come on... it's a dime.  Their dim sum is always fresh and their shrimp dumpling is mostly shrimp, unlike others.  Friendly service but the wait's the longest on Clement St also.  I like their spare ribs rice bowl for $2.20 that comes with bok choy and a cup of hot water.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: This was one of the first to go Dim Sum place I found when I first got to SF.  It's funny how things go full circle.  Now I am going back to this place.  Super cheat good Dim Sum.
author: Jim J.

description: For mostly take out dim sum it is okay although it is over priced and nothing overly special about this place. I can get cheaper and bigger shrimp dumplings in Chinatown. In fact almost everything is smaller portions than compared to normal dim sum take out joints, which this place is just that. You line up and they have a printed menu and pen on the counter for you. Although its not a giant menu I thought it was okay. Unfortunately by the time I got to the front of the line and turned in my slip with my choices, they did not have 2 of the items I had picked. And there was no offer of, "I am sorry we do not have these items. Would you like to substitute with something else?" Just the bum rush of having to pay. And after having to wait in line for 5-10 mins while I watched all the old Chinese men/women ahead of me buy boxes and boxes filled and leave. They could have given the courtesy of a minute to ask. That would have been nice. But seeing as the line was constant they probably didn't care about great individual customer service. Then to make matters worst I paid and sat in the very meager choices for seating just to find out that she screwed up my order. And I still think she over charged me but what am I to do? Argue with people who would not give me their  time of day nor speak English and understand English. It's not worth wasting my time to do so.  So I won't be making it a point to come again.
author: Ms. T.

description: I was looking for somewhere for dim sum and chanced upon Good Luck Dim Sum here.  Some may be taken aback at the attitude of some of the staff, but if you can get over that, you'll enjoy some really good dim sum.  The best part is that it's so cheap too!  Loved it.
author: Vince T.

description:
The line here is always really long but its so worth the wait! Yes, the ladies behind the counter are rude, but seriously, where can you buy delicious dim sum (a whole box and another box full of only eggrolls) that will feed an army for $35?!?! 

The quality of their food is consistent, as I have yet to have a bad tasting dumpling or with itsy bitsy filling. The kitchen is always whipping up freshly steamed, fried or baked goodies for the hungry (and patient) patrons. 

I suggest taking it to go as the dining room is very small and greasy. Plus its weird when you're trying to enjoy your food with people staring at you while they wait in line.
author: Vicki F.

description: Change my mind, 2 star to 3 now! though the food is not fab, I find myself coming back from time to time cuz it's fast cheap and convenient
author: Katherine C.

description:
I don't really care that this has been reviewed and whored out by everyone on yelp, it is my turn. 
 
What can I say, lately I feel as though I'm slipping from 30-21. Why is it that in our 30's, we party MORE these days, celebrate every friend's b-day in droves, and spend at least $100 at dinner on the weekends?  Maybe I need to have kids to settle down, but until then, let the hangovers take over my liver and may grease be my only salvation.

If you wake up on Saturday, left your credit card at the bar and your liver needs a tune up make your way down to good luck dim sum.  There should be a section on Yelp for "best hangover cure".  So I will start it...
scrounge the chang from your pockets, couch coushins, and car seats and order like this:
2 chinese chive dumplings (pan fried and delicious)
1 order shrimp dumpling
1 order chicken shu mai
1 order cilantro & shrimp dumpling

say "1 order" for 3 peices.  If you order "6" you will get "6" orders.

You will leave full, the grease will begin to sooth your stomach, and you may even have enough money left to buy yourself a "hair of the dog" pint.
author: Michele M.

description:
Ditto to what Andrew said, down to the soy sauce! Took wifo out for cheep eats, bill came to $11 and had leftovers. Could of gotten away with $9.
WILL BE BACK
author: montara b.

description:
No frills, serious business Dim Sum for those who know the real deal. I like to get an order and head to the beach to relax with some tea. Obviously it won't all make it to the beach untouched - its a 10min drive after all. 

You can settle your cravings and make your system happy for $3-5 each - hellz yeah. You sure dont pay for the service or decor, but I am here for the dim sum only. OK people watching while in line is always fun here.

Haven't had anything disapointing yet. I can be seen ordering wor teep, siu mai, cha siu bao (usually get a few extra for the fridge), lotus, and chive dumpling w/ shrimp - yummers.

Note: if you use the ordering menu circle the items what you want and if you want two orders put the 2 next to the circle. Each items is an order of 2-4 pieces. Maybe I was tired the 1st time I went but I missed that part and it could save someone else a tiny bit of embarrasement. All good fun though right.
author: Mike C.

description: I've been going here my whole life. First place I think of when someone says "dim sum" is "good luck". Forget those fancy dim sum restaurants where they go around with a cart. This place is definitely better and cheaper! Been loving their sui mai here for as long as I can remember.
author: Zherr-Anne A.

description: This super busy hole in the wall take out dim sum/bakery place is my fave place for Salted pork and preserved egg Jook/Porridge. They also have the best egg tarts here and really good Siu Mai. The only bad thing here is the long lines unless you go in-between their "rush hours". Oh yeah and being in the middle of the busiest part of Clement St means issues with parking and people jaywalking all the time. Gotta love Clement St.!
author: Samantha H.

description:
This is where my family comes for dim sum to go.  Of all the dim sum places on Clement, this one has the best shrimp dumplings (ha gow).  Beef siu mai is yummy and meaty.  They don't skimp on the meat.  Food here is cheap too.  

Best of all, it's easy to order here.  Grab one of the slips of pink paper on the counter and circle the items you want.  It's that simple.  Be prepared for a line though, especially on weekends.
author: Mick S.

description:
Really really cheap lunch...$4, and I was stuffed to the gills.  Unlike other Yelpers, I actually ate in the restaurant rather than doing take out.

Problem?  The dim sum was super greasy and cold!
* Potsticker - totally covered in oil. and really cold.
* Beef Shu Mai - greasy, cold
* Shrimp Crepe - cold, really sticky, not so tasty

The only thing I thought was decent was the Steamed Pork bun.   

I wish I could have put everything in the microwave to heat it up, maybe it'd have been better.  Maybe take out is the way to go.
author: Jane A.

description:
I have to admit, I am not all that savvy on the to-go dim sum style. I'm used to sitting at a restaurant, ideally with a Chinese-speaking friend, and ordering from the carts.

This place is a little bit intimidating if (a) you aren't a native speaker, (b) you don't have the dim sum names down or (c) you aren't a meat-eater, per say.

I stopped by for a late lunch snack, and I know what I love: shrimp dumplings. I saw several variations of this, as well as taro root and other vegetarian-looking items. Of about 6 different items, only 2-3 of them didn't have pork hidden in there somewhere.

I know what you're thinking: dim sum isn't for vegetarians. But, it can be, if you go to a place that has the time and patience to tell you what's inside their food. This place, honestly, does not bank on friendly customer service.

What they do bank on: very cheap, decent dim sum.

All in all, I'd say: I didn't have "good luck" at Good Luck Dim Sum. Better luck next time, I guess....
author: Erin M.

description:
Good God.
I miss Good Luck. 
I miss driving over to Inner Richmond in the morning and trying to find a spot.
I miss the old lady who was always sweeping outside the store a few doors down.
I miss the Har Gow.
I miss the chive dumpling.
I really miss the scallop dumpling.
I miss not really knowing what I am eating some of the time but alway thinking how delicious it is.
I miss the little pink sheets I finally started to fill ot with my basic order before pointing and nodding my way through the rest.
I miss the ladies who used to yell at me but got progressivley nicer (or did I get used to them?)
I miss the hip hop fish store down the street.
I even moss the utter chaos of driving down Clement.
If you are nearby and they aren't out of Baked Chicken Buns yet, could you grab me one? If not, you can always try place behind the bus stop across the street, or the place 2 doors down from that - but they really are mean there.
If you are in SF, go to Good Luck. Their pink awning means yum.
author: Neely M.

description:
Cheap cheap cheap. 3 piece dim sum for $1.50. $2 Porridge. I paid less than $5 for 6 pieces and 2 pork buns (I didn't ask for 2 pork buns and probably got charged so but I guess I can forgive the miscommunication). They're not very stingy with their portions and hook it up with A LOT of meat/shrimp. 

(*looking at review below me*)
Don't go after 2, because by then they run out of all the good dimsum. I'm not sure if the lady who was helping me was just trying to get me out of line or if she was annoyed at the fact that I was asking questions.  Ya, the ambiance is mediocre but you get what you pay for- hole in the wall. For cheap and good dimsum, why complain? If you want a more 'ideal' experience, then pay for sit down.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Yum, yum, yum!  On Sunday morning I made the drive to Good Luck for very cheap take out dim sum.  Normally I head to Y Ben or out to Milbrae for dim sum from the carts.  This was not nearly as fancy, but then again it was 1/3 the price.  

My boyfriend and I got in the already formed line to order.  I have read that the ladies behind the counter are kind of rude, but the lady who helped me was very nice and accommodating.  We got a whole tray of dumplings, buns, and fried balls for $7.50.  That's right, a giant try of yummy dim sum that fed two people for under 8 bucks.
author: Dana H.

description: Clean, fast, fresh, delicious. Reminds me of where we used to go in Oakland Chinatown growing up.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
This place is my favorite dim sum fast food joint!  The food is great and the price is cheap, cheap, cheap!!!!  Although the line is always long, the wait is worth it! I can have lunch and enough saved for dinner for $10!! What? I know!

People give this place less stars because of the service---WELL DUH!! You pay what you get folks! You are not paying for the service, you are paying for the good, cheap food!! Some of the ladies actually speak English, which is a plus! 

I say, bite the bullet, wait in line and chow down at Good Luck Dim Sum!
author: Alvin M.

description: Quick, adequate, decent, but nothing creative.  For the full on dim sum experience, there are much better places (Yank Sing, Ton Kiang)
author: Jay D.

description: I put it down on the dim sum like Godzilla ... I've tried many spots in my town (SF) and this was pretty good. Prepare to have cash and money in the meter to wait in line. (35 mins until i got out the door) I would only get "take-out" ... it would be uncomfortable to eat inside. They don't have sweet & sour sauce which was lame and they have only "BASIC" dim sum nothing crazy fancy .. the only veggie was the mushroom chow mien which was good shit. If your on Clement St and just want a bomb pork bun this is your spot ... don't waste gas on getting here.
author: Marcus B.

description:
Can I give ths place 6 stars?  This is the EPITOME of 100% focus on food instead of frills. The dim sum was off the hook good, the best I've had.  I've been to China and Hong Kong probably a dozen times. This was good Dim Sum.  Also, it was extremely freshly made. Finally, the pricing of the dim sum was unbelievable.  I thought I took a time machine to 1969. My wife and I got way more food than we could eat for a Sunday brunch type meal for $10.30!!!   How do they make money?  Answer is, everything is self service - including cleaning your table when done, and I'm 100% ok with that.  The only complaint I have is that the tile floor was very slippery.... felt like someone mopped the whole restaurant with cooking oil.  I was literally sliding around the whole time. Even when I tried to push the restroom door open, my body would slide backwards instead, like I was on roller skates.  They are asking for a massive injury lawsuit, but I assume this was a one time thing and is not representative of the norm.   

From now, every single trip my wife and I take to SF will include a visit to Good Luck Dim Sum!!!  I'm a fan!!!!!
author: Shemp Howard ..

description: I have been coming to this place for years and it is hands down the best place to get dim sum take out in the Rich. This place really does take me back to when I was a kid. A lot of the other places in the area really don't get the flavor and consistency of the dim sum just right.
author: Jen F.

description:
Try the Crystal Shrimp dumplings and the sesame balls with red bean paste. Yum. They're all that's really worth making sure you get there in time for before they run out. And they do. They run out of things alot, giving people the impression that they don't really sell more than 4 or five things.

Prices are nice and cheap, though the ladies behind the counter are pushy and rude. I suspect you get worse treatment if you do not speak the language. The place could be cleaner, but it isn't authentic dim sum if they actually passed the health code.  The food itself tastes well enough.
author: Clar L.

description:
One of the better dim sum small shops in the city. Definitely try out the shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling and beef balls. Their pot stickers are also good bets. **Recently went in to grab my Sunday noshes and noted that prices have been raised by 20 cents across the board...now 3 pieces = $1.50**

A lot of people are a bit put off by the brusque and blunt ways the workers take your order (which one person notes as soup-Nazi style), but with such a high line detail to turn over, sometimes the people who just hem and haw a-around doesn't help move the line.  Most of the time, you are waiting, so you do have time to decide beforehand. They have English ordering sheets for people who can't speak Cantonese/Mandarin to just circle what they want. Please people... just use those instead of deciding at the last second ^_-.
author: Pauline L.

description:
sunday dim sum done right!

walk in here, point, point point, pay. sit down at a pink table and enjoy all the dim sum you can eat! (note: this place is not all you can eat, but for $10.00 you can feed two people with leftovers)

speaking of leftovers, the to-go bins cost $0.15 extra.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I was starving today after washing cloths. Looked up cheap eats here on Yelp and found great reviews for this place. 

OK, I jump in my car and zoom down to Clement Street. The place wasn't busy and no line around 3:00pm. I notice the food was sitting out uncovered, isn't that some kind of health hazard? I was hungry so I order 3-4 pieces of everything. After paying only $8.00 and some change I started to lose my appetite. She stood there breathing and counting over my food and the place was just filthy (um, gross). 

I rushed home and bit into each one. The Sesame Ball and shrimp dumpling was just OK, two stars. The rest was slimy and bland. Even the BBQ Pork Bun was awful. 

I'm a bit picky when it comes to food. I usually go to restaurants and order the same thing. I don't want to waste food and be disappointed. Why eat if it doesn't taste good?  I ended up throwing it away. 

Just my taste buds, Buds.
author: Debbiedeb W.

description:
Excellent cheap dim sum, inexpensive.

I went here for the first time on Sunday on the way to the Legion of Honor. Got parking right out front. The line was crazy but worth the wait. 

So many items so little time.  We ended up with enough food for 5 people for $13, including the $1 charge for "take-out".

They bundled up our food in a nice pink box.  Since the day was so nice, went for a dim sum picnic.

Would recommend getting dim sum from this place. Not fancy, but the food is great.
author: Ed C.

description:
I have always liked this place...but I don't stop by often anymore.  But for some reason the other day my son really wanted siu mai for breakfast.  And since I didn't eat breakfast yet either I bought some stuff to go...I even got enough food for lunch.

Preserved egg and pork porridge-very tasty and for the price ($2 max)...can't beat it....they even had fried wontons and green onions for it.

Sparerib over rice-ok now for $2.30 an order.....rice...not the best but it was $2.30....they even give you steamed bok choy.  Just heat it up really hot and pour on a packet of soy sauce and you're good to go.

Siu mai-I assumed was good cuz my son ate all 3 and they were mighty pretty looking.

Shrimp and taro dumpling-good...always my favorite here.

So for about $8 I was able to get all that and I was very satisfied.  Also, I saw lots of folks eating in....beats the prices at the restaurants.
author: Allison T.

description: This place was recommended to us by a co-worker who lived in the neighborhood. The food was surprising very good, very fresh and super cheap! It was nice to be able to pick and choose the exact amount that we wanted to eat, even if just one piece of shu mai! My boyfriend claims their sticky rice was the best he ever had and it was huge! The only downside is they don't keep certain items warm after steaming, so some of our food was cold. If you're not a local observe at the beginning before ordering, these asian ladies are BUSY and won't have any patience for you. Also bring cash, they don't take cards.
author: Marilyn V.

description:
$4.60 netted me a baked pork bun, chicken lotus leaf, 3 chive dumpling ($1.50), and a pan fried chive/shrimp dumpling.  tasty, freshly made but not kept piping hot...maybe you have to come at breakfast
items here are cheap, but there is fierce competition along clement
author: Rob C.

description:
Best Ha-gao ever! Great price and quality.

You will need to be in line for their dim sum. The long line will give you enough time to make a decision on your order (whether 3 or 5 orders of ha-gao I should have) and prepare my lines before facing those two chinese ladies (sellers). They are intimidating and hardly smile but they are nice.. trust me. 

This is a small shop. Better for a take-out rather eat-in.
author: Poyz C.

description:
Service sucked but what can you expect from a woman who tried her hardest up-sell to only get $5 from me? There is a lot of effort that goes into making dim sum, but people won't pay big bucks for them. I can see why many dim sum ladies are so rude. 

I got ha gow, cheung fun, and some sesame balls. Ha gow was good. Sesame balls were yum. And cheung fun? The cheung fun was whack. Texture sucked, the shrimp was old and she didn't even give me the soy sauce until I asked for it. No sauce on the cheung fun? That's a deal breaker!
author: Da H.

description: Ok, this is not the fanciest dim sum in town but it's cheap, taste decent, and the portion is huge. The cha sui bao was great.
author: Victor C.

description: I've been grabbing tasty little treats from this place for about 2 years now and usually I would give it 5 stars without question, but my last experience was very disappointing. I was shocked to see there was no line (a first) at 12:00, and the lady taking my order was very rude. When I got my food I couldn't believe it...my pork bun was oily and cold inside. My pork and shrimp sui mai was also cold inside. What gives? The pot stickers were good, but I had to spit the last one out because of sand. Maybe I caught them on a bad day? Maybe they fired the cook? I'm not sure what to think. I'm not sure if I'm going back.
author: Mike M.

description: Cheap...yes.  Fast...yes.   Good...er no.  This is not a restaurant.  It's a take out with several tables if you care to eat here.  We ate here and the food we bought was served on paper plates.  Not something I'd recommend bringing your new date to.  I was unimpressed with the pork siu mai.  Not as flavorful as the ones I've had down in Orange County.  The spare rib was plain.  The shrimp dumpling was the same; I can't tell that there was shrimp in there.  Everything was moist and soft but lacks flavor.  I think that sums up this place.
author: Norcalscot L.

description: So cheap and good. The ladies behind the counter were very helpful and polite. You don't have to dim sum when you are expected to - go later in the day....no wait. Good luck...
author: Ramin R.

description:
Simply the best Shark Fin dumplings around. Throw in some solid Shrimp Har Gao, and Siu Mai; maybe a baked pork bun STILL UNDER $5.

Perfect in the morning after a hard work out.
author: Brad C.

description:
Mmmmm! One of my fav Saturday morning excursions is to get out to Clement early in the morning and browse the stores, then stop by Good Luck Dim Sum and order a ton of stuff to take home!  
I love their sui mai, char shu bao, egg rolls, har gao! And what a bargain! And don't confuse the wonderful women! If you circle an item on the menu, it is one order, not one piece.  (eg: one order sui mai= 3 pieces.)
They are very efficient for how packed it always is! And looks so clean!
author: Scott H.

description:
This is the place to go for dim sum on the run. 
I always stop by here when I get a chance. 
You can't beat the price.
Food is great but I wouldn't recommend staying and eating here
author: d o.

description:
Over 760 reviews and I wanted to get in on the game too!  All I read on the other reviews was "Cheap" and "Good".  That's all I needed to head over to Richmond to find out what all the fuss is about.

What I didn't read was the pink slip process of ordering.  But there wasn't a line and they were fine with a verbal order.  The ladies have been noted as dim sum nazis.  I've been to hogie places in New Jersey that are pretty similar so it didn't really phase me.  In fact, at the hogie place I would stand outside and squint to read the menu because as soon as you step in the door they start yelling at you if you don't know what you want.  So GLDS ladies really weren't that bad in my opinion.   You just have to be ready to jump in there.

That said, GLDS is a cut-to-the-chase kinda spot.  Know what you want, order it, eat and enjoy.  Don't worry if the table is sticky or why the soy sauce is almost like teriyaki.  Don't worry about whether you have to go bad enough to brave the bathroom.  Don't worry about if the item is too greasy or too doughy...just eat and enjoy.  Seriously.  It's cheap and good.  That's all you need to know ;)
author: Sonic D.

description:
Yelp reviewers have it right.  The staff at Good Luck are rude.  My friends and I call them the Dim Sum Nazis in reference to the Soup Nazi episode of Seinfeld.

My friend went there once to get food for his work crew.  He ordered over $40 worth of dim sum, which at Good Luck is a lot of food.  As they were packing the food, he asked for forks.  Rather than simply drop a few in, there was a bunch of grumbling and a "I have to check."  For plastic forks!  My friend was totally pissed and has vowed never to go back, but I can't help laughing at the story every time he re-tells it as a way to wave off prospective Good Luck customers.  But he's got it right, if customers don't know what they're doing or stray from a very fixed set of steps in the transaction, there's grousing.  Hence the Dim Sum Nazi reference.  

But the dim sum is good and worth waiting for.  Don't eat there (unless you like sitting next to a perpetual line of folks getting dim sum to-go.  The place is a bit dirty, but with the out-flow of food, it's gotta be fresh.
author: QuodE D.

description:
I've been coming here for years.

For me, it's the best overall Dim Sum on Clement.  And, probably the best take out Dim Sum in San Francisco.  Not only is the food outstanding; but, the prices are very reasonable.

They have a few tables in the back if you want to dine in.  But, you still have to stand in line first to order your food.

When I don't have enough time to wait in the long lines, Wing Lee Bakery is a good alternative http://www.yelp.com/biz/wing-lee-bakery-san-francisco
author: Roy C.

description:
when I am in the neighborhood, I always stop and buy  dim sum for lunch, light bites and/or take home for later muchies at home, it is inexpensive  and tasty than what they do sell at Ranch 99, or Marina Market near my home.. A great place to stop and buy a few items on your way to the golf course(Presidio), a snack in between holes..
Unfortunately very busy in the morning, but  it goes pretty fast as this morning there were 4 gals working behind the counter... But a must stop when you are in this chinatown...mmmmgooood
author: Tee L.

description:
One of the best Dim Sum locations on Clement!

The Dim Sum is so cheap, whenever I go I usually pay less than $7 for a box of dim sum that can feed me well for 2 meals. Plus, its yummy :)

I'd dock a half of a point for cleanliness, and a half of a point for difficulty communicating with the workers (but then again, a lot of the food locations on clement are not very cleanly, and more than half of the time its difficult to communicate with the workers).
author: Shelley A.

description: Cheap, good and greasy. Otherwise, nothing too special and in the scheme of dim sum offered in SF, there is definitely better but it comes with higher prices.
author: Midori S.

description:
This is what real dim sum should taste like!  I absolutely love this place.  Ya, ya, ya the ladies who work the counter are anything but nice, but their dim sum is perfect and I will put up with the lack of (or rather the absence of) any sort of customer service in order to satisfy my quite frequent cravings.  

My faves are the steamed pork buns, shrimp and chrystal dumplings,  and the BEST beef shu mai!  I also love the lotus ball, it is great with a cup of hot coffee.  And I even prefer the soy sauce they put out on the tables (which I am sure must be the generic and cheap soy sauce) instead of the packets they give you if you get your order to go.
author: Violet S.

description: Excellent dim sum.  Slow-moving, long line.  Hostile staff.  Still gets 4 stars.
author: Bonnie C.

description: Has anyone noticed the quality of this place going down a bit? I notice it mostly in the shu mai; it tastes a little funny to me now (and this has happened more than once). I still love this place, but I'm knocking off a star.
author: Leigh R.

description: Really good food at an amazingly cheap price without the glitz or glam of a "fancy" restaurant.
author: Chris B.

description: The Dim Sum at this place will leave you coming back for more. This is my go to spot for cheap, and delicious dim sum. They have a wide variety to choose from, all of which are good. Check this place out next time you are in the area and have $2-5 to spend. You will get MORE than your money's worth.
author: Nick C.

description:
Pros
1. Food tasted great, especially the pork sui mai (definitely order this!!!)
2. Food was cheap. example, $1.50 for 3 pieces of sui mai

Cons
1. Place is dirty with few places to sit
2. Service was bad

Overall
Perfect place for a quick sit down bite or takeout. Its worth trying because its so cheap!

Tip:
If you're planning to dine in with a group I recommend having someone grab a table while someone waits in line. There's always a line at this place. So by the time you have the food, your friend would have reserved a place to sit.
author: John F.

description:
As far as the abundance of Dim Sum places in SF goes, this is one of the better ones outside of Chinatown. To Basi L. for dissing the ambiance/sanitation -- what did you expect? A fancy dim sum bar? Honestly, it's a tiny little place that serves a bazillion Asian people in Clement street. It's clean compared to the other dingy Dim Sum places you see around the city. To enjoy, I think that this is something that takes getting used to --- possibly growing up eating and taking out dim sum in places such as this. Seriously, have you ever seen any people eating inside besides the usual crowd of old men reading Chinese newspaper? I haven't. That's because most people take out.

The food is awesome for dim sum this side of the city. I think the last time I had some was last week when I made a quick run for breakfast before driving away for my trip. The ha chern was a little bit on the too thick side but maybe it was too early in the morning.
author: tammy m.

description:
This is my favorite dimsum on Geary between Arguello and 10th Ave.

Adequate. Nothing tastes weird. Shrimp dumplings, shumei, etc are generally at room temperature. I know it's not up to health regulations, but at least it tastes fresh.

I go there frequently because it is cheap, predicable, and I haven't gotten sick yet.
author: Pandora B.

description: This was the 1st time I've ever had Dim Sum and the food was amazing. Little hole in the wall walk up counter. They don't speak English so forget about asking what to get, but it's so cheap, you just kinda pick a few things you'd think you'd like, and dive in. We liked almost everything we got. The egg rolls were disappointing, but decent. Super cheap. Now I just need to go to a traditional place with the carts and everything to compare, but the food was FANTASTIC.
author: Kathleen T.

description: This place is located in Chinatown #2, according to a family member who is a native San Franciscan. $11 for Dumplings that my girlfriend and I shared. We had about 18 items. They were out of this world. We tried pretty much every kind. Go here if you want great food for a cheap price. Cheap. Delicious. Amazing. Services was average, but... it's a small shop that stays pretty busy so what do you expect.
author: Vincent F.

description: Good food, bad service. It took 10-15 minutes to get through the line. Once I actually gave my slip of paper to the woman behind the counter, she worked at a snails pace to gather my order. Although she looked overworked, it was no excuse for such slow service when the line was 15 people long. As a vegetarian, I was only able to eat the fried noodles and nibble on other parts of the dishes. I think my friends enjoyed the food. It's a fun and different concept of getting sunday morning dim sum. I would recommend going to experience it but I don't see myself going back.
author: Andy C.

description: I love dim sum and so does my boyfriend. The prices are incredibly cheap and you can get enough food for days. The dim sum is super tasty and there are many choices to choose from. The women who work there are pushy, but when one of the sausage rolls was delivered to us cold, they were very nice and immediately delivered a new hot roll. The line and the simplicity of the place adds to the "hole in the wall" feel but that's part of the experience. We waited in line but it didn't take very long and all of the food was excellent. Wear a jacket in winter- it's cold inside. If I could have my way, I'd love a real restaurant with comfortable seating to be attached, but again, this adds to the experience.
author: Carly O.

description: Cheap, Delicious, and BIG portion dim sum! Long lines, but well worth it. Much better than a sit down yum cha place in terms of price and quality. As authentic as dim sum can get
author: Jon T.

description: Cheap dim sum and very good!  Service isn't the greatest but I wouldn't expect it either. You can feed 2 people for under $10. Parking can be a pain during peak time. If you don't mind cold or semi old dim sum, you can get great deals when they about to close because they will try to get rid of what they can to make an extra few bucks.
author: vinnie t.

description: The porridge containers are now smaller -- 20oz vs. 24oz. (a 17% reduction, for those of you with a mathematical bent).  It's still a good deal (still $1.80), just not as good as it used to be.  It doesn't affect my rating at all.
author: Eric W.

description:
How many pork buns and sesame balls can you stuff yourself with? On a tour of Clement, we picked up two pork buns, a sesame ball and a soy milk to hold us over until dinner at Good Luck. A bit down the road we picked up another sesame ball and at another place grabbed a mini hot dog wrapped in pastry. Combined, these purchases cost me a grand total of $3.60.

Good Luck Dim Sum's tasty treats definitely outranked the rest. Although not at all calculated or scientific in this instance, next time I promise to do a very scientific dim sum taste test and stop at each and every dim sum outlet on Clement and absolutely stuff myself.
author: Jenny T.

description: Whenever I am in the area, I pick up my usual.  I always stock up on the egg custard.  On the weekend, they make it out of egg whites, very smooth and tender.  The price is affordable.  The service is typical, some are nicer than others.
author: T K.

description:
Oh ya , it's good alright.  As a GLDS veteran, let me offer some advice.  Bring a pen or pencil !  Yep, that's right.  Grab a pink order form / menu from the counter, line up and circle the items you want.  Once you reach the counter, which will be about 15-20 minutes, just hand the form to the lady and you'll be sure to get the best pieces.  And please have your cash ready.  Dim sum plus a drink for 2 is usually $11 for us.  The shrimp dumpling (har gow) is as good as any in Hong Kong.

For those of you who stand in line mindlessly and then ho-hum through your order and have a shit load of questions about what is in a pot sticker, please find another dim sum joint NOW, especially the dumb red head behind me last week who yap on her cell phone the whole time only to reach the counter and say "oh, is it MY turn?".

Our favorite Saturdays are when we pick up dim sum here, drive over to the Conservatory of Flowers and picnic on the lawn while the dog waits for his har gow.  I love San Francisco.
author: Beautiful B.

description:
A mixed review is a good term. I saw many locals there, but the food is all right. The first time I ate there, it was so dirty but yesterday it was much better. The people are kind of rude and loud. I like many other dim sum places around town. The shrimp is good but if you do not eat red meat do not have the chicken tea roll sticky rice or the veggie dim sum the both have Chinese sausage.


The food is good if you do not mind the help and the meat in the chicken and veggie stuff. Great taste!
author: Thomas O.

description:
I am not quite sure about the dim sum.... but the service is POOR, really POOR.  I mean, I don't expect great service at a place like this, but I am chinese and I feel embarrassed and misrepresented by these SLOW WORKING chinese ladies.  Usually, when you see a long line, you would like to work faster and get even more business, but whoever hired these ladies, they are just ruining your business.

I usually prefer to eat down the street, where the dim sum is better, more fresh and at least better service.  The reason why I decided to come to this place was, I kept seeing long lines and heard that it's "good".  Before this previous experience, I tried lining up before, but I was pissed at watching these woman work.  So therefore, I gave up lining up.  Today there was no line, so I decided to try.  The woman was RUDE and I asked for tea (which I had no problem paying for), however, I speak fluent cantonese, yet, I'm not sure if she knows how to comprehend it.  So therefore, they just gave me a cup and NO TEA BAG... then, as I was getting my hot water, I asked another woman about the tea bag.. and I was being nice about it.  And they were like "blah blah blah", so I loudly said "nevermind".  I would think there is some kind of service recovery, but no.  Next thing you know, you are sitting there eating the dim sum on a filthy dirty tray, with just a piece of plastic under your food... AND THE SIU MAI WAS COLD, although it came from the steaming rack!  After eating my dim sum, and staring at my dirty tray and continuing to watch these woman work.. I LOST MY APPETITE.  

First and last try here.... I'm going back to my normal routine!  Down the street!  TOTAL DISAPPOINTMENT.  If service was poor, food was good, it would be different, but the food didn't make up for my major disappointment.
author: H L.

description: Staffs were RUDE,RUDE,RUDE.  My take out  Siomi got a rotten stinky smell when I bit on it.  Baked Barbeque pork bun was ok. I guessed, I got what I paid for. Cheap food but poor quality.
author: Leya P.

description:
I went there once in a blue moon for several years, but this last time was the worst. 

1. Cold food ... including the taro puffs that came straight out of the kitchen... go figure.

2. Rude staff ... when you eat there, you get a tray with saran wrap liner.  I got chewed out by the pony-tailed sales lady for not saving the tray-liner when I went back to buy more food. Foolish me, I used the old one as a garbage wrapper in clearing the tray before deciding to buy and try one more item. 

Given the current economy, you can get better food at sit-down dim sum restaurants for pennies more.
author: eastbay y.

description: I don't know what all the hype is about.  The food is not bad, but to me it's not worth it to wait in line for it.  Maybe I will have to try something else, but it's just old school dim sum that you can get any where else in any chinatown.
author: K K.

description: One of the better cheap dim sum spots in the outer richmond. There's a lot of dim sum places on Clement to choose from but this one is my favorite. And don't worry if you get yelled at by the mean lady. It's part of the experience!
author: Jb M.

description: Very tasty and cheap.  Lack of beverage choices is a bit of a downer, otherwise this is an awesome spot for dim sum.
author: Mikey P.

description:
Less greasy than every other authentic & cheap (ie NOT Yank Sing) dim sum place in SF. Certainly cleaner and fresher tasting than the Stockton St places. 

Line is long, and the ladies move slow, so this isn't a quick in-and-out type of place. But a lot of their dumplings are steamed, so you can feel relatively ungreasy after a meal.

I'd recommend the chicken shiu-mai, steamed pork buns, and crystal dumplings (shrimp+pork+chives).

Oh, and you can stuff yourself for less than $8. Literally.
author: jason e.

description: Ha how was cold and stale. Last thing you need in the morning from a decent dim sum joint.
author: Subho C.

description: Best dim sum we've ever had in NorCal. It was cheap too! Service was kind of rude but who cares. The parking sucks but you can get in and out of the restaurant pretty quickly. Limited amount of seating inside but we were able to get a table. We would definitely go back here every time we're in SF!
author: Jon H.

description: I really don't know how this place got 4 stars. Ya its super cheap but so are A lot of dirty line-based dim sum places. The staff was rude. The steamed pork buns flavorless, the shu mai and shrimp dumplings dry..AND there wasn't a lot of selection! Additionally, the place was dirty and I dropped a fork and was given HELL for having to ask for another one. Actually.. I feel like giving it one star only that seems a little too harsh.
author: Sophia S.

description:
This place the rice soup(con-gee) is good. But the dim sum is hits or missed, mostly missed. (cold & greasiest)
The service is the worst in the 10 blocks radius never a morning smile :( . I agree with one of the yelp er that across the street the place call wing lee is better
author: anthony b.

description:
they ran out of the chives/shrimp dumplings, and she summarily crossed it off my order, but then i noticed the pan-fried ones, which was what i really wanted anyway.  i asked in mandarin, and she answered in cantonese, but she understood me, which is amazing because my mandarin is terrible.  good shrimp, but could use more chives.  3/$1.80.

turnip cake was good.  except for bits of stuff, this is the "smooth" variety.  some places shred, but not pureed, the turnip so it has some texture.  this and the chives box... tastes better reheated in a pan (no oil) at home, so it's really hot.

chicken & sausage with sticky rice, wrapped in lotus leaf.  the rice looked kind of... white... but the whole thing had good flavor, and lots of meat compared to other places.  at $2.40, it's one of the more expensive items on the menu, but i had to have it...

i resisted adding an egg tart to my order.  i'm so proud of myself...
author: XinYi X.

description: To go dim sum, I go here! It's good, steamy hot and cheap to go!
author: Karen T.

description:
This place is very consistent, which highly determines its repeat factor.
As others have already said...
Yes, it's a grab-n-go dim sum place (no fanfare, no carts, but you point, pick and ask nicely to the ladies behind the counter), making it a must-stop during my Clement Street visit.
Yes, it's cheap prices are a great plus at $1.50/3pc for most of the dim sum, making it guilt-free to fill that big pink box an then share (or not...).
Yes, it's run by ladies who speak curtly to get the long line moving and who may sometimes forget health codes.  But even they are consistent.
Yes, their dishes are consistent.  The dumplings (har gow, shu mai, veggie filled dumplings, and pot stickers) are the best!  The baos, or steamed buns, are good too.  The fried stuff -- sesame balls and taros -- are not bad.  These aren't all the dishes, but just the main notables.
Hmm, they charge for tea.  So I take it all to-go and enjoy with tea brewed from elsewhere.
author: Carol K.

description: I waited for about 45 minutes in line today to get my dim sum. I hate lines and I hate waiting in them even more. Good Luck is totally worth it though. I don't care that they're a bit like dim sum nazis because anyone has an ample amount of time to get their order ready while they wait in that damn line; if you don't, then you deserve to get yelled at. I actually like the ladies here because of their efficiency and no-nonsense attitude. They remind me of my mom. Hehehe...
author: Queenie C.

description: Great bang for the buck! I've never had such great tasting dim sum for such a great price! Come here if you want to get your money's worth on quality dim sum for an amazing price. (:
author: Tee M.

description:
Just to level-set, this is take-out.

There are many places like this one on Clement St. in San Francisco that have a take-out counter with Dim Sum-type dumplings. I've tried 4-5 of them.

Good Luck Dim Sum is below average for take-out. Their pork-filled items were kind of mealy, chewy, maybe even undercooked.

If it's steamed dumplings you want, go half a block away to Gourmet Dim Sum (see my review for that).

Good Luck Dim Sum is definitely efficient, though: you mark your order on a pre-printed piece of paper. So if you're not sure how to pronounce something, this insures that you get what you asked for...
author: Gregg K.

description: Cheaps!  You better call in your order because there's always someone "me" who will buy the whole store.  Give me 100 orders of the beef siu mai.  Thanks!
author: Winsor L.

description: This place is great! I work with a 12-13 year-olds. I took about 8 of them on a trip to Good Luck. I was able to feed all of them for under $10! Of course, I also included myself in this amazing treat. So good! So cheap!
author: Nancy M.

description: Incredible dim sum, I second other comments, as good as Yank Sing or Koi Palace - this is definitely a take out dim sum place. The dim sum holds up very well, we picnicked & ate in Golden Gate park. Only in SF! Everything was good even after steaming up in box, though some of paper wrappers stick to dim sum. Even good the next day for lunch, who knew dim sum could be leftovers? Highlights were bbq bun, coconut dessert bun (crazy good), sesame buns and any of the traditional shrimp dim sum. Dim sum comes wrapped up in pink or white takeout box like a cake. Zero atmosphere inside and guaranteed long line. This will remind some of you of queues in China. Go in, grab a pink menu and pencil, write down what sounds good and hand to ladies. Food for 2 hungry hippos and leftovers the next day + plus two drinks = a whopping $12.60.
author: Steve B.

description: Ok, it's pure deliciousness if you're into the Dim Sum thing. Prices are most likely unbeatable. And it's so busy on weekends that you're guaranteed to get your DS fresh. But first time shoppers, beware, these biatches who work the store are just that - mean and grumpy and snappy and grrrrrrrr. So circle your orders on the menu you snag on the counter and smile. Don't even bother asking for chopsticks -they'll end up wedged in your eyeball.
author: Ali L.

description:
Contrary to what almost everyone who meets me thinks at first glance, I am NOT filipina! 
I'm 100% Chinese(-American). Dim sum has always been a huge part of my life, not exactly by choice, but I'm not complaining. =)

* X's below mark what we get here often for quick and cheap eats.

(Phonetic spellings are in brackets):
Pork Dumpling [ siu my ]  X
Beef Dumpling  X
Shrimp Dumpling [ har gow ]  X
Glutinous Rice with Chicken (and Sausage) wrapped in lotus leaves [ nor my guy ]  X  (love sticky rice)
Shark Fin Dumpling [ yu chee gow ]
BBQ Pork Bun [ cha siu bao ]  X
Spring Roll [ chun goon ]
Sesame Ball [ jean dway ]
Taro Ball [ woo gock ]  (X ooh)
White Turnip Cake [ law bahk go ]  (X yes, please)
Chive Dumplings [ jean gow choy bang ]
Dried Shrimp Rice Rolls [ jean ha my chong fun ]  X
Congee/Rice Porridge [ jook ]
Sweet rice ball w/ coconut on outside and peanut filling inside  (X yes!!)
Egg Custard Bun [ nye wong bao ]
Egg Custard Tart [ dahn taht ]  X
Do they have that spongey white dessert that's usually cut into big triangles? Maybe that's the "Crisp White Sugar Cake" on the menu in local business photos. (I haven't been to this location in so long. I just see whatever the fam brings home).

- The items listed above are foods that *should* be available from any dim sum place to take away in the dark pink box, and wrapped up with string or pink plastic string.

I looove sweet rice balls with coconut on the outside and peanut filling on the inside.

I also love BBQ pork buns. Not chicken. Do not buy me chicken buns.

(Psst, Egg Custard Tarts are supposedly the best ever at Golden Gate Bakery http://www.yelp.com/biz/golden-gate-bakery-san-francisco).

*****
Good Luck Dim Sum - THE #1 Spot to Get Take-Out Dim Sum!!!
*****
author: Kay N.

description: I gave the jook (rice porridge) a shot here b/c of Lolia S.' recommendation. It's excellent, just as good as she described. The texture was nice and thick and they give you plenty of tasty preserved egg and pork. I tried a few of the dumplings and they were ok, good enough for takeout standards. They also have cheap rice plates for like 2 bucks and change. The ladies here were kinda mean to me though, so minus a star. I'd still definitely come back for the jook.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Wow! There is something to be said for eating dim sum in a restaurant and having to wait for those little baskets of heaven to come.......because like a little piggy, I just went to town at Good Luck Dim Sum.....
When there is a bar/counter situation with dim sum, do not order everything you want at once, because once you sit down, you'll end up hoovering it down before you can utter "good luck."
Dim sum here is cheap, and comes in threes, three this, three that $1.40....The food quality is good, and the dim sum is YUMMY! While later in the day it can be a little less hot than I like (piping hot), it is still delicious!
I warn you, do not order everything at once....take it slow fellow yelpers, because enjoying dim sum is much more satisfying than just shoving it in.....well, I did just shove it in, and I am one happy piggy.....a very full piggy....but I'm sure I would have enjoyed it more if i had taken a breath in between little dumplings of goodness.
PS...this place is a hole in the wall.....go for the food, not the decor...
author: Bianca L.

description: I went with a friend and was surprised how god it was. Try it and you will come back for more!!!
author: Brandi R.

description:
A whole bunch of my friends gathered and we went here one day. Just for kicks..never been except for dim sum to go - which I might add isn't half bad. Anyways - we're eating a whole boat load of food. Nothing overly special but nothing bad. It was just good food. I remember the place more because of the discussion that took place because of the food. 

Let me set the background here...my ex is sitting between me and my brother. She then asks my brother...
"Would you like any pork?"
My brother looks at me from the corner of his eye and gets my attention. I know he's full because he's always been a light weight. He then says..."I'm sorry, I don't eat pork." And we all thought that was that. 
The ex then asks "Why not?"
My brother looks at me annoyed..."Because pigs are dirty animals!" I get that upset stomach feeling - knowing full well that nothing good will come of this.
"You know, cows are just as dirty as pigs are!"
"No, I didn't know that, but that doesn't change the fact that pigs are dirty animals and I don't want any."
"But cows are dirty too and you ate cow earlier."
"Ok..." He looks at me with a wink and proceeds with "I don't eat pork because I was traumatized when I was a kid..ever since I watched Charlotte's Web..."
"OIC...nevermind." She then excused herself to go to the bathroom. 
Immediately after she left, the whole table was like WTF!?!?! MY brother looks at me and asks what her problem was. I asked her why he perpetuated the conversation.....even though I later did admit it was kind of funny.....buhahahaha

In any case the pork was really good. ;D
author: John-Michael C.

description: Sorry, this place is just OK, and is only an acceptable option if it's too late for the above average fare, and/or you want to eat for super cheap.  The food quality is passable, but the major issue I have is that the food is not that hot.  That's a big problem for me.  Also not enough condiments.
author: Gregory C.

description: I brought my coworker here for lunch, and between the two of us, we paid $7 for enough food to fill us up.  We ordered 2 fried sesame balls, 2 steam BBQ pork buns, an order of pork sui mai, shrimp dumpling, and the shrimp taro dumpling.  This place is fast, convenient, and cheap.  In terms of the service and seating area....not the best, but it'll do if you want something quick, or if you take it to-go.
author: Lisa C.

description: It was my first Dim sum experience.  And I liked it.  I am giving 4 starts just for their food and the great prices.  Customer service on the other hand was horrible.  I asked one of the employees to point me to their restroom, she looked at me like i was asking her to give me one of her organs like 'who do you thing you are?' look.  another fellow customer quickly jumped in and said 'i think theres one in the back'.  Anyhow the service was needless to say bad, didn't get water, or the sauces on the table refilled...but hey the food was delicious.  we got 2 trays full of food for $19..Awesome!
author: Tania N.

description: Nom nom nom. If you're in the mood for a quick, cheap, yummy dim sum fix, this is your place. Service is terse, but the $1.60 per order is rock bottom. Three people can come here and feast for less than $10 total. Mind you, greasy, but so good.
author: Jo H.

description: Grumpy ladies dishing out the best cheap dim sum in the city. Prepare to stand in a long line and eat elsewhere -- even on a slow day, the four or five tables in the back fill up.  I recommend the sweet rice ball -- actually a savory treat filled with short rice, diced pork, and vegetables which makes a fine light lunch, a steal at sixty cents!
author: Tailypo W.

description:
outstanding and dirt cheap dim sum.  i love it so much that i brave the narrow restaurant with my HUGE jogging stroller just so i can get a nibble of these steamed bits of wonderful.

take-out only and they are closed on tuesdays.
author: Christina K.

description:
great lo mein for $2!
three dim sum pieces for $1.50...
you can't really go wrong here!
would have gotten five stars if the food was served piping hot, which it's not (warmish is the best i've gotten thus far in my mere two visits) but man it's GOOD. 
the line out the door at 11am tells all. next time perhaps i'll get a whole feast instead of a snack and bring it home and heat it up...
check it out, you won't be disappointed and you can't beat the value!
author: Wendy X.

description: If you want to spend the bulk of your money on drugs and still be able to eat regularly... plan on going to good luck dim sum every blurry eyed morning. Or hit it up casually, like once a month, and enjoy the taste and the rotting feeling in your gut. Either way.. I'd recommend 3 dollars and some acidopholous for after.
author: Stephen B.

description: cmon...a zagat rated dim sum togo place??? you cant go wrong....bao..fried taro..har gow..pork dumplings that just melt in your mouth....if i had a gripe then it would only be that they dont take cards here...strictly cash based.. but its ok..for under twenty bucks you can feed an army with these things.then crash at the nearby golden gate park or chrissy field for food coma.... well done for dimsum! 4/5 judochops hiya.
author: Dustin G.

description: Excellent as well as cheap! The ladies that take your orders usually arent the greatest..but if you look past that...the food is great. Their juk..not so good. Great place to take your dim sum to go! Not so great if you sit down at their tables and start using their dark nasty soy sauce to smother your goodies in.
author: Prescott T.

description: I love good luck dim sum! My good friend, Betsy introduced me to it, and I have been hooked ever since!!! Soooo delish! Tons of choices, and AMAZING prices is always a plus!!! Yum!
author: Chrissy A.

description: Good Luck Dim Sum is great not just because the food is fresh & delicious but it's also very reasonably priced. I could say that the food is good for the price -- but I've been to other dim sum restaurants that charged more than twice what they charge at Good Luck & the food was not much better. Everything I've ever had at Good Luck Dim Sum has been very good. I recommend that you go with three people because most of what they have comes in threes. Get a variety of things & share them
author: Ian F.

description: I was hurting from a night of too much vodka and jack.  I know now not to mix those two together.  I give Good Luck Dim Sum credit for helping me back into the land of the living.  My friend was good enough to go and wait in line on a Saturday morning and came out a half hour later with a ton of food for less than $10.  3 of us ate pieces throughout the day and by about 6pm, I felt normal again.   We had potstickers, pork shu mai and shrimp and chive as well as just shrimp dumplings.  All great.  We also got the fried sesame balls and the custard tart things.  I didn't have any of those but I heard they were good.
author: Seong P.

description:
I love Dim Sum, love it even better when its cheap.
The workers only speak chinese, so you need to fill out a pink sheet at the end of the counter when you first walk in. The lines are long, but well worth it.  Menu is in English and Chinese. Not a lot of places to sit down. Best to get to go and then take home.
author: Jeanne D.

description: Had a craving for dim sum so I checked out this takeout place. (yes, grab a menu and circle your choices when in line, and don't forget its cash only!) They have the usual suspects on the menu.  Great prices. I thought I might just try a few things... that doesn't work with dim sum. So I ordered a ton and the price was only $15.50. Incredibly fresh and made delicately. A bit greasy, but not so much as other places I've tried. My daughter and I ate some of it for lunch, then a good friend surprised us with a visit and had a meal out of the leftover dim sum, and then there's still enough for another lunch. Amazing!
author: Vicky P.

description: Horrible, abusive attitudes.  Cold dim sum heated in a microwave.  Filthy, stanky place.  Gotta disagree with the Yelp tide here.  Won't be going back to this sucky place.
author: Tim A.

description:
good luck to you, indeed, if you get hot dim sum.  

most of the time (at least in my previous experiences here), they'd sell you the ones that have been sitting there for a while... steam no longer escaping from the inner environment of that hargow or siumai...if i had the time, i'll wait for the fresh batch...other than that
they get a 2nd star coz it's cheap... you can get full from less than $3 worth of food.
author: Grace M.

description: Dim Sum Nazis to the max. I would drive from SFSU to Good Luck Dim Sum every weekend to happily get my box full of delish goodies. Like many places, you dont need to spend much money to get enough food to feed you all day. If you are a first timer here, I suggest to take someone along who had been before to show you the ropes. The ladies in here dont play games and get pissy if you are slow at ordering. While some people see this as mean, I think it adds to the "charm" of the place hehe. Totally worth their coldness. Loves it.
author: Spencer N.

description: Wow what a great price and I love the brutal Chinese efficiency of the place.  Got stuffed and had plenty to take home here today after Marissa and Ed treated me to some delicious and anonymous dim sum.  Didn't quite know what was what but it was good, cheap and filling - score!
author: Gene X.

description: lots of places for dim sum in this neighborhood but this our go to place for quick pick up to take home.  My favorites are the pork buns (steamed and baked) and hargow (shrimp dumpling).
author: WinnJess E.

description: I walked down Clement until I saw the place with the most people in it and figured all those people can't be wrong....and they weren't!  GLDS kills it.  Very minimal shop completely out-shined by the rock solid dim sum they pump outta the kitchen.   Easy. Fast. Cheap.  Just how I like it.
author: Chard M.

description: I've been here a few times: and I must say that there are few places as cheap and as good. We got a LOT of food the last time, the woman behind the counter actually stopped feeding us because our tray began to overflow. The food was great, but the help was a little surley. There were places to sit but as they were "cleaning up" they were resentful that we were there and showed it by hitting our chairs.
author: Benjamin M.

description:
one of my favorite low key urban excursions:

pack large tupperware, cutlery, picnic blanket, a thermos of strong black tea.

jump on bike and ride through golden gate park.

head over to green apple books on clement.

allow myself to indulge craving for food of my people.

head over to good luck dim sum. 

hand them the tupperware (cos fuck pink plastic bags) and order 
ha gao (shrimp dumplings)
jeen gau choy gao (fried shrimp + chive dumplings)
choy yook bao (mini pork + cabbage buns)
jeen dui (those superfried sesame-covered mochi balls with sweet red bean paste inside). 

oh, and the potstickers - possibly some of the best in the city. 

ride up 6th avenue, back into ggp.

find a good place to kick it, people watch, feel the grass beneath my feet, bask in sunshine, read my new books, and do 'yum cha' al fresco. 

it's pretty quality dim sum considering it's takeout stylee. exterior of steamed dumplings is usually delicate and chewy. interior is more about the shrimp or pork that's supposed to be inside, as opposed to the mouthfuls of lard (ew) you might find at other dim sum joints. and their crispy fried stuff, while still a tad greasy, is divine.

just moderate your intake. this is some heavy stuff.
author: Winter R.

description: I think the food is alright.  I've definitely had better.  I guess it's worth what you pay for.
author: Duckie A.

description:
not your traditional dim sum place, but still very excellent.  instead of people comign around in carts as you sit, you wait in line and order everything at once.  its not quite the same viseral experience as your more traditional dim sum, but that really isn't the point here.

good dim sum at unbelievably cheap prices.  you cannot argue with this.
author: Steve S.

description:
i live in the east bay and i can't find dim sum as good as good luck.  however,
the service stinks big time.  i was there monday, president's day and the line was very long.  there was only two cashier and they were in a conversation while customers were getting impatient.  it took me half an hour to get out of there.  i'm chinese and i think their manners are awful so how would the non-asians react to their rudeness.
author: casey j.

description: I haven't been here in over a year, but it has never been far from my mind. When I think of the perfect Dim Sum place, this little hole in the wall always comes first to mind. There's no waiting for the good dish to come carting around because it's a take out place, so service is quick and easy. Fill out the card, pay the price, and enjoy some delicious dim sum.
author: Jamie B.

description: This is the only place for dim sum on Clement Street. We ate at a lot of dim sum houses and restaurants on Clement and this little take out place is the best for the money. Our regular dim sum restaurant for dining in is the Golden Mountain on Broadway between Stockton and Grant. It is a little loud but a good standard for dim sum.
author: Bebe L.

description: While the dim sum are slightly better than other places, service is terrible. Yes, I know what to expect meaning I am not expecting much service at all, but i waited 45 min in line! Yes, my mom made me wait in line for 45 min. OMG! There were three people serving up front with only one of the lady really moving the line along, the other two were moving as if they didn't have their coffee in the morning. My mom would not budge and go elsewhere so I was stuck there with an empty stomach. I don't care how good the food are, there is no reason to wait that long for take out. Unless everything else on Clement are closed, is not likely that I will step foot in this place again.
author: Sandy N.

description: My wife and I love coming here even if they don't listen to you and yell at you. I guess it is part of the charm. I could care less though and I just go with the flow. They have unbelievable chow mein, pot stickers, pork dumplings, and egg rolls. I know they have even more great items but I cannot partake because I am allergic to shellfish. Bummer. This is probably your best bang for your buck in the city. If you spend $8 for one person you can feast for a couple of days. Places like Good Luck make me grateful I live in San Francisco.
author: Nick H.

description: Would be an easy 5 if i didn't often see kitchen staff with facial pubic hair, picking their nose, coughing up smurfs on the floor, but you know...maybe that is the magic behind this place.  i have to always do one order of the fried taro puffs, siu mai, ha gao, potstickers, chives, and one cha siu bao and the sticky rice...the proof is in da pudding AND no matter what anybody tells you the wait is worth it  ^ ^
author: omar b.

description:
Hey I don't mind a mean Chinese lady as long as the grub is cheap, and that's exactly what you get at this small hole in the wall that makes you wonder if your overall experience, though good, may be a bit unsanitary. Ah, just kidding, I love this place and if it was really unsanitary weak stomached woman that I am would have been rolling around on the floor with E. coli eons ago. Needless to say, if I don't get sick you won't.

Now where else can you go, and snag three different items off the steam rack for just $1.30? These days you can't even do that at McDonald's. But this is something different. Why? Because the food along with being cheap is generally pretty good. I tend to get the turnip cake, a pork bun, and some other random item whenever I go here. The result is salty goodness that is both delicious and filling. I have been to other places like Canton, and things like the turnip cake were not much better there than here. The pork buns, though good and cheap as can be, are significantly better at higher end places in terms of the quality of pork. The pork in Good Luck's pork buns is usually of the drier kind, taking away the sensation that one gets when eating a bun with juicer pork such as can be found at higher end dim sumeries.  However, if its the fluffy outside of a pork bun that'll take care of your fix then you can easily be satisfied here. Besides who are you to expect the world if when you're paying less than 50 cents?

In terms of dumplings, seaseme balls, and other treats - especially of the non-meat kind - you will be a bit surprised at what you're getting for your money. All and all it can be summed up like this:

 "Hey mom, remember that time we spent all that money at that snazzy dim sum spot in the suburbs? Well I don't know the math but man this place was WAY less than a quarter of the price we paid there....and it was better".

Now how many times in your life can you say that, especially to your mom?
author: Alexandra M.

description: Wonderful siu mai, baked BBQ pork bun and custard tart! Can't believe I never knew this place before until I read the Yelp reviews. The baked BBQ pork bun was so yummy and filled with non-fatty meat and great tasting sauce and meat. Quite a wait but the ladies behind the counter work it fast to accomodate everyone's orders.
author: Yan M.

description:
Hands down this is the best dim sum I have ever had. I have grown up eating dim sum and when my dad found this gem in New Chinatown I practically swore off all other dim sum. 

This is a bakery/ takeout place and as of my last visit in Jan of 2010 they only take cash. Having said that the prices can't be beat - about 1.60 for three pieces. Expect to wait in line and for the best selection go in the morning. Everything is fresh and wonderful. Their BBQ Pork Buns are the best i have every had.
author: Tim S.

description: You can't even get $3 meals at McDonald's!  Cheap, fresh dim sum from this takeout bakery in Richmond is pretty damn hard to beat, even by dim sum standards (which usually amounts to $10-15/person at sitdown restaurants, especially if you share with a large table of friends).  I've had dim sum all my life (being part Cantonese) and can vouch that Good Luck's dim sum is actually good (I guess there are instances where you don't get what you pay for).  Someone should tell them they can probably raise prices without affecting demand....shhh!
author: Chris P.

description:
mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm. :D

I was getting grumpy. You guys don't even want to know what I'm like when I get hungry and grumpy. It's not pretty at all. We got to Good Luck and I was skeptical and grumpy. We ordered food at the counter and they were not nice, and I was short tempered and grumpy. We sat down and had to clean our own table and I was annoyed and grumpy. We had to steal soy and chili sauce from the other table and I was grumpy and grumpy. And then I took a bite...

AMAZING. Instantly, the grumpy subsided and I realized that this stuff is amazing. We had ordered about 8 different types of dim sum, all of which were getting rid of the grumpy quite nicely. Highlights would be the shark fin dumpling, the shrimp and chive dumpling, and the sesame red bean balls. Everything was fresh and tasty and made me a happy camper. After the haze of grumpy subsided I realized we just paid $12 to feed three hungry grumpy people, and feed them well no less. Happy tummy, happy wallet.

I believe I typed grumpy about 80 times in this review. You're welcome.
author: Tara O.

description:
I guess it's fine for take-out. I ordered turnip cake, shrimp dumpling, shrimp/chive dumpling, pot stickers, and a pork/glutinous-rice wrap. The turnip cake was cold, which I didn't expect. I didn't eat it. I might re-heat them later. The pot stickers were too doughy for my liking, and the filling was slightly on the sweet side.

The best item was the shrimp/chive dumpling. If I went back, it would be just for them.
author: J R.

description:
I really wish I knew that this place was geared towards take out and didn't have any carts roaming around.

Other than that, the food was decent and CHEAP. Their soy sauce tasted a little funky though . . .
author: Pam R.

description: Food was ok - a bit disappointing after reading the good reviews. Most of it was cold, which was a bummer, since it probably would have been tasty had it been hot. Place was not clean...makes you wonder about how they prepare the food. Would not go back...
author: G S.

description: This place is delicious and cheap. This is somewhere where you want to get carry out on a Sunday because it's not a great gathering place, but it's worth the trek and so good. Three pieces for $1.60. We got so excited we ordered $26 worth of food...for two people. Go here. You have to stand in line for a bit, but its not too bad--maybe 20 mins.
author: Lady L.

description: dim sum to go, but they are not really up to  restaurant standards, but if you want a cheap dim sum lunch, this is the place.  It's like fast food dim sum.  Where else can you find 3 shrimp dumplings for 1.50 and have a dim sum meal for under 5 dollars?  Ain't no joke.
author: AhLin C.

description: The atmosphere is a step above a muni bus, but the greatness of their ridiculously cheap dim sum undeniable (Note to Zagat: don't you dare use that sentence).  My one and only gripe is that they forgot to give me the chicken feet I ordered.  I WANT CHICKEN FEET! *slamming both fists on counter and throwing a tantrum*  Fifth star pending chicken feet.
author: Leon R.

description: Having a cocktail party, packing a picnic lunch for your wine tasting, or tired of cooking, you will always make everyone happy with Good Luck's dim sum and noodles. People from all over the Bay Area come here. That's why there's usually a line and they sell out of the har gow (shrimp dumplings) by midday. it is the best in all of San Francisco - the skin is perfectly cooked with a large portion of shrimp filling. It's the best and most nutritious meal you can get at a very modest price.
author: L L.

description: If you want to grub on some cheap yet very tasty dim sum, you really can't do better than this place. Sure it lacks atmosphere, but you can gorge for $5. I know it's hard to believe, but despite having a healthy appetite after a game of flag football last weekend (OK, doesn't sound real tough), I literally hit the wall and had to take food home at the $7 mark. Go there and you'll understand. Be sure to bring a pen to circle what you want on the menu. Not a good date spot, just a good place to eat.
author: Russ T.

description: This is the dim sum Nazi. the ladies behind the counter are un-friendly and rude. they will yell and raise voice at customers in Chinese. Despite all that yelling and UN-friendliness, I still love this dim sum stand. Food is fresh, Delicious and piping hot. There is always a long line which makes food turn fast. More importantly, my dollar goes a long way here. I alwas come here whenever I am in town.
author: Andrew C.

description: It was just okay, no WOW factor. It was a little out of the way from downtown and the people weren't too helpful in assisting a newbie to dim sum. A big factor in giving this place any stars was the very very inexpensive price. Under $5 got me about 8 pieces, I could afford not eating some of the less desirable pieces.
author: Cristina M.

description:
good lucky me ---* caught them just before they closed
bad lucky me---* my potsticker was an odd texture. he was old
good lucky me---* my granny steamed my posticker. he came back to ife
author: Tianna R.

description:
Let me start of by saying that this is a great take out dim sum place ... so if you are new to dim sum do your homework at home before going here. The ladies that serve you will certainly not be helpful and guide you. 

That being said we had an opportunity to spend a long weekend in SF and ended up getting dim sum for two of our meals. We ate dumplings (all kinds), pork buns (baked and steam), sticky rice with sausage,  crispy taro root and siu mai. The only thing I would not recommend is the sticky rice - this is usually one of my favorites but it tasted bad and I ended up throwing it. Also it was expensive compared to the other things on teh menu. So stay away form it..

I'll definitely be back....
author: P From CA C.

description: Clement Street has a Dim Sum restaurant on every block, so we almost randomly chose Good Luck because we managed to find parking one block away from 8th St. We got there just after noon on a rainy Sunday. The ladies behind the corner spoke enough English to answer our questions and were very friendly. We ordered 6 BBQ pork buns, 6 pork shu mai, 6 shrimp dumplings, and 4 custards for our family of 4 (including 2 small kids) and it came to just over $12. Wow. Unfortunately all the tables were taken so we had to take the food back to our hotel, but everything was absolutely delicious. The kids loved it as much as my husband and I. We have eaten at maybe 5 dim sum places in SF, Fremont, and Sacramento but this was easily the best and by far the least expensive. The selection was not nearly as large as at a sit-down Dim Sum place with carts, but they had all of our favorites. No problem with MSG overload that we have experienced elsewhere either. We will definitely be back next time we visit SF.
author: Rebecca F.

description:
Good Luck Dim Sum gives you good Bang for Buck.  The food is definitely above average for a good price.  Sure, you can get better Dim Sum in the City, but you will pay for it.

This place is best for take out.  There are seats available, but you have to take care of yourself.   I would not bring people to eat there.  Rather, I'd buy it for take out and eat it at home.

For ordering more than two or three items, bring a pen and pick up one of their pink sheets.  You can mark and circle the items that you want.  It makes the process alot easier.  Also, its better if you get there early, since the line can get very long,
author: Mark Y.

description: It's a hit or miss with Good Luck. Sometimes their shrimp dumplings are a little bland, but overall I enjoy most of the dim sum, especially the special dim sums they have there. The pork bun can be a little too sweet though. The ladies that work there are not the most patient of servers, but there's usually a long line so I can understand why they're rushing you. It's typical of most Chinese dim sum places, although Ranch 99 has probably comparable dim sum taste-wise. It's a great snack on the go, but eating in can be a little depressing.
author: Gina R.

description: I always enjoy my experience here.  It's truly an experience that is not replicated.  It always surprises me when people are not ready to order after standing in line because their is always a line.  If you are not ready it's atleast a 2 lashing penalty.  Or just fun watching the Chinese lady's yell at you!!  If parking here were any easier, I would frequent more often.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
because of this place, dim sum will NEVER be a slightly expensive meal anymore!!!  it's a little out of the way from the south bay... but if you're in the clement area, this is definitely a place you should stop by!

the storefront looks quite similar to the other take out dim sum places surrounding clement, save for the ridiculously long line that has built itself inside the place.  i took a moment to deliberate whether i should tough out the long line or leave without the food... but in the end, the inner foodie in me won out.

they have all the things i usually order during dim sum- fried sesame balls [the bean paste wasn't overly sweet], har gow was a little small, but at the price of what it is- you really can't complain, plus it was delicious!, ham sui gok was FABULOUS, and almost all the stuff we got was just fantastic!  i was a little disappointed that the wu gok was kind of cold... but understandable, i guess.  at least the ham sui gok wasn't.

oh how i wish i discovered this place sooner!!  yay for inexpensive meals!!
author: Karen T.

description: Star ratings don't really work for a place that is so variable.  We have eaten there several times and the food was always excellent and quite reasonable (we can overlook the service issues and long wait).  They really kow how to cook shrimp.  UNFORTUNATELY, we took our daughter there just before Christmas (her first time) and were most disappointed.  All three of our items off the steam table were cold and the dough on the Crystal Dumplings was HARD and DRIED OUT (it was so old).  I don't think it was unsafe, but it certainly was unappetizing.  If this had been our first time, it would be a Zero Star.  We know they can do better and will give them one more chance.  This place is certainly getting sloppy.  Too bad quality control is not better.
author: Rick S.

description: The really good Har Gow and Chive and scallop dumplings to go make perfect instant cocktail party fodder and maybe the best $3 lunch in the avenues besides.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I just ate here this afternoon and was a bit disappointed. But, it must be said, this place is so damn cheap it is AMAZING. It's so cheap, it scares me. This place is so cheap, I don't understand how they stay in business... I guess I am just used to places like Yank Sing.
We had potstickers, har gow, sui mai, BBQ pork bun, sticky rice, sesame balls, and the "filled" fried dumplings (don't ask, don't tell). Overall, some things tasted good- in specific, the har gow and fried dumplings- but it just felt wayyy too unhealthy. 
I know, I know, a lot of the things we got were fried... but I didn't know the terms for most of the steamed dumplings. That could have been my problem. I really don't eat heavy fried food like this often and that was hard to stomach.
This may actually be more "authentic" than places like Yank Sing (?), but my poor California cuisine body says NOO to such cheap and heavy food. When you don't eat stuff like this often, I find it actually winds up tasting badly... even though we all know that greasy stuff can taste very good.
author: Amanda C.

description:
i don't think it is one of the best dim sum in town

dim sum is ok, and it is a little bit expensive

u don't have a lot of choices over there, so i will go to other restaurants nearby
author: Sue S.
