description: Eat dim sum for a cheap breakfast. You get a variety and it's an experience you won't forget. The best time to go is in the morning when it's fresh and before it gets crowded. Sometimes you have someone that orders all the food and you have to wait 10 minutes for a new batch. It's cash only. There are menus available to circle or write in your order.
author: Armstrong B.

description: One of the best downlow dim sum spots in the City. I used to live a block from this Clement Street gem and I have lost 6 lbs. since moving away. Great ha gow, pork siu mai, and cha siu bau for on-the-go.
author: Be N.

description: This has to be one of the best dim sum places in San Francisco! Their lines are long but if you get there early enough, you should be able to bypass the long lines and even find parking! Dont' pass up the hai gow (shrimp dumpling), potstickers, sesame balls, shu mai (pork dumplings) and the noodle rolls. The rice porridge is pretty good too. All in all, the value is wonderful, the quality is great and the taste is superb.....
author: La C.

description: The reviewers who rated this place low because of the screaming women behind the counter need to get over themselves.  My mother is Chinese so I know all there is to know about the culture.  Sounds like they're screaming or angry, but you shouldn't take it personally.  It just isn't one of the prettier languages out there.  That being said, Good Luck is by far the best dim sum place in the Richmond district.  There isn't a better dim sum place unless you want to go to Chinatown.  And, duh!  There's a reason why the lines are long!
author: Raine D.

description: I always get the chicken buns when I come here and for $1.40, that makes a very filling meal.  People aren't kidding when they say this is the best "dim sum to go" place on Clement St.  The portion sizes of certain dim sum (like the buns or sticky rice) are larger than at other places and for the same price, making this place a good deal and my favorite to go to.
author: Swirls L.

description: i love dim sum and have been to quite a few places in the area. THIS IS MY FAVORITE ONE. i love those angry, yelling asian ladies that will make you buy one more piece to "even the price" whatever that means. so cheap, so delicious, and always hot and fresh, not questionably warmish like some places.
author: Lisa M.

description: Didn't seem like that many choices were available but what I had was pretty decent. The steamed bbq pork bun was slightly saucey for my liking and they tried to pimp a chicken bun to me when they realized they were out of bbq pork buns... NEVER! It was funny to me how much they were Really loudly talking at each other and at other people in here, but that is the way it goes sometimes. The quality of the pork in the pork bun is highly variable so I wish you the best of luck. Try the lucky ball, I did.
author: Sven S.

description: Sometimes I wonder...how can one get sick-full; I'm talking beyond satiated full, for less than $5?  I mean, really, HOW?!?  Good eats, all the standards of a yum cha cafe.  They've got jook too!
author: Al K.

description: Hands down best dim sum for the money. You won't find any duck on the menu, and if you bring a date here it better be for a walk of shame brunch.. But for tasty greasy dim sum belly I can't reccomend a better venue. Everybody knows Clement is the real Chinatown anyway, Good Luck Dim Sum simply further legitimizes the claim.
author: Tal K.

description: I love this place! I was introduced to this place by a friend when I was home from college for the summer.  The place is truly a steal.  Tasty dimsum for a very cheap price!  I am looking forward to visiting Good Luck Dimsum again the next time I go home!
author: Paula G.

description: disgruntled employees + mediocre dim sum = I'm never returning!!!
author: Michelle T.

description: You know it's authentic when your white buddy's head sticks out a foot and a half above everyone else like Gargamel in the land of the Smurfs.  There are no big European people here.  Just Chinese, who unwittingly embarrass me since I'm second generation and don't speak.  It's the real deal.
author: Deb T.

description: I think if there's always  a line at lunch time, then it's probably a good sign. Good luck was closed for a bit, so glad they're re-opened. The dim sum is always good. I just point at each steamer for a good selection.  They also serve a small selection of other Chinese food, but I always go back for the dumplings and buns. There  is some seating in the restaurant, but I go to the beach or the GGNRA for a picnic.
author: Amy M.

description: I love this dim sum shop. I tasted several hole-in-the-wall dim sum shops in SF and selected Good Luck for supplying my family reunion picnic for 40 persons.  I made the perfect choice for several reasons.  I could place my order with a phone call a few days in advance.  They spoke English and understood my order and filled it to perfection.  I also asked them to put it in disposable aluminum catering trays, instead of their usual pink cake boxes.   I delivered the trays to them 2 days before my order pick-up.  They were able to hold onto the trays and use them when filling my order.  I asked that they don't smash the dim sum together in the tray.  The lady placed everything so beautifully and symmetrically.  It looked like an expensive restaurant had put the order together.  I ordered 11 different items and everyone of my 40 guests said it was the best dim sum they had.  They all asked where I had gotten it.  The size of each dumpling is very large, almost twice as large as something i would get at any other restaurant.  It was not overly oily.  There was a lot of meat and good fillings in each dumpling.  And no strange aftertaste nor saltiness.  And I was so impressed with the price.   It was very inexpensive.  When I budgeted the dim sum for 40 persons, I thought I would pay at least $15/person.  But with 11 items and 3 of them costing more than the usual .50/piece (baked char siu bao and sticky rice and the sesame coconut peanut puff), it only came to about $9/person with tax!  I am going to them again and again.  Great for large orders---they understand so well, and are easy to deal with.  It's an easier location than SF Chinatown for parking your car to pick up!
author: Denise B.

description: This place wasn't bad, just ok I guess;  I wouldn't be against eating there again but it didn't blow me away.  Maybe I'm just not that big a fan of dim sum.  Does the pork always taste somewhat undercooked at these places?  I had a little of almost everything that was left (peak hours were over) and overall the whole experience averaged out to about a 3.  But they had some big spongy sweet cake-like pastries that were very good, the most memorable item of my meal.
author: I. Lee W.

description:
I waited one hour on a Saturday afternoon before I reached the front counter.  Insane but so very worth it!  Cheap (on average $1.50/order of 3 pcs), fresh and tasty.  I guess that's the trade off.  You know when the food's good when you see customers pushing shopping carts full of dim sum orders out the door.  
Maybe the ladies at the counter seem so grouchy because they're always so busy and don't get a break?... I'm gonna try to catch them later in the day next time.
author: Amy T.

description: I have nothing but the fondest memories of this place ... It started way back in 1997 ... (nostalgic moment people) I was currently attending Washington high schools summer program ... For some reason I would find myself avoiding the confines of my classroom environment and was feeling the need to be free !!! That's when I stumbled upon this place and can I just say WHAT A FIND !!!!! Not only is it easy to find but oh my so affordable !!! I would pick my dim sum and then take it to go. I often brought my Dim Sim to Ocean Beach, there I would  break out my sketch book snack on my dim sum and draw till my heart was content !  Times have certainly changed for me but my love of Dim Sum hasn't ... And this place will always hold a special place in heart ... Filled with all my other childhood memories ... So if your asking for my oppinion ... Drop by, they are friendly (atleast when I use go there) and hey it's affordable and not as hard as trying to find parking in Chinatown !
author: Richelle P.

description: Really good, cheap take out. Their milk buns are delicious. BRING CASH!!! No credit card here
author: Zach Z.

description: I love dim sum...I could eat har gow and sesame balls all day but unfortunately demands of a normal life do not allow me to (i.e. doctor's orders to stop eating so much damn dim sum). I also pick up Chinese fry bread here for nights we have congee. They sell out quickly though so sometimes I go home empty-handed (well, not quite...I'll probably have a siu mai or two crammed in my mouth).
author: Nathalie L.

description: The stuff here ranges from pretty decent to just plain awful (I'm talking to you, sausage bun), but it's hard to beat on a pure dollars per calorie basis.  What I don't understand is when I come in shortly after opening and it still seems like half of my order has been sitting out for half a day.  Get the crystal dumplings -- they're good!
author: Ficus K.

description: They have some pretty good dim sum here for a good price.. It's a cheap eat for dim sum on the go or to take home for the family or friends.. they have baked goods as well.. a good variety of items to choose from always fresh and tasty.. my mom has been going here for awhile to pick up dim sum and stuff.. so it grew on me!
author: Rochelle F.

description: Dim Sum that's cheap and that's actually good...wow, whats the catch?  Then I see it's cash only...parking is minimal unless you get lucky (which I did) and seating is like playing musical chair...There were some things that I miss here that you could get from a different dim sum place but if your moolah is limited, you can always get a cheap deal here.
author: Drew R.

description: I like this place a lot. Their dim sum is CHEAP and consistent. THere's always a line, and don't double park because the traffic cops are always around giving out presents. Take out is good, I sat and ate there once but it felt weird...like cafeteria-esque
author: anocha s.

description: Dim Sum in San Francisco is like heaven on earth, this place lets me eat (and be full) for about 2 or 3  bucks. And ohhhh those lovely steamed pork buns.....so tender and delicious, just thinking about them makes me salivate.
author: Nichole H.

description:
This place has the BEST bbq bun, chicken bun, pork bun...actualli, any bun they make are good.  But that's pretty much the only good thing about them.  They always have a long line, so that somewhat proves how good they are.  My first time in line, I thought it was max 20 minutes wait, but I end up waited for 1.5 hours.  
The ladies there worked so slow [like all the ppl. in line were invisible], I wanted to jump in and help them out so the line would move faster.
They also talked so much I felt like their spits were all over my food [but I didn't want to just leave without anything in my hand after all that wait, even if I end up throwing away the chicken buns from disgust].

Bottom line, wait if you have time and want to try out the best chinese buns in the city & look away when they get it for you.  It's better if you bring a friend who speaks cantonese  with you so you don't have to repeat your order five times just so they'd understand.
author: Karen C.

description: This place is awesome! My friend from San Jose wanted to try some good cheap chinese in San Francisco and this place didn't disappoint. For 5.50  I got  9 pieces of dim sum and a soda!  My friend and I both had enough left over for dinner that night, and the food was really good. My only complaints were the long line and less than descriptive tiny blurbs in english underneath the chinese on the menu. But all that was more than made up for by the price and the taste! Rock on Good Luck Dim Sum! Rock on!
author: Melissa A.

description: Good dim sum to go (if you don't go far).  We picked up two large boxes of dim sum to take to a Bocce Ball game in Benicia.  The dumplings were a big hit, and the chicken buns were enjoyed by my husband, but the dumplings and buns were packed together so tightly, than some of the buns got a bit wet from the dumplings.  We reheated the baked pork buns at home before we took them to the game, so the wet bread did dry out.  I would not buy the baked pork buns again, as I thought there was too much bun, and not enough pork.  I would buy the pot stickers, siu mai, and green chive dumplings again.
author: Vicki T.

description:
the most inexpensive and delicious dim sum ever...my favs are 
the fried sesame balls, shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling and white rice cakes.... also, its not as greasy as other places... however, the line is deliciously long. ...
author: Tiffany L.

description: This is my favorite dim sum in the whole city.  It seems cleaner than a lot of other dim sum restaurants on Clement and the ladies who work there are rather funny.
author: Veronica M.

description:
awesomeness. i really struggle to go back into yank sing anymore. i'll get dragged into going there from time to time for a "business meal" on someone's expense account (which must mean something) but if i'm looking for max value and freshness, good luck is the place. i popped in the other day and picked up a giant full meal for two people for...ready for it? six dollars. 

the food is fresh, service is fast, and it's fun to hobnob with people in line who obviously know their dim sum.
author: Mulberry S.

description: If you are looking for some cheap good dim sum...this place is where it's at. With that being said, my only gripe is why do the women behind the counter stare at you with daggers in their eyes. I don't really expect exceptional customer service at fast food type places, but geez! Some favorites of mine include the har gow (shrimp dumplings) and their deep fried dumplings. Greasy, but worth it!
author: Janelle L.

description: probably some of the cheapest dim sum you can find with acceptable quality.  anything cheaper would just be the ayce $6 dim sum places that sf's "china town" is lined with, but their food is gag inducing.
author: Ngoc N.

description: I come in on the weekends sometimes to buy Sesame Seed Balls and Pineapple Buns, which they're always sold out of...so imagine my surprise when I stopped in yesterday right before closing to see if they had any and they did. I bought two for $.50 each! Only, I didn't love them. I don't know if it's because they weren't warm and fresh out of the oven or what.  I much prefer the ones up the street at Clement Restaurant.  However, the Sesame Seed Balls here are excellent. I think I'll just stick to those when I come here from now on.
author: Dee I.

description:
Back in the day, I would go to a dim sum place in the Bay Area called the Clement Street Bakery, but sadly (very sadly) it closed.  I still remember wandering Clement Street aimlessly craving dim sum when I came across Good Luck Dim Sum.  I felt the symbolism and walked in to try it out.  Well, that was 4ish years ago and frankly, I have never looked back.  

* I spend anywhere from 15 to 45 minutes looking for parking but never regret it.  

* I wait in line and fill out my order form with a broken pencil and using my hand as a desk while dodging the workers as they bring out hot pans of dim sum, but no problem.

* I stand facing the counterperson in complete befuddlement as she confirms my order and pfffts in exasperation as I blankly nod, but no big.

I run back to my car, drive down the Interstate 5 back home and it feels like no time as I enjoy the plump cha su bao, the delicious pot stickers, and the incredible shu mai and har gow. 
I am not a dim sum connoisseur, but I have my favorite items and this place knows how to bring it and they bring it hard.
author: Johnny A.

description: I've been coming here since I was... 8? They have good dim sum and good buns. But the one thing I don't get is why there's always such a gigantic line!? Is it THATTTTT good? I have no complaints, so I guess so? Some say their CHA SEW BOW is the best. I like the shrimp dumplings and the chive dumplings.
author: Elaine H.

description:
edit:

my bad, but i've reviewed this place by mistaking it for another dimsum joint on clement.

This is STILL one of the reasons I want to live in the Richmond.  Their price for one order (3 pcs) of dimsum is hiked up for about 5 cents more than another spot i normally go to - worth it.  Their soy sauce is awesome, has that sweet taste to it that goes perfect with the dimsum.  go full and satisfied for an easy average of 3-5 bucks.
author: Paul A.

description: Authentic.  Extremely Cheap.  Always a huge line, so be prepared to wait.  Yummy sweet pork buns.
author: Monika M.

description: With a name like Good Luck Dim Sum, one might think it's just another restaurant set to disappoint.  Not so here.  I've always had the 'best of luck' here picking out tasty dim sum.  Their selection is outstanding and best sampled earlier in the day.  The long lines are sometimes bothersome, but it's also the best indication that great food awaits the patient ones.   Just be sure to grab a 'pink slip' and fill it out while in line.  Sure, you can get by with a $5 lunch here, but I'm usually thinking also about breakfast the next day, and a snack later...buy enough to satisfy your dim sum fix, if you don't want to stand in line.  This is truly the best dim sum to-go restaurant in the whole Bay Area.
author: JeFF T.

description: be aware: chinese lady behind the counter is extremely RUDE !
author: J K.

description: The ambience was nonexistent and the food was merely okay. I was looking forward to one of those big banquet halls with the people pushing around carts. This place, on the other hand, was just a storefront where you get things to go, or if you want to stay, you sit at one of the grubby, dirty tables in the back, with your paper plate full of rapidly cooling adequate dim sum. Not worth the trip out there.
author: Melinda K.

description:
the women working the counter are super nice, as far as chinese women selling food products is concerned.

prices are great, even if all you do is save five cents per pork bun in comparison to the neighboring places. 

when im in the area, i just cant pass up a stop by to drop a dollar or two and grab some nice snack food.
author: Darrell L.

description: Can you say dim sum on steroids???  Biggest pieces of dim sum I have ever had and very cheap!  Wish I lived closer to it.
author: Darren I.

description: This place is excellent because you can load up on delicious dim sum for next to nothing!  Great selection and I've particularly enjoyed the BBQ pork buns and shrimp dumplings.  The place lacks atmosphere, but for the amount of food and such little money, who needs atmosphere--just load up on dim sum and go sit in the park and enjoy!
author: Jessica L.

description:
char siu bao was yummy and i liked that it didn't have any nasty, fatty pieces of char siu.  my favorite is the har gow!!! i'm not a har gow fan cause it's usually so plain but good luck's har gow is awesome!!! i don't know what's in it, but it's tasty. the coconut balls with peanuts was awesome too.  we tried to order the chicken and sausage over rice but she said they didn't have it.  so disappointed! oh well next time. 

thanks to other yelpers and the tips about using the ordering sheet to place your order.  so much easier!!! so to other yelpers, what is fun kor????  i was too scared to ask the ladies there.  

i'm so glad i found this place.  it was good take out dim sum, exactly what i was looking for and i don't need to try EVERY restaurant on clement!!!!!
author: Christie Y.

description: Let me give you Yelpers an insider tip, if you don't know the language of the natives, then don't even bother trying to speak to them. It's pointless. Just grab a paper menu, a pencil and circle what you want! Hand it to the middle aged Chinese Ladys and she'll be glad she didn't have to communicate with you via pidgin English sign language. Give a 20 and get your change and all will be well after you bite into their chicken shu mai!
author: Harry B.

description: I had dim dum for breakfast here once after I went to the dentist. It was awesome. Really made my day. Luckily I know some Cantonese (bidi, mnn-hou, godi!) so I had a pleasant experience.
author: Mitsi M.

description: I love Good Luck Dim Sum.  Why not five stars?  Well, it seems that I am not the only fan in town of their shrimp har gao, and sometimes, when you drive all the way across town, you will be disappointed to find "No more har gao!"  I just wish, since it is so popular, that they stayed on top of it a bit more.  I also think some of their ladies behind the counter could smile every once in a while, but that's not a prerequisite if the food is good (and available!).
author: Julie T.

description:
Definitely cheap prices but there's always a line so be prepared to know what you want...or get yelled at by the dim sum nazis!  I've eaten most of the items on the menu here and would say that the har gow never disappoints; I would pass on the sui mai though.  

There are very few tables here so you might consider taking it to go instead.
author: t n.

description: Great "to go" style dim sum.  Purchase your food then find a table to sit n enjoy your meal.  You'll find a lot of these places on Clement St.  Resonably priced, a lot cheaper than going to eat and sit down at a dim sum resturant.  Grab the paper menu selection while you wait in line to decide what you're going to get.  There's a lot of 3 pieces for $1.20.  You can always just get 1, if you're eating alone.  I would avoid going in the early morning, you could be waiting in line for a good 30mins.  Try going sometime in the afternoon or late in the day.  If you don't want to wait in line, try going to the ones down the street.
author: Christi S.

description: GOOD LUCK getting Dim Sum on Sunday mornings. The line there stretches to the back of the shop. That being said, there's a line for a reason. Great dim sum here: I recommend the shrimp dumplings.
author: Vince M.

description: The food here is awsome! it was $12 for two of us, and we couldnt finish it! The small downside is that sometimes they dont understand what you're saying; we ordered something, and received something totally different... but it was good! Highly recommend getting the take out,a nd going on a picnic!
author: Chieko H.

description: (3.5 Stars) Not even close to my absolute favorite dim sum place, but for the price, and the quality, it can't be beat.  Simple fresh dim sum, and did I mention CHEAP!!!  Sure I did, just remember that.
author: Kapeli M.

description: Which juice box goes better with shu mai, papaya or guava? Good Luck has a great selection of tasty dumplings and they don't skimp on the filling. I appreciate the menu with English translations and that there is no 3 piece minimum.
author: Rachel B.

description: Dimsum is fantastic here!!! Prices are cheap so try them all from their shrimp ha gow, pork sui mai, to their shark fin dimsum. Great flavors in every bit.
author: David M.

description:
so cheap and so delicious!

most items come in orders of 3 for $1.40-$1.50.  there are some small tables in the place to eat there, but many people get their dim sum to go.  can have long lines and parking can be tricky (metered, street) so be prepared.  it's definitely worth it.  
i had shrimp har gow (dumplings), shrimp and vegetable (chive, i believe) dumpling, and steamed chicken bun...i don't eat red meat.  all delicious and highly recommended!
here's the menu if you are interested: http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/restaurantdetails.asp?areaid=0&restaurantid=7567&neighborhoodid=0&cuisineid=21&home=Y
author: micaela r.

description: Great dim sum especially for HAW GRAW.... very cheap...  lines can be very long...
author: Lily T.

description: This place used to taste so much better.  I haven't been here in a long time until 3 days ago.  When did they increase their prices?  anyway, dimsum was alright.  their steamed bbq pork bun was good.  their shrimp dumpling and siumai was cold by the time I ate it.  what happened to this place?  I think the ladies working there don't speak very good english thats why they may come off as rude, but they're not.  I think this place is a little overrated.  The one on the corner of 6th & Clement taste better.
author: Erika C.

description: Pretty good. It's more of a take out place for dim sum. You can order dim sum and eat in the back if you'd like. service was not friendly at all. potstickers were great!  most of it was cold. soy sauce mysteriously tasted kinda sweet. this place was decent. good place for a dim sum fix.
author: Cynthia S.

description: I f'ing love pork buns.  I went here and really enjoyed the prices and pork buns even before I discovered one of my very lovely co-workers is the son of the owner -- we call him The Dim Sum Prince.  I do not think the women behind the selection bar are rude...it's just a different kind of customer service.  They are efficient, and I felt they were quite helpful to me.  Not sure why they are called the Dim Sum Nazis...I can't imagine someone being turned away from here.
author: Kimberly B.

description: Love the dim sum!! so cheap and good. The only thing I don't like is that you can't really sit inside and enjoy your food. So, I've always ended up doing take-out. But, it's all good though... my favorite dim sum is shrimp dumpling, shumai, and potsticker.. and they all are very good and cheap here! So, i really don't mind standing in line to buy or taking the food out and eat at home. It's all good!!
author: Daisy S.

description: My auntie owns this awesome dimsum shop! My family and I come to visit every once in awhile and when we do, we take home boxes of her delicious dim sum! She works tirelessly day and night to ensure tasty dim sum :] I'm glad there's so many rave reviews here =)
author: Karina C.

description:
On Clement Street, there is no dim sum place that rivals Good Luck.  The prices are so reasonable given that the cost of  food in the Richmond dist. is more than in Chinatown.  My favs here are the congee, chicken bao (savory chicken meat inside a steamed bun), egg roll, taro dumpling, steamed sticky rice in ti leaf.  Their other dumplings are good too.  
It's a sad day when I should happen to be on Clement St and find that Good Luck is closed for a day off and I have to seek out dim sum at Wing Lee, which is 2nd best in my book.  
The lines are horrifyingly long but they make it easy for you to select your food with a short menu to circle the items and quantity you want. Most are sold 3 pieces per order. 
There are a couple of tables in the back if you want to eat in, but it's not a great atmosphere.  If you don't mind all the people huddled at the front of the store trying to place their order, or the queue extending all the way back next to your table and beyond & having everyone staring down at you while you're trying to eat.  During the holidays, especially Chinese New Year, the lines are even worse!
author: Ry T.

description: Finally some petite looking yummy dim sum that is not the size of my fist!!!! Usually some of these cheap eats dim sum places seem to sell really gargantuan dim sum. Dim Sum is supposed to be petite!!! So I am finally happy that we found this joint that sells cute petite siew mai that is tasty and har gow with its thin translucent skin (some places make it too thick that the meat to flour/skin portion is all off!!!). Ooo and definitely get the porridge here cos it is velvety smooth and definitely get all the toppings - the crunchies and the green onions. Wished I had a bigger appetite for more but guess will have to save my tasting for another trip!
author: Topazskye L.

description: Great hidden spot for Dim Sum, but don't expect good service or a clean bathroom. So cheap.
author: Clementine J.

description: I've gotta admit, the workers behind the counter are scary and old Asian ladies always cut in front of me, but i love this place. The food is so cheap (around $1 to $2 for Dim Sum) and it is made so well! I have never tasted chicken as good as the chicken in their steam buns and I usually am not a big chicken fan. They're quick, it's easy and it's right next to Apple Books.
author: Devon M.

description: Got introduced to this place in the 90's and whenever I'm in the city I like to load up and bring some home. Very good dim sum. Love it.
author: Jim A.

description: Their dim sum are not the best, especially it takes you so long to wait in line.  But, who can complain with its low prices.  Comparatively, Good Luck charges 10 to 20 cents cheaper than its neighbors.  Other than waiting in line, you can call and make an order by phone if you are going to make a bulk order for party.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
good: shrimp dumplings, lo bak gao, chicken bun, ham sui gok and shrimp & taro dumplings

bbq pork buns were ok, but there was too much bun and it was a bit dry. shark fin dumpling was unidentifiable--we figured out what it was only through deduction.
author: Kan L.

description: MMMMM SO GOOD! Best dim sum on Clement Street. Usually a long line. They make it easy for Anglophones to order because you can just circle your order on the pink paper menu. Also, most items are listed in Chinese and English. It's verrry cheap.. great cha siu bao (BBQ pork bun), ha gao (shrimp dumpling), siu mai (beef ball thingy dumplingy), omgosh amazing coconut peanut ball!!!! AHH! oh but I have saved the best for last::: EGG YOLK BUN. I have roamed this city far and wide for a custard bun that is as good as my late grandfather's. Finally, I have found it hidden under the name EGG YOLK BUN. The consistency is perfect. Not too drippy custardy.. But oh so yellow and yolky A!!!GIOAJSG YUMYUMYUM good luck dim SUM
author: O K.

description: I feel lucky to have tried this place out for legit dim sum.  The woman at the counter was a sweetie and the food was ridockulously good.  I was going to post it at 4 because its not the nicest of places but who am I kidding, its perfect for Clement and should not be missed.  Order anything and everything and you'll laugh at how little it costs you.  You gas money out there is more then the bill.
author: Porfirio R.

description: I stopped in for a quick bite and left fat as a pig. All for 5 bucks.
author: F B.

description: The first dim-sum of my life  - which ignited my passion for dim-sium. 10 years later their dim sum is still very close to perfection. I don't like buns in general, and I am told that I am missing something really big. One of my benchmarks is hau gau, and I haven't find better ones yet. The shark fin dumplings are also incredible. The often insanely long line and the non-attractive cleanliness  of tables never stop me.
author: Donato M.

description: I don't understand why you'all would compare this place to Ton Kiang and the other "sit-down" places.  For to-go Dim Sum this place is the best.  Where else can you get a decent meal in the city for less than $5 bucks?  The one thing, I must admit bothered me at first until I just accepted it, are the Dim Sum Nazi-ettes that work there. (click here to see them:  http://www.flickr.com/photos/phatman/117704576/in/pool-c-green/ ) Just go there knowing that like the guards at the tower of london they are prohibited from smiling.
author: Travis H.

description: Came here to check out what fellow Yelpers were on about. yes the long line made this exciting. I must say this is the best deal around- plates and plates with two carton drinks for 10 dollars and we couldn't finish everything! Only downside was the lack of selection, but it was FRESH! the staff serving at the front were constantly shouting out to the kitchen at the back for re-orders and the kitchen staff were non stop bringing out fresh steaming bamboo steamers full of goodies. Stay away from the pan-fried dim sum as a little too greasy for my liking- lucky we scored some condiments (chilli and soy sauce randomly placed on the tables- running LOW) to help cut the oil! Dried shrimp 'crepe' (cheung fun) was pretty good- almost as good as my mums.... ahhhh! definitely no frills, no fuss, get what you pay for, down to earth food, quick and extremely efficient staff!
author: Sushi Y.

description:
blech. yuck.

maybe we went at a time when the dim sum wasn't piping hot fresh?  i don't know why it's rated so high for some stale tasting dim sum.  by stale i mean not fresh at all!

i mean, there were a lot of people going around the time we went so i'm assuming we weren't there at off hours.  yes, it is cheap, but is it good?  no!

there's another place down the street that we went to the other day that had waaayyyy better dim sum... it was fresh, and the place was cleaner. i'll have to figure out the name of that other place because i forgot it.. haha... it's just doors down from schubert's bakery though.  the dim sum at this place is at least hot and is just as cheap.  it seemed that they had more selection too!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I've been going here for more then 10 years, and each year that passes, the lines to get food at this place get ridiculous. 1 major thing that I've notices is the amount of non-asians that go to this place now......making it even more frustrating for Mr. Jimmy Snuka to get his dim sum!!!! Back in the 90s, this place went from your typical chinese customers to a tour bus stop from Pier 39!!!

Everyone stop going here!!

But secretly, I give this place 5 stars..... I just wanna lower the rating so the lines get more manageable.
author: Jimmy S.

description: The staff is rude.  The other day I had the owner giving me bad looks because I only bought one bake bun for .90 cents.  I always have old Asian's cutting in front of me. The food is so cheap and yummy!
author: Russ B.

description:
fresh, busy, cheap and damn tasty

watch you don't order to much like i always seem to
3 for $1.50 mean you get 3 for $1.50!  i thought you needed to pick 3, so i ended up with 9!!! doh

definitely fill out a order form to save all the hassle at the counter

shrimp
shrimp with parsely
pork bun
taro root
egg custard

done. eat. happy
author: david s.

description: I learned about this place from my girlfirend, the food is really good and the best part is its cheap! Sometimes we get attitude from one of the ladies there but that wont stop us from going back!
author: Bobby S.

description:
My family loves Good Luck Dim Sum. However, we are disturbed by the presence of "shark fin dumplings" on the menu. I have lived in Asia and know how important this delicacy is in Chinese traditions, but hope we can educate people to make better choices in what they buy and eat. My ask is that others who love Good Luck Dim Sum all ask the owners to remove the shark fin dumplings and cease participating in the tragic market for Shark Fin.

For those that don't know, the controversy around shark finning stems from the fact that poachers cut off shark's fins while the animal is still alive. They than let it free into the ocean because shark's meat costs very little and there is no point occupying ship's storages with it. However, research shows cutting off shark's fins leads sharks to suffer a painful and slow death.  Injured animals returned into the ocean cannot properly navigate in water and hunt without their fins. They will also often get eaten by other predators unable to swim away.

Good Luck Dim Sum, we love your dumplings. Please stop serving Shark Fin!
author: Steve F.

description: Another Inner Richmond take-out Dim Sum place, just like Wing Lee Bakery.  Only this time we actually grabbed a table in the back, got a subcommittee to mark up one of the pink menus, and then sent someone up to order at the counter (the line can be pretty long here, mind you).  Even if you eat in, you get take-out-style food (ie, plastic forks, paper cups and plates--even DIY teabags).  And honestly, if you have the means to get your order to Golden Gate Park while it's still hot (or Mountain Lake Park, actually a lot closer), you should probably eat there.  But everything was perfectly scrumptious, and the classics are all here (pork siu mai, turnip cakes, pork & taro, shrimp pot-stickers, fried rice in bamboo leaves, and a variety of sweet rolls).  The total bill in the end?  $5 a person.  Which makes you wonder: why grab a fancy latte on your way to work when you could be getting a stack of juicy dumplings instead?
author: Wes M.

description:
This was our first experience buying take out Dim Sum.  
Setting:  Mom and pop type hole in the wall.  Line up to get your order filled.  There is seating if you want to eat there after filling your order, but it is very basic.  Table and chairs with Chili sauce and soy sauce.  We were there after 11am and the line was twenty people deep inside.  It moved fast.  Parking is always difficult on this street, have a good relationship with the parking god.    
Service:  Brisk, language may be a problem.  Counter staff assume that people know their Dim Sum.  Pink self-service sheets to be filled in before you order (pens provided).  It is assumed you know about this.
Food:  I enjoyed all that I ate.  Friends that ate some of the dishes I didn't get to eat seemed to enjoy them too.  The only item that bothered me were the baked Cha Siu Bao.  They were very large but the filling was very small.  Prices were excellent however.  Prices start at 3 buns for $1.50.  The highest price I paid was 3 buns for $2.40.  Buns were sold in units of 3 and some were sold individually.
Note:  I don't give more than 3 stars unless the setting is as good as the food.  I don't give extra stars for value.  To get 5 stars a restaurants has to be near perfect.
author: Dennis T.

description: Good prices, but  too (very, very) greasy. Long lines for low prices, but 99% of  orders tend to be to go. Prefer Ton Kiang w. friends.
author: miriam b.

description: Yummy dim sum. Super cheap prices. Came here on a sunday afternoon and there wasn't that bad of a line but nothing was fresh and we were able to sit down. The soy sauce in the restaraunt sucksss and I mean really sucks. Their pork buns were really good and so were the shrimp dumplings. Matt N. and I got a big plate of dim sum for $15.80. We got something like 3 orders of shrimp dumplings, 2 orders of siu mai, one order of chicken siu mai, one oder of something with chicken and two orders of bbq prok buns. Oh and two cokes. Very yummy and pretty cheap.
author: Tiffany D.

description: They have good dim sum here. But the lines get so long during the peak hours of breakfast/lunch that I usually go after 2PM. These dumplings sell quickly and you hear the ladies at the counter calling to the back for more dumplings to be brought out. They offer a variety of dumplings and the service is fast. Only once did I have to wait 15 minutes for the next batch of shrimp dumplings. I like the mushroom chow mein and white rice noodle with dried shrimp/green onions. I eat here if I don't want to go to an actual restaurant for dim sum. This is the place to get everything at once without having to wait for the food carts to come your way.
author: Candace F.

description: I think people who go here for ambience and service aren't really getting this place at all.  The dim sum, particularly the shrimp based dumplings, are fantastic.  You just order at the counter and take away or eat in back.  You choose your own drinks from the cooler.  The soy sauce on the tables is their own propietary blend and I would kill for the recipe!  You can watch them making more dim sum and rolling it up front on carts as you eat.  What could be better!
author: Thelma Lee G.

description: This place is really good if you want to just do Dim Sums for to go....the price is good and food is actually pretty yummy.  Must try their Shrimp Hao Gao, Crystal Dumplings, Pork Dumplings...actually all dumplings are good!
author: JenJen W.

description: The place to go to when you're craving good, cheap dim sum. I'm a fan of their chicken buns and the shrimp & chive har gao. No, the ladies aren't friendly, but this isn't a place you go to for the ambiance or customer service.
author: Jane K.

description: Yet another place my girlfriend and roommates told me about. So on my trip to Clement St. we decided to also pick up some dim sum from this location. Do not, I repeat DO NOT come here at noon. It felt like the whole crowd of Clement St. shoppers were all in this place. However, I was one of them, waiting in line. No wonder this place got such a high review. The beef siu mai was so yummy. The chicken siu mai wasn't as yummy, but it was still good. I'm now a fan of Good Luck Dim Sum. Oh, and like everyone said, 3 for $1.40... how many did I order. 3 orders of each! I scarfed these bad boys like a fat kid on cake. Now I wish I didn't eat it so damn fast, because in minutes I finished all my food and I'm left wanting more...
author: Michael S.

description: How can such a stellar steamed shrimp dumpling come out of the same kitchen that yields such un-inspirational shark fin? But who cares -- really -- at these prices. Best take-out dim sum I've found in SF to-date.
author: N K.

description: Great walk-in and wait-in-line dim sum, arguably the best in town. Bring cash (you don't need much) and know what you want when you make your order.  So ... good.
author: Charles C.

description: This is the best dim sum in San Francisco for the price.  It beats anywhere else on Clement St. and in Chinatown.  Okay,  I haven't been to every place, so a little disclaimer here.  But, I know dim sum because I grew up on the stuff.  I love their lotus leaves wrapped rice, har gow (shrimp dumplings), chicken feet, and egg custard tarts.  Absolutely inexpensive and can get a good meal for under $5.  Be prepared to wait in long lines during peak lunch times.
author: Dbear T.

description: Excellent, fresh, tastey authentic dim sum to go and the price is great too!!  Caution, you may want to go early in the morning (8AM or 9AM) or late afternoon as the line/wait gets quite long.
author: J J.

description:
I went late in the afternoon, which might have explained for a little bit of my disappointment.  I tried a whole lot of things.

I would say the following were very good:
1.  The Baked BBQ Pork Bun
2.  The Har Gao (shrimp steamed one)
3. The Egg Roll
4.  The little pounded fried shrimp things
5.  The fried rice ball with red bean cake in the middle
6.  The flavor rice ball wrapped in paper, sorry I dont know the name
7. Shu Mai

I thought the following were just okay:
1.  The pot sticker (for me, it was too bland)
2.  The other big pot sticker like thing (I didnt like it....)

The price was reasonable, for $15, I had some for my daughter, and enough dinner for me and my husband last night, and lunch left over for me today.......
author: M R.

description: best egg custard ever. seriously. the crust is nice and flaky just the way i like it! it's also way cheaper than golden gate bakery (which i personally don't really think is even all that). also, try the taro bun here - it's the first place i've come across where they don't mix pork in with the taro. it's good stuff.
author: Sherilyn T.

description: Great place for take out dim sum.  There is always a line, but it moves fast.  The sticky rice is excellent.  Most of the items are great, and not at all greasy.  Pork baos are perfect;  chicken ones less so.  Also, chicken feet were fabulous if you like 'em.
author: Nicole N.

description:
I tried this place out based on all the high recommendation from Yelp, and I agree, its really good! In fact, probably the best take-out dim sum in San Francisco, especially since Ho and Ho's over on 6th near Clement went under in 2001. Of course, the very best Dim Sum is still to be found in sit-down dim sum restaurants (the reason I give this four rather than five stars), but for take-out, this is as good as it gets and approaches restaurant-quality.

I particularly recommend going here in late morning or early afternoon. While this is when the have the longest lines, they're also actively making dim sum in back, so the dim sum you'll get is more likely to be freshly prepared, rather than have been in a steamer for a few hours. Shark fin rolls, har gow, steamed pork buns, fried dumplings, steamed pork buns, and, for that matter, everything really are all good here. The only thing that wasn't good were the pot stickers, which had obviously been sitting out at room temperature for awhile and were lukewarm (yuck!).

Like other dim sum take-outs, dining on-site is available, but like other such places, the atmosphere is harsh and utilitarian, and cleanliness only maintained by the occasional harsh antiseptic mop and wipe-up.

And the price is right - you can easily get a filling lunch (with leftover snacks) for $6.
author: Peter W.

description: this is the place to go to for takeout dim sum on the cheap. now that i'm slowly getting better and regaining my sense of taste again, i had some take out dim sum for breakfast today ALWAYS in the form of : har gow (shrimp dumpling), siu mai (pork dumpling), lo mai gai (sticky rice w/ chicken wrapped in lotus leaf) and char siu bao (pork bun). the char siu baos are my favorite here, the bread is so soft and fresh tasting...I give this place 4 stars not 5 because everytime i get to eat it at home, it's always a little cold from the walk back and it's never a good idea to reheat dumplings because the texture is never the same!
author: kristin e.

description:
when i lived in inner richmond, there's tons of dimsum places but for some reason i kept going here because of the name!
i felt safe. hehehe. 
i've tried other places on clement but this place is far one of the best dim sums i've had for the price range. it's not fancy stuff but at least it's good and they usually serve their food warm!
author: sarah m.

description: If there is one thing I miss about the city it's this little gem. The real deal for folks who know. Sunday morning's will never be the same :) dumpling's coffe and little rooster sauce yum yum
author: Don L.

description: Dim Sum is awesome here and the price can't be beat - just don't expect much service or deliberating when ordering.   When you come here, the wait seems long, but it goes by pretty quickly.  You take a sheet and circle your choices for dim sum - and that's it.  If you need to change it - forget about it - just take what you can get or get back in line to get more.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Cheap.  Typical dim sum fare.  Maybe it's me but I didn't like their pork bun at all.  Everything else was good.  Great way to explore new things since it's so cheap.  Grab the pink piece of paper and fill it out while standing in line.
author: Janet L.

description: Best take out Dim Sum in the entire Bay Area.
author: The T.

description:
Food was awesome and the prices made it even more appetizing for us broke college students.  11 dollars gave us hella food and we had to take the remaining half home. 

My only gripe are the workers because they were hella rude and yet nice to the people in front and behind us.  Weird thing was that the those customers and the counter workers spoke the same language?  Go figure.  It is a minor thing because the wait in the line is no more than a couple of minutes.
author: Paolo C.

description: So for good, cheap and fast dim sum, this is the place. A little on the greasy side but hey, that's dim sum now isn't it? Not much ambiance so I never sit down to eat there but if you're on or near Clement St. and you need to get something quick, this is really the best deal around. Only problem is they're closed on Tuesdays. True that the lines tend to be long, though not always. Sometimes if you hit it right there's hardly a line at all. The Chinese ladies behind the counter don't smile much or go out of their way to make you feel welcome but then again, it ain't a four-star restaurant and they're busy trying to keep the grub coming so cut'em some slack on that.
author: John L.

description:
Our third experience from this hole-in-the-wall proves that they are consistent with the quality of their food! We were were very surprised to find parking right in front and a very short line inside. We were in and out in less than 15 minutes with a huge collection of assorted dim sum. 
Once again, we gorged on steaming hot har gow, beef shu mai and fun gor as we navigated throughout the City running errands.
Beginners and experienced alike should ask for a ordering sheet to mark their selections to eliminate any misunderstandings about what you want to order and how many. 
The jook was still terrific two days later after a quick reheat in the microwave.
For good, inexpensive take-out dim sum, this is the place to go!
author: sumodog d.

description: Funky little place with the best dim sum on the strip. Cheap, tasty.
author: Tucky D.

description: This is probably one of the better take out dim sum places in the City.  Usually take out dim sum quality is not as good as dim sum from a dine-in restaurant.  When ordering take out always avoid fried or pan fried items, stick with the steamed dim sum and you usually can't go wrong.  Try the shrimp har gaw and sticky rice dim sum - both delicious.
author: Kenneth L.

description: this place is really good. not the best in the city, if you want that go down to geary and 22nd, but this is as good and as cheap as it gets for dim sum... a little treasure on clement really. the ladies can be really nice or really grouchy, depending on how busy they are and stuff... hit and miss, but man i love me some shrimp and chives!
author: Nitai V.

description: The BEST steamed char-siu bao on Clement Street, but the WORST WORST WORST absolute WORST service, specifically the short, skinny lady with the cropped hair in the mornings. She's SLOW (especially when there's a line forming) and seems to ignore people and only helps Chinese customers. What gives?
author: Eugene V.

description: hey, this was pretty tasty! it's too early to see if i'll experience any good luck, but i feel fine several hours later. we tried several different things that were all delish with the exception of the shrimp and taro dumpling. DO NOT RECOMMEND. everything else was fresh and not too greasy and really good. better than wing lee. no pigeon here! the mushroom chow mein was especially good and peppery. yes, the line is way long but it's worth it i think. and SUPER cheap - $8 fed the 2 of us well.
author: Mary V.

description: aahhhh....i love this place..i'd get the rice porridge every morning if i lived in the city! =D...got it twice last week though!..and for only $1.80! steal of deals!
author: Linda L.

description: The Dim Sum is good!  The customer service, unfortunately, is horrible.  The women who work there act like they are doing you a huge favor to wait on you!
author: Michael F.

description: You know a place is good when the line is frustratingly long, and is just as diverse as one at the DMV. Best Ha Gow ever!
author: Ali W.

description: $1.50 dimsum! That's a steal! It's not the best dim sum on Earth but it's pretty fresh, big in portion (jumbo shrimp dimsum!!) and not too greasy too! Most of the dimsum is $1.50 for 3 pieces. Although their selection isn't too big, they do have the basic dimsum like chicken feet, ha gow, malay bun... just to name a few. I also ordered the congee to go which was only $1.90!!! Back in NYC, it's double the price. Who've heard of congee for $1.90 and it came in a big quart too! Once you go in, you can grab a piece of the menu and write down the quantity and give it over to the ladies who will put the dimsum into a big container for you. Get there early b/c the line can get long.
author: Xue T.

description: ah.maze.ing. shrimp dumplings & both steamed and baked pork buns = party in my mouth. lines are a little long and they're kind of stingy with the utensils/napkins but all worth it!
author: elina h.

description:
good food. amazing cheap and fast! 

be prepared when it's your turn or you'll receive some dirty looks!

recommend the pork bun in sweet bread and the shrimp or chicken dumplings.
author: Melissa W.

description: Ha! The other reviews were spot-on! You're gonna get good dim sum for SUPER cheap...but you're also gonna get shitty service! We got 9 items and walked away only paying $12! But the lady was sooo rude! Every time I tried to ask what the item was, she got pissed and would only tell me the name of it. Uh, ya, cause that's gonna help! Tell me what's inside the damn thing lady! Luckily, a regular felt our pain and broke EVERY item down to us. Everything was good, not overly greasy and cooked thoroughly. I'd go back, but it wouldn't be for the customer service, that's for sure...you can't beat $12 for lunch for 2!
author: vanessa m.

description: I was at Good Luck Dim Sum twice last week.  First time was good service and average food.  Second time was bad service and bad food.  The price maybe cheap, but freshness is average.  You get this better at other places.  The service... after finish dining, where they it is self serve and given you tiny small square paper plate, the server yell at my mom and friend to clean the table (if I had known, I would had said something).      My mom and I went back the second time 2 days later with 2 friends.  The server kept ignoring me, while helping my mom's friend.  Even thou we where not finish, the older server ask for payment, and left us to help someone else.  I never got so mad, that I yell at her, and informed how impolite she was to ignore me.  To all this is not a good relaxing place, and I do not recomment this place for service and food!   Food was so so, not hot enough on top tray, and dry. Good Luck!
author: S S.

description: This review is for the service only.  While the value of dim sum is great the service isn't.  I would rate the service as zero!!!!  The ladies here are rude and very disrespectful, especially if you don't speak their language.  They will talk about you right in front of your face while smirking with the other employees or other customers!!!
author: SillySP P.

description: Good food. Authentic Hong Kong style service. Love it.
author: T L.

description: i gladly line up here for dim sum. their pan fried chive ones are incredible! it's a good bet to just get whatever the guys from the back bring out (hot and fresh). for people who don't speak cantonese; when the cashier ladies yell really loudly, they're not talking smack about you. they're simply reporting to the kitchen to make some more of whatever is running out. good luck dim sum is good eats.
author: Patricia S.

description: I'm not sure if they put cocaine in their food or what, but it's addicting. I had their shrimp dumplings one seemingly mundane Saturday afternoon, and I started craving them for two weeks straight just waiting until I could come back to San Francisco for my next fix. Fortunately, the food here isn't as expensive as crack (not that I would know how much cocaine is, I promise), so you can inexpensively feed your addiction with $1.50 for three pieces of most dim sum items. I recommend coming early though as I've been told they sell out of their most popular dim sum items by 1pm or 2pm sometimes.
author: J J.

description: love love love this place.  come in around 1 after the rush, and the shrimp dumplings are fresh and delicious.  also love the turnip cakes.  no frills, but dirt cheap and tasty.  closed on tuesdays though!
author: Hal P.

description: We (my wife, 2 young daughters and I) took the advice of the sweetest server at Hog Island Oyster Company to try Clement Street instead of going to China Town for dim sum and boy are we happy we did!  What we did Sunday morning was walk around to see what looked good.  After walking 4 or 5 blocks with kids in tow, we decided to try the place with the longest line (Good Luck Dim Sum).  After waiting in a line that was at least 15 people deep, we got our breakfast (yes, we were brave and decided to eat there).  It was so worth the wait, the bao (both baked and steamed) were amazing and HUGE compared to what we get here in LA (Arcadia, Monterey Park, China Town).  The shrimp dumplings and sui mai (pork and beef) were HUGE and delicious as well.  None of that greasy, overcooked stuff here!  I wanted so thank the person who gave us the recommendation so we went back to Hog Island Oyster Co. to have lunch (and see her) but she was not working. :(  On our next weekend in San Francisco, we will definitely be going back to Good Luck!
author: Jeff D.

description: there's always a line...but you get served pretty quickly 'cuz there's about 3-4 ladies that take orders. the dim sum is worth the trip and the parking headaches. while everyone seems to be in a hurry to take the food home, I just opt to eat in and enjoy them there, while they're still warm. you should be able to load up for under $7 with the array of dim sum offered. a buddy of mine loves their soy sauce so much that he tried asking where they get it from. of course they didn't want to say, so he just took matters into his own hands--if you know what i mean.
author: Chris C.

description: I live right off Clement Street, where every good dim sum place in the city is.  I've been to most if not all and good luck is by far the best dim dum I've ever eaten.  It is better than the dim sum at waiter-served restaurants around the city, including Tong Kiang.  I reccommend it more than any other asian food restaurant in the city.
author: Hannah S.

description: This is a crazy secret of those of us who love DimSum in San Francisco and live near enough to make the trip to Good Luck.  #1 get there as early as you can, #2 take a pen to write your order on the "pink slip", #3 don't freak out, just make your best guess at what any of it means and go with it, nothings really bad anyway, #4 don't over order, its easy to fall into that trap, but don't worry its cheap anyway. The ladies behind the counter don't have time to explain anything and everyone in line will think you are an ass if you hold up the show, so make out your order and if you have questions ask the people in line, not the ladies behind the counter.  Pay in CASH bring $20 and you'll get lots of change back unless you are feeding 10 people or something.  I love this place, the DimSum is sooo fresh because they are making and selling it as fast as they can.  Try it, its a great experience, but don't hold up the show!!!!
author: Sarah H.

description: I was there in the afternoon so this might explain why dim sum was not hot.  I don't think I could even call it warm - maybe room temperature.  I had ordered pork siu mai, har gow, and steamed pork bun to go.  It was still tasty though.  Prices were good and service was prompt.  I'll have to try again earlier in the day and re-review.  For now they get 3 stars.
author: Maryanne D.

description: Quality food at a very very cheap price.  Sure the line is long if you come here during the weekends at lunch time, but the food is worth the wait, and CHEAP!  It's only 4 stars because you can't really eat here, this is more of a take out place and the Cantonese English accent is not exactly easy to understand sometimes.  Bottom line, come here get a to go for some cheap good dim sum!
author: Jeff L.

description: The food here rocks and this place also appears to be quite a bit cleaner than some of the other Clement and China Town Dim Sum bakeries.  It's also a bargain.  Take out is the way to go and go early!  The shrimp and chive dumplings are truly fabulous.  Regular shrimp dumplings are also delicious.  And the BBQ pork buns are worth the wait and the grumpy ladies behind the counter talking sh*t about you in a language you probably don't understand (just like Elaine in that Seinfeld episode in the nail salon.)  Go for the food not the atmosphere!
author: RB P.

description: good....fast...dim sum to-go....thats what everyone in the area comes here for...and all i have to say is....if the old asian women come here to get their dim sum then what else do you need to know...seriously
author: David L.

description: i came here, circled a bunch of random things on the menu, walked out with a big box full of dim sum for $12. some of it wasnt that hot, but shoot, it still tasted good.
author: Micaela G.

description: i love this place. fun to experiment, because its so cheap and everything is pretty good. try the chicken skewers.
author: Angelo M.

description: I'm so lucky we live near Clement.  Whenever I come home we go to mass on Sundays and then go buy some dim sum.  We usually go to the much pricier Flower Lounge in Millbrae for a proper sit-down dim sum, but for some really good take out this is the place to go to.  Restaurant quality and fresh but for a fraction of the price.  Be forewarned though, there are ridiculously long lines in the morning.
author: Priscilla P.

description:
My instituition tour continues,

       Get in line. Upon entering good luck dim sum, get in line. There will be a line and you will wait. If for some cataclysmic reason there is no line, get in line anyway, even if you are not hungry and have already ate. You will have time to ponder your decision, while you are waiting by checking out the small take out menu or looking at the board. Be ready, when it is your time to order. Keep your questions quick and to a mimimum. If you can not speak cantonese (and this includes my abc/mandarin speaking and non-chinese asian friends) please do not ask the nice lady what is in the sharks fin dumpling. If you are a beginner, please do not, I repeat do not, circle things on the menu. This and your lack of lingo back up will only confuse things. Just point and tell them what you want.  There are a lot of delicious items on the menu, unfortunately because I am a no-beef, no-pork eating fool ( I still think it tastes good, just for health reasons) I can not enjoy alot of them. I tend to stick with the chicken buns and shrimp dumplings and venture out from there on my restricted dim sum highway.  You will not be similiarly encumbered. Oh yeah, and it is ridiculously cheap and  the ladies are really nice once you get to know them. I have been going there for years and they even remember me now. It does take a while to thaw, but they are truly miles away from a silly comparison to the soup nazi I read in another review. They just do not suffer fools gladly. Go to 8th/clement and mangia, mangia, mangia..........
author: Dan T.

description: Ok...here we go again with another hole-in-the-wall in SF....totally worth the 35 minute wait in line.....today after all IS the 1st of the year!  I always try to plan ahead but who woulda known that everyone & his mother would have a craving for dim sum today!!!!!!!!!!  Came home with 4 boxes (ala $32.60) worth of dumplings that together with the hot mustard & low sodium (of course!) soy sauce is gonna make Momma happy tonight!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Steph K.

description: I absolutely love this place. Dim Sum is inexpensive, but there's always a line in the morning. I normally buy a lot to feed my whole family at home. It's a great place for quick dim sum. They have simple lunches too.
author: bob k.

description: probably the best place for everyday take-out dim sum outside of chinatown.  the prices are seriously dirt cheap. the three things i get from any dim sum joint is siu mai, "shrimp foot", and turnip cake.  The shrimp foot here is really good and plump.  The siu mai is just ok, not nasty by any means, but anytime I eat one I feel like theres something missing.  Making good turnip cake is what I look for from a dim sum place, because its the hardest to find done well.  The turnip cake at good luck falls into the "just like the rest of them" category.  Texture is a little chunky, still need to go to chinatown to get my proper turnip cake fix.
author: david w.

description: Ok, contrary to what many people think, I don't think that Good Luck Dim Sum is worth as much attention as it deserves. The dim sum is really OK. I am not impressed by it at all. Their prices are competitive, but that is about it. I wouldn't go out of my way to get shrimp dumplings there, but the ladies there are very friendly, I must say.
author: Eric C.

description: Aside from the low prices, I was not happy with this place at all.  First, while standing in line  for dim sum, i noticed a roach on the wall to my right and 2 bugs and a fly crawling on the white boxes to my left.  Second, the tables were dirty - they were greasy and had soy sauce rings everywhere.  Third, the servers were rude and demanding.  They were impatient in answering questions and expected you to know what every kind of dim sum was in that restaurant. Also, despite my 4 person order, the cashier was tight in giving out a take-out box for our leftovers.  Lastly, the food sucks.  My turnip cake was cold and tasted uncooked.  Also, the sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf was huge but it contained 98% sticky rice and 2% other stuff.  What a rip off.  IN SUM, this place had bad service, a long line, not-so-good dim sum, and creatures crawling everywhere.
author: ana a.
